Section 337 (2) A person who, during the period of a special legal order and in front of a large audience, states or disseminates any untrue fact or any misrepresented true fact that is capable of hindering or preventing the efficiency of protection is guilty of a felony and shall be punished by imprisonment for one to five years.

LA COMISIÓN LEGISLATIVA NACIONAL En ejercicio de la atribución que le confiere el artículo 6 numeral 1 del Decreto de la Asamblea Nacional Constituyente mediante el cual se establece el Régimen de Transición del Poder Público, publicado en la Gaceta Oficial No. 36.920 de fecha 28 de marzo del año 2000, en concordancia con lo dispuesto en los artículos 187, numeral 1, y 203 de la Constitución de la República Bolivariana de Venezuela. DECRETA la siguiente, ORGANIC LAW OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS
TITLE I GENERAL PROVISIONS

ARTICLE 1.- This Law has as its object to establish the legal framework for general regulation of telecommunications, in order to guarantee the human right of persons to communication and to the carrying out of the telecommunications economic activities necessary to achieve it, with no more limitations than those derived from the Constitution and the laws. The regulation of the content of transmissions and communications carried out through the different telecommunications media is excluded from the object of this Law, which shall be governed by the corresponding constitutional, legal and regulatory provisions.

ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 1. Defend the interests of users, ensuring their right of access to telecommunications services, in adequate conditions of quality, and safeguard, in the provision of these, the validity of constitutional rights, in particular that of respect for the rights to honor, to privacy, to secrecy in communications and that of the protection of youth and childhood. To these ends, obligations may be imposed on service operators for the guarantee of these rights.

ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 2. Promote and assist the exercise of the right of persons to establish community public service non-profit sound broadcasting and open television media, for the exercise of the right to free and plural communication.
ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 3. Seek conditions of competition among service operators.

ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 4. Promote the development and use of new services, networks and technologies when they are available and access to them, on conditions of equality of persons and promote the integration of the geographic space and economic and social cohesion.
ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 5. Promote the efficient integration of telecommunications services.
ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 6. Promote research, development and technology transfer in telecommunications matters, training and employment in the sector.

ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 7. Make possible the effective, efficient and peaceful use of limited telecommunications resources such as numbering and the radioelectric spectrum, as well as the adequate protection of the latter.

ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 8. Incorporate and guarantee compliance with Universal Service obligations, quality and uniform minimum coverage targets, and those obligations related to security and defense, in telecommunications matters.
ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 9. Favor the harmonious development of telecommunications systems in the geographic space, in accordance with the law.

ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 10. Favor the development of regional integration mechanisms in which the Republic is a party and promote the country's participation in international telecommunications organizations.
ARTICLE 2.- The general objectives of this Law are: 11. Promote national and international investment for the modernization and development of the telecommunications sector.

ARTICLE 3.- The comprehensive regime of telecommunications and the radioelectric spectrum is the competence of the National Public Power and shall be governed by this Law, its regulations and other normative provisions issued in accordance with them. National, state and municipal authorities shall provide the officials of the National Telecommunications Commission with the necessary cooperation for the full, timely and effective fulfillment of their functions.

ARTICLE 4.- For the purposes of this Law, telecommunications are understood to be any transmission, emission or reception of signs, signals, writings, images, sounds or information of any nature, by wire, radioelectricity, optical means, or other related electromagnetic means, invented or to be invented. The regulations developing this Law may specifically recognize other means or modalities that may arise in the field of telecommunications and that fall within the parameters of this Law. For the purposes of this Law the radioelectric spectrum is defined as the set of electromagnetic waves whose frequency is conventionally fixed below three thousand gigahertz (3000 GHz) and that propagate through space without artificial guidance. The radioelectric spectrum is divided into frequency bands, which are designated by integer numbers, in increasing order. Frequency bands constitute the grouping or set of radioelectric waves with upper and lower limits defined conventionally. These in turn may be divided into sub-bands.

ARTICLE 5.- The establishment or operation of telecommunications networks, as well as the provision of telecommunications services are considered activities of general interest, for the exercise of which prior obtaining of the corresponding administrative authorization and concession if necessary will be required, in the cases and conditions established by the law, the regulations and the General Conditions established for that purpose by the National Telecommunications Commission. By virtue of their condition as activities of general interest and in accordance with what the corresponding regulations provide, telecommunications services may be subject to quality parameters and special uniform minimum coverage targets, as well as the provision of services under preferential access and price conditions to schools, universities, libraries and public assistance centers. Likewise, by virtue of being activities of general interest, the content of transmissions or communications carried out through the different telecommunications media may be subject to limitations and restrictions established for reasons of public interest by the Constitution and the law.

ARTICLE 6.- The establishment or operation of telecommunications networks, as well as the provision of telecommunications services, may be carried out for the benefit of the communication needs of those who develop them or of third parties, in accordance with the particularities established for that purpose in laws and regulations.

ARTICLE 7.- The radioelectric spectrum is a public domain asset of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, for the use and exploitation of which the respective concession must be held, in accordance with the law.

ARTICLE 8.- Telecommunications services for national security and defense are reserved to the State. The qualification of a service as security and defense shall be made by the President of the Republic, in Council of Ministers, after hearing the opinion of the National Defense Council, in accordance with the law.

ARTICLE 9.- Administrative authorizations for the provision of telecommunications services, as well as concessions for the use and exploitation of the radioelectric public domain, shall only be granted to persons domiciled in the country, except as provided in international agreements or treaties signed and ratified by the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. The participation of foreign investment in the field of telecommunications may only be limited in sound broadcasting and open television services, in accordance with what the corresponding legal and regulatory norms provide.

ARTICLE 10.- The meaning of terms used in this Law or in its regulations and not defined in them shall be that assigned by international conventions or treaties signed and ratified by Venezuela, in particular the definitions adopted by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), and in default of these the rules established in the respective regulation.

ARTICLE 11.- Before producing or modifying the normative acts that it may issue in accordance with this Law, the National Telecommunications Commission shall carry out prior public consultations with the interested sectors. To this end it shall establish by resolution the mechanisms that allow ensuring timely information to interested parties and the possibility that they provide suggestions or recommendations, under the terms and conditions determined, for which it shall seek the establishment of open, electronic or audiovisual mechanisms. Natural or legal persons may propose to the National Telecommunications Commission the regulation of new telecommunications services.
TITLE II RIGHTS AND DUTIES OF USERS AND OPERATORS
CHAPTER I RIGHTS AND DUTIES OF USERS

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 1. Access on equal terms to all telecommunications services and to receive an efficient, quality and uninterrupted service, except for limitations arising from the capacity of such services;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 2. Privacy and inviolability of their telecommunications, except in those cases expressly authorized by the Constitution or which, by their nature, are public.

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 3. Exercise individually and collectively their right to free and plural communication through the enjoyment of adequate conditions to found community public service non-profit sound broadcasting and open television media, in accordance with the law.

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 4. That all charges for the services they receive be billed timely and in detail, avoiding erroneous, late or unjustified billing, except in cases of prepaid services, in accordance with the regulation of this Law, that such billing be expressed in terms easily understandable and to receive such billing on time;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 5. Have a free emergency call service, whatever the operator responsible for its provision and regardless of the type of terminal used. Routing of calls to emergency services shall be the responsibility of the operator;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 6. Have, free of charge, an updated, electronic or printed and unified directory for each geographic scope, related to the service regardless of the operator. All subscribers shall have the right to appear in such directories and to a national information service about their content, without prejudice, in any case, to the right to the protection of their personal data, including the right not to appear in such directories;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 7. Timely obtain the reimbursement, in cash, of what they had delivered as deposits or guarantees, as well as for balances that result in their favor, in accordance with the rules established in the respective regulation;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 8. Receive compensation or reimbursement for interruption of telecommunications services in the terms established by the respective regulation. For such purposes subscribers may choose, among the compensation or reimbursement mechanisms established by said regulation, the one they consider most convenient and satisfactory to their interests;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 9. That in contracting telecommunications services, models of contracts previously authorized by the National Telecommunications Commission are used and to obtain a copy of them;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 10. That all their requests, complaints or claims arising from the provision of the service be attended to promptly and effectively, and especially to demand compliance by telecommunications service operators with minimum quality parameters in the provision of services which shall be established for each service by the National Telecommunications Commission;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 11. To be informed in advance and adequately of the suspension, restriction or elimination of the telecommunications services they have contracted, stating the causes of such measures;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 12. To be informed of the existence of faults in the telecommunications systems that affect them, the estimated time for their repair and to claim for unjustified delay in the repair of faults;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 13. Access information in the Spanish language relating to the proper use of telecommunications services and to the handling, installation and maintenance of terminal equipment, as well as additional facilities that they provide;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 14. Be provided with adequate and timely protection against anomalies or abuses committed by telecommunications service providers or by any other person who violates the rights established in this Law;

ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 15. Be offered precise, truthful and free information about current tariffs, consultable from the terminal equipment used by the user, in order to allow correct use and favor freedom of choice;
ARTICLE 12.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the right to: 16. Other rights deriving from the application of laws, regulations and other applicable norms.

ARTICLE 13.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the duty to: 1. Pay punctually the charges for services received, in accordance with the pre-established prices or tariffs that apply;

ARTICLE 13.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the duty to: 2. Inform the service provider of any interruption, deficiency or damage occurred in the system, once they become aware of the fact;

ARTICLE 13.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the duty to: 3. Not alter terminal equipment they own, even if they are their property, when as a result of this they may cause damage or interference that degrades service quality according to standards established by the National Telecommunications Commission or with the object of producing evasion of payment of tariffs or prices due;

ARTICLE 13.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the duty to: 4. Provide all possible collaboration to officials of the National Telecommunications Commission, when these request it in the performance of their functions;
ARTICLE 13.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the duty to: 5. Inform the National Telecommunications Commission about facts that may go against the provisions of the law;
ARTICLE 13.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the duty to: 6. Respect the property and usage rights of other persons related to elements linked to telecommunications;

ARTICLE 13.- As a user of a telecommunications service, every person has the duty to: 7. Respect legal and regulatory provisions, the rules issued by the National Telecommunications Commission and the general conditions of contracting services.
CHAPTER II RIGHTS AND DUTIES OF OPERATORS

ARTICLE 14.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following rights: 1. To the use and protection of their networks and installations used in the provision of the telecommunications service;

ARTICLE 14.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following rights: 2. To participate, as offerors, in selection processes for obtaining administrative authorization or concession for the use and exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum, with the limitations derived from this Law and its regulations, Telecommunications plans or maintenance of competition, according to decisions or recommendations that the Superintendency for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition may issue. Participants in these processes shall do so on equal terms.

ARTICLE 14.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following rights: 3. To request and receive timely information on plans, programs, instructions and other normative provisions, as well as individual ones in which they are interested, issued by the National Telecommunications Commission.

ARTICLE 14.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following rights: 4. To participate in consultation processes carried out by the National Executive in telecommunications matters, in the form and conditions to be established by regulation.
ARTICLE 14.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following rights: 5. Other rights deriving from the law and regulations.

ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 1. Respect the rights of users established in the Constitution and in the law, to adequate and non-misleading information about the content and characteristics of the products and services they consume, to freedom of choice and to equitable and dignified treatment.

ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 2. Respect the minimum quality conditions established by the National Telecommunications Commission in the provision of their services, in accordance with the regulations of this Law;
ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 3. Comply with the obligations provided in the corresponding administrative authorization;
ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 4. Act under schemes of fair and free competition, in accordance with the law;

ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 5. Publish the maximum prices of the services they provide to users, with at least fifteen continuous days prior notice to their entry into force, in newspapers with highest circulation in the geographic area in which they operate or, failing that, in national circulation newspapers, as well as notify the National Telecommunications Commission, within the same period, of the maximum prices of the services indicated above.

ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 6. Comply with decisions that in accordance with this Law and its regulations the National Telecommunications Commission issues;
ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 7. Pay in a timely manner the legally established taxes;

ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 8. Contribute to the realization of national telecommunications plans, in the manner determined by the respective regulation;
ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 9. Orient their activities and procedures to compliance with the law and regulations.

ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 10. Comply with obligations of assistance, provision of services, supply and provision of goods and resources, and with all those obligations established in the applicable regulations for telecommunications services in states of exception, and in the plans for states of exception formulated for that purpose.

ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 11. Submit their financial statements in accordance with the particularities of the uniform chart of accounts to be issued by the National Telecommunications Commission, in accordance with the law and regulations.
ARTICLE 15.- Operators of telecommunications services, duly accredited, have the following duties: 12. Other duties deriving from legal and regulatory provisions.
TITLE III PROVISION OF SERVICES AND THE ESTABLISHMENT AND OPERATION OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS NETWORKS
CHAPTER I GENERAL PROVISIONS

ARTICLE 16.- The administrative authorization is the title granted by the National Telecommunications Commission for the establishment and operation of networks and for the provision of telecommunications services, to those who have fulfilled the requirements and conditions established for such purposes by said body, in accordance with this Law. The specific activities and services that may be provided under the protection of an administrative authorization shall be called attributes of the administrative authorization, which grant the rights and duties inherent to the activity for which the operator has been authorized, in accordance with the provisions of Articles 14 and 15 of this Law. In cases where use of the radioelectric spectrum is required, the operator must also obtain the corresponding concession.

ARTICLE 17.- The laws and regulations enacted in execution of this Law shall establish the different types of administrative authorization that the National Telecommunications Commission will grant according to the attributes it determines for the specific case.

ARTICLE 18.- Anyone who applies to the National Telecommunications Commission for the granting of an administrative authorization or the incorporation of specific attributes to one they already hold must state in the respective application, under oath, whether any natural or legal person linked to them provides the same or similar service.

ARTICLE 19.- Every administrative authorization shall contain, in addition to the matters required by the Organic Law of Administrative Procedures, the following: 1. The type of administrative authorization in question and the attributes it confers;

ARTICLE 19.- Every administrative authorization shall contain, in addition to the matters required by the Organic Law of Administrative Procedures, the following: 2. The determination of the characteristics of the networks and services; their coverage area and implementation schedule, as well as the modalities of access to them and distribution of the percentages of uniform minimum coverage within the area corresponding to it, if applicable in accordance with the respective regulations;

ARTICLE 19.- Every administrative authorization shall contain, in addition to the matters required by the Organic Law of Administrative Procedures, the following: 3. The time during which it is granted;

ARTICLE 19.- Every administrative authorization shall contain, in addition to the matters required by the Organic Law of Administrative Procedures, the following: 4. An express reference to the General Conditions of the administrative authorizations applicable that the National Telecommunications Commission has established, in accordance with the law and regulations, with expression of the number and date of the Official Gazette of their publication.

ARTICLE 20.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, taking into account the particularities of the type of networks and services in question, the General Conditions to which those interested in obtaining an administrative authorization in telecommunications matters must be subject, in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In any case, in accordance with the respective regulations, the General Conditions shall be aimed at guaranteeing, among other aspects: 1. The compliance by the person who is the beneficiary of the administrative authorization with the essential requirements for an adequate provision of the service, the correct establishment or operation of a network;

ARTICLE 20.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, taking into account the particularities of the type of networks and services in question, the General Conditions to which those interested in obtaining an administrative authorization in telecommunications matters must be subject, in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In any case, in accordance with the respective regulations, the General Conditions shall be aimed at guaranteeing, among other aspects: 2. Suitable mechanisms for information and protection of the rights of users or service contractors;

ARTICLE 20.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, taking into account the particularities of the type of networks and services in question, the General Conditions to which those interested in obtaining an administrative authorization in telecommunications matters must be subject, in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In any case, in accordance with the respective regulations, the General Conditions shall be aimed at guaranteeing, among other aspects: 3. Adequate access to services by persons with disabilities or special needs;

ARTICLE 20.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, taking into account the particularities of the type of networks and services in question, the General Conditions to which those interested in obtaining an administrative authorization in telecommunications matters must be subject, in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In any case, in accordance with the respective regulations, the General Conditions shall be aimed at guaranteeing, among other aspects: 4. Competitive behavior of operators in telecommunications markets;

ARTICLE 20.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, taking into account the particularities of the type of networks and services in question, the General Conditions to which those interested in obtaining an administrative authorization in telecommunications matters must be subject, in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In any case, in accordance with the respective regulations, the General Conditions shall be aimed at guaranteeing, among other aspects: 5. Effective and efficient use of numbering capacity;

ARTICLE 20.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, taking into account the particularities of the type of networks and services in question, the General Conditions to which those interested in obtaining an administrative authorization in telecommunications matters must be subject, in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In any case, in accordance with the respective regulations, the General Conditions shall be aimed at guaranteeing, among other aspects: 6. The rights and obligations in matters of network interconnection and service interoperability, as well as other technical and quality requirements to be established;

ARTICLE 20.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, taking into account the particularities of the type of networks and services in question, the General Conditions to which those interested in obtaining an administrative authorization in telecommunications matters must be subject, in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In any case, in accordance with the respective regulations, the General Conditions shall be aimed at guaranteeing, among other aspects: 7. Compliance with environmental, land use and urban planning norms;

ARTICLE 20.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, taking into account the particularities of the type of networks and services in question, the General Conditions to which those interested in obtaining an administrative authorization in telecommunications matters must be subject, in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In any case, in accordance with the respective regulations, the General Conditions shall be aimed at guaranteeing, among other aspects: 8. Respect for Universal Service norms, measures adopted for reasons of public interest, and the protection of personal data.

ARTICLE 21.- The duration of administrative authorizations may not exceed twenty-five years; they may be renewed for equal periods provided that their holder has complied with the provisions of this Law, its regulations, the General Conditions established by the National Telecommunications Commission and the respective authorization.

ARTICLE 22.- The modification of the General Conditions of administrative authorizations by the National Telecommunications Commission shall be made with prior public consultation, according to the mechanism established by the respective regulation. When the General Conditions are modified, the National Telecommunications Commission shall establish a reasonable adaptation period for preexisting authorized holders, who must adjust to the new requirements within the established period, under penalty of application of the sanctions established by law.

ARTICLE 23.- Administrative authorization shall not be required for the installation or operation of telecommunications equipment or networks, in the following cases: 1. When they are security or intercommunication equipment that without connection to public networks and without using the radioelectric public domain, are used within a property or to serve certain properties;

ARTICLE 23.- Administrative authorization shall not be required for the installation or operation of telecommunications equipment or networks, in the following cases: 2. When they are equipment that, despite using portions of the radioelectric spectrum, have been classified as free use by the National Telecommunications Commission;

ARTICLE 23.- Administrative authorization shall not be required for the installation or operation of telecommunications equipment or networks, in the following cases: 3. When they are telecommunications equipment or networks of organs of the Republic, of the states or of the municipalities, when such activities are carried out to satisfy their communication needs, without economic consideration of third parties and without using the radioelectric public domain.

ARTICLE 23.- Administrative authorization shall not be required for the installation or operation of telecommunications equipment or networks, in the following cases: 4. When they are services that use as support networks, links or telecommunications systems, with the purpose of offering additional facilities to those defined as attributes of administrative authorizations, applying to these facilities processes that make possible the availability of information, operation over them or interaction with the system. Internet service providers are excluded. Sole Paragraph: By regulation it may be established the cases and modalities in which the assumptions provided in this article will require notification to the National Telecommunications Commission or prior registration of the respective project.

ARTICLE 24.- The Ministry of Infrastructure, through the National Telecommunications Commission, shall promote technological and service convergence, provided that this does not worsen access to services and their quality.
CHAPTER II PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING ADMINISTRATIVE AUTHORIZATIONS OR INCORPORATION OF ATTRIBUTES TO THEM

ARTICLE 25.- Persons interested in providing one or more telecommunications services to the public or in establishing or operating a telecommunications network must apply to the National Telecommunications Commission for the corresponding administrative authorization or for the expansion of the attributes of which they are the holder. Both cases shall be governed by the procedure established in this Title.

ARTICLE 26.- The application referred to in the previous article shall be made in writing and contain the following requirements: 1. Identification of the applicant, and where appropriate, of the person acting as their representative with expression of names and surnames, domicile, profession and identity card or passport number.

ARTICLE 26.- The application referred to in the previous article shall be made in writing and contain the following requirements: 2. The type of telecommunications activity for which the administrative authorization is intended and the attributes associated with it.

ARTICLE 26.- The application referred to in the previous article shall be made in writing and contain the following requirements: 3. Clear and precise description of the corresponding technical project.

ARTICLE 26.- The application referred to in the previous article shall be made in writing and contain the following requirements: 4. Reference to annexes that support the project and compliance with the General Conditions.

ARTICLE 26.- The application referred to in the previous article shall be made in writing and contain the following requirements: 5. The address of the place where notifications will be made. The applicant, if any, may indicate an email address in which the corresponding notifications may be made.
ARTICLE 26.- The application referred to in the previous article shall be made in writing and contain the following requirements: 6. Any other circumstances required by legal or regulatory norms.
ARTICLE 26.- The application referred to in the previous article shall be made in writing and contain the following requirements: 7. Signature of the applicants.

ARTICLE 26.- The application referred to in the previous article shall be made in writing and contain the following requirements: 8. The regulation of this Law may provide that the application be made by electronic mechanisms that guarantee its security, privacy and authenticity.

ARTICLE 27.- If, in the opinion of the National Telecommunications Commission, the applicant's administrative authorization application is unclear, inaccurate or incomplete, it shall issue a sufficiently motivated act by which it orders the applicant to correct the defects of the application within a period of fifteen working days counted from its notification. If the applicant does not correct or complete the aspects of their application so indicated within the aforementioned period, or does so in a manner different from that indicated, the National Telecommunications Commission shall issue an act in which the application is declared inadmissible and its file ordered.

ARTICLE 28.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall have a period of forty-five continuous days, counted from receipt of the application, to issue a resolution determining whether the application complies with the form and substantive requirements provided in this Law, its regulations and the General Conditions. Said period may be extended by a motivated act, only once, for up to fifteen continuous days. During the period it has to decide, the National Telecommunications Commission may request from the applicant the information it considers pertinent for the purpose of evaluating the application, in which case it shall notify the applicant that they have a period of ten working days to submit the requested information. From the applicant's notification, the National Telecommunications Commission's decision period shall be interrupted for up to a maximum of ten working days.

ARTICLE 29.- When the National Telecommunications Commission determines that the requirements and conditions established in the law and regulations have been met, it shall grant by motivated act the corresponding administrative authorization or the expansion of its attributes, as the case may be.

ARTICLE 30.- In the event that the National Telecommunications Commission determines that the applicant does not comply with the required matters, it shall issue a motivated act in which the application is declared inadmissible, the constitutive administrative procedure shall be terminated and the applicant shall be notified.

ARTICLE 31.- If the National Telecommunications Commission does not pronounce on the admissibility or not of the application within the periods established in this Chapter, such silence shall be understood as a refusal regarding the application made.

ARTICLE 32.- If the constitutive procedure were to be paralyzed for causes attributable to the applicant for more than fifteen working days, counted from the notification made to them advising of such situation, the application shall be deemed withdrawn and the file shall be ordered to be archived.

ARTICLE 33.- The National Telecommunications Commission may decide, by motivated act, to shorten the procedure referred to in the previous articles, taking into account the temporary nature of the service requested and the urgency with which it is required to be provided, in accordance with what is established in the regulation of this Law. In the act opening the procedure, the summary procedure shall be established with all precision.

TITLE V DEVELOPMENT OF THE TELECOMMUNICATIONS SECTOR

CHAPTER I UNIVERSAL SERVICE AND ITS FUND Section first Universal Service ARTICLE 49.- The State guarantees the provision of the Universal Telecommunications Service. The Universal Telecommunications Service is the defined set of telecommunications services that operators are obliged to provide to users to offer them minimum standards of penetration, access, quality and economic affordability irrespective of geographic location. The Universal Service aims at the purpose of national integration, maximization of access to information, educational and health service development and reduction of inequalities of access to telecommunications services among the population.

ARTICLE 50.- The National Telecommunications Commission, in coordination with the Ministry of Infrastructure, shall establish as a priority for progressively achieving Universal Service obligations the following provisions: 1. That all persons can receive connection to the public fixed telephone network and access to the provision of the public available fixed telephone service. The connection must offer the user the possibility to make and receive national and international calls and allow transmission of voice, text and data.

ARTICLE 50.- The National Telecommunications Commission, in coordination with the Ministry of Infrastructure, shall establish as a priority for progressively achieving Universal Service obligations the following provisions: 2. That telephone service subscribers have, free of charge, an updated and printed unified telephone directory for each territorial scope. All subscribers shall have the right to appear in the directories and to a national information service about their content, without prejudice, in any case, to respect for norms regulating personal data protection and the right to privacy.

ARTICLE 50.- The National Telecommunications Commission, in coordination with the Ministry of Infrastructure, shall establish as a priority for progressively achieving Universal Service obligations the following provisions: 3. That there be a sufficient offer of public pay phones in the public domain throughout the Venezuelan geographic space.

ARTICLE 50.- The National Telecommunications Commission, in coordination with the Ministry of Infrastructure, shall establish as a priority for progressively achieving Universal Service obligations the following provisions: 4. That all persons have access to the global information network Internet.

ARTICLE 50.- The National Telecommunications Commission, in coordination with the Ministry of Infrastructure, shall establish as a priority for progressively achieving Universal Service obligations the following provisions: 5. That disabled users or those with special social needs have access to the public available fixed telephone service, on conditions comparable to those offered to other users.

ARTICLE 51.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall periodically quantify, plan, review and expand Universal Service obligations according to satisfaction of telecommunications needs and market development, and to this end shall carry out the public consultations established by law, and request the participation of the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition in order to avoid distortions in the telecommunications market. In any case, the National Telecommunications Commission may not worsen the users' rights guaranteed by obligations that constitute Universal Service.

ARTICLE 52.- To guarantee the Universal Telecommunications Service throughout the Venezuelan geographic space, the assignment of Universal Service obligations shall be subject, in each case, to open selection processes in which interested operators may participate, and the obligation shall be assigned to the interested operator requiring a smaller amount from the Universal Service Fund, provided that technical requirements and quality levels established by the National Telecommunications Commission are satisfied. The procedure for assigning Universal Service obligations shall be determined by regulation. The National Telecommunications Commission shall publish annually the list of geographic areas and services subject to Universal Service obligations, complying with the requirements provided for that purpose by the respective regulation.

ARTICLE 53.- The National Telecommunications Commission may declare the selection processes provided in the preceding article deserted for lack of at least two valid offers, in which case it shall directly assign to one or several telecommunications service providers the fulfillment of Universal Service obligations. In such cases, the National Telecommunications Commission shall require the corresponding economic proposal from the operator(s) it deems convenient; evaluate the suitability of the operator(s) in terms of their technical and economic capacity, proximity, experience and economy in achieving the pursued ends; and assign the obligation or reformulate its terms, if it deems convenient for the public interest.

Section Second Universal Service Fund ARTICLE 54.- The Universal Service Fund is created, which shall have the character of separated patrimony dependent on the National Telecommunications Commission. The structure, organization and control mechanisms of the Universal Telecommunications Service Fund shall be those determined by this Law and the respective regulation.

ARTICLE 55.- The Universal Telecommunications Service Fund shall have the purpose of subsidizing infrastructure costs necessary for the fulfillment of Universal Service obligations while maintaining neutrality of its effects from the point of view of competition, according to the directives established in this Law and developed according to the respective regulation. By regulation the necessary costs referred to in this article shall be defined. The determination of the amount to be subsidized shall be made by the telecommunications operator providing universal service in accordance with criteria established by the National Telecommunications Commission, which must approve the calculation result after hearing the opinion of the Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board, following an audit carried out by it or by the entity it designates for these purposes.

ARTICLE 56.- The Universal Service Fund shall have a Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board chaired by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission or whoever performs his functions. The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall also be integrated by a representative appointed by the Minister of Infrastructure, a representative appointed by the Minister of Planning and Development, a representative appointed by the Minister of Production and Commerce, and a representative appointed by persons who contribute to the Fund. The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have an Executive Secretary appointed by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission from among the Commission's officials. External professional services may also be hired when considered necessary.
ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 1. Ensure compliance with the Fund's purpose.
ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 2. Issue its internal regulations.

ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 3. Evaluate the performance of operators providing Universal Service and approve disbursement of Fund resources for financing it, when appropriate in accordance with this Law.

ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 4. Approve projects presented for financing by the Fund, in accordance with assumptions established by this Law.

ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 5. Ensure neutrality and transparency in the assignment of Universal Service obligations by the National Telecommunications Commission, formulating recommendations as it deems convenient.
ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 6. Recommend cessation or modification of the Universal Service obligation.

ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 7. Ensure that the National Telecommunications Commission timely delivers Fund resources to Universal Service operators, in accordance with the approved schedule.
ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 8. Ensure profitability and liquidity in financial operations related to the Fund.

ARTICLE 57.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have the following powers: 9. Present an annual report of its activities to the President of the Republic and the Comptroller General of the Republic.

ARTICLE 58.- Resources of the Universal Service Fund shall come from: 1. Contributions made by telecommunications service operators with profit-making purposes, in accordance with Article 151 of this Law;
ARTICLE 58.- Resources of the Universal Service Fund shall come from: 2. Contributions made as donations by any natural or legal person.

ARTICLE 58.- Resources of the Universal Service Fund shall come from: 3. Resources of this Fund shall be deposited in the specific bank account designated for such purpose by the National Telecommunications Commission and may be placed in investments that guarantee the greatest security, profitability and liquidity.

ARTICLE 58.- Resources of the Universal Service Fund shall come from: 4. Management expenses of this account shall be deducted from its balance and the returns it generates shall increase the Fund's resources.

ARTICLE 59.- The result of the calculation made for the purposes of the previous article, as well as the conclusions of the corresponding audits, shall be available to all operators upon request and in accordance with the procedure established in the respective regulation, who may make observations to the National Telecommunications Commission as they deem appropriate.

ARTICLE 60.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall prepare and make public an annual report on the contributions made to the Fund for its financing and the amounts of Universal Service subsidies that have been granted, being able to require all information it deems necessary from the operators involved.

ARTICLE 61.- Use of Universal Service Fund resources for purposes other than those provided in this Chapter shall be sanctioned in accordance with the Organic Law for the Safeguard of Public Patrimony.

ARTICLE 62.- Infrastructure subsidized with Universal Service Fund resources and used by an operator to satisfy a Universal Service obligation may not be alienated, assigned or encumbered by it without prior approval of the National Telecommunications Commission. In any case, such goods must be used to satisfy the universal service. Likewise, they may not be subject to preventive or executive judicial measures. The corresponding regulation shall regulate cases of replacement and decommissioning of equipment, as well as modernization of networks used to meet a Universal Service.

CHAPTER II TELECOMMUNICATIONS RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT FUND ARTICLE 63.- The Telecommunications Research and Development Fund is created, which shall have the character of separate patrimony dependent on the Ministry of Science and Technology. The structure, organization and control mechanisms of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall be those determined in this Law and in the respective regulation.
ARTICLE 64.- The Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the purpose of guaranteeing financing for research and development in the telecommunications sector.

ARTICLE 65.- Resources of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall come from: 1. Contributions of operators obliged to contribute to it; 2. Contributions made as donations by any natural or legal person. Sole Paragraph: Resources destined to this Fund shall be deposited exclusively in the specific bank account designated for such purpose and may be placed in investments that guarantee the greatest security, profitability and liquidity. Management expenses of this account shall be deducted from its balance and the returns it generates shall increase its amount. Resources corresponding to the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall be administered by the Minister of Science and Technology for the purposes provided in this Law, as separate patrimony, without being able to give them a different use.

ARTICLE 66.- The Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have a Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board chaired by the Minister of Science and Technology or whoever exercises his functions. It shall also be integrated by two representatives with expertise in telecommunications R&D appointed by the Minister of Science and Technology, a representative appointed by the Minister of Education, Culture and Sport, a representative appointed by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission, a representative appointed by National Universities and a representative appointed by the companies that contribute to the Fund. The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board shall have an Executive Secretary appointed by the Minister of Science and Technology, whose powers shall be determined by regulation and by the Board's internal regulations.
ARTICLE 67.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the following powers: 1. Ensure compliance with the Fund's purpose.
ARTICLE 67.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the following powers: 2. Issue its internal regulations.

ARTICLE 67.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the following powers: 3. Evaluate and approve projects presented for financing by the Fund.

ARTICLE 67.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the following powers: 4. Ensure neutrality and transparency in the allocation of Fund resources, formulating recommendations as it deems convenient.

ARTICLE 67.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the following powers: 5. Recommend modification, reorientation or suppression of projects.

ARTICLE 67.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the following powers: 6. Ensure that the Ministry of Science and Technology timely delivers resources to beneficiaries.

ARTICLE 67.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the following powers: 7. Ensure profitability and liquidity in financial operations.

ARTICLE 67.- The Project Evaluation and Monitoring Board of the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund shall have the following powers: 8. Present an annual report of its activities to the President of the Republic and the Comptroller General of the Republic.

ARTICLE 68.- The Ministry of Science and Technology shall prepare and make public an annual report on contributions made to the Fund for its financing and the amounts of resources granted with indication of the project concerned, being able to require all information it deems necessary from beneficiaries. Use of Telecommunications Research and Development Fund resources for purposes other than those provided in this Chapter shall be sanctioned in accordance with the Organic Law for the Safeguard of Public Patrimony.

TITLE VI LIMITED RESOURCES CHAPTER I RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM ARTICLE 69.- The administration, regulation, planning and control of the radioelectric spectrum correspond to the National Telecommunications Commission, in accordance with this Law and the binding norms issued by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), also seeking to harmonize its activities with the recommendations of said organization. The National Telecommunications Commission shall exercise necessary coordination for the international projection use of the radioelectric spectrum, in accordance with this Law and treaties and international agreements signed and ratified by the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.

ARTICLE 70.- Administration, regulation, planning and control of the radioelectric spectrum include, among other powers, planning, determination of the national table of frequency band attributions, assignment, changes and verification of frequencies, technical checking of radioelectric emissions, establishment of technical norms for spectrum use, detection of irregularities and disturbances, control of its proper use and imposition of sanctions as appropriate, in accordance with the law.

ARTICLE 71.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall approve and publish in the Official Gazette of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela the National Table of Frequency Band Attribution (CUNABAF) and associated technical utilization plans. The National Telecommunications Commission may allocate portions of the radioelectric spectrum for fulfillment of Public Power functions through its entities and organs, as well as for development of community public service non-profit sound broadcasting and open television. Portions of the radioelectric spectrum for governmental use must be registered in the respective CUNABAF. The National Telecommunications Commission shall make available to the public the status of frequency bands that have been assigned without requiring detailed identification.

ARTICLE 72.- The CUNABAF and associated technical plans shall conform to international treaties signed by the Republic and shall be based on the best criteria to achieve efficient spectrum use, at the discretion of the National Telecommunications Commission. Spectrum use shall in any case conform to the CUNABAF and assignment of use shall promote development of telecommunications markets and guarantee availability of spectrum portions for socially purposed activities.

ARTICLE 73.- The concession for the use of the radioelectric spectrum is a unilateral administrative act through which the National Telecommunications Commission (CONATEL) grants or renews, for a limited time, to a natural or legal person the status of concessionaire for the use and exploitation of a determined portion of the radioelectric spectrum, after compliance with requirements established in this Law. Without prejudice to applicable legal and regulatory provisions, relations arising from a concession shall be governed by the respective concession contract. Rights over the use and exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum derived from a concession may not be ceded or alienated; however, the concessionaire may request the National Telecommunications Commission to substitute the concession’s titularity to the person it indicates, provided that this person meets conditions and principles established in this Law.

ARTICLE 74.- The National Telecommunications Commission may, by motivated act, change the assignment of a frequency or frequency band that has been granted in concession, in the following cases: 1. For reasons of national security;

ARTICLE 74.- The National Telecommunications Commission may, by motivated act, change the assignment of a frequency or frequency band that has been granted in concession, in the following cases: 2. For the introduction of new technologies and services;

ARTICLE 74.- The National Telecommunications Commission may, by motivated act, change the assignment of a frequency or frequency band that has been granted in concession, in the following cases: 3. To solve interference problems;

ARTICLE 74.- The National Telecommunications Commission may, by motivated act, change the assignment of a frequency or frequency band that has been granted in concession, in the following cases: 4. To comply with modifications to the CUNABAF. In the cases provided in the foregoing numerals the National Telecommunications Commission shall grant the concessionaire, by direct award, new available frequency bands through which the services originally provided can be offered, without prejudice to compensation where such change causes damages to the concessionaire. If no frequencies or frequency bands are available, expropriation of the use and exploitation right previously conferred to the concessionaire shall proceed and compensation for material damages incurred shall be made.
ARTICLE 75.- Concession shall not be required for spectrum use in the following cases: 1. Point-to-point links whose usage period does not exceed three (3) continuous days;

ARTICLE 75.- Concession shall not be required for spectrum use in the following cases: 2. Pilot tests of new technology equipment that require spectrum use for a period not exceeding three (3) continuous non-extendable months;
ARTICLE 75.- Concession shall not be required for spectrum use in the following cases: 3. When they are radio amateurs who have the condition of such under this Law;

ARTICLE 75.- Concession shall not be required for spectrum use in the following cases: 4. For the use of free-use equipment, in accordance with this Law. Sole Paragraph: In the cases expressed in numerals 1 and 2 the interested party shall request a special administrative authorization from the National Telecommunications Commission, according to particulars and summary procedure to be established by regulation, and pay the corresponding fee for administration and control of spectrum use.

CHAPTER II PROCEDURE FOR CONCESSION OF USE AND EXPLOITATION OF THE RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM ARTICLE 76.- To carry out telecommunications activities involving spectrum use, operators must obtain in advance the corresponding use concession granted by the National Telecommunications Commission through the public offer procedure or by direct award, in the form and conditions regulated by this Law and its regulation.

ARTICLE 77.- In selecting persons to be granted telecommunications concessions, the National Telecommunications Commission shall be subject to principles of equality, transparency, publicity, efficiency, rationality, plurality of competitors, competition, technological development and incentive of initiative, as well as protection and guarantee of users.
ARTICLE 78.- Persons wishing to participate in procedures established in this chapter shall provide additional information and documentation required by the National Telecommunications Commission.

Section First Public Offer Commission ARTICLE 79.- The Public Offer Commission shall be composed of five members, two representatives appointed by the Minister of Infrastructure and three officials appointed by the Governing Board of the National Telecommunications Commission.

ARTICLE 80.- The Comptroller General of the Republic may designate an official to act as observer in sessions of the Public Offer Commission, with the right to speak. The regulation of this Law may determine the intervention of other observers.

ARTICLE 81.- Powers of the Public Offer Commission include: 1. Handle the Public Offer procedure for concession of use and exploitation of spectrum portions and recommend to the National Telecommunications Commission the prequalification or not of interested parties;

ARTICLE 81.- Powers of the Public Offer Commission include: 2. Submit to the National Telecommunications Commission the possibility of declaring the Public Offer procedure deserted, under assumptions established in the regulation.

ARTICLE 82.- The Public Offer Commission shall meet timely according to the schedule established by its President. Said schedule shall be notified to Commission members and the Comptroller General. The Public Offer Commission may meet extraordinarily without prior call when at least the President, the Legal Counsel and two other members are present.
ARTICLE 83.- It shall correspond to the President of the Public Offer Commission: 1. Direct the Public Offer Commission meetings;
ARTICLE 83.- It shall correspond to the President of the Public Offer Commission: 2. Establish the Public Offer Commission session schedule;
ARTICLE 83.- It shall correspond to the President of the Public Offer Commission: 3. Sign communications of the Public Offer Commission;
ARTICLE 83.- It shall correspond to the President of the Public Offer Commission: 4. Designate among Commission members who should take and keep minutes of what is discussed and decided in sessions;
ARTICLE 83.- It shall correspond to the President of the Public Offer Commission: 5. Certify Commission minutes;
ARTICLE 83.- It shall correspond to the President of the Public Offer Commission: 6. Other powers corresponding to the Public Offer Commission and not assigned to another official.

Section Second Public Offer ARTICLE 84.- The Public Offer procedure for concession of spectrum use and exploitation comprises a prequalification phase and a selection phase, the latter to be carried out by auction or based on satisfaction under better conditions of certain parameters established by the National Telecommunications Commission for each process, in accordance with this Law and its regulations. The Public Offer procedure is excepted for granting concessions of spectrum use and exploitation in broadcasting and open television, cases in which direct award shall proceed.

ARTICLE 85.- Before the start of each calendar year, the National Telecommunications Commission shall determine by resolution published in the Official Gazette the bands or subbands of available spectrum to be subject to the Public Offer procedure, as well as the criteria to be used for selection, in case said body decides to assign them during that period, which resolution shall be an annex to the National Telecommunications Plan. In said resolution the National Telecommunications Commission shall preferably establish auction as the selection mechanism when frequency bands or subbands to be granted are classified by it as of high economic valuation, are intended for mass-use services, are useful for more than one operator and their use prevents concurrent use by other concessionaires in the portion of spectrum subject to the procedure.

ARTICLE 86.- The Public Offer procedure shall be initiated ex officio by the National Telecommunications Commission which shall determine precisely, before its start, the General Conditions that will govern the process, which shall state at least the band or subbands to be assigned, the estimated base price, technical, economic and legal requirements, as well as the criteria to be used for prequalification and selection, the date for publication of the call to participate and, where appropriate, the concession contract for the activity to be signed immediately after publication in the Official Gazette of the act by which the use concession over the radioelectric spectrum is granted. Notwithstanding the foregoing, persons who wish to be concessionaires of the limited resource referred to in this Chapter may inform the National Telecommunications Commission in writing, without this implying a subjective right to initiate the respective procedure. The informative writing shall indicate at least the spectrum portion of interest, with specifications and technical indications as appropriate and the intended use.

ARTICLE 87.- The Public Offer procedure shall be initiated by a motivated act issued by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission, ordering publication in at least two newspapers of highest circulation in the national territory, with a difference of seven working days between publications, of a notice calling interested parties to participate in the procedure to obtain concessions in a determined band or subband. Said publication shall state at least: 1. The portion of the radioelectric spectrum object of the Public Offer, sufficiently individualized;

ARTICLE 87.- The Public Offer procedure shall be initiated by a motivated act issued by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission, ordering publication in at least two newspapers of highest circulation in the national territory, with a difference of seven working days between publications, of a notice calling interested parties to participate in the procedure to obtain concessions in a determined band or subband. Said publication shall state at least: 2. Base price and amount of bank or insurance company bond guaranteeing participation until conclusion, as well as the opportunity to deposit the price by the selected party in case selection by auction proceeds;

ARTICLE 87.- The Public Offer procedure shall be initiated by a motivated act issued by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission, ordering publication in at least two newspapers of highest circulation in the national territory, with a difference of seven working days between publications, of a notice calling interested parties to participate in the procedure to obtain concessions in a determined band or subband. Said publication shall state at least: 3. Technical, economic and legal requirements participants must meet;

ARTICLE 87.- The Public Offer procedure shall be initiated by a motivated act issued by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission, ordering publication in at least two newspapers of highest circulation in the national territory, with a difference of seven working days between publications, of a notice calling interested parties to participate in the procedure to obtain concessions in a determined band or subband. Said publication shall state at least: 4. Place, period and schedule where interested parties must obtain the set of General Conditions for participation and its value;

ARTICLE 87.- The Public Offer procedure shall be initiated by a motivated act issued by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission, ordering publication in at least two newspapers of highest circulation in the national territory, with a difference of seven working days between publications, of a notice calling interested parties to participate in the procedure to obtain concessions in a determined band or subband. Said publication shall state at least: 5. Place, date and schedule for submission of technical and legal documents for prequalification.

ARTICLE 88.- The period for supplying information to interested parties regarding the Public Offer procedure may not exceed twenty working days. Said period shall begin from the date of the last publication. Without prejudice to publication under Article 87, the National Telecommunications Commission shall ensure that the call to participate in the Public Offer process is adequately announced on the Internet or any other medium it deems convenient so that information about the process has the widest possible reach.

ARTICLE 89.- Prequalification is the phase of the Public Offer procedure by which the National Telecommunications Commission determines the existence of interested parties that comply with technical, economic and legal requirements to be concessionaires of a determined portion of the radioelectric spectrum, according to the general conditions, the law and other applicable legal provisions.

ARTICLE 90.- Persons wishing to participate in the Public Offer process must notify the Public Offer Commission of the National Telecommunications Commission in writing 48 hours prior to the act of document receipt, under penalty of being unable to later participate in the process. They must also indicate the person(s) who will participate in the act of receiving technical, economic and legal documentation, indicating the capacity in which they will act and that they have sufficient authority to bind the interested party in the procedure.
ARTICLE 91.- The will to participate in the process as well as technical and legal documentation must be presented in Spanish or translated into Spanish by a public interpreter.

ARTICLE 92.- The Public Offer Commission of the National Telecommunications Commission, in public act and at the time and place established, shall receive from interested parties who have expressed their will as provided in this chapter the documents related to technical, economic and legal documentation, of which it shall draw up minutes, to be signed by Commission members and interested parties or their duly accredited representatives.

ARTICLE 93.- The minutes shall record the essential content of technical aspects, in accordance with particulars to be set by resolution of the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission. A copy of said minutes shall be supplied on the same act to participants who request it.

ARTICLE 94.- The Public Offer Commission shall have ten working days, extendable by an equal period, to make its recommendation to the Governing Board of the National Telecommunications Commission regarding prequalification of interested parties. In performing its functions the Public Offer Commission may request collaboration of any Directorates of the body and, in its evaluation, shall adhere as far as possible to objective valuation parameters generally contained in General Condition Documents. In its recommendation the Public Offer Commission shall sufficiently state technical, economic and legal reasons for recommending prequalification of certain interested parties as well as reasons technical, economic or legal for considering non-prequalification of others, if applicable.

ARTICLE 95.- The Governing Board of the National Telecommunications Commission, after considering the Public Offer Commission recommendation, shall grant prequalified status to applicants that conform to required legal matters and meet technical and economic parameters established for the limited resource concerned. Failure to grant such status shall be by sufficiently motivated act.

ARTICLE 96.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall notify interested parties who participated in the process whether they have been prequalified or not. To this end the Commission shall order personal notification to the applicant's domicile or that of their representatives, or via electronic mechanisms, in accordance with what the regulation of this Law provides. In addition, the notification shall be published in a newspaper of greatest circulation in the national territory.
ARTICLE 97.- Auctions shall be directed by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission or, failing that, by the natural or legal person he determines.

ARTICLE 98.- The auction is the selection modality by which the National Telecommunications Commission shall choose among prequalified applicants the one offering the highest price for the opportunity to be concessionaire of a determined band or subband. The auction shall be carried out by rounds, in terms established in this Law and its regulation.

ARTICLE 99.- Once the prequalification phase is concluded and when selection must be made by auction, the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission shall set the place, date and time for the first public auction round, which must take place within ten working days following publication under Article 96.

ARTICLE 100.- In the first auction round, after receiving offers from all prequalified applicants or after one hour from the start if other prequalified applicants have not presented themselves, the possibility shall be opened for participants to improve their initial offers in the same act by bidding on price. The act shall extend until an offer is not surpassed by another participant, in which case the round is concluded and the highest offers by each participant shall be recorded in minutes. Price bids may only be made that exceed by at least two percent (2%) the highest price offered to that point.

ARTICLE 101.- After the first round, the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission shall set place, date and time for the second public auction round, to be held within ten working days following the first. It shall be expressly warned that if in the second round no offers exceed the best of the first round, the award shall be granted to the first-round best bidder.

ARTICLE 102.- The second round shall be carried out under the same parameters as the first, except that if no superior offer is made, award shall be granted to that offer. The same rules apply to subsequent rounds. The National Telecommunications Commission may establish that auction rounds be held through electronic or audiovisual means, in which case procedure established in the opening act of the public offer procedure shall be followed, ensuring transparency and suitability.

ARTICLE 103.- Economic resources generated by auctions under this Law shall go directly to the National Treasury, after deducting expenses incurred by the National Telecommunications Commission in the process. The National Telecommunications Commission may impose limitations on time or spectrum portion to participation of operating companies established in public offer processes when associated technologies allow or facilitate rapid entry of new operators into the relevant market.

Section Third Direct Award ARTICLE 104.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall grant by direct award concessions relating to determined portions of the radioelectric spectrum. For this purpose, applicants shall make the corresponding request to the National Telecommunications Commission and comply with required legal, economic and technical matters in accordance with this Law and its regulations. In broadcasting and open television cases direct award shall be granted by the Minister of Infrastructure according to State telecommunications policy, after considering the corresponding report from the National Telecommunications Commission. The Minister shall rule within a period no greater than thirty continuous days counted from receipt of the report presented by the National Telecommunications Commission.
ARTICLE 105.- Direct award shall be granted for spectrum use and exploitation concessions in the following cases: 1. When the spectrum portion lacks economic valuation in accordance with this Law.

ARTICLE 105.- Direct award shall be granted for spectrum use and exploitation concessions in the following cases: 2. When concessionaires are affected by a change in assigned use of frequencies in cases established in Article 74.

ARTICLE 105.- Direct award shall be granted for spectrum use and exploitation concessions in the following cases: 3. When the applicant is a national, state or municipal public organism to satisfy its communication needs.
ARTICLE 105.- Direct award shall be granted for spectrum use and exploitation concessions in the following cases: 4. When it concerns spectrum use in broadcasting and open television.

ARTICLE 105.- Direct award shall be granted for spectrum use and exploitation concessions in the following cases: 5. When, having initiated a Public Offer procedure, the number of prequalified is equal to or less than the number of spectrum portions offered.
ARTICLE 105.- Direct award shall be granted for spectrum use and exploitation concessions in the following cases: 6. When necessary to fulfill Universal Service obligations.

ARTICLE 106.- Applications for a concession to use the spectrum by direct award shall lapse two years after filing, unless the applicant ratifies in writing its interest to the National Telecommunications Commission. Under equal conditions preference shall be given to older applications, provided they conform to National Telecommunications Plan parameters.

Section Fourth Common Provisions to Preceding Sections ARTICLE 107.- For the purposes of this Law, a portion of the radioelectric spectrum is understood to be available when the following concurrent requirements are met: 1. When it is susceptible to being assigned in a use concession to a private or public entity at a given time, in accordance with the National Telecommunications Plan and the CUNABAF issued by the National Telecommunications Commission; and 2. It is not occupied by a concessionaire, without prejudice to the Commission's power to change frequencies under this Law.

ARTICLE 108.- A use concession for the radioelectric spectrum shall not be granted to those who, despite being selected in accordance with modalities established in this Law, are in the following situations: 1. When the National Telecommunications Commission finds false or inaccurate data supplied by the selected party or adjudicatee, or when they have been declared in arrears or bankrupt;

ARTICLE 108.- A use concession for the radioelectric spectrum shall not be granted to those who, despite being selected in accordance with modalities established in this Law, are in the following situations: 2. When the selected party or adjudicatee formally renounces such status and notifies the National Telecommunications Commission;

ARTICLE 108.- A use concession for the radioelectric spectrum shall not be granted to those who, despite being selected in accordance with modalities established in this Law, are in the following situations: 3. When the selected party or adjudicatee does not pay within deadlines provided in the process the corresponding amounts in auction cases.

ARTICLE 108.- A use concession for the radioelectric spectrum shall not be granted to those who, despite being selected in accordance with modalities established in this Law, are in the following situations: 4. When the selected party or adjudicatee ceases to have technical, economic or legal qualities that allowed participation;

ARTICLE 108.- A use concession for the radioelectric spectrum shall not be granted to those who, despite being selected in accordance with modalities established in this Law, are in the following situations: 5.
