When serious circumstances related to State security arise that, at the President's discretion, make granting inconvenient. First Paragraph: In cases where concession is not granted for reasons in numerals 1,2,3 and 4 of this article, the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission (CONATEL) shall issue a resolution indicating reasons for not signing the contract and record existence of one of the provided situations. In such situations procedures shall proceed in accordance with the next article and regulation. Second Paragraph: In cases where concession is not granted for causal in numeral 5, the President of the Republic shall issue the corresponding Decree establishing existence of those circumstances. The regulation shall determine consequences derived from this situation.

ARTICLE 109.- When concession is not granted due to reasons in numerals 1,2,3 and 4 of the previous article, the following shall apply: 1. When selection occurred by auction, the National Telecommunications Commission shall award the contract to the prequalified who presented the second best offer, provided difference between it and the best offer did not exceed three percent (3%). Otherwise the Commission shall declare the process closed and may initiate a new Public Offer procedure ex officio or at a party's request.

ARTICLE 109.- When concession is not granted due to reasons in numerals 1,2,3 and 4 of the previous article, the following shall apply: 2. Regulation may under certain conditions exempt from prequalification those who participated in the previous procedure.

ARTICLE 109.- When concession is not granted due to reasons in numerals 1,2,3 and 4 of the previous article, the following shall apply: 3. When selection occurred by direct award, the National Telecommunications Commission shall act in accordance with what regulation provides.
ARTICLE 110.- Together with granting the concession for spectrum use and exploitation the National Telecommunications Commission shall grant the administrative authorization associated thereto.

CHAPTER III NUMBERING ARTICLE 111.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall administer, control and regulate the limited resource of numbering, establish National Numbering Plans and respective norms. For this Law, Numbering means unique representation, through identifiers, of terminal equipment of telecommunications networks, network elements, or telecommunications networks themselves. Identifiers granted directly or indirectly by international entities other than those administered and granted by the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela through the National Telecommunications Commission are excluded. Identifiers shall be based on codes or alphanumeric characters following guidelines established by international or regional regulatory bodies.

ARTICLE 112.- Numbering attributes granted under this Law shall be purely instrumental. Therefore their grant does not confer rights or interests to operators, so their modification or suppression when they are idle per respective administrative authorization shall not generate any right to compensation. Numbering resources may not be transferred to another operator, directly or indirectly, without express authorization from the National Telecommunications Commission, which must adhere to National Numbering Plans.

ARTICLE 113.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall assign numbering resources under objective, transparent and non-discriminatory conditions, according to normative established by resolution following Numbering Plans. Telecommunications service operators offering public services shall have the right to dispose of numbers and numbering intervals when necessary to enable effective provision and comply with National Numbering Plans.

ARTICLE 114.- National Numbering Plans shall be issued by the National Telecommunications Commission respecting international agreements subscribed and ratified by the Republic. Such plans are mandatory and operators, network providers, manufacturers and equipment suppliers must take necessary measures for compliance and with Commission decisions regarding same. Modification of National Numbering Plans shall be aimed at efficient resource distribution or compliance with international obligations of the Republic. The Commission shall consider affected parties' interests and adaptation costs to minimize them insofar as possible and compatible with causes motivating modification.

ARTICLE 115.- National Numbering Plans and acts related to its management shall be public, except matters that may affect national security and defense. National Numbering Plans shall be published in full in the Official Gazette, except where for reasons related to State security part or all must be reserved.

ARTICLE 116.- In exercising functions as administrator and controller of numbering resources, the National Telecommunications Commission may require holders of limited resources to provide information necessary to evaluate numbering system efficiency and appropriate use of assigned resources. Collected information shall be confidential and used only by the Commission for requested purposes.

ARTICLE 117.- Telecommunications operators shall guarantee, in cases, terms, conditions and deadlines determined by the National Telecommunications Commission, that service contract holders may retain assigned numbers according to modalities established by the Commission based on norms and international trends. Number portability shall not, in any case, worsen service availability and quality. As a minimum obligation operators must preserve telephone numbers when contract holders change operator or physical location within the same locality. To enjoy number retention operators must be current with the operator that provides their service. Costs of complying with obligations in this article shall be borne exclusively by respective operators without right to claim compensation.

ARTICLE 118.- Telecommunications operators shall guarantee, in cases, terms, conditions and deadlines determined by the National Telecommunications Commission that service contract holders can select, as they wish, among operators providing national or international long-distance telephony which to use, without this obligation worsening availability and quality of service.

CHAPTER IV SATELLITE USE ARTICLE 119.- The National Telecommunications Commission is responsible for administration, regulation, planning and control of the radioelectric spectrum associated with satellite networks, as well as access and use of orbit-spectrum resources for space networks assigned by the Republic and registered in its name, all in accordance with international treaties validly signed and ratified by the Republic. These resources may be exploited only by concession granted in accordance with this Law and other applicable norms, considering their nature.

ARTICLE 120.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall carry out necessary procedures, coordinating with involved national and international dependencies, to seek availability of sufficient orbit-spectrum resources for establishing national security networks and for providing telecommunications services of social character.

ARTICLE 121.- Concessionaires of orbit-spectrum resource and associated frequencies assigned by the Republic shall be obliged to operationalize a satellite network within a maximum period of five years after obtaining the respective concession. For technical reasons the National Telecommunications Commission may grant an extension of up to two years.

ARTICLE 122.- Priority shall be given to use of Venezuelan satellites for provision of satellite services in the country if they provide technical and economic conditions equivalent to foreign satellites. For this Law a Venezuelan satellite is understood to be one using orbital resources and associated spectrum assigned by the Republic and registered in its name with relevant International Organizations and whose control and monitoring stations and business headquarters are installed in national territory. Without prejudice to international treaties and agreements validly signed and ratified by the Republic, exploitation and provision of satellite services in Venezuela by foreign satellites requires technical and commercial presence in the country of the foreign company representing it.

ARTICLE 123.- The concession to exploit orbit-spectrum resource and associated frequencies assigned by the Republic shall be granted for a maximum period of fifteen years, which may be extended for an equal or lesser period, at the discretion of the National Telecommunications Commission and in accordance with the National Telecommunications Plan, according to the following guidelines: 1. Immediately after the exploitation request for satellite services is made, the National Telecommunications Commission shall evaluate the information and decide in accordance with the regulation whether it is pertinent to submit corresponding information to the ITU. This does not imply granting exploitation to the applicant.

ARTICLE 123.- The concession to exploit orbit-spectrum resource and associated frequencies assigned by the Republic shall be granted for a maximum period of fifteen years, which may be extended for an equal or lesser period, at the discretion of the National Telecommunications Commission and in accordance with the National Telecommunications Plan, according to the following guidelines: 2. The beneficiary of the orbit-spectrum concession and associated frequencies shall be chosen in accordance with the assignment procedure established for spectrum insofar as applicable.

ARTICLE 123.- The concession to exploit orbit-spectrum resource and associated frequencies assigned by the Republic shall be granted for a maximum period of fifteen years, which may be extended for an equal or lesser period, at the discretion of the National Telecommunications Commission and in accordance with the National Telecommunications Plan, according to the following guidelines: 3. The beneficiary of the concession of orbit-spectrum and associated frequencies, when Venezuelan satellites are involved, shall be chosen by direct award without prejudice to fulfillment of requirements determined by the National Telecommunications Commission. If simultaneous applicants and shortage of orbit-spectrum resources and associated frequencies exist, the Commission shall use public offer procedures established in this Law.

ARTICLE 124.- Provision of any direct satellite telecommunications service in the country is subject to the general regime of service provision established in this Law. The National Telecommunications Commission shall grant the corresponding administrative authorization to those who have complied with requirements and conditions established for that purpose by said body in accordance with this Law, its regulations and international treaties and agreements subscribed and ratified by the Republic.

ARTICLE 125.- Use of the radioelectric spectrum for provision of direct satellite telecommunications services shall require obtaining the corresponding concession granted by the National Telecommunications Commission. Telecommunications service operators duly authorized by the National Telecommunications Commission under this Law may operate with satellites owned by international entities established under treaties or international agreements signed and ratified by the Republic. Such entities are exempted from establishing legal personality in the country and from requesting an enabling title.

ARTICLE 125.- The use of the radioelectric spectrum for the provision of direct satellite telecommunications services shall require obtaining the corresponding concession granted by the National Telecommunications Commission.

ARTICLE 125.- Operators of telecommunications services duly authorized by the National Telecommunications Commission under the terms established in this Law may operate with satellites owned by international entities established under the protection of treaties or international agreements subscribed to and ratified by the Republic. Such entities are exempted from establishing legal personality in the country and from applying for a habilitating title.
CHAPTER V
OF THE GENERAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS PATHWAYS

ARTICLE 126.- General telecommunications pathways are understood to be the elements that allow the placement of the physical means necessary for the provision of telecommunications services, in accordance with the provisions of the respective regulation.

ARTICLE 126.- Any person who exclusively or predominantly owns or controls a general telecommunications pathway must allow access to or use of the same by telecommunications operators who request it, when its replacement is not feasible for physical, legal, economic, technical, environmental, security or operational reasons.

ARTICLE 126.- All operators shall have the right to make use of existing general telecommunications pathways, in the form and modalities determined by the National Telecommunications Commission, in accordance with this Law and other applicable legal provisions.

ARTICLE 127.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall seek the rational and non-discriminatory use of general telecommunications pathways and shall also promote their creation and exploitation. In urban development plans and in the construction of public works in general, the necessary provisions shall be taken for the incorporation of such general telecommunications pathways.

ARTICLE 128.- General telecommunications pathways may be used by persons other than the owner or controller thereof, in which case payment of consideration shall be generated, which shall be fixed by mutual agreement between the parties.

ARTICLE 128.- The exercise of the right of access to and use of a general telecommunications pathway shall not irrationally affect the free use of the same by the person who owns or controls it, cause damage to his installations, or affect the continuity and quality of his service.
ARTICLE 128.- The parties shall agree by mutual agreement on the terms and conditions under which access to and use of general telecommunications pathways will be carried out.

ARTICLE 128.- Anyone who wishes to make use of a general telecommunications pathway must request it in writing from the person who owns or controls it, indicating all the technical elements of the project to be developed and other requirements provided for in the Regulation of this Law.

ARTICLE 128.- The applicant must send a copy of said request to the National Telecommunications Commission, within ten business days following, for its information. Likewise, the parties must send to the National Telecommunications Commission a copy of the agreement they reach, within ten business days following its signing, for its review.

ARTICLE 129.- In the event that a party refuses to allow access to and use of a general telecommunications pathway or abstains from issuing a pronouncement in this regard within the term established by the regulation of this Law, the other party may request the National Telecommunications Commission to, after hearing the interested parties, rule on the matter, having heard the opinion of the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition. In its decision the National Telecommunications Commission shall declare, if appropriate, the irreplaceability of the general telecommunications pathway and, consequently, the compulsory execution of the obligation to allow access and use, on the terms and conditions set for that purpose.

ARTICLE 129.- The decision of the National Telecommunications Commission must be produced within a period not greater than thirty continuous days counted from the receipt of the request, extendable for an equal period if the complexity of the matter submitted for its consideration so warrants and it declares so by express act.
TITLE VII
ON INTERCONNECTION

ARTICLE 130.- Telecommunications network operators have the obligation to interconnect with other public telecommunications networks with the objective of establishing interoperable and continuous communications in time between the users of their services. Interconnection shall be made in accordance with the principles of neutrality, good faith, non-discrimination, and equal access among operators, pursuant to the terms established in this Law, its regulations and other applicable rules.

ARTICLE 131.- Telecommunications network operators shall adopt open network architecture designs to allow interconnection and interoperability of their networks. To that end, the National Telecommunications Commission shall prepare and administer the fundamental technical plans for numbering, transmission, signaling, tariffing and synchronization, among others, which telecommunications network operators must comply with.

ARTICLE 132.- The initiative to request interconnection may originate from any of the operators involved. In case of a request, it must be made in writing, stating with full precision the technical and economic elements applicable. The applicant must send a copy of the request with the corresponding acknowledgment of receipt to the National Telecommunications Commission, for its information.

ARTICLE 132.- Upon receipt of the request by the operator to whom the interconnection was required, the parties shall mutually determine the negotiation mechanisms they consider convenient and the period in which they propose to reach an agreement, which may not exceed sixty continuous days counted from the date on which the request was received.

ARTICLE 132.- Without prejudice to compliance with other requirements deriving from this Law and regulations, the interconnection agreement shall precisely provide the following: 1. The period and modalities under which the agreement will be executed.

ARTICLE 132.- Without prejudice to compliance with other requirements deriving from this Law and regulations, the interconnection agreement shall precisely provide the following: 2. The obligations of each operator.

ARTICLE 132.- Without prejudice to compliance with other requirements deriving from this Law and regulations, the interconnection agreement shall precisely provide the following: 3. The statement of the term in which any of them may request the other to review the respective agreement. Said term may not exceed two years.

ARTICLE 133.- The parties shall mutually agree the interconnection charges in the contracts they enter into, orienting them to costs that include a reasonable profit margin. When the parties do not reach an agreement within the period provided therefor, the National Telecommunications Commission shall have a period not exceeding thirty continuous days, extendable for the same time, to order that the requested interconnection be made effective, and to establish its technical and economic conditions.

ARTICLE 133.- The action of said Commission, in this case, must be strictly necessary to protect the interests of users and shall be carried out ex officio, at the instance of both interested parties or of one of them and its decision shall be issued after hearing the parties affected.
ARTICLE 134.- Operators must notify the National Telecommunications Commission, within five business days following their subscription, of the interconnection agreements they have reached.

ARTICLE 134.- Within forty-five days following the notification, the National Telecommunications Commission shall proceed to formulate its comments on the corresponding interconnection agreement, which shall have the character of an informative addendum to it and shall be available to the public together with the interconnection agreement.

ARTICLE 135.- Any dispute arising in relation to an interconnection contract shall be resolved between the parties, in accordance with the terms established in the corresponding contract. In case the parties do not reach an agreement that ends the dispute, it shall be submitted by one or both parties, by motivated communication, to the National Telecommunications Commission, which must decide in a reasoned manner within a period of thirty continuous days, counted from its submission, once the arguments and evidence of the parties have been presented. In said period the National Telecommunications Commission may carry out inspections or audits as well as request any other additional information that may be pertinent for the resolution of the matter under debate.

ARTICLE 135.- The period referred to in this article may be extended by the National Telecommunications Commission for an equal time, when the complexity of the matter or particular circumstances of the case so require.
ARTICLE 136.- Disputes arising in relation to an interconnection contract to telecommunications networks may in no case give rise to unilateral disconnection of networks by the operators.

ARTICLE 136.- The National Telecommunications Commission may order, as a precautionary measure or in its final decision, the disconnection from the networks of one of the parties when it deems it appropriate, in accordance with applicable legal provisions.
ARTICLE 136.- The National Telecommunications Commission must issue measures to be applied in order to minimize the negative effects for users in the event of disconnection.

ARTICLE 137.- Interconnection between telecommunications networks must be carried out without diminishing the services and quality originally provided, so that it complies with the plans and programs in telecommunications approved by the National Telecommunications Commission.
ARTICLE 137.- Responsibility for the service and its quality shall fall on the operator contracted by the user, unless he proves causes not attributable to him.
TITLE VIII
OF RADIO AMATEURS
ARTICLE 138.- The radio amateur service is a universal radiocommunication service whose purpose is individual instruction, intercommunication and technical studies of radio technology.
ARTICLE 138.- A radio amateur is understood to be the person duly authorized who is interested in radio technology for exclusively personal and non-profit purposes.

ARTICLE 139.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall authorize for the installation and operation of radio amateur stations Venezuelan nationals, and foreigners resident in Venezuela or in transit in the national territory, provided that they comply with the requirements established in this Law, its regulations and other rules issued on the matter.

ARTICLE 140.- Radio amateur stations may only be operated in the territory of the Republic by persons previously authorized by the National Telecommunications Commission. The holder of an authorization must not: 1. Use his equipment for purposes other than those for which the authorization was granted;
ARTICLE 140.- The holder of an authorization must not: 2. Permit any person to operate his station without the corresponding authorization.
TITLE IX
OF HOMOLOGATION AND CERTIFICATION

ARTICLE 141.- Telecommunications equipment are subject to homologation and certification, with the aim of guaranteeing the integrity and quality of telecommunications networks, the radioelectric spectrum and the safety of users, operators and third parties. Imported equipment that have been homologated or certified by an entity or organization internationally recognized, at the discretion of the National Telecommunications Commission, shall not be required to be homologated or certified again in Venezuela. To that end, the National Telecommunications Commission shall keep a public register of national or foreign entities or organizations recommended for the certification and homologation of telecommunications equipment.

ARTICLE 142.- The National Telecommunications Commission, through the national or foreign certification entities it has recognized for such purposes, shall homologate and certify telecommunications equipment and devices manufactured or assembled in Venezuela.

ARTICLE 142.- The National Telecommunications Commission is the body responsible for supervising and requiring the homologation certificates or certification seals that telecommunications equipment must carry incorporated.

ARTICLE 143.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall issue the technical standards relating to the homologation of telecommunications equipment and devices, and shall approve and publish a list of homologated brands and models and the uses that may be given to them. Inclusion on this list implies the automatic fulfillment of the certification requirement, provided that the use is in accordance with that foreseen in the respective homologation.

ARTICLE 143.- Likewise, the National Telecommunications Commission may require the homologation of certain equipment or installations not specifically intended to provide telecommunications services, but which, by their nature, may cause interference to them.

ARTICLE 143.- In the cases referred to in this article, the list of homologated brands and models shall be permanently updated ex officio by the National Telecommunications Commission. Said body shall be obliged to pronounce on the homologation of equipment and devices within the term set by the regulation of this Law, which shall not exceed ninety days.

ARTICLE 144.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall set the amount of the fees applicable in the process of obtaining homologation, with the purpose of absorbing the costs of the tests that must be carried out in the verification tasks.
TITLE X
OF PRICES AND RATES

ARTICLE 145.- Telecommunications service providers shall set their prices freely, except with respect to services provided under a universal service obligation. In such cases, the respective operator shall immediately submit to the consideration of the National Telecommunications Commission its proposal for minimum and maximum tariffs, which shall come into force once approved by the Commission and published in the Official Gazette of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.

ARTICLE 145.- When there is a dominant position by one or more companies, derived from the existence of cartels, monopolies, oligopolies or other forms of market dominance, the National Telecommunications Commission may determine the minimum and maximum tariffs to which the companies shall be subject, having heard the recommendation made for this purpose by the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition, which shall remain in force until conditions exist that permit effective competition in that market. The determination of the existence of a dominant position referred to in this article, as well as the evaluation regarding the cessation of its effects in the market, corresponds to the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition.

ARTICLE 146.- Cross-subsidies between the different services provided by the same provider are prohibited, as well as subsidies between services provided through subsidiaries, affiliates or related companies. For the determination of linkage between companies, the National Telecommunications Commission shall follow the parameters established for that purpose by the Law to Promote and Protect the Exercise of Free Competition.
TITLE XI
OF TAXES, FEES AND CONTRIBUTIONS
CHAPTER I
OF TAXES

ARTICLE 147.- Those who provide sound broadcasting or open television services for profit shall pay the National Treasury a tax of one percent (1%) of their gross income derived from the exploitation of such services. Those who provide any other telecommunications service for profit shall pay the National Treasury a tax of two point three percent (2.3%) of their gross income derived from the exploitation of such services.

ARTICLE 147.- This tax shall be settled and paid quarterly, within the first fifteen continuous days following each quarter of the calendar year and shall be calculated on the basis of the gross income corresponding to the previous quarter.
CHAPTER II
OF SPECIAL FEES AND CONTRIBUTIONS

ARTICLE 148.- Those who provide telecommunications services for profit shall pay the National Telecommunications Commission a special contribution of one-half percent (0.50%) of gross income derived from the exploitation of that activity, which shall form part of the Commission's own revenues for its operation.

ARTICLE 148.- This special contribution shall be settled and paid quarterly, within the first fifteen continuous days following each quarter of the calendar year and shall be calculated on the basis of the gross income corresponding to the previous quarter.

ARTICLE 149.- Those who exploit or use the radioelectric spectrum shall pay annually to the National Telecommunications Commission a fee for its administration and control, which shall not exceed one-half percent (0.5%) of their gross income. In the case of sound broadcasting and open television services, this percentage shall not exceed zero point two percent (0.2%) of their gross income derived from the exploitation of such services.
ARTICLE 149.- This fee shall be settled and paid annually, within the first forty-five continuous days of the calendar year.

ARTICLE 149.- The Regulation of this Law shall define the model for the calculation of said fee, based on the following criteria: assigned frequencies and bandwidth, extent of the geographic area covered and population existing in it, time for which the concession has been granted and mode of use.

ARTICLE 149.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall remit to the National Treasury fifty percent (50%) of the amount resulting from this concept and the rest shall form part of the Commission's own revenues.

ARTICLE 150.- The central and functionally decentralized bodies and entities of the Republic's administration, of the states and of the municipalities shall be exempt from the payment of the tax established in the preceding article, in the following cases: 1. When they make use of frequencies reserved for official uses, according to the National Table of Frequency Band Allocation (CUNABAF); or,
ARTICLE 150.- 2. When such activities are carried out to meet their communication needs, without providing services to third parties.
ARTICLE 151.- Those who provide telecommunications services for profit shall contribute to the Universal Service Fund one percent (1%) of their gross income.
ARTICLE 151.- Providers of sound broadcasting services or open television are exempt from this obligation only with respect to the gross income they obtain from such activities.

ARTICLE 151.- This contribution shall be settled and paid quarterly, within the first fifteen continuous days following each quarter of the calendar year and shall be calculated on the basis of the gross income corresponding to the previous quarter.
ARTICLE 152.- Those who provide telecommunications services shall contribute to the Telecommunications Research and Development Fund one-half percent (0.50%) of their gross income.
ARTICLE 152.- Providers of sound broadcasting services or open television are exempt from this obligation only with respect to the gross income they obtain from such activities.

ARTICLE 152.- This contribution shall be settled and paid quarterly, within the first fifteen continuous days following each quarter of the calendar year and shall be calculated on the basis of the gross income corresponding to the previous quarter.

ARTICLE 153.- Procedures provided for in this Law relating to applications for granting, renewal, incorporation of attributes, substitution, modification or transfer of administrative authorizations or concessions, authorizations, equipment homologation, mandatory technical inspections and geographic or non-geographic numbers shall cause the payment of fees for an amount that may not exceed four thousand Tax Units (4,000 T.U.) nor be less than one hundred Tax Units (100 T.U.).
ARTICLE 153.- The regulation of this Law shall discriminate the amount of the fees applicable for each of the aspects listed, within the limits established in this article.
CHAPTER III
COMMON PROVISIONS

ARTICLE 154.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall exercise the powers and duties that the Organic Tax Code attributes to the Tax Administration, in relation to the taxes established in this Law. Likewise, the Ministry of Science and Technology shall exercise the powers and duties referred to in this article with respect to the contributions corresponding to the Research and Development Fund provided for in this Law.

ARTICLE 155.- It shall be understood that gross income has been generated in the following situations: 1. On the date of billing of the users or contractors of the services; 2. When the operator receives in advance the consideration for a service that it commits to provide.

ARTICLE 155.- Sole Paragraph: For the purposes of this Title, amounts paid by telecommunications operators on account of interconnection shall not form part of the amount of gross income generated. Likewise, the income of telecommunications operators derived from dividends, sale of assets and financial income shall not form part of gross income.

ARTICLE 155.- In the case of sound broadcasting and open television, amounts derived from the sale of artistic productions, such as soap operas, radio novels and documentaries, shall also not form part of gross income.
ARTICLE 156.- In accordance with the Constitution of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, the telecommunications activity shall not be subject to the payment of state or municipal taxes.
ARTICLE 157.- The taxes, fees and special contributions established in this Law shall be subject to the self-assessment modality in accordance with what is established by regulation.

ARTICLE 158.- Amateur radio services are excluded from the taxes established in this Law. They shall only pay a fee equivalent to one (1) Tax Unit for the granting or renewal of their respective administrative authorizations.

ARTICLE 158.- The President of the Republic, in Council of Ministers, may totally or partially exempt border broadcasters, sound broadcasting and open television community public service non-profit stations, which have such condition according to the respective regulation, from payment of the taxes established in this Law. Likewise, he may exempt states and municipalities or their functionally decentralized entities that carry out non-profit telecommunications activities with social interest from the payment of such taxes.
TITLE XII
SANCTIONING REGIME
CHAPTER I
GENERAL PROVISIONS

ARTICLE 159.- The sanctions that may be imposed for the infringements and crimes typified in this Law are: 1. Public reprimand; 2. Fine; 3. Revocation of the administrative authorization or concession; 4. Cessation of clandestine activities; 5. Disqualification; 6. Confiscation of equipment and materials used for the performance of the activity; 7. Imprisonment. The sanctions referred to in this article shall be applied in the manner and assumptions determined in the following articles.

ARTICLE 160.- In determining liability arising from the commission of acts or omissions that infringe the provisions of this Law, the provisions relating to the concurrence of several persons in the same punishable act provided for in the Penal Code shall be applicable.
ARTICLE 161.- Liability arising from non-compliance with this Law is independent of the civil liability that such acts may generate.

ARTICLE 162.- Violations of this Law in the area of consumer and user protection and education, as well as those relating to the promotion and protection of free competition, shall be sanctioned by the authorities competent in those areas, in accordance with the legal norms governing such matters. The National Telecommunications Commission shall inform said authorities of the existence of facts in the area of telecommunications whose knowledge might fall within their competence.

ARTICLE 163.- Without prejudice to the personal liability that officials may incur, the administrative power to impose the sanctions provided for in this Law prescribes in a term of five years, counted from the day on which the National Telecommunications Commission became aware of the facts, by any means. The execution of the administrative sanctions provided for in this Law prescribes in three years counted from the moment in which they became definitively final.
CHAPTER II
ADMINISTRATIVE SANCTIONS
Section One
Of administrative infractions and their sanctions

ARTICLE 164.- It shall be sanctioned with a fine of up to five thousand Tax Units (5000 T.U.), in accordance with what the Regulation of this Law provides: 1. Failure to notify the National Telecommunications Commission by an operator about the total or partial interruption of a telecommunications service, in the cases, form and terms established in this Law.
ARTICLE 164.- 2. Unjustified delay in delivering the information required by the National Telecommunications Commission, in accordance with this Law.
ARTICLE 164.- 3. The use of service contracts whose basic models have not been approved by the National Telecommunications Commission.

ARTICLE 164.- 4. Modifying or concealing brands, labels or identification signs of telecommunications equipment, when this hinders the inspection and supervision tasks of the National Telecommunications Commission.
ARTICLE 164.- 5. Failure to attend the summons made by the National Telecommunications Commission, when said body is to carry out mediation actions in accordance with legal or regulatory provisions.

ARTICLE 165.- It shall be sanctioned with a fine of up to thirty thousand Tax Units (30,000 T.U.), in accordance with what the Regulation of this Law provides: 1. Causing harmful interference to telecommunications services, negligently;

ARTICLE 165.- 2. Performing interconnection on terms or conditions different from those established in the corresponding agreement or those established in the interconnection order that the National Telecommunications Commission may issue, in the cases provided in this Law;
ARTICLE 165.- 3. Lack of contingency plans by telecommunications service operators, or failure to timely update them;

ARTICLE 165.- 4. The refusal to allow duly authorized and identified officials of the National Telecommunications Commission access to the facilities, equipment or documentation that it is entitled to inspect or audit under this Law;

ARTICLE 165.- 5. Supplying the National Telecommunications Commission with inaccurate or incomplete information about aspects that it has specifically requested, for the benefit of oneself or a third party;

ARTICLE 165.- 6. The issuance or transmission of false or misleading identification signals by an operator, which may mislead users or the National Telecommunications Commission regarding the authorship of such emissions or transmissions;

ARTICLE 165.- 7. Failure to comply with the general conditions established in this Law, relating to administrative authorizations or concessions, not sanctioned by a special provision contained in this title;
ARTICLE 165.- 8. Overbilling of amounts actually owed, carried out negligently.

ARTICLE 166.- It shall be sanctioned with a fine of up to fifty thousand Tax Units (50,000 T.U.), in accordance with what the Regulation of this Law provides: 1. The installation, operation and exploitation of telecommunications services or the use of spectrum frequencies that require administrative authorization or concession, without having them;
ARTICLE 166.- 2. Causing harmful interference to telecommunications services, willfully;
ARTICLE 166.- 3. Causing the total or partial interruption of a legally established telecommunications service;

ARTICLE 166.- 4. Failure to attend to the requirements of the National Telecommunications Commission, within the term and conditions determined by it, relating to the cessation of radioelectric emissions that produce harmful interference;
ARTICLE 166.- 5. Increasing the price of telecommunications services and facilities provided without having published them in accordance with the provisions of this Law;

ARTICLE 166.- 6. The abstention of an operator to immediately comply with the order of the National Telecommunications Commission to allow interconnection with the networks of another operator, on the specific terms and conditions it establishes for that purpose, in the cases provided in this Law;
ARTICLE 166.- 7. The abstention of an operator to timely comply with orders of requisition and mobilization in contingency situations;
ARTICLE 166.- 8. Failure to adopt the systems of separate and detailed accounting by services that the National Telecommunications Commission establishes;
ARTICLE 166.- 9. Overbilling of amounts actually owed, carried out willfully;
ARTICLE 166.- 10. The abstention or refusal to provide documents or information required by the National Telecommunications Commission, in accordance with this Law.
ARTICLE 167.- The operation of radio amateur equipment without the corresponding administrative authorization shall be sanctioned with a fine of up to one hundred Tax Units (100 T.U.).

ARTICLE 168.- For the purposes of determining by the National Telecommunications Commission the amount of fines referred to in this Law, the following are considered aggravating situations: 1. Their continuous character; 2. The affecting of the service; 3. The obtaining of economic benefits by the offender; 4. Clandestinity; 5. The lack of homologation or certification of the devices or equipment used.

ARTICLE 169.- For the purposes of imposing the fines referred to in this Law, the following are considered mitigating situations: 1. Having acknowledged the existence of the infringement during the procedure; 2. Having remedied the infringement situation on one's own initiative and fully compensated the damages that may have been caused.

ARTICLE 170.- In case of recurrence in the violations or non-compliances provided for in this Chapter, the National Telecommunications Commission shall impose fines increased successively by twenty-five percent (25%) up to the maximum limit provided for the type, without prejudice to the revocation of the corresponding administrative authorization or concession.

ARTICLE 171.- Without prejudice to the fines to be applied in accordance with the provisions of this Law, the following shall be sanctioned with revocation of the administrative authorization or concession, as the case may be: 1. The recipient of a Universal Service obligation who fails to comply with the provisions, activities and burdens derived therefrom;
ARTICLE 171.- 2. The one who fails to comply with the quality, coverage and efficiency parameters determined by the National Telecommunications Commission;
ARTICLE 171.- 3. The one who does not make effective use of the portion of the radioelectric spectrum that had been assigned to him, under the terms and conditions established for that purpose;
ARTICLE 171.- 4. The one who disregards an extremely provisional or precautionary measure issued by the National Telecommunications Commission, in accordance with the provisions of this Law;
ARTICLE 171.- 5. The one who causes interference to telecommunications services willfully;
ARTICLE 171.- 6. The one who uses or allows the use of the telecommunications services for which he is authorized as means to aid in the commission of crimes;
ARTICLE 171.- 7. The one who willfully supplies information to the National Telecommunications Commission based on documents declared false by a final judgment;
ARTICLE 171.- 8. The one who fails to obtain the approval of the National Telecommunications Commission in the operations referred to in article 195 of this Law;
ARTICLE 171.- 9. The one who evades payment of the taxes provided for in this Law;
ARTICLE 171.- 10. Repetition within one year of an infringement referred to in this Section counted from the moment in which the previous sanction becomes definitively final.
ARTICLE 171.- 11. The revocation of the concession of the radioelectric spectrum shall imply the revocation of the corresponding administrative authorization and vice versa.

ARTICLE 172.- The revocation of the administrative authorization or concession to natural or legal persons shall entail their disqualification for a period of five years from obtaining another, directly or indirectly. Said period shall be counted from the moment in which the administrative act becomes definitively final.

ARTICLE 172.- In the case of legal entities, the disqualification shall extend to the administrators or other bodies responsible for the management and direction of the sanctioned operator who were in office during the time of the infringement, provided that they had knowledge of the situation that generated the revocation and did not notify it in writing to the National Telecommunications Commission, prior to the opening of the sanctioning procedure.

ARTICLE 172.- Violations of the disqualifications and incompatibilities established in this Law shall entail for the natural persons responsible for such transgression a special disqualification to participate in the capital, be administrators or directors of telecommunications companies, directly or indirectly, for a period of five years.

ARTICLE 173.- Without prejudice to the fines to be applied in accordance with the provisions of this Law, the confiscation of the equipment and materials used in the installation, operation, provision or exploitation of said services or activities shall be sanctioned to whoever: 1. Makes clandestine use of the radioelectric spectrum; 2. Reoffends in the installation, operation, provision or exploitation of networks or telecommunications services without possessing the respective authorization; 3. Does not comply with the decision of the National Telecommunications Commission arising from the revocation of an administrative authorization or concession, as the case may be.

ARTICLE 174.- Public reprimand shall proceed as an accessory sanction in cases where the infringement has affected the provision of the service of another telecommunications operator. The act of reprimand shall be published at the expense of the offender in two of the newspapers with the greatest national circulation, leaving record of the impact that his conduct has produced on the provision of the services of another operator.
ARTICLE 175.- In the case established in numeral 3 of article 189 of this Law, the National Telecommunications Commission shall order the offender to cease his clandestine activities.
Section Two
On the sanctioning procedure
ARTICLE 176.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall exercise its sanctioning power adhering to the principles of legality, impartiality, rationality and proportionality.
ARTICLE 177.- The procedures for determining the infringements referred to in this Title shall be initiated by complaint, ex officio, or by initiative of the National Telecommunications Commission.

ARTICLE 178.- In the event that a factual situation comprises a set of acts allegedly constitutive of different infringements committed by one or more subjects, the National Telecommunications Commission for reasons of merit or opportunity may initiate a sanctioning procedure for each of the alleged infringements and subjects, or accumulate them.

ARTICLE 179.- The act of opening the sanctioning procedure shall be issued by the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission, after hearing the opinion of the Legal Counsel of the body, and shall clearly establish the facts imputed and the consequences that could arise from their verification, summonsing the alleged offender so that within a period not exceeding fifteen business days he may submit the allegations and evidence he deems pertinent for his defense.

ARTICLE 179.- If in the course of the investigation it is determined that the same imputed facts could give rise to sanctions different from those established in the opening act, such circumstance shall be notified to the alleged offender, granting him a period not exceeding fifteen business days to submit allegations and evidence.

ARTICLE 179.- If facts unrelated to the ongoing procedure appear, but which could constitute infringements of this Law, the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission shall order the opening of another sanctioning procedure.

ARTICLE 180.- Once the opening of the procedure has been ordered, the Legal Consultancy shall carry out all the necessary actions for the substantiation of the same, except deciding on the application of the extremely provisional or precautionary measures provided in this Law, which shall correspond to the Director General. The substantiation of the file must be concluded within thirty continuous days following the opening order, but may be extended for up to ten days when the complexity of the matter so requires.

ARTICLE 181.- In the substantiation of the administrative sanctioning procedure the National Telecommunications Commission shall have the broadest investigative powers, its activity being governed by the principle of freedom of evidence. Within the substantiation activity the National Telecommunications Commission may carry out, among others, the following acts: 1. Summon any person to testify in relation to the alleged infringement.
ARTICLE 181.- 2. Require persons related to the procedure to provide documents or information pertinent to clarifying the facts.

ARTICLE 181.- 3. Summon, through the national or regional press, any interested person who could provide information related to the alleged infringement. In the course of the investigation any private person may submit to the administrative file the documents he deems pertinent for the clarification of the situation.

ARTICLE 181.- 4. Request from other public agencies relevant information regarding the persons involved, provided that the information they have has not been declared confidential or secret in accordance with the law.
ARTICLE 181.- 5. Carry out the inspections it deems pertinent for the purposes of the investigation.
ARTICLE 181.- 6. Gather the necessary evidence to clarify the facts subject to the sanctioning procedure.

ARTICLE 182.- In the course of administrative sanctioning procedures the National Telecommunications Commission may issue precautionary measures referred to in this Section, for which purpose it must carry out a balancing between the serious damages that operators and users affected by the conduct of the alleged offender could suffer, and the damages that the adoption of such measure would imply for him, all in view of the presumption of good right that would emerge from the situation.

ARTICLE 183.- The precautionary measures that the National Telecommunications Commission may adopt, attending to the parameters established in the previous article, may consist of: 1. Ordering the immediate suspension, total or partial of the activities allegedly infringing this Law; 2. Ordering the performance of acts or actions in matters of Universal Service, interconnection, right of way, restoration of services, billing of services, security and defense; 3. Proceeding to the seizure of the equipment employed and closure of the premises or establishments where operation takes place, when dealing with allegedly clandestine activities that imply the use of the radioelectric spectrum.

ARTICLE 183.- Sole Paragraph: The measures referred to in this article may be issued by the National Telecommunications Commission, with an extremely provisional character, in the act of opening the administrative sanctioning procedure without complying with the extremes referred to in article 182 of this Law, when reasons of urgency so warrant. Once the extremely provisional measure is executed, the National Telecommunications Commission shall pronounce on its precautionary character, confirming, modifying or revoking the adopted measure, in accordance with the provisions of articles 182 and following of this Law.

ARTICLE 183.- When the offender is charged with the exploitation or provision of a service without the corresponding administrative authorization or concession, the extremely provisional measures may be agreed in the opening order of the procedure.

ARTICLE 184.- Once a precautionary measure has been agreed, the party against whom it is directed or any interested party may oppose it within five business days following the notification of the same to the party against whom the measure is directed. In case of opposition, an evidentiary stage of eight business days shall be opened, in which the parties and interested parties may present their evidence and allegations. Upon expiration of that period, the National Telecommunications Commission shall decide what is appropriate within the following three business days.

ARTICLE 184.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall revoke the precautionary measure it had issued when it deems that its effects are not justified. In any case, the precautionary measures that had been issued shall cease to have effect as such when the decision that ends the sanctioning procedure is issued or the period established for the definitive decision expires without it having been produced.

ARTICLE 185.- Once the substantiation of the file is concluded or the period for it has expired, it shall be forwarded to the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission who, without prejudice to being able to order the performance of any additional act of substantiation that he deems convenient, must issue the corresponding decision within fifteen continuous days following its receipt. This period may be extended by reasoned order for up to fifteen continuous days when the complexity of the case so warrants.

ARTICLE 186.- In the decision of the Director General the existence or not of infringements shall be determined and, if affirmative, the corresponding sanctions shall be established, as well as the corrective measures that may be appropriate, except in cases of revocation, whose decision corresponds to the Board of Directors or to the Minister of Infrastructure in accordance with this Law.

ARTICLE 187.- The person sanctioned by the decision of the National Telecommunications Commission must voluntarily execute what is provided in the respective act within the period set by said provision. In case the private party does not voluntarily execute the decision of the National Telecommunications Commission, it may execute it forcibly in accordance with the provisions of the Organic Law of Administrative Procedures, unless by express legal decision it must be entrusted to a judicial authority.
CHAPTER III
PENAL SANCTIONS

ARTICLE 188.- Whoever through gross negligence causes damage to terminal equipment intended for public access, installations or telecommunications systems, so as to partially interrupt or prevent the provision of the service, shall be punished with imprisonment of four to twelve months.

ARTICLE 188.- Whoever through gross negligence produces harmful interference that partially interrupts or prevents the provision of the service shall be punished with imprisonment of four to twelve months.
ARTICLE 188.- Whoever uses or enjoys a telecommunications service or facility fraudulently shall be punished with imprisonment of four to twelve months.

ARTICLE 189.- Whoever intentionally causes damage to terminal equipment, installations or telecommunications systems, so as to partially or totally interrupt the provision of the service, shall be punished with imprisonment of one to four years.

ARTICLE 189.- Whoever, using equipment or technologies of any kind, provides a third party with fraudulent or improper access to or enjoyment of a telecommunications service or facility shall be punished with imprisonment of one to four years.

ARTICLE 189.- Whoever clandestinely uses the radioelectric spectrum shall be punished with imprisonment of one to four years. It shall be understood that there is clandestine use of the radioelectric spectrum when, in cases where a concession is required, at least the corresponding frequency reservation does not exist.
ARTICLE 189.- Whoever produces harmful interference with the specific purpose of generating the interruption of a telecommunications service shall be punished with imprisonment of one to four years.

ARTICLE 190.- The illegal interception, interference, copying or disclosure of the content of transmissions and communications shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of the special law on the matter.
TITLE XIII
FINAL AND TRANSITORY PROVISIONS
CHAPTER I
FINAL PROVISIONS

ARTICLE 191.- No natural or legal person or group of persons may, either directly or through an intermediary, obtain in concession or come to control more than one broadcasting or open television station in the same frequency band per locality. The same restriction applies in relation to the shareholders of a concessionary company.
ARTICLE 191.- By regulation other restrictions may be established to guarantee plurality and democratization in the distribution and use of such resources.

ARTICLE 191.- In any case, the State may reserve for itself frequencies in each of the sound broadcasting and open television bands included in the National Table of Frequency Band Allocation (CUNABAF).

ARTICLE 192.- Without prejudice to legal provisions on security and defense, the President of the Republic may, directly or through the National Telecommunications Commission, order operators that provide subscription television services, through their customer information channel and broadcasting sound and open television companies, the free transmission of official messages or addresses from the Presidency or Vice Presidency of the Republic or from the Ministers. By regulation the modalities, limitations and other characteristics of such emissions and transmissions shall be determined.
ARTICLE 192.- Publicity by public entities shall not be subject to the obligation established in this article.

ARTICLE 193.- The establishment and development of telecommunications networks by the State or by private parties is declared of public and social utility, in accordance with the plans developed by the National Executive.
ARTICLE 194.- Operators who, in accordance with this Law, have Universal Service obligations may benefit from expropriation and the establishment of easements.
ARTICLE 194.- The President of the Republic may order the expropriation of the goods necessary for such purposes, in benefit of and at the expense of the interested operator.

ARTICLE 194.- Likewise, the National Telecommunications Commission may order the constitution of the administrative easements necessary for the benefit of the same operators and at their cost. In either of the cases mentioned, if there is no agreement for the determination of the amount of the compensation to which there is place, the procedure established for expropriation processes for reasons of public or social utility in the Expropriation Law shall be followed.

ARTICLE 195.- The subscription of a merger agreement between telecommunications operating companies, the total or partial acquisition of these companies by other operating companies, as well as their spin-off, transformation or the creation of subsidiaries that exploit telecommunications services, when they imply a change in control thereof, must be submitted to the approval of the National Telecommunications Commission for such operations to acquire effectiveness. For such purposes, the interested parties shall send to the National Telecommunications Commission a copy of the corresponding documents within ten days following the realization of the operation.

ARTICLE 195.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall only approve the operations referred to in this article when there is a favorable opinion from the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition.

ARTICLE 195.- The administrative act by which the realization of the operation is not approved must state clearly its grounds and, if applicable, make the pertinent recommendations. The act of rejection shall definitively prevent the execution of the operation in the scheduled manner, unless the interested parties accept the observations or recommendations made by the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition, or the administrative act of rejection is annulled by a definitively final decision.

ARTICLE 196.- Whoever requests from the National Telecommunications Commission the incorporation as concrete attributes of his administrative authorization of certain services to offer them to the public must state in the respective project, under oath, whether any company related to him provides the same or similar service or services. In such cases, the National Telecommunications Commission shall request the opinion of the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition on the effects that granting the requested attribute could have on the market, after hearing the interested parties.
ARTICLE 196.- In this regard, the condition of related companies shall be taken into account in accordance with the provisions of the Law to Promote and Protect the Exercise of Free Competition.

ARTICLE 196.- Without prejudice to its other powers, the National Telecommunications Commission shall refrain from approving the respective project if the opinion of the Superintendent is unfavorable.

ARTICLE 197.- Telecommunications operators may rent circuits or resell capacity on their systems, provided they do so in transparent terms and on non-discriminatory conditions that do not harm free competition. In no case may the operations referred to in this article be carried out to the detriment of service quality or user rights.

ARTICLE 198.- Telecommunications operators may constitute subsidiaries to provide, through them, one or several services for which they have obtained the corresponding administrative authorization or concession. In any case, this management modality must be notified to the National Telecommunications Commission and control of management and responsibility over the subsidiaries must be maintained at all times. Likewise, telecommunications operators may cede to their subsidiaries part of the attributes of the administrative authorizations or concessions of which they are holders, with prior authorization of the National Telecommunications Commission.

ARTICLE 198.- By regulation the need may be established for certain telecommunications services to be provided through subsidiaries or subject to the control of the holder of the administrative authorization or concession.

ARTICLE 199.- States and municipalities shall seek in their respective territorial scopes the promotion, harmonious development and provision of suitable general telecommunications pathways, in accordance with the guidelines established by the National Executive through the Ministry of Infrastructure.

ARTICLE 199.- States and municipalities may receive the revenues derived from the leasing of telecommunications ducts that they build or that are ceded to them, provided that non-discriminatory treatment and freedom of access to operators are guaranteed.

ARTICLE 200.- The State shall promote the existence of community public service, non-profit sound broadcasting and open television stations, as means for the plural and transparent communication and action of organized communities in their respective scope. Their regime, ordering, characteristics, requirements and limitations shall be determined by regulation, in accordance with the National Telecommunications Plan and the National Table of Frequency Band Allocation (CUNABAF).

ARTICLE 201.- The State shall promote the existence of non-governmental organizations defending the rights of telecommunications service users, which shall seek to coordinate their action with the Ombudsman's Office.

ARTICLE 202.- The State, through the National Telecommunications Commission, shall promote the use and updating of technological innovations in all their modalities, with the purpose that permanent technological modernization plans in the field of telecommunications are established.

ARTICLE 203.- The regulations of this Law may provide for the obligation that telecommunications operators separate their accounting by services, in order to guarantee transparency in their operations and allow effective control by the National Telecommunications Commission and by the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition, in accordance with the rules established for that purpose.

ARTICLE 204.- The Organic Law of Administrative Procedures shall apply subsidiarily to the procedures instructed by the National Telecommunications Commission. Decisions adopted by the Board of Directors and the Director General of the National Telecommunications Commission shall be directly appealable to the Minister of Infrastructure or to the Political-Administrative Chamber of the Supreme Court of Justice, at the option of the interested party. In the first case, the appeal must be exercised within fifteen business days following the date of notification of the act and may not be appealed to the Political-Administrative Chamber until the corresponding decision has been adopted, or the period to decide it has expired without any pronouncement in that regard.

ARTICLE 205.- The filing of contentious-administrative actions against fines imposed by the National Telecommunications Commission shall suspend their execution when so expressly requested by the plaintiff in his appeal. Notwithstanding the foregoing the National Telecommunications Commission may make use of the precautionary measures referred to in the Civil Procedure Code in matters of tax credits.
ARTICLE 206.- The Political-Administrative Chamber of the Supreme Court of Justice shall be competent to hear appeals of interpretation regarding the meaning and scope of the provisions of this Law.
ARTICLE 207.- Except as provided in article 208 of this law, existing legal and regulatory provisions are repealed insofar as they are contrary to the provisions of this Law.
CHAPTER II
TRANSITORY PROVISIONS

ARTICLE 208.- Until the law that regulates the content of transmissions and communications routed through the different means of telecommunication is enacted, the National Executive, by regulation, may continue to establish the regulations it deems necessary. All legal and regulatory provisions and any other normative instrument that regulate, limit or restrict the content of such transmissions or communications shall remain in force, unless otherwise provided by the National Assembly or the National Executive, as the case may be, and especially those contained in: 1. Decree No. 2427 of February 1, 1984, which establishes the Radiocommunications Regulation, published in Official Gazette No. 3,336 of February 1, 1984.
ARTICLE 208.- 2. Resolution No. 703, dated March 6, 1969 published in Official Gazette No. 28,883, dated March 23, 1969, which regulates contest programs.
ARTICLE 208.- 3. Decree No. 1200 of September 11, 1981, published in Official Gazette No. 32,310 of the same date, by which the transmission of advertising for alcoholic beverages is prohibited.

ARTICLE 208.- 4. Decree No. 598 of December 3, 1974, published in Official Gazette No. 30,569, dated January 9, 1975, referring to the obligation of sound broadcasting stations to include in their daily musical programming at least fifty percent (50%) Venezuelan music in its different manifestations: folkloric, typical or popular.
ARTICLE 208.- 5. Regulation on the Operation of Sound Broadcasting Stations issued by Decree No. 2771 of January 21, 1993, published in Official Gazette Ext. 4530 of February 10, 1993.

ARTICLE 208.- 6. Decree No. 996 of March 19, 1981, published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Venezuela No. 32,192, dated March 20, 1981, referring to the prohibition of the transmission of direct or indirect advertising of cigarettes and tobacco manufacturing.

ARTICLE 208.- 7. Decree No. 849 of November 21, 1980, published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Venezuela No. 32,116, of November 21, 1980, referring to the prohibition of transmission of advertising of cigarettes and other products derived from tobacco manufacturing through audiovisual broadcasting stations.

ARTICLE 208.- 8. Partial Regulation on Television Transmissions published by Decree No. 2,625 of November 5, 1992, published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Venezuela No. 35,996, of November 20, 1992.
ARTICLE 208.- 9. Decree No. 525 of January 12, 1959, which establishes the General Food Regulation published in Official Gazette No. 25,864 of January 16, 1959.

ARTICLE 208.- 10. The provisions provided regarding the content of transmissions and communications routed through the different means of telecommunications, established in the Organic Law of Education, Organic Law on Narcotic and Psychotropic Substances, Organic Law for the Protection of Children and Adolescents, Law of Defense Against Venereal Diseases, and in the Organic Law of Suffrage and Political Participation.

ARTICLE 208.- Sole Paragraph: Until the law regulating the content of transmissions and communications routed through the different means of telecommunication is enacted, the National Telecommunications Commission shall continue to be responsible for ensuring faithful compliance with the regulation referred to in this article and that issued by the National Executive in this matter.

ARTICLE 209.- Until the corresponding law is enacted, the National Executive may, when it deems convenient to the interests of the Nation, or when required by public order or security, suspend the transmission of communications routed through the different means of telecommunications, all in accordance with the Constitution of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.

ARTICLE 210.- The National Telecommunications Commission shall establish, by resolution, special schedules for the transformation of the current concessions and permits granted in accordance with previous legislation, into the administrative authorizations, concessions or obligations of notification or registers established in this Law. While such adaptation occurs, all rights and obligations acquired under the previous legislation shall remain in full force, under the same terms and conditions established in the respective concessions and permits.

ARTICLE 210.- The transformation of the legal titles must be carried out within two years following the publication of this Law in the Official Gazette, shall be mandatory and shall be carried out in accordance with the following principles: 1. Transparency, good faith, equality and promptness.
ARTICLE 210.- 2. The rights of use and exploitation given in concession over legally granted frequencies shall remain in full force.
ARTICLE 210.- 3. It shall not imply the granting of more powers for the provision of public services than those that operators currently have in accordance with their respective legal titles.

ARTICLE 210.- 4. The object, coverage and term of validity of the concessions or permits in force at the time of the entry into force of this Law shall be respected. Subsequent renewals of the administrative authorizations or concessions provided for in this Law shall be governed by the general rules contained herein.

ARTICLE 210.- 5. Operators who currently have obligations relating to quality, development, expansion and maintenance goals of their networks, in accordance with their respective concession contracts, shall comply with the same.
ARTICLE 210.- 6. Only limitations compatible with the principles of this Law and the development made of them by the respective regulations shall be established.

ARTICLE 210.- 7. The transformation of the legal title referred to in this article must be requested by the interested party within the term established for that purpose by the National Telecommunications Commission, which may not be less than sixty (60) business days. Once the period referred to in this numeral has expired, the National Telecommunications Commission shall publish in at least one national circulation newspaper the list of concessionaires that have not responded to the call for transformation of the titles, granting them an additional period of five (5) business days for such purposes, under the warning that, if they do not make the corresponding request, it shall be understood as a waiver of the concessions or permits previously obtained before the publication of this Law in the Official Gazette.

ARTICLE 210.- 8. The transformation of the current titles in no way implies that telecommunications operators existing before the entry into force of this Law are subject to the general procedure established for the granting of administrative authorizations or to the extinction, revocation or suspension of concessions or permits granted under the previous legislation, on that account.

ARTICLE 211.- The National Executive, through the Regulation for the Opening of the Basic Telephony Service, shall determine the model, conditions, limitations, requirements and any other necessary aspect to obtain the conditions it deems convenient for the opening of the Basic Telephony service, for which purpose it may establish asymmetric regulations. In any case, it is established that for the protection of the general interest the National Executive shall proceed to do everything necessary so that, from the day following the cessation of the limited concurrence privilege existing at present, operators who have complied with the requirements established by the Regulation for the Opening of the Basic Telephony Service may provide said service to the public.

ARTICLE 212.- Concessionaires existing prior to the entry into force of this Law shall comply with the coverage, penetration and service quality goals established in their respective concessions, under penalty of the application of the sanctions currently established in the respective contracts. Said goals and sanctions shall form part of their administrative authorizations until they are satisfied.
ARTICLE 212.- The obligations provided in this article may not be covered with resources from the Universal Service Fund.

ARTICLE 213.- The provisions of Title IX of this Law shall enter into force as of January 1, 2001. In any case, compliance with such provisions shall not be enforceable for telecommunications equipment and devices acquired, installed or in operation before the entry into force of this Law.

ARTICLE 214.- In order to analyze the evolution and behavior of telecommunications markets after the entry into force of this Law, and without prejudice to adjusting them to new realities when convenient, the existing tariff mechanisms shall remain in force within the year following the publication of this Law in the Official Gazette of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.

ARTICLE 214.- Exempted from this time limit are the special provisions established in the Basic Telephony Service Opening Regulation that deal with the tariff regime, which shall apply with preference to the period provided in this article and shall remain in force until effective competition is produced in the relevant market, as determined by the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition.

ARTICLE 214.- The National Telecommunications Commission and the Superintendent for the Promotion and Protection of Free Competition shall sign an Inter-administrative Agreement establishing mechanisms to monitor and follow the behavior of the telecommunications market.

ARTICLE 215.- The tax regime provided in Title XI of this Law shall enter into force as of January 1, 2001. From that date the Stamp Tax Law shall be repealed insofar as it provides for fees in telecommunications matters.

ARTICLE 216.- The special contribution provided for in article 148 of this Law shall be applied progressively to broadcasting and open television operators as follows: Year 2001: 0.1% Year 2002: 0.2% Year 2003: 0.3% Year 2004: 0.4% From the year 2005: 0.5%.

ARTICLE 217.- Without prejudice to the provisions of Title XI of this Law, companies that exploit cellular mobile telephony services shall pay until 2005 an additional special tax, calculated on the amount of their annual gross income derived from such activity, the rate of which shall be settled and paid annually and shall decrease as follows: Year 2001: 4.5% Year 2002: 3.5% Year 2003: 2.5% Year 2004: 1.5% Year 2005: 0.5%.

ARTICLE 217.- Amounts paid by current cellular mobile telephony operators at the time the Republic granted them the corresponding concessions, as initial payment of the contractual concession right, may in no case be imputed or offset against the taxes established in this Law, nor do they generate rights to compensation at the expense of the Republic.

ARTICLE 218.- Concessionaires existing prior to the publication of this Law in the Official Gazette shall adopt the necessary mechanisms to adapt their signaling systems to the Common Channel Signaling No. 7 system, in order to guarantee network interoperability and provision of new services, within a period not exceeding eighteen (18) months counted from the entry into force of this Law.

ARTICLE 218.- This adaptation of signaling systems has the condition of a technical requirement, which must be complied with obligatorily and shall be implemented in accordance with the criteria that the National Telecommunications Commission progressively establishes for that purpose.

ARTICLE 219.- Concessionaires existing prior to the publication of this Law in the Official Gazette shall adopt the necessary mechanisms to adapt their networks and systems in order to comply with the numbering conservation obligation provided for in article 117, within a period not exceeding three years counted from its entry into force.

ARTICLE 220.- Concessionaires existing prior to the publication of this Law in the Official Gazette shall adopt the necessary mechanisms to adapt their networks and systems in order to comply with the obligation provided for in article 118, in accordance with what the Basic Telephony Service Opening Regulation provides.

ARTICLE 221.- The current basic telephony operator may only provide subscription television service from November 28, 2000. Between November 28, 2000 and November 28, 2002, the current basic telephony concessionaire may provide the subscription television service, provided that it concurrently complies with the following conditions: 1. That it has acquired the corresponding attribute; 2. That it guarantees, to the satisfaction of the National Telecommunications Commission, access of subscription television operators to the ducts, manholes and other necessary elements for the placement of cables that are under its control or possession by any title.

ARTICLE 221.- Sole Paragraph: To provide the mentioned service in areas of the country where there are no subscription television cable operators, the current basic telephony operator must demonstrate to the National Telecommunications Commission that it has publicly made available to other subscription television cable operators access to the ducts, manholes and other necessary elements for the placement of cables that are under its control or possession by any title.
