579. Provided that nothing contained in this section shall apply if: (b) The Election Commission, in consultation with the Government, certifies that it is difficult to hold the bye-election within the said period.
580. A member elected to fill a casual vacancy shall only serve for the remainder of his/her predecessor's term of office.

Inherent Powers
581. The Supreme Court shall have the power to award reasonable penalty where a particular offence is not covered or is only partially covered by this or any bylaw made under this Act, and is not otherwise excluded from adjudication.

Amendment
582. The amendment of this Act by way of addition, variation or repeal shall be effected only by a simple majority of the respective Houses or a vote of no less than two-third of the total Members of Parliament present and voting on a motion submitted by one-third of the members of either House, provided that the amendment does not undermine the functions and effectiveness of the Election Commission.

583. Parliament shall have the moral responsibility to ensure that an amendment does not undermine the authority and effectiveness of the Election Commission in the conduct of free and fair elections.

Authoritative Text
584. The Dzongkha text shall be the authoritative text, if there exists any difference in meaning between the Dzongkha and the English text.

In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (j) “Delimitation Commission” means the Delimitation Commission of Bhutan established under section 77;
In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (k) “Deliberative vote” means a vote cast by each member on an issue;
In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (l) “Dependents” means spouse, parents, or minor children inclusive of adopted children whose livelihood is dependent on his/her earnings;
In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (m) “Dzongkhag” means a district;
In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (n) “Dzongkhag Tshogdu” means the District Council;

In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (s) “Election Symbol” means a pictorial design or sign, reserved for a political party, or a candidate by the Election Commission, which represents or identifies a political party or a candidate in the form of a party logo, flag or posters;

In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (z) “Gung” means a household registered in accordance with the Bhutan Civil Registration System;

In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (cc) “Local Government” includes Dzongkhag Tshogdu, Gewog Tshogde and Thromde Tshogde;

Article 1: Function of the Decree
This decree defines the principles, regulations and measures for managing information on the Internet to promote national stability, peace and social order. It is focused on protecting the integrity of and benefits to be derived by service providers, service users, and society in order to contribute to national development.

Article 2: Information Management on the Internet
Information management on the Internet refers to the monitoring, reviewing, resisting and suppressing the use of information on the Internet, which threatens society, and stability of the nation.

Article 3: Definition
In this Decree:
9. Internet service user means the individual who connects to the Internet in different forms in order to read, write, send, and forward information on the Internet.

Article 4: Government Policy on Information Usage on the Internet
The government promotes and encourages individuals, legal entities, and organizations, both Lao nationals and expats, who live and work in the Lao PDR, to use information through the Internet for their work, especially in the education sector, public health sector, and research on science and technology, in order to increase efficiency and the quality of life and to improving the standard of living of residents of the Lao PDR. The government promotes and creates the environment of using the national Internet code (.LA) broadly; they also encourage the process of transitioning to use modern technology of Internet Protocol Version (IPV6). In addition, the government promotes the creation of programs in the Lao language, creating websites and online networking that is being implemented legally, based on Lao law.

Article 5: Scope of this Decree
This decree applies to individuals, legal entities, governmental organizations, and the private sector, both Lao nationals and expats, which provide and use Internet service in the Lao PDR.

Article 6: Dissemination of Information through the Internet
The dissemination of information through the Internet refers to the posting of messages, animations, photos, voices, and videos on the website in order to present, comment, share, send, and forward messages to one or many people.

Article 7: Regulations for Disseminating Information on the Internet
Individuals, legal entities, and organizations are able to disseminate information through social media but they must identify the source of information correctly. Website managers and the personal registration account owner in social media shall inspect the content of information before disseminating it on their web page. Information that has not gone through official media or legal media offices cannot be used as official information. Website owners or website managers have the responsibility of checking content and information thoroughly before allowing others to disseminate it through their website.

Article 8: Creating a Personal Account on Social Media
Individuals, legal entities, or organizations that create an account on social media shall identify their names, family names, and current address correctly.

Article 9: Security of Information Usage
Individuals, legal entities, or organizations, which use information through the Internet shall save and change their passwords regularly to assure the security of using their personal information. They also won’t create conditions for others to use their personal information illegally.

7. Use the names of individuals or organizations in animations, photos, voices, videos, signatures, codes, credit cards, or personal documents of others to earn benefits, or for any other purposes without permission from the owner.

Article 11: Content Allowed for Dissemination on the Internet
Content and information that are allowed to be disseminated are those having creative components, which heightens knowledge, are useful for society, and do not conflict with Article 10 above.

Article 22: Responsibilities of other Sectors
Line ministries, line agencies and local authorities shall be responsible for information management that is related to their own departments. They shall coordinate with concerned sectors to fight and suppress the dissemination of information on the Internet that is in violation of this decree and other related regulations and laws.

Article 23: Suppression Measures
The Post, Telecommunication, and Communication sector is the center of coordination with the Information, Culture, and Tourism sector, and with the public security sector in order to monitor and inspect content and information on the Internet, and to suppress, restrict, and respond to the content that conflicts with this decree.

Article 24: Creating Activities and Dissemination information on Internet Usage
Information, Culture and Tourism sector are the core sectors which are to coordinate with related sectors in creating activities, organizing campaigns, and disseminated Internet usage in order to make it appropriate and correct, help Internet service users, and society, avoid the negative impacts arising from not knowing, and avoid disseminating information that conflicts with this decree.

Article 25: Warning
Website managers shall warn, and set the conditions for disseminating information through their own web pages.

Article 26: Measures against Violators
Individuals, legal entity or organizations that violate this decree may be warned, educated, penalized, fined, and subjected to civil or criminal charges depending on the severity of the case.

Article 27: Implementation
The Ministry of Post, Transportation, and Communication shall be assigned to be the main Line Ministry to coordinate with related parties to implement this decree effectively. Line ministries, line agencies, local authorities, individuals, legal entity, both Lao nationals and expats, providing and using Internet service in the Lao PDR acknowledge and implement this decree accordingly.

Article 28: Entry into Force
This decree shall enter into force from the date of signature and after it is registered as an official notice within 15 days.

Article 1.- No one may be punished for an act that is not expressly provided as punishable by law, nor with penalties that it has not previously established. Punishable acts are divided into crimes and misdemeanors.

Article 2.- Penal laws have retroactive effect insofar as they favor the accused, even though at their publication there may already have been a final sentence and the accused may be serving the sentence.
Article 3.- Anyone who commits a crime or misdemeanor within the geographic space of the Republic shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan law.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 1- Venezuelans who, in a foreign country, become guilty of treason against the Republic and those who, among themselves, commit punishable acts according to their laws.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 2- Subjects or foreign citizens who in a foreign country commit any crime against the security of the Republic or against any of its nationals. In the two foregoing cases it is required that the accused have come to the geographic space of the Republic and that action be attempted by the aggrieved party, or by the Public Ministry in cases of treason or crime against the security of Venezuela. It is also required that the accused has not been tried by foreign courts, unless having been tried he evaded the sentence.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 3- Venezuelans or foreigners who, without authorization from the Government of the Republic, manufacture, acquire or dispatch arms or ammunition, destined for Venezuela, or in any way favor their introduction into Venezuelan territory.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 4- Venezuelans who, in a foreign country, infringe the laws relating to the civil status and capacity of Venezuelans.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 5- Diplomatic employees, in the cases permitted by the Public Law of Nations, in accordance with what is established by the Constitution of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 6- Diplomatic employees of the Republic who perform their functions badly, or who commit any punishable act not triable at the place of their residence by reason of the privileges inherent to their office.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 7- Officers and other members of the crew and marines of national warships and aircraft for committing, anywhere, punishable acts.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 8- Captains or masters, other employees and the crew and marines, as well as the passengers of the merchant ships of the Republic, for punishable acts committed on the high seas or on board in another nation's waters; always excepted, with respect to passengers, what is established in the second paragraph of number 2 of this Article.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 9- Venezuelans or foreigners who have come to the Republic who, on the high seas, commit acts of piracy or other crimes which International Law qualifies as heinous and against humanity; unless they have already been tried in another country and served the sentence.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 10- Venezuelans who, inside or outside the Republic, take part in the slave trade.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 11- Venezuelans or foreigners who have come to the geographic space of the Republic who, in another country, counterfeit or take part in the counterfeiting of legal tender currency in Venezuela or public use seals, stamps or credit securities of the Nation, bearer banknotes or bonds of capital and income, issued by law of the nation.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 12- Venezuelans or foreigners who in any way favor the introduction into the Republic of the values specified in the previous number. In the cases of the foregoing numbers the provisions of the second paragraph, number 2, of this Article remain always reserved.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 13- Chiefs, officers and other members of an army, by reason of punishable acts that they commit while marching through neutral foreign territory, against the inhabitants thereof.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 14- Foreigners who enter places of the Republic not open to foreign trade or who, without right, appropriate their terrestrial, maritime, lacustrine or fluvial productions; or who without permits or titles make use of their unpopulated lands.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 15- Foreigners who infringe quarantines and other provisions established for the benefit of public health.

Article 4.- Those who are subject to prosecution in Venezuela and shall be punished in accordance with Venezuelan criminal law: Article 4.- 16- Foreigners or Venezuelans who, in peacetime, from territory, warships or foreign aircraft, launch projectiles or otherwise harm the populations, inhabitants or the territory of Venezuela, saving what is set forth in the two paragraphs of number 2 of this Article.

Article 5.- In the cases provided in the previous article, when a person who has been sentenced abroad is again convicted in the Republic, the part of the penalty that has been served in the other country and the time of detention shall be credited in favor of the convict, in accordance with the rule of Article 40.

Article 6.- The extradition of a Venezuelan may not be granted for any reason; but he must be tried in Venezuela, at the request of the aggrieved party or of the Public Ministry, if the crime with which he is charged would merit punishment under Venezuelan law. The extradition of a foreigner may also not be granted for political crimes nor for offenses connected with these crimes, nor for any act that is not classified as a crime by Venezuelan law. The extradition of a foreigner for common crimes may be granted only by the competent authority, in accordance with the procedures and requirements established for that purpose by International Treaties signed by Venezuela and in force, and, in their absence, by Venezuelan laws. The extradition of a foreigner accused of a crime that has assigned in the legislation of the requesting country the death penalty or a life sentence shall not be granted. In any case, once the extradition request has been made, it falls to the National Executive, according to the merit of the supporting documents submitted, to decide on the preventive detention of the foreigner, before passing the matter to the Supreme Court of Justice.

Article 7.- The provisions of this Code in its First Book shall also apply to matters governed by other laws, insofar as they prescribe penalties and provided that nothing to the contrary is established in them.
Article 8.- Penalties are divided mainly into corporal and non-corporal.
Article 9.- The corporal penalties, which are also called restrictive of liberty, are the following: Article 9.- 1.- Presidio (imprisonment in the most severe sense).
Article 9.- The corporal penalties, which are also called restrictive of liberty, are the following: Article 9.- 2.- Prison.
Article 9.- The corporal penalties, which are also called restrictive of liberty, are the following: Article 9.- 3.- Arrest.
Article 9.- The corporal penalties, which are also called restrictive of liberty, are the following: Article 9.- 4.- Relegation to a Penitentiary Colony.
Article 9.- The corporal penalties, which are also called restrictive of liberty, are the following: Article 9.- 5.- Confinement.
Article 9.- The corporal penalties, which are also called restrictive of liberty, are the following: Article 9.- 6.- Expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 1.- Subjection to the supervision of the public authority.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 2.- Civil interdiction by criminal conviction.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 3.- Political disqualification.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 4.- Disqualification to practice a profession, industry or post.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 5.- Dismissal from office.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 6.- Suspension from the same.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 7.- Fine.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 8.- Bond not to offend or harm.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 9.- Admonition or warning.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 10.- Loss of instruments or arms with which the punishable act was committed and of effects deriving from it.
Article 10.- The non-corporal penalties are: Article 10.- 11.- Payment of procedural costs.

Article 11.- Penalties are also divided into principal and accessory. They are principal: Those that the law applies directly to punish the crime. They are accessory: Those that the law brings as adherent to the principal, necessarily or accidentally.

Article 12.- The penalty of presidio shall be served in the Penitentiaries established and regulated by law. Said penalty entails forced labor inside or outside the respective establishment, as determined by law, which shall also fix the time that the convict must spend in cellular isolation. In any case, the labors shall be proportional to the convict's strength, who, in case of illness, shall be cared for in the establishment's infirmary or in suitable premises, with due security.
Article 13.- Are accessory penalties to presidio: Article 13.- 1.- Civil interdiction during the time of the penalty.
Article 13.- Are accessory penalties to presidio: Article 13.- 2.- Political disqualification while the penalty lasts.
Article 13.- Are accessory penalties to presidio: Article 13.- 3.- Subjection to the authority’s supervision for one quarter of the time of the conviction, from when it ends.

Article 14.- The penalty of prison shall be served in the penitentiary establishments established and regulated by law and failing that in one of the same Penitentiaries intended for the serving of presidio penalties. In this case due separation shall be maintained between those sentenced to one penalty or another.

Article 14.- Parágrafo Único.- When the prison time does not exceed one year after deducting the time of detention, computable according to Article 40, the convict may not be sent to National Penitential Establishments located outside the limits of the State, Metropolitan District of Caracas or Federal Territory where he was sentenced in first instance, but shall serve the penalty in the respective local penitentiary establishment.

Article 15.- The convict sentenced to prison shall not be obliged to other labors except the arts and trades that may be carried out within the establishment, with the faculty to choose what best conforms to his aptitudes or previous occupations.
Article 16.- Are accessory penalties of prison: Article 16.- 1.- Political disqualification during the time of the conviction.
Article 16.- Are accessory penalties of prison: Article 16.- 2.- Subjection to the authority’s supervision for one fifth of the time of the conviction, once it is terminated.

Article 17.- Arrest shall be served in local penitentiary establishments or in police barracks, as determined by the executing court of the sentence, without in any case being able to force the condemned to work against his will. However, when expressly provided by law, arrest shall be served in a Fortress or penitentiary establishment. This penalty entails the suspension, while it is served, of the employment that the convict holds.

Article 18.- Women shall serve the penalties of presidio, prison and arrest in special establishments, and while such separate establishments are not founded and they have to serve them in common establishments, they shall always be separated therein from men.

Article 18.- Parágrafo Único.- The President of the Republic may order, in a determined case, through the Ministry of Interior and Justice, that women serve the mentioned penalties by rendering their services in official charitable establishments, hospices and hospitals, with due securities and under absolute prohibition to leave these until the term of the penalty.

Article 19.- The penalty of relegation to a penitentiary colony imposes on the convict the obligation to reside in the colony designated by the final sentence that imposes the penalty among those that the law will create or that the National Executive may order to found in the Federal Territories or in depopulated borders of the Republic. The relegated shall be subject to the surveillance rules that the colony regulations prescribe to prevent desertions, but not to forced labor. This penalty has as accessory the suspension, while it is served, of the employment the convict holds.

Article 20.- The penalty of confinement consists in the obligation imposed on the convict to reside, during the time of the conviction, in the Municipality indicated by the final sentence that applies it, none may be designated for this purpose that is less than one hundred kilometers distant both from that where the crime was committed and from those in which the convict was domiciled at the time of committing the crime, and from those of the aggrieved at the date of the First Instance sentence. The convict shall be obliged, to prove that he is serving the sentence and while the sentence lasts, to present himself to the Civil Headquarters of the Municipality with the frequency that the Civil Chief indicates, which may not be more than once each day nor less than once a week. Suspension, while it is served, of the employment that the convict holds is an accessory penalty to confinement.

Article 21.- Expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic imposes on the convict the obligation not to return thereto during the time of the sentence. This penalty entails as accessory the same indicated in the final paragraph of the previous article.

Article 22.- Subjection to the supervision of the public authority may not be imposed as a principal penalty but only as accessory to presidio or prison and obliges the convict to report to the respective Civil Chiefs of the Municipalities where he resides or through which he travels, of his departure and arrival to those.

Article 23.- Civil interdiction for criminal cause may not be imposed as a principal penalty, but only as accessory to presidio. Its effects are to deprive the convict of the disposition of his assets by acts inter vivos and of the administration thereof, of parental authority and marital authority. The administration of the assets of the interdicted will be provided as the Civil Code disposes with respect to those who are under interdiction.

Article 24.- Political disqualification may not be imposed as a principal penalty but as accessory to presidio or prison and produces as effect the deprivation of public or political offices or employments that the convict has and incapacity, during the conviction, to obtain others and to enjoy active and passive suffrage rights. He shall also lose any dignity or official decoration that may have been conferred on him, without being able to obtain the same or any other during the same time.

Article 25.- Disqualification for the exercise of some profession, industry or art may not be perpetual nor absolute, but temporal and limited to a determined or determined professions, industries or arts. It may be imposed as principal or accessory.
Article 26.- Dismissal from employment produces as effect the separation from it of the convict, without being able to hold it again except by new election or appointment.

Article 27.- Suspension of employment prevents the convict from performing it during the time of the conviction, with the right, once the sentence is terminated, to resume it if for its exercise a term had been fixed that would still be running. Parágrafo Único.- This penalty and that of the previous article may be imposed as principal or as accessory.

Article 28.- The removals that the authority, whose free appointment is the respective destination, may order of the employee who is being tried, nor the provisional suspension in the exercise of his office that, in the same case, is made in accordance with the procedural law, of the employee who has the right to enjoy it for a determined time, shall be considered penalties.

Article 29.- When the penalties of political disqualification, dismissal and suspension of employment fall on ecclesiastical persons, their effects are limited to the offices, rights and honors in the provision or pass of which official intervention has taken place; but, in any case, ecclesiastics who incur in said penalties are prevented, for the time of their duration, from exercising ecclesiastical jurisdiction in the Republic, the cure of souls and the ministry of preaching.

Article 30.- The penalty of fine consists of the obligation to pay to the Treasury of the respective State, or to the Municipal Revenues of the Metropolitan District of Caracas in their cases or to the National Treasury if the trial was initiated in a Federal Territory, the amount that the law determines by the sentence. If the trial has been for a misdemeanor, the fine shall benefit the respective Municipal Treasury.
Article 31.- The penalty of bond not to offend or harm obliges the convicted to give the securities that the executing Judge deems necessary.

Article 32.- Admonition, or warning, is the verbal correction that the executing Judge gives to the convict in the terms ordered by the sentence, an act of that being extended, which shall be published in the official period.

Article 33.- The loss of instruments or arms with which the punishable act was committed and of the effects that derive from it is necessarily accessory to another principal penalty; and it shall be executed thus: the arms shall be confiscated in accordance with Chapter I of Title V of Book Two of this Code; and the other effects shall likewise be confiscated and auctioned to allocate their price to the respective National, State or Municipal Treasury, according to the rules of Article 30.

Article 34.- The conviction to pay procedural costs shall not be considered a penalty except when applied in criminal trial and in this it is necessarily accessory to any conviction to principal penalty or penalties and shall be applied thus, the convict being obliged: to replace the stamped paper that the respective law indicates in place of the common one used, to invalidate the stamps that were left unused in the process, to the indemnifications and rights fixed by prior law and to satisfy other expenses caused in the trial or on the occasion of those not appraised by law, which shall be determined by the Judge, with assistance of the party. Parágrafo Único.- Those convicted for the same infringement shall be jointly and severally obligated to pay procedural costs. Those convicted in the same trial for different punishable acts shall only be jointly liable for the payment of common costs.
Article 35.- Whenever the Courts impose a penalty that carries with it other accessories by provision of the law, they shall also sentence the convict to these latter.
Article 36.- The detention of the accused during the trial does not constitute a penalty, but it shall be taken into account for the purposes of Article 40.

Article 37.- When the law punishes a crime or misdemeanor with a penalty comprised between two limits, it is understood that the normally applicable one is the middle term obtained by adding the two numbers and taking half; it shall be reduced to the lower limit or increased to the upper, according to the merit of the respective mitigating or aggravating circumstances that concur in the concrete case, compensating them when there are some of both kinds. Nevertheless, the penalty shall be applied at its upper or lower limit when the law so expressly provides, and also one or the other limit shall be exceeded when necessary by virtue of a legal provision that orders to increase or decrease the corresponding penalty to the crime by a quota part, which shall then be calculated in proportion to the amount of penalty that the Judge would have applied to the convict if the reason for increase or decrease did not concur. If for the increase or decrease itself two limits are also set, the Court shall within them make the respective increase or decrease, according to the greater or lesser gravity of the act. In all these cases the rule of Article 94 shall always be borne in mind.

Article 38.- The penalties of dismissal and admonition or warning shall be applied indivisibly to whoever deserves them, without taking into account aggravating or mitigating circumstances and without distinction of consummated or not crime, nor of greater or lesser degree of participation in the act.

Article 39.- The spans of penalties that must be suffered for a determined time shall be counted in the manner provided in the Civil Code. Time of flight shall not be counted in that of the sentence being served, but the time of involuntary illness shall be computed.

Article 40.- In convictions to presidio penalty, the detention elapsed after five months from its being made shall be computed in favor of the convict at the rate of one day of detention for one of presidio. In other cases, the time of detention in favor of the convict shall be computed thus: one day of detention for one of prison; one for two of arrest; one for three of relegation to Penitentiary Colony; one for four of confinement or expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic; and one for each fifteen bolívares of fine.

Article 41.- The computation ordered in the previous article shall be made by the Judge of the cause in the interlocutory order in which he orders the execution of the final sentence; and from that day the time of the penalties of presidio, prison or arrest shall begin to be counted, deducted the time of the computation made, even though the convict is not sent until later to the Penitentiary or Penitentiary Establishment where the sentence is to be served. If it is a question of penalties of relegation to Penitentiary Colony, confinement or expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic, in the same interlocutory order the convict shall be computed, in the proportion indicated, the time that must elapse between that date and the arrival to the Colony, to the place of confinement or to the port or border of the Republic by which he leaves for the exterior, as the case may be. The duration of the trip shall be calculated at the rate of thirty kilometers per day, and the time during which the penalty must be suffered shall be calculated after making the aforesaid deductions, and shall begin to be counted from the day of the arrival of the convict to the Colony, to the place of confinement or to the place of departure from the Republic.

Article 42.- In the case of a conviction to presidio penalty, whatever its duration, or to prison that must last more than one year, after making the computation to which the previous articles refer, as well as also in all cases of conviction to arrest in Fortress or Penitentiary Establishment, the Judge of the cause shall send a certified copy of the final conviction and of the interlocutory order containing the computation, through the Ministry of Interior and Justice, to the President of the Republic, so that he designates the National Penal Establishment where the convict must serve the penalty.

Article 43.- When the penalty must be served in a local penitentiary establishment or in a police barracks, the Judge of the cause shall send a certified copy of the sentence to the Head of the respective Establishment and shall take all measures conducive to its execution.

Article 44.- When it is a question of penalties of relegation to Penitentiary Colony, confinement or expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic, the Judge of the cause shall take, directly, all the measures of the case so that the convict is transferred to the place where he must remain relegated or confined or to the port or border site by which he must be made to leave the national territory.

Article 45.- In the cases of the previous article, the Judge shall send a certified copy of the final conviction and of the interlocutory order containing the computation, to the chief of the Penitentiary Colony where the relegation is to be served or to the Civil Chief of the Municipality where the confined person will reside. If it is a question of expulsion from the national territory, he shall send equal copies to the President of the Republic, so that he issues the measures conducive to prevent the convict from returning to Venezuela during the time of the sentence.
Article 46.- No sentence that imposes a penalty on someone who is in serious danger of imminent death due to illness shall be executed nor even notified to the convict, until such danger disappears.

Article 47.- The punishment of a pregnant woman, when by reason of it her life or health, or by the life or health of the child she carries in her womb, may be endangered, shall be deferred until six months after that child's birth, provided the child lives.

Article 48.- At seventy years all corporal penalties that have lasted at least four years shall terminate and that which by then shall have lasted less and is in course shall be converted into arrest, if it is presidio, or prison until four years elapse. The measures of the case shall be dictated by the Criminal First Instance Judge who knew of the process.

Article 49.- Outside the cases expressly determined by law, when by impediment of the sentenced to presidio or prison the imposed sentence could not be carried out, the Judge of the cause may commute it, in accordance with the following rules: Article 49.- 1.- The presidio penalty shall be converted into prison with an increase of one third.

Article 49.- Outside the cases expressly determined by law, when by impediment of the sentenced to presidio or prison the imposed sentence could not be carried out, the Judge of the cause may commute it, in accordance with the following rules: Article 49.- 2.- The prison penalty shall be converted into arrest with an increase of one fourth.

Article 50.- When the penalty provided for the crime is a fine and the convict could not satisfy it, it shall be converted into prison or arrest, according to the age, robustness, weakness or fortune of the convict, fixing the Court the duration of such penalties at the rate of one day of prison for each thirty bolívares of fine and of one of arrest for each fifteen bolívares. In misdemeanors, the proportion shall be ten bolívares for each day of arrest.

Article 51.- Prison by conversion of fine may not exceed six months, nor arrest for the same cause nine months, if it is a question of crimes, nor two months if it is a question of misdemeanors. The convict can always make prison or arrest cease by paying the fine, deducting the part corresponding to the time elapsed in one or the other.

Article 52.- Any convict sentenced to prison who, according to the sole paragraph of Article 14, serves it in a local penitentiary establishment, may request the Judge of the cause, once three quarters of said time have elapsed, observing good conduct, evidenced by a certificate of the Mayor of the respective Establishment, the conversion of the remainder of the penalty into confinement for an equal time, and the Court may grant it thus, proceeding summarily.

Article 53.- Any convict sentenced to presidio or prison or destined to Penitentiary or penitentiary Establishment, who has served three quarters of his sentence, observing exemplary conduct, may petition the Supreme Court of Justice, in authenticated writing, requesting the commutation of the remainder of the penalty into relegation to a Penitentiary Colony for the same time or confinement for a time equal to that which remains of the penalty, with an increase of one third.

Article 54.- To address the grace to which the previous article refers, the Supreme Court of Justice shall consult the copies that rest in its archive, and that the Heads of all National Penal Establishments must send to it each month, of the summary entries that in the book destined for that effect they will note weekly, making record of the conduct observed by each convict. In the absence of said copies, the Supreme Court of Justice shall base itself on other evidence presented.

Article 55.- The procedure before the Supreme Court of Justice shall be brief and summary; however, by order to better provide, it may order the investigations it deems necessary. While the Penitentiary Colonies are founded, the commutation shall be agreed in confinement.

Article 56.- In no case may the grace of commutation be granted to the recidivist nor to the convict of homicide perpetrated against ascendants, descendants, spouse or siblings, nor to those who have acted with premeditation, cruelty or treachery, or for profit. In the case of any other crime not committed in such circumstances, the Supreme Court of Justice is empowered to grant or deny the commutation, according to the assessment of the case.

Article 57.- When the penalty that should be imposed on the convict does not exceed thirty days of arrest, forty-five days of confinement or four hundred and fifty bolívares of fine, the Judge of the cause may commute it to an admonition or warning, provided that the crime was committed with mitigating circumstances and without the aggravating circumstance of recidivism.

Article 58.- When the delinquent falls into madness or imbecility after a final condemnatory sentence, it shall proceed as provided in Article 62 in its final paragraph, and if he recovers reason, he shall serve the time of penalty still pending, deducted by the time of the illness.

Article 59.- The penalty that a woman condemned to prison must suffer if, once the detention computation has been made, should not exceed six months, shall be commuted into arrest for the same time, and arrest in the same conditions into confinement.
Article 60.- Ignorance of the law excuses no crime nor misdemeanor.

Article 61.- No one may be punished as guilty of a crime without having had the intention to carry out the act that constitutes it, except when the law attributes it to him as a consequence of his action or omission. He who incurs in misdemeanors is responsible for his own action or omission, even if it is not proven that he wished to commit an infraction of the law. The action or omission punished by law shall be presumed voluntary, unless the contrary is established.

Article 62.- He who executes the act while asleep or in a state of mental illness sufficient to deprive him of consciousness or freedom of acts is not punishable. However, when the insane or demented person has executed an act that is equivalent in degree to a serious crime, the court shall decree confinement in one of the hospitals or establishments intended for this class of sick, from which he may not leave without prior authorization of the same Court. If the crime is not serious or if the establishment is not adequate, he shall be delivered to his family, under custody bond, unless they do not wish to receive him.

Article 63.- When the mental state indicated in the previous article is such that it greatly mitigates responsibility, without excluding it totally, the penalty established for the crime or misdemeanor shall be reduced according to the following rules: Article 63.- 1.- In place of presidio, prison shall be applied, diminished between two-thirds and one-half.

Article 63.- When the mental state indicated in the previous article is such that it greatly mitigates responsibility, without excluding it totally, the penalty established for the crime or misdemeanor shall be reduced according to the following rules: Article 63.- 2.- In place of prison, arrest shall be applied, with the indicated diminution.

Article 63.- When the mental state indicated in the previous article is such that it greatly mitigates responsibility, without excluding it totally, the penalty established for the crime or misdemeanor shall be reduced according to the following rules: Article 63.- 3.- Other divisible penalties shall be applied reduced by half.

Article 64.- If the state of mental disturbance of the accused at the time of the crime arises from drunkenness, the following rules shall be followed: Article 64.- 1.- If it is proven that, in order to facilitate the perpetration of the crime, or to prepare an excuse, the accused had made use of liquor, the penalty to be applied shall be increased by one-fifth to one-third, provided that the total does not exceed the maximum fixed by law for that kind of penalty. If the penalty to be imposed would be presidio, this shall be maintained.

Article 64.- If the state of mental disturbance of the accused at the time of the crime arises from drunkenness, the following rules shall be followed: Article 64.- 2.- If it is proven that the accused knew and it was notorious among his relations that drunkenness made him provocative and quarrelsome, the penalties provided for the committed crime by this Code shall be applied to him without mitigation.

Article 64.- If the state of mental disturbance of the accused at the time of the crime arises from drunkenness, the following rules shall be followed: Article 64.- 3.- If neither of the two foregoing circumstances is proven and the disturbance results demonstrated by cause of drunkenness, the penalties shall be reduced to two-thirds, substituting prison for presidio.

Article 64.- If the state of mental disturbance of the accused at the time of the crime arises from drunkenness, the following rules shall be followed: Article 64.- 4.- If drunkenness is habitual, the corporal penalty to be suffered may be ordered to be served in a special correctional establishment.

Article 64.- If the state of mental disturbance of the accused at the time of the crime arises from drunkenness, the following rules shall be followed: Article 64.- 5.- If drunkenness is entirely casual or exceptional, having no antecedent, the penalties incurred by the accused shall be reduced from one-half to one-quarter in duration, substituting prison for presidio.
Article 65.- Not punishable: Article 65.- 1.- He who acts in fulfillment of a duty or in the legitimate exercise of a right, authority, office or post, without exceeding legal limits.

Article 65.- Not punishable: Article 65.- 2.- He who acts by virtue of legitimate and due obedience. In this case, if the executed act constitutes a crime or misdemeanor, the corresponding penalty shall be imposed on the one who is found to have given the illegal order.

Article 65.- Not punishable: Article 65.- 3.- He who acts in defense of his own person or right, provided the following circumstances concur: Article 65.- 3.a- Illegitimate aggression by the one who results injured by the act. Article 65.- 3.b- Necessity of the means employed to prevent or repel it. Article 65.- 3.c- Lack of sufficient provocation on the part of the one who claims to have acted in self-defense. It is equated to legitimate defense the act by which the agent, in a state of uncertainty, fear or terror, exceeds the limits of defense.

Article 65.- Not punishable: Article 65.- 4.- He who acts constrained by the necessity to save his person, or that of another, from a serious and imminent danger, to which he has not voluntarily given cause, and which he cannot avoid otherwise.

Article 66.- He who exceeds the limits imposed by Law in the case of number 1 of the previous article, and by the authority that gave the order in the case of number 2 of the same, and he who exceeds in defense, or in the means employed to save himself from the serious and imminent danger, doing more than necessary, shall be punished with the corresponding penalty, diminished from one to two-thirds. The pecuniary penalty shall be applied with diminution of one-half.

Article 67.- He who commits the punishable act in a moment of frenzy or intense pain, determined by unjust provocation, shall be punished, unless special provision, with the corresponding penalty diminished from one-third to one-half, according to the gravity of the provocation.

Article 68.- When someone, by mistake, or by some other accident, commits a crime harming a person different from the one against whom he had directed his action, the aggravating circumstances that emanate from the category of the offended or injured person or from their ties to him shall not be imputed to him, but those that would have diminished the penalty of the act if he had committed it to the detriment of the person against whom he had directed his action shall be imputed.

Article 69.- Not punishable: the minor under twelve years of age, in any case, nor the over twelve and under fifteen years of age, unless it appears that he acted with discernment. The Court shall take the measures it considers appropriate regarding the education of the irresponsible minor, who shall be kept in an adequate educational establishment or in a responsible foster home.

Article 70.- If the over twelve and under fifteen years of age is declared responsible, the penalty corresponding to the punishable act shall be converted into arrest if it were presidio or prison, with diminution by half; likewise other penalties shall be halved and all those he is suffering shall cease on reaching twenty-one years.
Article 71.- Whoever commits a punishable act being over fifteen years of age but under eighteen shall be punished with the corresponding penalty diminished by one-third.

Article 72.- No proceedings shall be taken in any case against a deaf-mute who, when committing the punishable act, had not reached fifteen years of age; but if he is over that age and under eighteen years, the provisions of the previous article shall be applied if he acts with discernment; if not, he shall be declared irresponsible, but the Court shall dictate the measures it deems conducive regarding his education until he reaches twenty-one years.
Article 73.- Not punishable is he who incurs in some omission being impeded by legitimate or insurmountable cause.

Article 74.- The following shall be considered mitigating circumstances which, except for special legal provisions, do not give rise to special reduction of penalty, but to take them into account to apply it below the middle term, but without going below the lower limit of that which the law assigns to the respective punishable act: Article 74.- 1.- Being the convict under twenty-one years and over eighteen at the time of committing the crime.

Article 74.- The following shall be considered mitigating circumstances which, except for special legal provisions, do not give rise to special reduction of penalty, but to take them into account to apply it below the middle term, but without going below the lower limit of that which the law assigns to the respective punishable act: Article 74.- 2.- Not having had the guilty intention to cause harm of such gravity as that produced.

Article 74.- The following shall be considered mitigating circumstances which, except for special legal provisions, do not give rise to special reduction of penalty, but to take them into account to apply it below the middle term, but without going below the lower limit of that which the law assigns to the respective punishable act: Article 74.- 3.- Having been preceded by insult or threat by the aggrieved party, when not of such gravity as to give rise to the application of Article 67.

Article 74.- The following shall be considered mitigating circumstances which, except for special legal provisions, do not give rise to special reduction of penalty, but to take them into account to apply it below the middle term, but without going below the lower limit of that which the law assigns to the respective punishable act: Article 74.- 4.- Any other circumstance of equal entity that in the Court's judgment diminishes the gravity of the act.

Article 75.- To him who commits a punishable act being over seventy years of age, no presidio penalty shall be imposed, but in place of this and of prison arrest shall be applied not to exceed four years.

Article 76.- In the case of the previous article the same measures provided in the final paragraph of Article 62 may be ordered, instead of applying the arrest penalty or even after this is being served.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 1.- To execute it with treachery. There is treachery when the guilty acts by ambush or on certainty.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 2.- To execute it by price, reward or promise.

Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 3.- To commit it by means of flooding, fire, poison, explosion, stranding of a ship, deliberate damage, derailment of a locomotive or by use of another device that may cause great devastation.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 4.- Deliberately increasing the harm of the act, causing other unnecessary evils for its execution.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 5.- To act with known premeditation.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 6.- To employ cunning, fraud or disguise.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 7.- To employ means or to concur circumstances that add ignominy to the act's effects.

Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 8.- To abuse superiority of sex, of force, of arms, of authority or to employ any other means that weakens the defense of the offended.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 9.- To act by abuse of trust.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 10.- To commit the punishable act taking advantage of fire, shipwreck, flood or other similar calamity.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 11.- To execute it with weapons or in union with other persons that ensure or provide impunity.

Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 12.- To execute it in a deserted place or at night. This circumstance shall be considered by the Courts taking into account those of the delinquent and the effects of the crime.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 13.- To execute it in contempt or offense of the public authority or where it is exercising its functions.

Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 14.- To execute it with offense or contempt of the respect that by his dignity, age or sex the offended deserves, or in his dwelling, when he has not provoked the event.

Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 15.- To execute it with burglary. There is burglary when one enters by a way that is not intended for the purpose.

Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 16.- To execute it with breaking of wall, roof or pavement or with fracture, understanding by this any force, breakage, decomposition, demolition, demolition, pulling down or drilling of walls, grounds or pavements, doors, windows, locks, padlocks or other utensils or instruments that serve to close or prevent passage or entry and of all kinds of locks, whatever they may be.

Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 17.- To be the aggrieved spouse of the offender, or his legitimate, natural or adoptive ascendant or sibling; or spouse of these; or ascendants, descendants or legitimate sibling of his spouse; or his ward, disciple, intimate friend or benefactor.

Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 18.- That the author, on the occasion of executing the act and to prepare to perpetrate it, had become deliberately intoxicated, as established in rule 1 of Article 64.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 19.- To be vagrant the guilty party.
Article 77.- Aggravating circumstances of any punishable act are the following: Article 77.- 20.- To be by quarrelsome character.

Article 78.- The circumstances enumerated in the previous article shall be taken into account for the calculation of the penalty that Article 37 orders in its first part, but they may give rise to the application of the maximum and also to an exceptional increase that exceeds the upper extreme of the two assigned by the law to the crime, when that law itself specially provides that in the concurrence of some of said circumstances a penalty in its maximum shall be imposed or it shall be increased by one fourth.

Article 79.- The aggravating circumstances that by themselves constitute a crime specially punished by the law, expressed when describing or punishing it, nor those so inherent to the crime that, without their concurrence, it could not be committed, shall not produce the effect of increasing the penalty.

Article 80.- Punishable, in addition to the consummated crime and the misdemeanor, are the attempt of crime and the frustrated crime. There is attempt when, with the object of committing a crime, someone has begun its execution by appropriate means and has not carried out all that is necessary for its consummation, for causes independent of his will. There is frustrated crime when someone has carried out, with the purpose of committing a crime, all that is necessary to consummate it and, nevertheless, has not achieved it for circumstances independent of his will.

Article 81.- If the agent voluntarily desists from continuing the attempt, he is only liable to penalty when the acts already carried out constitute, by themselves, another crime or crimes or misdemeanors.

Article 82.- In the frustrated crime the penalty shall be reduced by one-third of the penalty that should have been imposed for the consummated crime, considering all the circumstances; and in the attempt of the same crime, the penalty shall be reduced from one-half to two-thirds, except in either case special provisions.

Article 83.- When several persons concur in the execution of a punishable act, each of the perpetrators and of the immediate cooperators is subject to the penalty corresponding to the perpetrated act. The same penalty is incurred by him who determined another to commit the act.

Article 84.- They incur the penalty corresponding to the respective punishable act, reduced by half, those who participated in it in any of the following ways: Article 84.- 1.- Inciting or reinforcing the resolution to perpetrate it or promising assistance and aid for after it is committed.

Article 84.- They incur the penalty corresponding to the respective punishable act, reduced by half, those who participated in it in any of the following ways: Article 84.- 2.- Giving instructions or supplying means to carry it out.

Article 84.- They incur the penalty corresponding to the respective punishable act, reduced by half, those who participated in it in any of the following ways: Article 84.- 3.- Facilitating the perpetration of the act or providing assistance or aid so that it is carried out, before its execution or during it. The reduction of penalty provided in this article does not take place with respect to one who is found in any of the specified cases when without his concurrence the act would not have been carried out.

Article 85.- Aggravating or mitigating circumstances inherent to the person of the delinquent or that consist in his particular relations with the offended or in another personal cause shall serve to mitigate or aggravate the responsibility only of those in whom they concur. Those that consist in the material execution of the act or in the means employed to carry it out shall serve to aggravate responsibility only of those who had knowledge of them at the moment of the action or at the time of their cooperation to perpetrate the crime.

Article 86.- To the guilty of two or more crimes, each of which carries presidio penalty, only the penalty corresponding to the most serious act shall be applied, but with an increase of two-thirds of the time corresponding to the penalty of the other or others.

Article 87.- To the guilty of one or more crimes that would merit presidio penalties and of another or others that carry prison, arrest, relegation to penitentiary colony, confinement, expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic, or fine, these shall be converted into presidio and only the presidio penalty corresponding to the most serious crime shall be applied, but with the increase of two-thirds of the other or others presidio penalties in which he incurred for the other crimes and of two-thirds also of the time that results from the conversion of the other indicated penalties into presidio. The conversion shall be made computing one day of presidio for two of prison, for three of arrest, for four of relegation to penitentiary colony, for five of confinement or expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic, and for sixty bolívares of fine.

Article 88.- To the guilty of two or more crimes each of which carries prison penalty, only the penalty corresponding to the most serious shall be applied, but with the increase of one-half of the time corresponding to the penalty of the other or others.

Article 89.- To the guilty of one or more crimes that would merit prison penalty and of another or others that carry penalties of arrest, relegation to penitentiary colony, confinement, expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic or fine, these shall be converted into prison and only the prison penalty that he deserves for the most serious act shall be applied, but with the increase of one-half of the time corresponding to the other or others prison penalties in which he incurred and of one-half also of the time that results from the conversion of the other indicated penalties into prison. The conversion shall be made computing one day of prison for two of arrest, for three of relegation to penitentiary colony, for confinement or expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic and for thirty bolívares of fine.

Article 90.- To the guilty of two or more punishable acts, each of which carries arrest penalty, only the penalty corresponding to the most serious shall be applied; but increased by one-third of the time corresponding to the penalty of the other or others.

Article 91.- To the guilty of one or more punishable acts that deserve arrest penalty and of another or others that carry penalties of relegation to penitentiary colony, confinement, expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic or fine, these shall be converted into arrest and only the penalty of the most serious act that merits it shall be applied, but with an increase of one-third of the other or others arrest penalties in which he incurred and of one-third also of the time that results from the conversion of the other indicated penalties into arrest. The conversion shall be made computing one day of arrest for two of relegation to penitentiary colony, confinement or expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic, and for fifteen bolívares of fine.

Article 92.- To the guilty of two or more punishable acts that deserve penalties of relegation to penitentiary colony, confinement or expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic, the first shall be applied with an increase of one-fourth of the time corresponding to the other or others. In the same terms shall the confinement be applied, if with them only the expulsion from the territory of the Republic concur.

Article 93.- When the penalty of fine concurs with relegation to penitentiary colony, confinement or expulsion from the territory of the Republic, the fine shall not be applied but it shall be converted into that which is concurrent with it and which shall then be imposed with the increase of the time corresponding to the fine. The conversion shall be made at the rate of one day of relegation to penitentiary colony, of confinement or of expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic, for ten bolívares of fine.
Article 94.- In no case shall the restrictive penalty of liberty imposed in accordance with the law exceed the maximum limit of thirty years.
Article 95.- The duration of accessory penalties shall be calculated according to the amount of the single principal penalty that is imposed in accordance with the preceding articles.

Article 96.- To the guilty of two or more punishable acts that carry respective penalties of fine, all shall be applied, but never more than twenty thousand bolívares if it is a question of crimes, nor three thousand bolívares if it is a question of misdemeanors.

Article 97.- The rules contained in the previous articles shall apply to the case in which, after a conviction, the same person must be tried for another punishable act committed before the conviction or after it, but while he is serving it. However, if the penalty has been served or the conviction extinguished before the new one is enforceable, the new punishable act shall be punished with the penalty that corresponds to it.
Article 98.- He who with the same act violates several legal provisions shall be punished in accordance with the provision that establishes the most severe penalty.

Article 99.- Several violations of the same legal provision shall be considered as a single punishable act, even if they were committed on different dates, provided that they have been carried out with executive acts of the same resolution; but the penalty shall be increased by one-sixth to one-half.

Article 100.- He who after a conviction and before ten years have elapsed from having served it or from having the conviction extinguished, commits another punishable act, shall be punished for this with a penalty comprised between the middle term and maximum of that which the law assigns to him. If the new punishable act is of the same kind as the previously perpetrated, the corresponding penalty shall be applied with an increase of one-fourth.

Article 101.- He who after two or more convictions to corporal penalties incurs in a punishable act that merits one of the same species and is of the same kind, in the term indicated in the previous article, shall be punished with the penalty corresponding to the new act increased by one-half.

Article 102.- For the purposes of criminal law, are considered crimes of the same kind not only those that violate the same legal provision, but also those included under the rubric of the same Title of this Code and even those that, included in different Titles, have affinity in their motives or consequences.

Article 103.- The death of the accused extinguishes the criminal action. The death of the convict also extinguishes the penalty, even the pecuniary one imposed and not satisfied and all penal consequences thereof, but does not prevent the confiscation of the objects or instruments with which the crime was committed nor the payment of procedural costs which shall be enforced against the heirs.

Article 104.- Amnesty extinguishes the criminal action and makes the execution of the conviction and all penal consequences thereof cease. The pardon or grace that condones the penalty makes it cease with all its accessories. When the pardon is granted by commuting the imposed penalty for another inferior, the latter shall be served with the accessories that correspond to it.
Article 105.- The fulfillment of the conviction extinguishes criminal responsibility.

Article 106.- In punishable acts for whose investigation and punishment an instance of the aggrieved party is necessary, the forgiveness of the offended party extinguishes the criminal action, but does not make the execution of the sentence cease except in those cases established by law. The forgiveness obtained by one of the convicts also reaches the others. Forgiveness does not produce effect with respect to one who refuses to accept it.

Article 107.- Neither amnesty nor pardon or grace, nor the forgiveness of the offended party give the right to restitution of the confiscated weapons or instruments, nor of amounts paid as fines or for procedural costs, but amounts that the accused still owed may not be collected.
Article 108.- Except where law provides otherwise, criminal action prescribes as follows: Article 108.- 1.- For fifteen years, if the crime would merit presidio penalty exceeding ten years.

Article 108.- Except where law provides otherwise, criminal action prescribes as follows: Article 108.- 2.- For ten years, if the crime would merit presidio penalty greater than seven years, not exceeding ten.
Article 108.- Except where law provides otherwise, criminal action prescribes as follows: Article 108.- 3.- For seven years if the crime would merit presidio penalty of seven years or less.
Article 108.- Except where law provides otherwise, criminal action prescribes as follows: Article 108.- 4.- For five years, if the crime would merit prison penalty of more than three years.

Article 108.- Except where law provides otherwise, criminal action prescribes as follows: Article 108.- 5.- For three years, if the crime would merit prison penalty of three years or less, arrest of more than six months, relegation to penitentiary colony, confinement or expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic.

Article 108.- Except where law provides otherwise, criminal action prescribes as follows: Article 108.- 6.- For one year, if the punishable act only carries arrest for a time of one to six months or fine greater than one hundred and fifty bolívares or suspension from exercise of profession, industry or art.

Article 108.- Except where law provides otherwise, criminal action prescribes as follows: Article 108.- 7.- For three months, if the punishable act only carries a fine less than one hundred and fifty bolívares or arrest of less than one month.

Article 109.- Prescription shall begin: for consummated punishable acts, from the day of perpetration; for attempted or frustrated infringements, from the day the last act of execution was carried out; and for continued or permanent infringements, from the day when the continuation or permanence of the act ceased. If the criminal action cannot be initiated or proceeded with except after special authorization or after a prejudicial question referred to another court is resolved, prescription shall remain suspended and shall not run again until the day on which authorization is given or the prejudicial question is defined.

Article 110.- The course of the prescription of the criminal action shall be interrupted by the pronouncement of the sentence if it is condemnatory, or by the requisition that is issued against the accused if he escapes. The order of detention or of citation to render interrogation and the procedural diligences that follow it shall also interrupt prescription; but if the trial, without fault of the accused, is prolonged for a time equal to the applicable prescription plus half of the same, prescription shall be declared. If the law establishes a term of prescription less than one year, it shall be interrupted by any act of procedure; but if within one year, counted from the day on which prescription began to run, a condemnatory sentence is not passed, the criminal action shall be deemed prescribed. Interrupted prescription shall begin to run again from the day of interruption. The interruption of prescription has effect for all who have concurred in the punishable act, even though the acts that interrupt prescription refer only to one.

Article 111.- When a convicted person is submitted for any other punishable act to a new trial, the prescription shall be computed according to the penalty that must be imposed in the new sentence, when it turns out to be lower than that imposed in the previous one.
Article 112.- Penalties prescribe thus: Article 112.- 1.- Those of presidio, prison and arrest for a time equal to the penalty to be served, plus half of the same.

Article 112.- Penalties prescribe thus: Article 112.- 2.- Those of relegation to penitentiary colony, confinement and expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic, for a time equal to the conviction, plus one-third of the time.

Article 112.- Penalties prescribe thus: Article 112.- 3.- Those of suspension of employment or disqualification for the exercise of profession, industry or art, for a time equal to the sentence, plus one-fourth of the same.

Article 112.- Penalties prescribe thus: Article 112.- 4.- Those of fines in these lapses: those that do not exceed one hundred and forty bolívares, at three months; and those that exceed said limit, at six months; but if they are greater than two thousand five hundred bolívares, they shall prescribe only after one year.

Article 112.- Penalties prescribe thus: Article 112.- 5.- Those of admonition or warning, at six months. It is understood that the penalty to be served, to which numbers 1 and 2 of this article refer, is that which results according to the computation made by the judge of the cause. When the final sentence imposes penalties for more than one crime, the time for prescription shall be increased by one-fourth of that designated in this article for the respective penalty. The time for prescription of the conviction shall begin to run from the day on which the sentence became final or from the breach of the conviction if it has begun to be served; but in the case of new prescription, the time of the served conviction shall be computed for the convict. This prescription shall be interrupted, the time elapsed becoming without effect, in the case that the convict presents himself or is found, and when he commits a new punishable act of the same kind before completing the prescription time, without prejudice to that it may begin to run again. If, by reason of a new penal provision more favorable to the convict, it is necessary to review a condemnatory sentence modifying the imposed penalty, only the penalty that proceeds according to the new legal provision shall be taken into account for the purposes of prescription, which shall have retroactive effect insofar as it benefits the convict. Neither shall the aggravation that should be applied for breach of the respective conviction be taken into account for the purposes of prescription of the penalty.

Article 113.- Any person criminally responsible for some crime or misdemeanor is also civilly responsible. The civil liability arising from the criminal one does not cease because the latter or the penalty is extinguished, but shall last like other civil obligations subject to the rules of civil law. However, the forgiveness of the offended party regarding the criminal action produces the waiver of the civil action if no express reservation has been made. The civil action that proceeds against public officials for acts executed in the exercise of office shall prescribe in ten years.

Article 114.- The exemption from criminal responsibility declared in Article 62 number 4 and Article 65 and Articles 69, 72 and 73 does not include exemption from civil liability, which shall be made effective subject to the following rules: Article 114.- 1.- Those responsible civilly for the acts executed by the insane or dementes and other persons included in Article 62 are their parents or guardians unless they prove that there was no fault or negligence on their part. Failing these or not having assets, the authors of the act shall answer with their own, except the benefit of competition in the manner established by civil law.

Article 114.- The exemption from criminal responsibility declared in Article 62 number 4 and Article 65 and Articles 69, 72 and 73 does not include exemption from civil liability, which shall be made effective subject to the following rules: Article 114.- 2.- Those in whose favor the evil has been provided shall be civilly liable in proportion to the benefit they have obtained. The Courts shall determine, according to their prudent discretion, the proportional quota that each interested party must answer.

Article 114.- The exemption from criminal responsibility declared in Article 62 number 4 and Article 65 and Articles 69, 72 and 73 does not include exemption from civil liability, which shall be made effective subject to the following rules: Article 114.- 3.- Minors under fifteen years who execute the act punished by law shall respond with their own assets, except the benefit of competition. If they have no assets their parents or guardians shall answer, unless it is shown that there was no fault or negligence on their part. The same rule shall be observed with respect to the deaf-mute irresponsible criminally.

Article 114.- The exemption from criminal responsibility declared in Article 62 number 4 and Article 65 and Articles 69, 72 and 73 does not include exemption from civil liability, which shall be made effective subject to the following rules: Article 114.- 4.- In the case of Article 73 those who caused the omission shall be civilly liable and failing them those who have incurred in it, except with respect to the latter the benefit of competition.
Article 115.- Other persons exempt from criminal responsibility are also exempt from civil liability.

Article 116.- Are civilly liable, in default of those who are criminally responsible, innkeepers, owners of houses selling provisions or liquors, and any other persons or companies, for crimes that are committed in the establishments they direct, provided that by their part or that of their dependents there has been infringement of police regulations.

Article 117.- Innkeepers or directors of establishments or boarding houses are also subsidiarily liable for effects stolen from them within the same houses or establishments, or for their indemnification, provided that the lodged had given notice to the same innkeeper, or director or to his deputy, of the deposit of said objects and, moreover, had observed the precautions that said innkeepers, or their substitutes, had made to them about care and vigilance of the same. This responsibility shall not take place in case of robbery with violence made to persons, unless this has been executed by the house's dependents. The same subsidiary responsibility and with the same conditions applies to captains or masters of merchant or transport vessels, for the robbery of the passengers' effects placed on board them, provided that what is said in the previous paragraph about dependents is understood here with respect to subordinate employees of the ship.

Article 118.- Teachers and persons engaged in any trade are also subsidiarily liable for misdemeanors or crimes committed by their pupils, officers or apprentices in the performance of their duty or service. They do not incur this liability if they prove that they could not have prevented the act of their pupils, officers or apprentices.

Article 119.- In case of rebellion there exists solidarity in civil liability derived from the damages and expropriations caused by rebel forces. Such joint liability comprises all who appear in the insurrection with the rank of general, even though it is usurped, and wherever in the Republic the rebel forces have caused the damage. As for rebels who have acted with lower ranks, even though they are usurped, the solidarity exists only for damages and depreciations caused by any rebel force in the respective State, Metropolitan District of Caracas, Territory or Federal Dependency, where they have participated in the rebellion. Only soldiers recruited by the rebels, or who on committing the damage did so in compliance with superior orders, are excepted from civil liability.
Article 120.- The civil liability established in the previous articles comprises: Article 120.- 1.- Restitution.
Article 120.- The civil liability established in the previous articles comprises: Article 120.- 2.- Repair of the caused damage.
Article 120.- The civil liability established in the previous articles comprises: Article 120.- 3.- Indemnification of losses.

Article 121.- Restitution must be made of the same thing, whenever possible, with payment of deterioration or diminutions as regulated by the Court. Restitution must be made even though the thing is in the possession of a third party who possesses it legally, without prejudice to his recourse against whom corresponds. This provision shall not apply when the third party has acquired the thing in the manner and with the requirements established by the laws to make it irreclaimable. If restitution is not possible, the loss shall be repaired by paying its value. Repair shall be made valuing the extent of the damage at the Court's discretion, taking into account the natural price of the thing, whenever possible, and the degree of affection in which the aggrieved has it; and it shall only be required when there is no place for restitution.
