Article 122.- Indemnification of loss shall include not only those caused to the aggrieved but also those inflicted by reason of the crime to his family or to a third party. The Courts shall regulate the amount of this indemnification, in the same terms provided for the repair of damage in the preceding article.

Article 123.- The obligation to restitute, repair the damage or indemnify losses is transmitted to the heirs of the responsible, but up to the amount of the inheritance, provided they accept it under benefit of inventory. The action to recover restitution, repair or indemnification is likewise transmitted to the heirs of the injured party.
Article 124.- If the punishable act is imputable to several persons, they are jointly and severally obligated for the caused damage.
Article 125.- He who for lucrative title participates in the effects of a crime or misdemeanor is obligated to compensation up to the amount in which he participated.

Article 126.- Those convicted as criminally responsible shall also be so in the very sentence, in any case to restitution of the other's thing or its value; in procedural costs and in indemnification of losses, in case the aggrieved constituted himself as accuser and civil party.
Article 127.- In case civil liability must be claimed against a person different from the one who committed the act it may not be enforced except in a separate trial in which he intervenes.

Article 128.- Anyone who, in agreement with a foreign Nation or with external enemies, conspires against the integrity of the territory of the homeland or against its republican institutions, or hostilely acts against it by any means for any of these purposes, shall be punished with presidio of twenty to thirty years.

Article 129.- Anyone who inside or outside Venezuela, without complicity with another Nation, attempts alone against the independence or the integrity of the geographic space of the Republic, shall be punished with presidio of twenty to twenty-six years. The same penalty shall be imposed on anyone who requests, manages or obtains in any way the intervention of a foreign government to overthrow the Venezuelan government.

Article 130.- Anyone who, in time of war of some foreign Nation with Venezuela, takes up arms in rebellion against the legitimate Government of the Republic and does not lay them down at the first admonition of the public authority, shall be punished with presidio of eighteen to twenty-five years.

Article 131.- Anyone who, inside or outside the national territory, when Venezuela is threatened by foreign war, favors, facilitates or aids directly or indirectly, with internal revolts, or by means of acts of public order disturbance, the aims, plans or purposes of the foreign enemies and does not depart from those revolts, nor withdraws from said acts at the first admonition of the public authority or by his own or spontaneous deliberation, shall be punished with presidio of twelve to twenty-four years.

Article 132.- Anyone who, inside or outside the national territory, conspires to destroy the political republican form that the Nation has given itself shall be punished with presidio of eight to sixteen years. The same penalty shall be incurred by the Venezuelan who solicits foreign intervention in Venezuela's internal political affairs, or asks for its assistance to disturb the Republic's peace or who before its officials, or by publications in the foreign press, incites civil war in the Republic or defames its President or insults the diplomatic Representative or the consular officials of Venezuela, because of their functions, in the country where the act is committed.

Article 133.- Anyone who in the manner expressed in Article 128 obstructs or impedes, enervates or diminishes the action of the National Government or of the States for national defense, without attending to nor respecting the admonitions of the public authority, shall be punished with presidio of five to ten years.

Article 134.- Anyone who improperly and to the Republic's detriment has revealed political or military secrets concerning Venezuela's security, whether by communicating or publishing documents, data, drawings, plans or other information relating to material, fortifications or military operations, or by making their knowledge public in another manner, shall be punished with presidio of seven to ten years. The penalty shall be eight to twelve years if the secrets have been revealed to a Nation at war with Venezuela or to agents of that Nation, or also if the act has caused disturbance of friendly relations of the Republic with another government. The penalty shall be increased by one-third if the guilty had drawings, plans or documents, or had acquired knowledge of the secrets by reason of his employment, public office or functions. The penalty shall also be increased in the same manner if by fraud, theft or violence the acquisition of such knowledge or of those objects had been made.

Article 135.- Anyone who has obtained the revelation of the secrets or has procured them by any illegitimate means shall be punished with the penalties established in the previous article, and in accordance with the distinctions made therein.

Article 136.- If the secrets specified in Article 134 have been divulged as a result of negligence or imprudence of those who, because of their employment, were in possession of the drawings, plans or documents, or had knowledge of the secrets, the guilty shall be punished with prison of forty-five days to nine months.

Article 137.- Anyone who improperly has lifted the plans of fortifications, warships or aircraft, establishments, roads or military works, or who for that purpose had clandestinely or by deceit introduced himself into places prohibited to public access by the military authority, shall be punished with prison of three to fifteen months. The mere fact of entering deceitfully or clandestinely into the mentioned places merits a prison penalty that may be from one to three months.

Article 138.- The individual entrusted by the Government of the Republic to handle Venezuela's business with a foreign Government who betrays his mandate harming public interests shall be punished with presidio of six to twelve years.

Article 139.- The penalties determined by Articles 128 and following shall also apply if the crime has been committed to the detriment of a Nation allied with Venezuela for war and in the course thereof.

Article 140.- The Venezuelan or foreigner resident in the Republic who in time of war facilitates directly or indirectly to the enemy Nation or its agents money, food supplies or war elements that may be used to the detriment of Venezuela, shall be punished with prison of one to five years.

Article 141.- Anyone who out of contempt tears away, breaks or destroys in a public or publicly open place the national flag or other emblem of the Republic shall be punished with prison of two months to one year. If this crime is committed when the Republic is engaged in a foreign war, the prison shall be thirteen months to two years.
Article 142.- The Venezuelan who accepts honors, pensions or other gifts from any Nation at war with Venezuela shall be punished with presidio of six to twelve years.

Article 143.- Public employees who, without fulfilling the requirement imposed in ordinal 13 of Article 187 of the Constitution of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, accept gifts, posts, honors and rewards from foreign Nations, shall incur a fine of one hundred to one thousand bolívares.

Article 144.- Shall be punished with presidio of twelve to twenty-four years: Article 144.- 1.- Those who publicly rise, in hostile attitude, against the legitimately constituted or elected Government, to depose it or prevent it from taking possession of command.

Article 144.- Shall be punished with presidio of twelve to twenty-four years: Article 144.- 2.- Those who, without the object of changing the republican political form that the Nation has given itself, conspire or rise to violently change the Constitution of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. In half of the referred penalty shall incur those who commit the acts referred to in the previous numbers with respect to the Governors of the States, the Legislative Councils of the States and the Constitutions of the States; and in a third of said penalty, those committed against Mayors of Municipalities.
Article 144.- Shall be punished with presidio of twelve to twenty-four years: Article 144.- 3.- Those who promote civil war between the Republic and the States or among them.

Article 145.- Anyone who, without authorization of the National Government, levies or arms Venezuelans or foreigners in the geographic space of the Republic to put them at the service of another Nation shall be punished with arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for six months to two years. The penalty shall be one to three years if among the recruited there is one who belongs to the Army.

Article 146.- Anyone who executes any act that has the object of making inhabitants of the Republic take up arms against the Public Powers of the Nation shall be punished with presidio of three to six years. When the acts referred to in this article are committed with respect to any of the States of the Republic, the penalties established shall be reduced to half of those indicated.

Article 147.- He who, without being authorized by law nor by order of the Government, takes command of troops, garrisons, fortresses, military posts, ports, towns or warships or aircraft, shall be punished with arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for thirty months to five years.

Article 148.- He who offends verbally or in writing, or in any other manner disrespects the President of the Republic or whoever is acting in his place, shall be punished with prison of six to thirty months if the offense is grave and with half of that penalty if mild. The penalty shall be increased by one-third if the offense was made publicly. Parágrafo Único.- If the offense is against the President of either of the Legislative Chambers or the President of the Supreme Court of Justice, the penalty shall be four months to two years when the offense is grave and half of that penalty when it is mild.

Article 149.- When the acts specified in the preceding article are committed against the Governor of any of the States, or against the Ministers of the Cabinet, Executive Vice President of the Republic, Mayor of the Metropolitan District of Caracas, Magistrates of the Supreme Court of Justice, Presidents of the Legislative Councils of the States and Superior Judges, or against the person acting in their place, the penalty indicated in said article shall be reduced to half, and to one third if it concerns Mayors of Municipalities.

Article 150.- Anyone who vilifies publicly the National Assembly, the Supreme Court of Justice or the Cabinet or Council of Ministers, as well as any of the Legislative Councils of the States or some of the Superior Courts, shall be punished with prison of fifteen days to ten months. In half of said penalty shall those incur who commit the acts referred to in this article with respect to Municipal Councils. The penalty shall be proportionally increased by one-half if the offense was committed while the mentioned Corporations were exercising their official functions.
Article 151.- It corresponds to the Courts of Justice to determine the gravity or leniency of the offenses referred to in Articles 148, 149 and 150.

Article 152.- Prosecution for the acts referred to in the preceding articles shall not take place except by request of the offended person or body, made through the Representative of the Public Ministry, before the competent Judge.

Article 153.- Venezuelans or foreigners who commit acts of piracy shall be punished with presidio of ten to fifteen years. This crime is incurred by those who commanding or crewing a vessel not belonging to the Navy of any Nation, nor provided with a duly issued letter of marque, or being part of an armed body aboard it, attack vessels or commit depredations on them or on the coastal places where they land, or declare themselves in rebellion against the Government of the Republic.

Article 154.- Venezuelans or foreigners who in Venezuela recruit people or collect arms, form juntas or prepare expeditions or leave the geographic space of the Republic in hostile attitude to attack or invade that of a friendly or neutral Nation shall be punished with imprisonment of three to six years in Fortress or Political Prison. In the same penalty determined in this article incur Venezuelans or foreigners who in Venezuela build ships, arm them for war or increase their forces or stores, their crew or the number of their sailors to make war on a nation with which the Republic is at peace.

Article 155.- The penalties fixed in the preceding article shall be increased by one-third if the hostile acts against the friendly or neutral Nation have exposed Venezuela to the danger of international war or have caused the rupture of friendly relations of the Government of the Republic with that Nation. The said penalties shall be doubled if as a consequence of the mentioned acts war has been declared on the Republic.

Article 156.- They incur penalty of arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for one to four years: Article 156.- 1.- Venezuelans or foreigners who, during a war of Venezuela against another Nation, breach truces or armistices or the principles observed by civilized peoples in war, such as respect due to prisoners, non-combatants, the white flag, to parliaments, to the Red Cross and other similar cases, without prejudice to what military laws provide, which shall apply specially in all that they order on this respect.

Article 156.- They incur penalty of arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for one to four years: Article 156.- 2.- Venezuelans or foreigners who, with acts of hostility against one of the belligerents, committed within the geographic space of the Republic, breach its neutrality in case of war between foreign nations.

Article 156.- They incur penalty of arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for one to four years: Article 156.- 3.- Venezuelans or foreigners who violate the Conventions or Treaties celebrated by the Republic, in a manner that compromises the responsibility of the same.

Article 157.- Venezuelans or foreigners who, against the prohibition of laws, decrees or commands of the authorities of a friendly or neutral Nation, enter it by force or clandestinely departing from Venezuela, shall be punished with expulsion from the geographic space of the Republic for two to five years.

Article 158.- Anyone who commits a crime in the geographic space of the Republic against the Head or First Magistrate of a foreign Nation shall incur in the penalty applicable to the committed act with an increase of one-sixth to one-third. If it were an act against the life, security or personal freedom of said personage, the aggravation of the penalty, in accordance with the foregoing provision, may not be less than three years of prison. In other cases the corporal penalty may not be less than sixty days, nor the pecuniary penalty less than two hundred and fifty bolívares. If the punishable act is one that does not permit ex officio procedure, the trial shall take place only at the instance of the foreign Government.

Article 159.- Anyone who by an act of contempt to a foreign Power tears away, breaks or destroys the flag or any other emblem of said Nation shall be punished with arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for one to six months. Prosecution shall not take place except at the instance of the foreign Government.

Article 160.- In cases of crimes committed against Representatives of foreign Powers accredited to the Government of Venezuela, by reason of their functions, the penalties established for the same acts committed against Venezuelan public officials, by reason of their functions, shall apply. If it is a question of offenses committed, prosecution may not take place except through the corresponding instance of the aggrieved party.

Article 161.- Anyone who to commit any of the crimes provided in Articles 131, 144 and 146 uses armed force or exerts in it superior command or special attributions shall be punished with arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for five to seven years.

Article 162.- Anyone who, outside the cases provided in Article 84, voluntarily provides shelter or assistance, facilitates recourse to the armed force referred to in the preceding article, or in some way favors its operations, shall be punished with arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for three to thirty months.

Article 163.- Exempted from the penalty signaled to the acts provided in the two preceding articles are: Article 163.- 1.- Those who before any measure of authority or of the public force, or immediately after, have dissolved the armed gathering or prevented it from committing the crime for which it had assembled.

Article 163.- Exempted from the penalty signaled to the acts provided in the two preceding articles are: Article 163.- 2.- Those who not having participated in the formation or command of the armed gathering, consent before or immediately after said measure, to withdraw without resistance delivering or abandoning their arms.
Article 163.- Exempted from the penalty signaled to the acts provided in the two preceding articles are: Article 163.- 3.- Soldiers recruited by the rebel forces.

Article 164.- When several persons have agreed or attempted, by determined means, to commit any of the crimes provided in Articles 128, 144 and 146 and the first part of Article 158, each of them shall be punished as follows: Article 164.- 1.- In the cases of Article 128, with presidio of six to twelve years.

Article 164.- When several persons have agreed or attempted, by determined means, to commit any of the crimes provided in Articles 128, 144 and 146 and the first part of Article 158, each of them shall be punished as follows: Article 164.- 2.- In the case of Article 144, with presidio of three to six years and in the case of Article 146, with presidio of six months to one year.

Article 164.- When several persons have agreed or attempted, by determined means, to commit any of the crimes provided in Articles 128, 144 and 146 and the first part of Article 158, each of them shall be punished as follows: Article 164.- 3.- In the case of the first paragraph of Article 158, with prison of one to three years. They shall be exempt from any penalty those who withdraw from the plot before the execution of the crime has begun and before the corresponding judicial procedure is initiated. He who, outside the cases provided in Articles 83 and 84, publicly incites to commit any of the crimes provided in Articles 128, 144 and 146, shall be punished, only for that act, with presidio of one to three years in the case of Article 128 and with prison for equal time in the cases of the other two articles.

Article 165.- When in the course of the execution of any of the crimes provided in this Title, the accused commits another crime that merits corporal penalty greater than thirty months, the penalty resulting from application of Title VIII of Book One shall be increased by one-sixth. If the new crime committed were homicide or injuries, the following rules shall be followed: Article 165.- 1.- If such crimes were committed by rebel forces in action of war, the penalty normally indicated for their punishment shall be increased by one half.

Article 165.- 2.- Homicides and injuries committed by rebel forces not in action of war shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of Chapters I, II and III, Title IX Book Second of this Code.
Article 165.- 3.- Homicides and injuries committed by Government forces shall be punished according to the Military Code.

Article 166.- The provision of the preceding article shall also apply to him who, to commit any of the crimes provided in this Title, invades any public or private building or seizes by violence or deceit, arms, munitions or provisions existing in the place of sale or deposit, even though the act merits a corporal penalty less than thirty months.

Article 167.- Anyone who, by means of violence, threats or riots, prevents or paralyzes, totally or partially, the exercise of any political rights, provided that the act is not foreseen by a special legal provision, shall be punished with arrest in Fortress or Political Prison for fifteen days to fifteen months. If the guilty party is a public official and has committed the crime with abuse of his functions, the arrest shall be six to thirty months.

Article 168.- He who by offending any lawfully established or that is established in the Republic cult, prevents or disturbs the exercise of religious functions or ceremonies, shall be punished with arrest from five to forty-five days. If the act is accompanied by threats, violence, outrages or demonstrations of contempt, the arrest shall be for forty-five days to fifteen months.

Article 169.- He who out of hostility against any established or to be established cult in the Republic vilifies the person who professes it, shall be punished, by accusation of the aggrieved party, with prison of one to six months.

Article 170.- He who out of contempt to an established or to be established cult in the Republic destroys, mistreats or defaces in any way, in a public place, the things destined to said cult; and also he who violates or vilifies any of its ministers, shall be punished with prison of forty-five days to fifteen months. If it is another crime committed against the minister of a cult in exercise of his functions or because of these, the penalty fixed for said crime shall be increased by one-sixth.

Article 171.- Anyone who in places intended for worship, or in cemeteries, deteriorates, defaces or disfigures monuments, paintings, stones, tombstones, inscriptions or tumuli, shall be punished with arrest of one to six months or fine of one hundred fifty to one thousand five hundred bolívares.

Article 172.- Anyone who commits acts of profanation on the corpse or the ashes of a person and anyone who with an injurious or simply illicit purpose fraudulently takes away the whole or part of the spoils or remains themselves, or in some way violates a tumulus or funerary urn, shall be punished with prison of six months to three years.

Article 173.- Anyone who outside the cases before indicated, profanes totally or partially the corpse of some person, exhumes it, steals it or takes possession of its remains, shall be punished with prison of three to fifteen months. If the act has been committed by the administrator or caretaker of a cemetery or burial place, or by a person to whom the custody of the corpse or remains had been entrusted, the penalty shall be increased by one-third in the first case, and by one-fourth in the second.

Article 174.- Anyone who reduces to slavery some person or subjects them to an analogous condition shall be punished with presidio of six to twelve years. The same penalty shall be incurred by those who intervene in the slave trade.

Article 175.- Anyone who illegitimately has deprived someone of their personal freedom shall be punished with prison of fifteen days to thirty months. If the guilty party to commit the crime or during its commission made use of threats, cruelty or deceit, or if he committed it out of spirit of vengeance or profit, or with the pretense of religion, or if he kidnapped the person to put him at the military service of a foreign country, the prison shall be two to four years. If the crime has been committed against an ascendant or spouse, against any member of the National Assembly; of the Legislative Councils of the States, against any Magistrate of the Supreme Court of Justice or against any other Public Magistrate, by reason of their functions, or if from the act some serious harm has resulted for the person, health or goods of the aggrieved, the prison penalty shall be thirty months to seven years. If the guilty party, spontaneously, has freed the person before any prosecution procedure, without having achieved the end he proposed nor having caused any harm to him, the penalty shall be fifteen months to three and a half years.

Article 176.- Anyone who, without authority or right for it, by means of threats, violence or other illegitimate coercion, forces a person to execute an act that the Law does not oblige him to or to tolerate it or prevents him from executing some that is not prohibited to him by the same, shall be punished with prison of fifteen days to thirty months. If the act has been with abuse of public authority, or against some ascendant or spouse, or against some public official by reason of their functions, or if from the act some serious harm has resulted for the person, health or goods of the aggrieved, the penalty shall be prison of thirty months to five years. Whoever, outside the indicated cases and others provided by law, threatens someone with causing him serious and unjust harm, shall be punished with relegation to penitentiary colony for a time of one to ten months or arrest of fifteen days to three months, prior complaint of the threatened.

Article 177.- The public official who with abuse of his functions or breaching the conditions or formalities prescribed by law deprives someone of liberty shall be punished with prison of forty-five days to three and a half years; and if the crime has been committed with some of the circumstances indicated in the first and second paragraphs of the previous article, the prison shall be three to five years. In the case provided in the last paragraph of Article 175, the penalty shall be ten months to two and a half years.

Article 178.- Anyone who with an object other than to satisfy his own passions, to contract marriage or to obtain some gain has abducted a person under fifteen years of age, even with his consent, from his parents, guardians or other custodians even temporarily, shall be punished with prison of six months to two years; and the same penalty shall be imposed on him who unduly kidnaps said person although the latter gives consent. If the crime has been committed without the acquiescence of the abducted or kidnapped person, or if he does not have twelve years of age, the provisions and penalties specified in the preceding articles shall be applied as appropriate.
Article 179.- The public official who, abusing his functions, orders or executes the search or body search of a person shall be punished with prison of one to five months.

Article 180.- The public official who, ruling a penitentiary establishment or a penal establishment, receives as prisoner or detainee some person without written order of the competent authority, or refuses to obey a written order of release emanating from the same authority, shall be punished with prison of four to six months.

Article 181.- Any competent public official who, being aware of a detention, omits, delays or refuses to take measures to make it cease or to denounce it to the authority that must provide therefor shall be punished with a fine of one hundred to one thousand bolívares.

Article 181-A.- The public authority, whether civil or military, or any person at the service of the State who illegitimately deprives a person of their liberty, and refuses to recognize the detention or to give information about the destination or situation of the disappeared person, impeding the exercise of their constitutional and legal rights and guarantees, shall be punished with presidio of fifteen to twenty-five years. With the same penalty shall be punished members or integrants of groups or associations with terrorist, insurgent or subversive ends, who acting as members or collaborators of such groups or associations, forcibly make a person disappear, by kidnapping or abduction. Whoever acts as accomplice or coverer-up of this crime shall be sanctioned with presidio of twelve to eighteen years. The crime established in this article shall be considered continued while the victim's destination or location is not established. No order or instruction of a public authority, whether civil, military or of another kind, nor a state of emergency, exception or restriction of guarantees may be invoked to justify the forced disappearance. The criminal action arising from that crime and its penalty shall be imprescriptible, and those responsible for its commission may not enjoy any benefit, including pardon and amnesty. If those who having participated in acts that constitute forced disappearances contribute to the victim's reappearance alive or voluntarily give information that allows clarifying forced disappearance cases, the penalty established in this article may be reduced for them by two-thirds.

Article 182.- Any public official in charge of custody or conduct of a detained or convicted person who commits arbitrary acts against him or subjects him to acts not authorized by the regulations of the case shall be punished with prison of fifteen days to twenty months. And the public official who, invested, by reason of his functions, of authority over said person, executes with him some of the indicated acts shall incur the same penalty. Sufferings, affronts to human dignity, vexations, tortures or physical or moral outrages committed against a detained person by his guardians or jailers, or by the one who gave the order to execute them, in contravention of the individual rights recognized in ordinal 3° of Article 60 of the Constitution, shall be punished with prison of three to six years.

Article 183.- When to commit any of the crimes provided in the previous articles the public official had proceeded to satisfy some private interest, the penalties shall be the following: in the case of Article 181, instead of the penalty of fine, prison of three to forty-five days shall be imposed; and in the other cases the corresponding penalty shall be increased by one-sixth.

Article 184.- Anyone who arbitrarily, clandestinely or fraudulently introduces himself or sets up in another's domicile, or in its dependencies, against the will of who has the right to occupy it, shall be punished with prison of fifteen days to fifteen months. If the crime has been committed at night or with violence to persons, or with arms, or with the concurrence of several individuals, the prison shall be six to thirty months. Prosecution shall not take place except by accusation of the aggrieved party.

Article 185.- The public official who with abuse of his functions or failing the conditions or formalities established by law enters another's domicile or its dependencies shall be punished with prison of forty-five days to eighteen months. If the act is accompanied by searches or some other arbitrary act, the prison shall be six to thirty months. If it is established that the guilty acted for cause of some private interest, the penalties shall be increased by one-sixth.

Article 186.- He who improperly opens some letter, telegram or sealed packet not addressed to him, or who improperly takes it to know its content, even though it is not sealed, belonging to another, shall be punished with arrest of eight to twenty days. If, divulging the content, the guilty has caused some harm, the penalty shall be fifteen days to ten months of arrest.

Article 187.- Anyone who has improperly suppressed some epistolary or telegraphic correspondence that does not belong to him, even if, being sealed, he has not opened it, shall be punished with arrest of one to six months. If the act has caused some harm, the arrest may not be less than forty-five days.

Article 188.- Anyone who having in his possession an epistolary or telegraphic correspondence not intended for publicity makes it unduly public, even though it has been addressed to him, provided that the act may cause some harm, shall be punished with fine of fifty to one thousand bolívares.

Article 189.- He who being employed in the postal or telegraph service, with abuse of his office appropriates some letter, telegram, communication or any other correspondence not sealed, or, being sealed, opens it to know its content, or retains it or reveals its existence or content to another person other than the title of its destination, shall be punished with prison of fifteen days to fifteen months. The same penalty shall be imposed on him who in service and with abuse of the mentioned offices suppresses any of said correspondences. If any of the acts provided in this article causes some harm, the prison penalty shall be of three months to two years.

Article 190.- He who having by reason of his state, functions, profession, art or office, knowledge of some secret whose divulgation may cause some harm, reveals it, nevertheless, without just cause, shall be punished with prison of five to thirty days.

Article 191.- Regarding the crimes provided in Articles 186, 187, 188 and 190, whenever the act has not caused some harm that interests public order, prosecution shall not take place except by accusation of the aggrieved party.
Article 192.- Anyone who, by means of violence or threats, restricts or suppresses in any way the liberty of commerce or industry shall be punished with prison of one to ten months.

Article 193.- Whoever by means of violence causes or makes continue a cessation or suspension of work, with the object of imposing on workers, employers or entrepreneurs some decrease or increase of wages or also agreements different from those agreed, shall be punished with arrest of one to ten months.
Article 194.- The chiefs or promoters of the acts provided in the preceding articles shall be punished with penalty of forty-five days to eighteen months.

Article 195.- Any public official who steals the monies or other movable objects of which he is in charge by virtue of his functions shall be punished with presidio of three to ten years. If the harm is not serious, or if it were entirely repaired before the guilty is brought to trial, prison of three to twenty-one months shall be imposed.

Article 196.- Any official who, abusing his functions, compels some person to give or promise to him or to a third party some sum of money or other undue gain or gift, shall be punished with prison of eighteen months to five years. If the sum or thing unduly given or promised is of little value, prison shall be for three to twenty-one months.

Article 197.- Any official who, abusing his functions, induces some person to commit any of the acts referred to in the previous article shall be punished with prison of two to sixteen months. If the official receiving what was not due to him does nothing more than take advantage of the other's error, prison shall be three to fifteen months. If the sum or thing unduly given or promised were of little value, the prison, in the first case, shall be of one to ten months; and in the second, of fifteen days to six months.

Article 198.- Any official who, for his own or another's account, receives for some act of his functions, in money or other thing, some retribution that is not due to him or whose promise he accepts, shall be punished with prison of one to two months.

Article 199.- Any public official who by delaying or omitting some act of his functions or by performing some that is contrary to the very duty that they impose, receives, or has promised to him, money or other utility, either by himself or through another person, shall be punished with presidio of three to five years. The presidio shall be four to eight years if the act committed has had the effect of: Article 199.- 1.- Conferring public employments, subsidies, pensions or honors, or causing contracts to be agreed in which the administration to which the official belongs is interested.

Article 199.- 2.- Favoring or causing some prejudice or damage to one of the parties in a civil trial, or to the guilty in a criminal process. If from the act a condemnatory sentence restrictive of individual liberty results, exceeding six months, the presidio shall be three to ten years.

Article 200.- Anyone who, without achieving his object, endeavors to persuade or induce some public official to commit any of the crimes provided in the preceding articles shall be punished, when the inducement is with the object that the official incurs in the crime provided by Article 198, with fine of one hundred fifty to one thousand bolívares; and if it is with the aim that he incurs in that indicated by Article 199, with the penalties there established, but reduced by one-half.
Article 201.- Those who manage to corrupt public officials, making them commit any of the crimes provided in this Chapter, shall incur the same penalties as the bribed employees.
Article 202.- When the bribe mediates in a criminal cause in favor of the convict, by his spouse or by some ascendant, descendant or sibling, the penalty shall be reduced that should...

Article 200.- Whoever, without achieving his objective, endeavors to persuade or induce any public official to commit any of the crimes provided in the preceding articles shall be punished, when the inducement is with the object that the official incur in the offense provided by Article 198, with a fine of one hundred fifty to one thousand bolívares; and if it is with the purpose that he incur in the offense indicated by Article 199, with the penalties established there, but reduced by half.
Article 201.- Those who manage to corrupt public officials, causing them to commit any of the crimes provided in this Chapter, shall incur the same penalties as the bribed employees.

Article 202.- When the bribery intervenes in a criminal case in favor of the accused, by his spouse or by any ascendant, descendant or sibling, the penalty that should be imposed on the briber, considering all the circumstances, shall be reduced by two thirds.
Article 203.- In the cases provided in the preceding articles, the money or object given shall be confiscated.

Article 204.- Any public official who, abusing his functions, orders or executes to the detriment of any person any arbitrary act that is not specially provided as a crime or offense by a provision of law, shall be punished with imprisonment of fifteen days to one year, and if he acts for a private interest, the penalty shall be increased by one sixth.
Article 204.- Any public official who, in the exercise of his functions, incites any person to disobey the laws or the measures taken by the authority shall be punished with the same penalty.

Article 205.- Any public official who for himself, through an intermediary person, or by simulated acts obtains some personal utility in any of the acts of the public administration in which he exercises his functions, shall be punished with imprisonment of six months to five years.

Article 206.- Any public official who communicates or publishes the documents or facts of which he is aware or in possession by reason of his functions and which he must keep secret, shall be punished with arrest of three to fifteen months, and likewise any public official who in any way favors the dissemination of those.

Article 207.- Any public official who under any pretext, even that of silence, obscurity, contradiction or insufficiency of the law, omits or refuses to perform any act of his office, shall be punished with a fine of fifty to one thousand five hundred bolívares.
Article 207.- If the offense has been committed by at least three public officials, and with prior understanding for that purpose, the fine shall be one hundred to two thousand bolívares.

Article 207.- If the public official is of the judicial branch, he shall be deemed guilty of the omission or excuse whenever the conditions required by law concur to attempt against him the remedy of complaint, in order to make effective civil liability.

Article 208.- Any public official who having acquired, in the exercise of his functions, knowledge resulting from those same functions, of some punishable fact for which the law orders proceedings ex officio and omits or unduly delays to report it to the competent authority, shall be punished with a fine of fifty to one thousand bolívares.

Article 209.- Public officials who, numbering three or more and by prior agreement, improperly abandon their functions, shall be punished with a fine of two hundred to one thousand bolívares and with suspension from the position for a time of one or two years.
Article 209.- The same penalty shall be applied to any public official who abandons his functions to prevent the dispatch of any matter or to cause any other detriment to the public service.

Article 210.- The minister of any cult who, in the exercise of his functions, treats with public contempt or vilification the institutions, the laws of the republic or the acts of the authority, shall be punished with arrest of one to six months.

Article 211.- The minister of any cult who, taking advantage of his character, excites contempt and disobedience of the institutions, laws or provisions of the authority, or of the duties inherent to a public office, shall be punished with arrest in Fortaleza or Political Prison for a time of forty-five days to one year. If the act has been committed publicly, the arrest may be imposed for up to two years.

Article 211.- The minister of any cult who, taking advantage of his character, constrains, induces or persuades any person to perform acts or make statements contrary to the laws or to the rights acquired by virtue of them shall be punished with the same penalties.

Article 212.- Clerics who breach the provisions of the law on ecclesiastical patronage, or who in any other way, by virtue of functions, jurisdiction or ecclesiastical duties, usurp civil jurisdiction, or fail to recognize the sovereignty of the Nation, or disobey the laws of the Republic and the resolutions and prohibitions that, consequently, the Government issues and establishes, shall incur the penalty of expulsion from the geographical space of the Republic for a time of one to three years.
Article 212.- The Supreme Court of Justice may commute the penalty referred to in the previous article into confinement for an equal time:
Article 212.- 1.- To a place of another diocese, if the one who committed the infraction is an Archbishop, Bishop, Chapter, Vicar Capitular or Provisor.

Article 212.- 2.- To a District, Parish or place of the same diocese, different from that of the jurisdiction or residence of the author of the infraction, if he is a Vicar Foráneo, Parish Priest or other cleric.

Article 213.- When the minister of any cult, taking advantage of his character, commits any other crime not provided in the preceding articles, the penalty indicated for the committed crime shall be increased by one sixth to one third, unless his aforementioned quality of minister has already been taken into account by the law.

Article 214.- Whoever improperly assumes or exercises civil or military public functions shall be punished with imprisonment of two to six months, and the same penalty shall be incurred by any public official who continues to exercise them after having been legally replaced or the position eliminated.
Article 214.- It may be ordered that, at the expense of the convicted person, the sentence be published in extract in some newspaper of the place that the Judge will indicate.

Article 215.- Whoever unlawfully and publicly uses habit, insignia or uniforms of the clerical or military state, of a public office or of a scientific institute, and who arrogates academic or military degrees, or decorations or attributes to himself the quality of professor and publicly exercises acts proper to a faculty that for that purpose requires an official title, shall be punished with a fine of fifty to one thousand bolívares.
Article 215.- The Judge may order in these cases that the sentence be published, as provided in the final part of the previous article.

Article 216.- Whoever uses violence or threat against the person of any member of the National Assembly, or against a public official, with the object of constraining him to do or omit any act of his functions, shall be punished with imprisonment of forty-five days to fifteen months.

Article 216.- Whoever uses violence or threat against the person of any member of the National Assembly, or against a public official, with the object of constraining him to do or omit any act of his functions, if the act has been committed with weapons, shall be punished with imprisonment of six months to three years.

Article 216.- Whoever uses violence or threat against the person of any member of the National Assembly, or against a public official, with the object of constraining him to do or omit any act of his functions, if the act has been committed in a meeting of more than five persons, concerted for the purpose, even if they were not armed, shall be punished with imprisonment of two to five years.

Article 217.- Whoever uses violence or threat to prevent or disturb the meetings or functioning of legitimately constituted bodies, judicial, political, electoral or administrative, or of their representatives or of another authority or public institutes, or to influence their deliberations, shall be punished with the penalties established in the preceding article.

Article 218.- Whoever is part of an association of ten or more persons that aim to commit, by means of violence or threat, the act provided in the preceding article, shall be punished with imprisonment of one month to two years.
Article 218.- If the act is committed with weapons, the imprisonment shall be three months to three years.
Article 218.- If at the first requirement of the authority the association dissolves, the persons who had been part of it shall not incur any criminal liability for the act provided in this article.

Article 219.- Whoever uses violence or threat to oppose any public official in the fulfillment of his official duties, or the individuals he has called to support him, shall be punished with imprisonment of one month to two years.

Article 219.- Whoever uses violence or threat to oppose any public official in the fulfillment of his official duties, or the individuals he has called to support him, if the act was committed with bladed or firearms, imprisonment shall be three months to two years.

Article 219.- Whoever uses violence or threat to oppose any public official in the fulfillment of his official duties, or the individuals he has called to support him, if the act was committed with weapons of any kind, in a meeting of five or more persons, or in a meeting of more than ten persons without weapons and by virtue of some concerted plan, imprisonment shall be one to five years.

Article 219.- If the act aimed to prevent the capture of its author or of any of his close relatives, the penalty shall be imprisonment of one to ten months, or confinement not less than three months, in the case of the first paragraph of this article.

Article 219.- If the act aimed to prevent the capture of its author or of any of his close relatives, in the case of the first number the penalty of imprisonment of two to twenty months shall be applied, and in the case of the second number, of six to thirty months.

Article 219.- 3.- If the resistance has been made without bladed or firearms to Police Agents, merely eluding an arrest that the Agents themselves tried to carry out for simple offenses in which the offender had incurred, the penalty shall be only one to six months of arrest.
Article 220.- For the purposes of criminal law, close relatives are considered: the spouse, ascendants and descendants, uncles and nephews, siblings and in-laws in the same degree.
Article 221.- The penalties provided in the preceding articles shall not be applied if the public official provoked the act by exceeding the limits of his powers with arbitrary acts.
Article 222.- The leaders or promoters of the acts provided in the preceding articles shall be applied the same penalties, increased by one sixth to one third.

Article 223.- Whoever verbally or by act offends in any way the honor, reputation or decorum of a member of the National Assembly, or of any public official, shall be punished as follows, if the act occurred in his presence and on occasion of his functions:
Article 223.- 1.- If the offense was directed against any agent of the public force, imprisonment of one to three months.
Article 223.- 2.- If the offense was directed against a member of the National Assembly or some public official, imprisonment of one month to one year, according to the category of such persons.
Article 224.- If the act provided in the preceding article has been accompanied by violence or threat, it shall be punished with imprisonment of three to eighteen months.

Article 224.- Whoever in any other way and outside the cases provided in the previous Chapter uses violence or threat against a member of the National Assembly or any public official, if the act takes place on the occasion of the offended person's functions, shall be punished with the same penalties.

Article 225.- When any of the acts provided in the preceding articles has been committed against any public official, not because of his functions but at the very moment of exercising them, the same penalties shall be applied reduced by one third to one half.

Article 226.- Whoever verbally or by act offends in any way the honor, reputation, decorum or dignity of any judicial, political or administrative body, if the crime has been committed in the act of being constituted, or of any magistrate in audience, shall be punished with imprisonment of three months to two years.
Article 226.- If the culpable has used violence or threats, the imprisonment shall be six months to three years.

Article 226.- Prosecution shall only proceed upon request of the offended body. If the crime has been committed against bodies not assembled, prosecution shall only proceed upon request of the members who preside them.
Article 226.- This request shall be addressed to the Representative of the Public Prosecutor's Office so that he promotes what is appropriate.

Article 227.- In the cases provided in the preceding articles, no proof about the truth nor even about the notoriety of the facts or defects imputed to the offended party shall be admitted from the culpable.
Article 228.- The provisions established in the preceding articles shall not apply if the public official gave rise to the act by exceeding with arbitrary acts the limits of his attributions.

Article 229.- In all other cases not provided by a special provision of law, whoever commits any crime against a member of the National Assembly or any public official, by reason of their functions, shall incur the penalty established for the committed crime, plus an increase of one sixth to one third.

Article 230.- Whoever in any way has violated the seals placed by virtue of a provision of law or an order of the authority, to ensure the preservation or identity of some thing, shall be punished with imprisonment of two to eighteen months.

Article 230.- If the culpable is the same public official who ordered or executed the imposition of the seals, or the one who has custody or deposit of the sealed thing, the penalty shall be imprisonment of fifteen to thirty months.
Article 230.- If the crime has been committed by negligence or imprudence of the public official or depositary, he shall be punished with a fine of one hundred to one thousand bolívares.

Article 231.- Whoever has stolen, suppressed, destroyed or altered any instrument, or effect of some punishable fact, act or document placed in an office in charge of some public official by reason of his position, shall be punished with imprisonment of six to thirty months.

Article 231.- If the culpable is the same public official who by reason of his functions had custody of the instruments or effects expressed or of the acts or documents, the penalty shall be imprisonment for a time of one to four years.

Article 231.- If the damage caused has been slight or if the culpable has fully restored the act or the document without having had benefit, and before the procedural diligences, the penalty shall be, in the case of the first part of this article, imprisonment for a time of three to eighteen months, and in the case of the preceding paragraph, imprisonment for six months to two years.

Article 232.- Whoever has stolen or converted to his own or another's benefit or has refused to deliver to the rightful person the objects given as pledge or placed in sequestration that had been entrusted to his custody, shall be punished with imprisonment of six to thirty months.
Article 232.- If the culpable is the owner himself of the pledged or seized object, the penalty shall be imprisonment of one to six months.
Article 232.- If the crime has been committed by negligence or imprudence of the depositary, he shall be punished with a fine of twenty-five to five hundred bolívares.

Article 232.- If the value of the object is of little importance or if the culpable restores the thing or pays the price before the judicial procedure, the penalty shall be reduced by one sixth to one third.

Article 233.- Whoever, giving himself out as having influential relations with some public official, or member of the National Assembly, receives or has given or promised to him, for himself or for another, money or other advantages, either as encouragement or reward for his mediation with that person, or under pretext of buying favors or remunerating benefits, shall be punished with imprisonment of six to thirty months.

Article 234.- Whoever, with contempt of his obligations, causes the lack of provisions or other necessary effects in an establishment or public service, or that are destined to the relief of some public calamity, shall be punished with imprisonment of three to eighteen months.
Article 234.- If the failure to comply is only by negligence, the culpable shall be punished with imprisonment of one to six months.
Article 235.- Whoever commits fraud regarding the species, quality or quantity of the effects indicated in the preceding article, shall be punished with imprisonment of three to thirty months.
Article 235.- Whenever the frauds referred to aim at another kind of supplies destined to an establishment or public service, the prison penalty shall be two months to one year.
Article 236.- For the purposes of criminal law, the following are considered as public officials:

Article 236.- 1.- All those who are invested with public functions, even if they are transitory, remunerated or gratuitous, and have the purpose of serving the Republic, some State of the Republic, Territory or Federal Dependency, Section, District or Municipality or any public establishment subject by law to tutelage of any of these entities.

Article 236.- 2.- The agents of the public force. Assimilated to public officials, from the point of view of legal consequences, are associate judges, associates, jurors, arbitrators, experts, interpreters, witnesses and prosecutors during the exercise of their functions.

Article 237.- In the case that the quality of public official is a constitutive element or an aggravating circumstance of a punishable fact, it includes that in which it is perpetrated when the official has already ceased to be so if it has been committed against him because of the functions he exercised.

Article 238.- When to commit a crime someone makes use of the faculty or special means offered by reason of the functions with which he is invested, the penalty indicated for the committed crime shall be applied with an increase of one sixth to one third, unless the law has already taken into account, for that purpose, the quality of public official.

Article 239.- Any individual who, summoned by the judicial authority as a witness, expert, doctor, surgeon or interpreter, excuses himself from appearing without justified motive, shall be punished with imprisonment of fifteen days to three months. Whoever, having appeared, refuses without legal reason his depositions or the performance of the office that motivated his summons, shall incur the same penalty.
Article 239.- Besides imprisonment, the culpable shall be disqualified from the exercise of his profession or art for a time equal to that of imprisonment, once it has terminated.
Article 239.- The penalties established in this article shall not apply except in cases where special provisions do not establish otherwise.

Article 240.- Whoever reports to the judicial authority or to an investigating official a supposed or imaginary punishable fact shall be punished with imprisonment of one to fifteen months. Whoever simulates the signs of a punishable fact, so that it gives rise to an investigative principle, shall be imposed the same penalty.

Article 240.- Whoever before this judicial authority falsely declares that he has committed or helped to commit some punishable fact, so that it gives rise to an investigative principle, unless his declaration is intended to save some close relative, an intimate friend or his benefactor, shall incur the same penalty.

Article 241.- Whoever, knowing that an individual is innocent, reports or accuses him before the judicial authority, or before a public official who has the obligation to transmit the report or complaint, attributing to him a punishable fact, or simulating the appearances or material signs of a punishable fact, shall incur the penalty of six to thirty months of imprisonment.
Article 241.- The culpable shall be punished with imprisonment of eighteen months to five years in the following cases:
Article 241.- 1.- When the imputed crime merits corporal punishment that exceeds thirty months.
Article 241.- 2.- When the false inculpation has caused conviction to corporal punishment of lesser duration.
Article 241.- If the imposed sentence has been imprisonment, the calumniator shall be imposed the penalty of five years of imprisonment.

Article 242.- The penalties established in the preceding article shall be reduced to two thirds if the guilty party retracts his imputations or reveals the simulation before any act of prosecution against the calumniated person.
Article 242.- The said penalties shall only be reduced to half if the retraction or revelation intervenes before the sentence that is passed as a result of the false inculpation.

Article 243.- Whoever, testifying as a witness before the judicial authority, affirms the false or denies the true or keeps silent, totally or partially, what he knows in relation to the facts about which he is questioned, shall be punished with imprisonment of fifteen days to fifteen months.

Article 243.- If the false testimony has been given against any accused for a crime or in the course of a criminal trial, the imprisonment shall be six to thirty months, and if both circumstances concur, it shall be from eighteen months to three years.
Article 243.- If the false testimony has been the cause of a condemnatory sentence to imprisonment, the imprisonment shall be three to five years.
Article 243.- If the testimony has been given without oath, the penalty shall be reduced from one sixth to one third.
Article 244.- The following shall be exempt from all penalty for the crime provided in the preceding article:

Article 244.- 1.- The witness who, if he had told the truth, would have inevitably exposed his own person, that of a close relative, intimate friend or benefactor to a serious danger, touching freedom or honor.

Article 244.- 2.- The individual who, having stated his name and circumstances to the authority, should not have been considered as a witness or was not warned of the faculty he had to abstain from declaring.
Article 244.- If the false testimony has exposed some other person to criminal proceedings or to a conviction, the penalty shall be reduced only to half to two thirds.

Article 245.- The one who, having declared in the course of a criminal procedure, retracts his false testimony and testifies according to the truth before the summary inquiry is concluded by an order of no grounds to continue it or the process by an order of dismissal founded on lack of merits for charges or before the falsity of the testimony is discovered, shall be exempt from all penalty in relation to the crime provided in Article 243.

Article 245.- If the retraction is carried out afterwards or if it refers to a false disposition in a civil trial, the penalty shall be decreased by one third to one half, provided that the retraction takes place before the definitive judgment of the matter.

Article 245.- If the mere false testimony has been the cause of the detention of a person or of some other serious prejudice to the same, only one third of the penalty shall be reduced in the case of the first paragraph of this article and one sixth in the case of the first aside.

Article 246.- The provisions of the preceding articles shall also apply to experts and interpreters, who called as such before the judicial authority give false reports, news or interpretations, who shall also be punished with disqualification for the exercise of their profession or art for a time equal to that of the imprisonment, once it has terminated.

Article 247.- Whoever has bribed a witness, expert or interpreter with the object of making him commit the crime provided in Article 243 shall be punished, when the false testimony, expertise or interpretation have been carried out, with the following penalties:
Article 247.- 1.- In the case of the first part of the cited article, with imprisonment of forty-five days to eighteen months.

Article 247.- 2.- In the cases provided in the first aside of said article, with imprisonment of one to three years, or of two to four years, respectively, if the two circumstances indicated in the cited aside concur.
Article 247.- 3.- In the case of the second aside of the same article, with imprisonment of four to five years.
Article 247.- If the false testimony, expertise or interpretation have been made without oath the penalty shall be reduced from one sixth to one third.

Article 247.- Whoever by means of threats, gifts or offers has only attempted to bribe a witness, expert or interpreter, shall incur the penalties established in the previous provisions, but limited to one third.
Article 247.- Everything that the bribing party has given shall be confiscated.

Article 248.- If the culpable of the crime provided in the preceding article is the tried person himself or his close relatives or whenever he has not exposed another person to criminal proceedings or to a conviction, the established penalties shall be reduced by half to two thirds.

Article 249.- When the false testimony, expertise or interpretation have been retracted in the manner and at the opportunity indicated in Article 245, the penalty incurred by the guilty of the crime provided in Article 247 shall be decreased in the proportion of one sixth to one third.
Article 250.- Whoever, being a party in a civil trial, incurs perjury, shall be punished with imprisonment of three to fifteen months.
Article 250.- If the culpable retracts before concluding the litigation, the imprisonment shall be fifteen days to three months.

Article 251.- The agent, lawyer, attorney, counselor or director who harms the cause entrusted to him by collusion with the opposing party or by other fraudulent means, or who in the same cause serves at the same time parties of opposed interests, shall be punished with imprisonment of forty-five days to fifteen months and suspension from the exercise of his profession for a time equal to that of the sentence.

Article 251.- Any of the individuals indicated above who, after having defended one of the parties, without her consent, takes on the defense of the opposing party, shall be punished with imprisonment of one to three months.

Article 252.- The agents, attorneys or defenders specified in the preceding article who, in a criminal cause and outside the cases provided in the same article, maliciously harm the accused they defend, shall be punished with imprisonment of fifteen days to eighteen months and suspension from the exercise of their profession for a time equal to that of the sentence.
Article 252.- If the defended was accused for some crime that merits corporal punishment of thirty months or more, the imprisonment penalty shall be for a time of eighteen months to two years.

Article 253.- Prosecutors or Representatives of the Public Ministry who, by collusion with the opposing party or for any other fraudulent motive, improperly request the acquittal or the condemnation of the accused or the dismissal of the cause, shall be punished with imprisonment of three to eighteen months.

Article 254.- Any of the individuals referred to in Article 252 who causes to be delivered from his client money or other things, under pretext of procuring the favor of witnesses, experts, interpreters, Representatives of the Public Ministry, magistrates or associate judges who are to decide the cause, shall be punished with imprisonment of one to three years and suspension from the exercise of his profession for a time equal to that of the sentence.

Article 255.- Those who after a crime punishable by imprisonment or prison has been committed, without prior agreement to the very crime and without contributing to carry it to further effects, help nevertheless to secure its proceeds, to elude the investigations of the authority or that the accused escape the pursuit of this or the fulfillment of the sentence, and those who in any way destroy or alter the traces or signs of a crime that merits the aforementioned penalties, shall be punished with imprisonment of one to five years.

Article 256.- When the penalty that should be imposed according to the previous article exceeds half of that corresponding to the crime committed by the person whom the concealer tries to favor, it shall be reduced to that half.

Article 257.- When the acts provided in Article 255 aim to conceal a punishable fact, punished with penalties different from imprisonment and prison, those acts shall be punished with a fine of two thousand to three thousand bolívares, if the concealment is of crimes; and from fifty to two hundred bolívares, if it is of offenses.
Article 258.- The concealer of his close relatives is not punishable.

Article 259.- Whoever, being legally detained, escapes from the establishment where he is, making use of violent means against persons or things, shall be punished with imprisonment of forty-five days to nine months.

Article 260.- Sentenced persons who have broken their sentence of imprisonment, prison, expulsion from the geographical space of the Republic, relegation to a Penitentiary Colony, confinement or arrest, and execute it with any of the circumstances of violence, intimidation, resistance with weapons, breaking of doors, windows, walls, ceiling or floor, use of false keys, scaling or any other aggravating circumstance that is not simple escape, shall suffer, according to the nature and number of these concomitant acts, an aggravation of penalty of the same species, between one fifth and one fourth of the principal, at the discretion of the Tribunal.

Article 260.- If the escape has been effected without any of the circumstances to which the preceding paragraph refers, the aggravation of the penalty shall not exceed one eighth of the principal. If the broken sentence was that of expulsion from the geographical space of the Republic, the condemned person, who in any case will be expelled, shall be so at his expense, if he has assets.

Article 261.- Those politically or professionally disqualified or the dismissed who exercise the employment or profession against the tenor of the sentence shall be condemned, as aggravation of penalty, to an arrest of one to twelve months or a fine of five hundred to one thousand five hundred bolívares, at the discretion of the tribunal.
Article 262.- If the breach of sentence is in the case of suspension from employment, the surcharge of penalty shall be a fine between two hundred fifty and one thousand bolívares.

Article 263.- If it is in the cases of subjection to the surveillance of the public authority or of bail, in the first, by surcharge of penalty the surveillance time shall be increased, and in the other the time of arrest if any, up to one third of these same penalties, at the discretion of the Tribunal.
Article 264.- Even when there are several breaches of sentence, in none of the cases of the articles of this Chapter may the corporal charged penalty exceed the time of twenty years.

Article 265.- Whoever in any way procures or facilitates the escape of a prisoner shall be punished with imprisonment of one to two years, taking into account the gravity of the accusation or nature and duration of the penalty the escaped person still has to serve.

Article 265.- If to procure or facilitate the evasion, the culpable has used any of the means indicated in Article 259, the penalty shall be two to four years of imprisonment when the escape takes place; and when it does not occur, it shall be one to two years of imprisonment. In either case the gravity of the accusation or the nature and duration of the unserved sentence must be taken into account.
Article 265.- If the guilty person is a close relative of the prisoner, the penalty shall be reduced by one third to one half, according to the proximity of kinship.

Article 266.- The public official who, in charge of the conduct or custody of a detainee or sentenced person, procures or facilitates in any way his evasion, shall be punished with imprisonment for a time of two to five years.

Article 266.- If to procure or facilitate the evasion the culpable cooperates in the acts of violence referred to in Article 259, or if for that he has given the arms or instruments or has not prevented them from being supplied, the penalty shall be three to six years of imprisonment if the evasion is carried out; and one to three years in the contrary case.

Article 266.- When the evasion has been verified by negligence or imprudence of the public official, he shall be punished with imprisonment of two months to one year and if the escaped was serving a sentence of imprisonment the penalty shall be six to eighteen months.
Article 266.- For the imposition of the penalty the gravity of the imputed fact and the nature and duration of the sentence that still remains to be served shall always be taken into account.

Article 267.- The penalties established in the preceding articles shall be increased by one third when the violences provided in the same articles have been committed with weapons or as effects of a concerted plan or if the act happens in meeting of three or more persons.

Article 268.- The public official who, in charge of the custody or conduct of some detainee or sentenced person, allows him, without being authorized to do so, to leave even temporarily the place where he must remain detained or the place where he must serve his sentence, shall be punished with imprisonment of fifteen days to six months.
Article 268.- In the case that by reason of that permission the detainee or sentenced person manages to escape, the imprisonment shall be three months to two years.
Article 269.- When the escaped person voluntarily surrenders himself as prisoner, the penalty established in the preceding articles shall be reduced to one fifth.

Article 270.- To the official who, being guilty of the acts respectively provided in the second aside of Article 266, has achieved within the three months following the escape the capture of the escaped or his presentation to the authority, his penalty shall be reduced to one fifth.

Article 271.- Whoever, with the sole object of exercising a pretended right, does justice by himself, making use of violence on things, when recourse could have been had to the authority, shall be punished with a fine of two hundred fifty to two thousand bolívares.

Article 271.- If the culpable uses threats or violence against persons, even if he has not used violence against things, he shall be punished with imprisonment of one to six months or confinement of three months to one year.
Article 271.- If the violence has been committed with weapons, he shall be punished with double the established penalty.
Article 271.- And if bodily injury or some other crime results, he shall be punished with the corresponding penalty to those punishable acts.
Article 271.- If the act is not accompanied by another crime prosecutable ex officio, proceedings shall only be initiated upon request of a party.
Article 272.- When the culpable of the crime provided in the preceding article proves the existence of the right with which he proceeds, the penalty shall be diminished by one third to one half.

Article 273.- The introduction, manufacture, trade, possession and carrying of weapons that are carried out in contravention of the provisions of this Code and of the Law on Arms and Explosives are considered crimes and shall be punished according to the pertinent articles of this Chapter.

Article 273.- It shall be considered an aggravating circumstance if such crimes are committed by police officers, customs guards, public officials, legally authorized private guards and public employees, in which cases the penalty shall be increased up to one third of the average.

Article 274.- Weapons, in general, are all instruments proper to maltreat or injure others; for the purposes of this Chapter, only those that are enumerated in the Law cited in the previous article shall be considered as such.

Article 275.- The trade, importation, manufacture, carrying, possession, supply and concealment of weapons classified as war weapons according to the Law on Arms and Explosives and other legal provisions concerning the matter shall be punished with imprisonment of five to eight years.

Article 276.- Those who possess collections of weapons considered as historical or study objects shall not incur the penalty provided in the previous article, provided that to form, preserve or alienate such collections they adhere to the Regulations issued by the National Executive.

Article 277.- The trade, import, manufacture and supply of other weapons that are not war weapons, but with respect to which such operations are prohibited by the Law on Arms and Explosives, shall be punished with imprisonment of five to eight years.
Article 278.- The carrying, detention or concealment of the weapons referred to in the previous article shall be punished with imprisonment of three to five years.
Article 279.- In the cases provided in Articles 275, 277 and 278, the weapons subject of the process shall be confiscated and destined to the National Park.

Article 280.- Military personnel in service, police officials, customs guards, nor public officials or employees authorized to have or carry them by the laws or regulations governing the performance of their positions shall not incur the crimes and penalties established in Articles 278 and 279.

Article 281.- Neither shall citizens to whom the National Executive expressly authorizes to carry them in accordance with laws and regulations on the matter incur the crimes and penalties provided in Articles 278 and 279.
Article 282.- The persons referred to in Articles 280 and 281 may not make use of the weapons they carry except in case of legitimate defense or in defense of public order.

Article 282.- If they make improper use of said weapons, they shall be subject to the penalties imposed by Articles 278 and 279, increased by one third as the case may be, in addition to the penalties corresponding to the crime in which using such weapons they have incurred.

Article 283.- Possessors of weapons who have registered them in accordance with the Law on Arms and Explosives shall not incur the penalties imposed in Articles 277, 278 and 279, provided that subsequently they have not given them a destination contrary to the provisions of that Law, in which case they shall incur the cited penalties, as the case may be.
Article 284.- Whoever publicly instigates another to commit a determined infraction shall be punished by the mere fact of the instigation:
Article 284.- 1.- If it is a crime for which a prison sentence has been established, with imprisonment of ten to thirty months.
Article 284.- 2.- If it is a crime whose penalty is prison, with imprisonment of three to twelve months.
Article 284.- 3.- In all other cases, with a fine of fifty to one thousand bolívares, according to the entity of the instigated act.
Article 285.- In the cases of numbers 2 and 3 of the previous article, one may never exceed one third of the penalty set for the punishable act to which the instigation refers.

Article 286.- Whoever publicly excites disobedience of the Laws or hatred of some inhabitants against others or makes the apologia of an act that the law provides as crime, in such a way that public tranquility is put in danger, shall be punished with imprisonment of forty-five days to six months.
Article 287.- When two or more persons associate with the purpose of committing crimes, each of them shall be punished, by the mere fact of the association, with imprisonment of two to five years.

Article 288.- If the associated roam the fields or the roads and at least two of them carry weapons or have them in a determined place, the penalty shall be imprisonment for a time of eighteen months to five years.

Article 289.- The promoters or leaders of the gang shall incur the penalty of imprisonment of eighteen months to five years, in the case of Article 287, and of thirty months to six years, in the case of Article 288.

Article 290.- Whoever, outside the cases provided in Article 84, gives refuge or assistance to the gang members or to any of them, or procures subsistence for them, shall be punished with imprisonment of three to six months.
Article 291.- Whoever, in the case provided in Article 290, shelters or provides food to a close relative, intimate friend or benefactor, shall be exempt from penalty.

Article 292.- Regarding the crimes committed by all or some of the associates during the existence of the association or by reason of it, the penalty shall be aggravated with an increase of one sixth to one third, except as provided in Article 79.
Article 293.- Whoever has taken part in an association with the object of committing the crimes provided in Article 286 shall be punished with imprisonment of six months to one year.

Article 294.- Whoever has executed any act that aims to expose some part of the Republic to devastation or looting shall be punished with imprisonment of eighteen months to five years. If the attempt is made, even in part, the penalty of imprisonment of five to nine years shall be imposed.

Article 295.- Whoever, to commit a determined punishable act, has formed an armed body or exercises in it a superior command or some special function, shall be punished for this sole fact with imprisonment of one to four years.
Article 295.- The other individuals who are part of the armed body shall be punished with imprisonment of one to two years.
Article 295.- The provisions of Articles 163 and 290 of this Code shall be applicable.

Article 296.- Whoever, without being legally authorized, forms an armed body, even if it is not intended to commit punishable acts, shall be punished with arrest in Fortaleza or Political Prison for a time of three to six months.
