Article 453.- Whoever brands or marks ear-marked animals knowing them to be other's property, even on his own property, shall incur the penalty of presidio of six months to three years.
Article 453.- Whoever counterbrands or countermarks another's animals anywhere without the right to do so shall incur the penalty of presidio of six months to three years.

Article 453.- Whoever issues false documents or falsifies them to obtain guides, or to transit animals that are not his property without being duly authorized for it, or uses falsified certificates or guides for any transaction concerning cattle or hides, shall incur the penalty of presidio of six months to three years.

Article 453.- Public officials or employees who issue guides or certified copies of documents about animals or permit benefit of livestock without having observed the requirements or formalities established in the respective Laws, Regulations or Ordinances shall incur the penalty of presidio of six months to three years.
Article 453.- Whoever detains or conducts herds or skins whose possession cannot be justified shall incur the penalty of presidio of six months to three years.

Article 453 (continued).- The penal provisions contained in Decree number 406 on the National Registry of Brands and Marks shall only apply in cases in which the preceding aside provisions are not applicable.

Article 454.- The penalty of imprisonment for the crime of theft shall be two to six years if the crime has been committed: 1.- In offices, archives or public establishments, appropriating things kept in them, or other objects intended for some use of public utility.
Article 454.- 2.- In cemeteries, graves or tombs, appropriating either the things that make up their ornament or protection, or those found on the corpses or buried with them at the same time.
Article 454.- 3.- Appropriating things that serve or are destined for worship, in places consecrated to its exercise, or in annexes destined to preserve said things.
Article 454.- 4.- From a person, by artifice or dexterity, in a public place or open to the public.
Article 454.- 5.- Appropriating objects or money of travelers, both in land, air or water vehicles, whatever their class, as well as in stations or offices of public transport companies.

Article 454.- 6.- Appropriating animals that are in stables, or those that by necessity are left in open fields and with respect to which the provision of number 12 of the next Article would not be applicable.

Article 454.- 7.- Appropriating wood deposited in firewood sales piled in some place, or materials destined for some factory, or products removed from the soil and left by necessity or other reason in open fields or other open places.
Article 454.- 8.- Appropriating objects that by virtue of custom or their own destination are kept exposed to public trust.

Article 455.- The penalty of imprisonment for theft shall be four to eight years in the following cases: 1.- If the act has been committed abusing the confidence arising from an exchange of good offices, from a contract for work or of a lodging, even temporary, between the thief and his victim, and if the act has had as its object the things that under such conditions were exposed or left to the good faith of the guilty.
Article 455.- 2.- If to commit the act the guilty has taken advantage of the facilities offered by some disaster, calamity, public disturbance or the particular misfortunes of the stolen-from.
Article 455.- 3.- If, not living under the same roof as the stolen-from, the guilty committed the crime at night or in some house or other place destined for habitation.

Article 455.- 4.- If the guilty, either to commit the act or to transport the stolen thing, has destroyed, broken, demolished or disturbed enclosures made of solid materials for the protection of persons or properties, even if the breaking or rupture had not been effected at the place of the crime.

Article 455.- 5.- If to commit the act or to transport the stolen thing, the guilty has opened locks using false keys or other instruments, or making use of the true key lost or left by its owner, or taken from him, or improperly held or retained.

Article 455.- 6.- If to commit the act or to transport the stolen thing the guilty has used a route different from that ordinarily intended for people's passage to get into the house or its enclosure, or to leave them, obstacles and fences such that they could not be overcome except by artificial means or by force of personal agility.
Article 455.- 7.- If the act has been committed violating seals placed by some public official by virtue of the Law, or by order of the authority.
Article 455.- 8.- If the theft has been committed by a person illicitly uniformed, wearing religious habit or otherwise disguised.
Article 455.- 9.- If the act has been committed by three or more persons gathered.
Article 455.- 10.- If the act has been committed by taking advantage of a simulated condition of public officials, or using falsified identity documents.
Article 455.- 11.- If the stolen thing is among those notoriously destined for public defense or for the public repair or relief of some misfortune.

Article 455.- 12.- If the act has had as its object herd animals or large livestock, even not yet in herd, whether in corrals or in open fields, whether in stables or mangers that do not constitute immediate dependencies of inhabited houses.
Article 455 (continued).- If the crime is revested with two or more of the Circumstances specified in the different numbers of this Article, the imprisonment shall be for six to ten years.

Article 456.- Whoever, without being duly authorized, has gleaned, gleaned by hand or searched fruits in another's estates, when the harvest has not been entirely gathered, shall be punished with a fine of five to twenty-five bolívares, at the complaint of the injured party.
Article 456 (continued).- In case of residence the penalty shall be arrest of three to fifteen days.

Article 457.- Whoever, by means of violence or threats of imminent serious harm against persons or things, has constrained the holder or another person present at the place of the crime to deliver to him a movable object or to tolerate that he takes possession of it, shall be punished with presidio of four to eight years.

Article 458.- The individual who at the moment of taking possession of another's movable thing, or immediately after, has made use of the said violences or threats against the robbed person or against those present at the place of the crime, whether to commit the act, or to carry off the stolen object, or, finally, to procure impunity for himself or to procure it for any other person who has participated in the crime, shall incur the same penalty as in the previous Article.
Article 458 (continued).- If the violence is directed only to snatch the thing from the person, the penalty shall be imprisonment of six to thirty months.

Article 459.- Whoever, by means of violence or threats of serious harm to the person or to his goods, has constrained someone to deliver, subscribe or destroy, to his detriment or that of a third person, an act or document that produces any legal effect, shall be punished with presidio of three to six years.

Article 460.- When any of the crimes provided in the preceding Articles has been committed by means of threats to life, at gunpoint or by several persons, one of whom has been manifestly armed, or by several persons illegally uniformed, wearing religious habit or disguised otherwise, or if, finally, it has been committed by means of an attack on individual liberty, the presidio penalty shall be eight to sixteen years; without prejudice to the application to the person or persons accused of the penalty corresponding to the crime of illicit carrying of arms.

Article 461.- Whoever, infusing by any means the fear of a serious harm to persons, in their honor, in their goods, or simulating orders of authority, has constrained anyone to send, deposit or put at the disposal of the guilty, money, things, titles or documents that produce any legal effect, shall be punished with presidio of three to five years.

Article 462.- Whoever has kidnapped a person to obtain from him or from a third party, as the price of his liberty, money, things, titles or documents that produce any legal effect in favor of the guilty or of another he indicates, even if he does not achieve his intent, shall be punished with presidio of ten to twenty years. If the kidnapping is executed to cause alarm, the penalty shall be two to five years of presidio.

Article 463.- Whoever, outside the cases provided in Article 84, without giving notice thereof to the authority, has carried correspondence or written or verbal messages, to procure the accomplishment of the purpose of the crime provided in the preceding Article, shall be punished with imprisonment of four months to three years.

Article 464.- Whoever, by artifices or means capable of deceiving or surprising the good faith of another, inducing him into error, procures for himself or for another an unjust benefit to the prejudice of another, shall be punished with imprisonment of one to five years.

Article 464 (continued).- The penalty shall be two to six years if the crime has been committed: 1.- To the detriment of a public administration, of an autonomous entity in which the State has an interest or of a social assistance institute. 2.- By infusing in the offended person the fear of an imaginary danger or the erroneous conviction that he must execute an order of authority.

Article 464 (continued).- Whoever commits the crime provided in this Article using as means of deceit a falsified or altered public document, or issuing a cheque without provision of funds, shall incur the corresponding penalty increased by one sixth to one third.

Article 465.- The following shall incur the penalties provided in Article 464: 1.- One who defrauds another using a false mandate, assumed name or simulated quality. 2.- One who makes another sign by deceit a document that imposes some obligation on him or that signifies total or partial waiver of a right. 3.- One who alienates, encumbers or leases as his own some immovable property knowing that it is another's. 4.- One who alienates an immovable or real right already sold to other persons, provided that any of the following circumstances concur: a) That by consequence of the registration of the second alienation it would be legally impossible to register the first. b) That, it not being legally possible to register the second alienation because the first is registered, the buyer has paid the price of the immovable or real right or part of it.

Article 465 (continued).- 5.- One who collects or assigns a credit already paid or ceded. 6.- One who alienates or encumbers goods as free, knowing that they are seized or encumbered or are the object of litigation. 7.- One who, offering, although with appearances of legitimate business, participation in feigned treasures or deposits in exchange for money or reward. 8.- One who, abusing for his own benefit or that of another, the needs, passions or inexperience of a minor, interdicted or incapacitated person, makes them sign any act containing an obligation charged to the minor or a third party, despite the resulting nullity due to their incapacity.

Article 466.- In the following cases the following penalties shall be applied: 1.- Imprisonment of one to five years to anyone who, having sold an immovable by private or authenticated document and received the price of the transaction or part of it, encumbers it in favor of another person without the express consent of the buyer or without guaranteeing to the buyer the full compliance with the celebrated contract. 2.- Imprisonment of one to four years to anyone who defrauds another by promoting a joint-stock company in which false statements are made about the company's capital, or fraudulent facts about it are concealed. 3.- Imprisonment of six months to two years to anyone who, to obtain some profit, removes, conceals or renders unusable, in whole or in part, a file or document to the prejudice of another. 4.- Imprisonment of three to eighteen months to anyone who, by raffles or lotteries, keeps in whole or in part the amounts received without delivering the thing offered. 5.- Imprisonment of six to eighteen months to anyone who defrauds another under pretext of a supposed remuneration to public officials. 6.- Imprisonment of two to six months to anyone who has destroyed, deteriorated or concealed things of his property with the object of collecting for himself or another the price of an insurance. If he has achieved his purpose he shall incur the penalties established in Article 464. 7.- Arrest of two to six months to anyone who buys a movable offering to pay it in cash and refuses, after receiving it, to make the payment or return it.

Article 467.- Whoever, with a purpose of profit, induces some person to emigrate, deceiving him, adducing facts that do not exist or giving false news to them, shall be punished with imprisonment of six to thirty months.

Article 468.- Whoever has appropriated, for his own or another's benefit, some alien thing that had been entrusted or delivered to him by any title that entails the obligation to return it or to make of it a determined use, shall be punished with imprisonment of three months to two years, by accusation of the aggrieved party.

Article 469.- Whoever, abusing of a blank signature that had been entrusted to him, with the obligation to return it or to make of it a determined use, has written or caused to be written some act that produces any legal effect, to the prejudice of the signatory, shall be punished with imprisonment of three months to three years, by accusation of the aggrieved party.
Article 469 (continued).- If the blank signature had not been entrusted to the guilty, the provisions of Chapters III and IV, Title VI of this Book shall apply to the case.

Article 470.- When the crime provided in the preceding articles has been committed over objects entrusted or deposited by reason of the profession, industry, trade, business, functions or services of the depositary, or when they are by reason of necessary deposit, the imprisonment penalty shall be one to five years; and in prosecution proceedings shall be ex officio.

Article 471.- By accusation of the aggrieved party, the following shall be punished with imprisonment of fifteen days to four months or a fine of twenty-five to five hundred bolívares: 1.- Whoever, finding a lost thing, takes possession of it without adjusting to the prescriptions of law, in the corresponding cases. 2.- Whoever, finding a treasure, appropriates, to the prejudice of the owner of the estate, more than what corresponds to him by law. 3.- Whoever appropriates the alien thing that went into his power as a consequence of an error or fortuitous event.
Article 471 (continued).- If the guilty knew the owner of the appropriated thing, the imprisonment shall be three months to one year.

Article 472.- Whoever, outside the cases provided in Articles 255, 256, 257 and 258, acquires, receives or hides money or things coming from crime or in any way interferes so that said money or things are acquired, received or hidden, without having taken part in the crime itself, shall be punished with imprisonment of three months to one year.

Article 472 (continued).- If the money or things come from a crime punished with a penalty restricting individual liberty for a time greater than thirty months, the guilty shall be punished with imprisonment of six months to two years.
Article 472 (continued).- In the cases provided in the preceding provisions, the imprisonment may not exceed half of the penalty established for the crime from which the things come.

Article 472 (continued).- If the guilty habitually performs the acts punished in this Article, the imprisonment shall be one to three years in the first case here provided, and eighteen months to five years in the second.

Article 473.- Whoever, to appropriate, in whole or in part, an immovable thing of another's belonging or to take advantage of it, removes or alters its boundaries or limits, shall be punished with imprisonment of four to fifteen months.
Article 473 (continued).- The same penalty applies to whoever, to procure an undue benefit, diverts public or private waters.

Article 473 (continued).- If the fact has been committed with violence or threats against persons, or by two or more individuals with weapons, or by more than ten without them, the imprisonment shall be applied for six to thirty months; without prejudice to the application, to the armed persons, of the penalty corresponding to the crime of illicit carrying of arms.
Article 474.- Whoever, by means of violence against persons, has disturbed the peaceful possession of another's estate, shall be punished with imprisonment of one to six months.

Article 474 (continued).- If the fact has been committed by several persons with arms, or by more than ten without them, the imprisonment shall be six to eighteen months; and the respective penalty for illicit carrying of arms shall also be applied.

Article 475.- Whoever in any manner has destroyed, annihilated, damaged or deteriorated things, movable or immovable, belonging to another, shall be punished, upon complaint of the aggrieved party, with imprisonment of one to three months.

Article 475 (continued).- The imprisonment shall be forty-five days to eighteen months if the fact has been committed with any of the following circumstances: 1.- By revenge against a public official, because of his functions. 2.- By means of violence against persons, or by any of the means indicated in numbers 4 and 5 of Article 455. 3.- In public buildings or those destined to some public use, public utility or the exercise of a cult; or in buildings or works of the species indicated in Article 351, or in public monuments, cemeteries or their dependencies. 4.- In dikes, embankments or other works destined for the repair of a public disaster or in the apparatus and signals of some public service. 5.- In canals, locks and other works destined to irrigation. 6.- In plantations of sugar cane, coffee, cacao, fruit trees or shrubs or seedbeds of smaller fruits.

Article 476.- When the act provided in the preceding Article has been committed on occasion of violence or resistance to authority, or in a meeting of ten or more persons, all who have taken part in the crime shall be punished thus: In the case of the first part, with imprisonment up to four months; and in the cases provided in the sole aside, with imprisonment of one month to two years, proceedings always ex officio.
Article 477.- Whoever has caused devastation in another's estate by introducing in it without right or by leaving animals therein, shall be punished according to the provisions of Article 475.

Article 477 (continued).- For the mere fact of having introduced or abandoned abusively the animals to make them perish, the guilty party, at the instigation of the aggrieved party, shall be punished with arrest of eight to forty-five days or fine of fifty to two hundred fifty bolívares.

Article 478.- Whoever arbitrarily has entered another's enclosed estate, fenced with ditches, live hedges, trenches, artificial causeways, stone or wood fences, or otherwise, shall be punished, upon complaint of the aggrieved party, with a fine of ten to twenty-five bolívares; and, in case of recidivism, the guilty shall incur arrest of eight to fifteen days.

Article 479.- Whoever, without the prior license of the owner, enters to hunt in another's estate, shall be punished upon accusation of the aggrieved party with a fine of ten to twenty-five bolívares.
Article 479 (continued).- In case of recidivism, the guilty shall incur arrest of eight to fifteen days.
Article 479 (continued, sole paragraph).- If the estate is fenced, the penalty shall be arrest of fifteen days to one month.

Article 480.- Whoever without necessity has killed another's animal or has caused him some harm that renders it useless, shall be punished upon accusation of the aggrieved party with arrest of eight to forty-five days.

Article 480 (continued).- If the prejudice is slight, a fine up to one hundred fifty bolívares may be applied alone. If the animal has only diminished in value, the arrest penalty shall be at most fifteen days or the fine of one hundred fifty bolívares maximum.
Article 480 (continued).- No penalty shall be imposed on one who has committed the act against flying animals found within his own estate, at the time of causing some devastation or damage.

Article 481.- Whoever, outside the cases provided in the preceding Articles, soils or stains an alien thing in any manner, movable or immovable, shall be punished, upon accusation of the aggrieved party, with a fine of twenty-five to two hundred bolívares.
Article 481 (continued).- If any of the circumstances indicated in Article 476 has occurred, the fine may be imposed up to five hundred bolívares and prosecution shall be ex officio.

Article 482.- When the guilty of any of the crimes provided in Chapters I, III, IV and V of this Title and in Article 475, in its first part, 477 and 480, before any judicial measure against him, has restored what he had taken, or entirely repaired the damage caused, in case that by the nature of the act or by other circumstances restitution is not possible, the penalty shall be diminished in the proportion of one to two thirds.
Article 482 (continued).- If restitution or repair is carried out in the course of the trial before sentence, the penalty shall be diminished in the proportion of one sixth to one third.

Article 483.- Concerning the acts provided in Chapters I, III, IV and V of this Title, and in Article 475, in its first part, 477 and 480, no proceedings shall be promoted against one who has committed the crime: 1.- To the prejudice of the spouse not legally separated. 2.- To the prejudice of a relative or affinity in ascending or descending line; of the adoptive father or mother, or of the adoptive child. 3.- To the prejudice of a brother or sister who lives under the same roof as the guilty party.

Article 483 (continued).- The penalty shall be diminished by one third if the act has been executed to the prejudice of his legally separated spouse, of a brother or sister who do not live under the same roof with the author of the crime, of an uncle, nephew or an affinity in the second degree who lives in family with said author; and proceedings shall only be by complaint of the injured party.

Article 484.- Concerning the crimes specified in this Title, the Judge may increase the penalty up to half of its designation, if the value of the thing upon which the crime has fallen, or that corresponding to the damage it has caused, were of great importance.
Article 484 (continued).- He may, on the contrary, decrease it up to half if it is slight and up to a third if it were very slight.
Article 484 (continued).- To determine the value account shall be taken not of the profit that accrues to the guilty but the value that the thing had and the damage caused at the time of the crime.

Article 484 (continued).- The indicated reductions of penalties shall not be applicable if the guilty was a recidivist in some crime of the same nature, or if it were some of the crimes provided in Chapter II of this Title.

Article 485.- Whoever has disobeyed an order legally issued by the competent authority or has not observed some measure legally dictated by said authority in the interest of justice or of public safety or health, shall be punished with arrest of five to thirty days, or a fine of twenty to one hundred fifty bolívares.

Article 486.- Whoever, in case of tumult, calamity or flagrante delicto, has refused without just reasons to render his aid or service, or has excused himself from providing the indications or news required of him by a public official in exercise of his ministry, shall be punished with a fine of ten to fifty bolívares.
Article 486 (continued).- If the accusations or news communicated were false, the fine may be fifty to two hundred fifty bolívares.

Article 487.- Whoever, interrogated by a public official in the exercise of his ministry, refuses to give his name and surname, his status or profession, the place of birth or domicile or any other personal quality, shall be punished with a fine of ten to fifty bolívares. If the indications given were false, the fine may be fifty to one hundred fifty bolívares.

Article 488.- Any individual who, in contempt of the legal prohibitions of the competent authority, has promoted or directed religious ceremonies outside the places destined to worship or processions, both civil and religious, in plazas, streets or other public ways, shall be punished with a fine of twenty to one hundred bolívares.
Article 488 (continued).- If the act has caused public tumult, the guilty shall be punished with arrest up to thirty days.

Article 489.- The minister of any cult who has proceeded to external cult religious ceremonies in opposition to the provisions legally dictated by the competent authority shall be punished with arrest of one to two months or with a fine of fifty to seven hundred fifty bolívares.

Article 490.- The doctor, surgeon, midwife or any public sanitation employee who, having rendered his professional assistance in cases that appear to present characteristics of crime against persons, has kept them secret or delayed in communicating them to the judicial or police authority shall be punished with a fine of fifty to two hundred fifty bolívares, except in the case that, by transmitting them, he would have exposed the assisted person to criminal proceedings.

Article 491.- Whoever, having received as good coins whose value exceeds ten bolívares, and recognizing them immediately as false or altered, does not consign them or does not notify the authority for the corresponding investigation within the next three days, informing it of their origin as far as possible, shall be punished with a fine of fifty to one hundred fifty bolívares.
Article 492.- Whoever has refused to receive by their value the coins that are in legal course in the Republic shall be punished with a fine of ten to fifty bolívares.

Article 493.- Any individual who, without adjusting to the prescriptions of law, exercises the typographic art, lithography or any other art that consists in reproducing multiple copies by chemical or mechanical procedures, shall be punished with a fine of one hundred to seven hundred bolívares.

Article 494.- Whoever, without permission of the authority when such permission is required by law, has put on sale or distributed in a public place printed materials, drawings or manuscripts, shall be punished with a fine of fifty bolívares maximum.

Article 494 (continued).- If they are printed materials or drawings already embargoed by the authority the penalty shall be arrest up to thirty days and the fine shall be fifty to one hundred fifty bolívares.

Article 495.- Whoever, selling or distributing printed materials, drawings or manuscripts in a public place or open to the public, has advertised them with cries, with news capable of accusing the disturbance of public tranquility or of individuals, shall be punished with a fine of one hundred bolívares; and if the news were false or supposed, the penalty shall be a fine of fifty to one hundred fifty bolívares or arrest up to fifteen days.

Article 496.- Whoever has affixed by himself or by others printed materials, drawings or manuscripts, without permission of the authority if such permission is required by law, or outside the points or places in which fixing is permitted, shall be punished with a fine of ten to fifty bolívares.

Article 497.- Whoever has in any way torn down, destroyed or otherwise rendered useless printed materials, drawings or manuscripts that the authority has had affixed, shall be punished with a fine of twenty to one hundred bolívares; and if he does so in contempt of the authority, he shall be punished with arrest up to fifteen days.

Article 497 (continued).- If they are printed materials, drawings or manuscripts that private individuals have had affixed, observing for this the provisions of law or authority and when the act has been executed the same day or the next of the affixing, the penalty shall be a fine not exceeding fifty bolívares.

Article 498.- Whoever opens or keeps open places destined for public spectacles or gatherings without having fulfilled the prescriptions dictated by the authority in the interest of public order shall be punished with arrest up to fifteen days or a fine of fifty to three hundred bolívares.

Article 499.- Any individual who, without permission of the authority, has given some spectacle or any representation in a public place, or open to the public, shall be punished with a fine of ten to one hundred bolívares; and if the act has been committed against prohibition of the authority, the penalty shall be arrest for fifteen days or a fine of fifty to three hundred bolívares.

Article 500.- Any individual who, without being previously authorized, has opened an agency of business, some establishment, or any enterprise that needs permission of the authority, shall be punished with a fine of fifty bolívares.
Article 500 (continued).- In case of recidivism in the same infraction, the penalty of arrest up to fifteen days shall also be imposed.

Article 500 (continued).- If the permission has been denied, the fine may be up to two hundred fifty bolívares; in case of recidivism in the same infraction, the penalty of arrest up to forty-five days shall also be imposed.

Article 501.- Any owner or director of an agency, establishment or enterprise of the kind indicated in the preceding Article who has not observed the prescriptions established by law or by the authority shall be punished with a fine up to fifty bolívares; and in case of recidivism in the same infraction, shall incur, moreover, arrest up to fifteen days and suspension for a month at most of the exercise of his art or profession.

Article 502.- Any individual who, for wages, has lodged, received as a boarder or to care for a person, without adjusting to the ordinances relative to the declarations or the reports that must be made to the authority, shall be punished with a fine up to fifty bolívares; in case of recidivism in the same infraction, the fine shall be up to one hundred bolívares.

Article 502 (continued).- If the guilty has exercised his industry in contempt of the prohibitions of the authority, the fine may be imposed up to the amount of one hundred bolívares; and from twenty-five to two hundred fifty bolívares in case of recidivism in the same infraction.

Article 503.- Any individual who, without permission of the authority, opens enlistments or recruitment places shall be punished with arrest up to nine months, or a fine of fifty to one thousand bolívares.

Article 504.- Whoever, being fit for work, is found begging shall be punished with arrest up to six days; and in case of recidivism in the same infraction, the arrest may be imposed up to fifteen days.
Article 504 (continued).- To one not fit for work, who begs without complying with local ordinances of the case, the same penalties shall apply.
Article 504 (continued).- The contravention does not cease by the beggar's doing so under pretext or appearance of rendering to another a service or of selling some objects.

Article 505.- Whoever begs in a threatening, humiliating or repugnant manner by circumstances of time, place, means or persons, shall be punished with arrest up to one month, and of one to six months in case of recidivism in the same infraction.
Article 506.- The authority may order that the arrest penalty established in the preceding Articles be served in a house of labor or by rendering a service in some public utility enterprise.
Article 506 (continued).- If he refuses the work or service, the arrest shall be effected in the ordinary form.

Article 507.- Any individual who has permitted that a minor under twelve years old, subjected to his authority or entrusted to his custody or supervision, be given to begging or serve another for this object, shall be punished with arrest up to two months or a fine of three hundred bolívares. In case of recidivism in the same infraction, the arrest shall be of two to four months.

Article 508.- Anyone who, with shouts or vociferations, by abuse of bells or other instruments, or making use of noisy exercises or means, failing the provisions of law or regulations, has disturbed public meetings, or the occupations or rest of citizens, shall be punished with a fine up to twenty-five bolívares, possibly up to fifty in case of recidivism in the same infraction.

Article 508 (continued).- If the act is committed in the early hours of the night, the fine shall be twenty to fifty bolívares and may be imposed up to one hundred bolívares in case of recidivism in the same infraction.
Article 508 (continued).- If the act has been capable of producing alarm in the public, arrest up to one month may be added to the fine.

Article 509.- Whoever publicly, out of petulance or other blameworthy motive, has molested some person or disturbed his tranquility, shall be punished with a fine up to fifty bolívares or with arrest up to eight days.

Article 510.- Whoever in a public place or open to the public has tried, using any imposture, to abuse popular credulity in such a way that damage to another or a disturbance of public order may result, shall be punished with arrest up to fifteen days, this penalty possibly being doubled in case of recidivism in the same fault.

Article 511.- Whoever, without prior permission of the competent authority, has established a factory of arms and munitions for free trade, or who without adhering to the legal prescriptions has introduced into the Republic more than those that were permitted, shall be punished with arrest up to three months or a fine of fifty to one thousand bolívares.

Article 512.- Whoever, without permission of the competent authority, has fabricated or introduced into the country powder not dense nor pyroxylinated or other explosive materials, shall be punished with arrest up to three months.

Article 513.- Whoever, without prior permission of the competent authority, sells or puts on sale arms of lawful trade whose sale requires such permission, shall be punished with arrest up to one month.

Article 514.- Shall be punished with a fine up to one thousand bolívares any individual who, even with permit of the authority to carry firearms: 1.- Has delivered or allowed to be carried loaded said arms to a person under fourteen years old or to anyone who does not know or cannot handle them with due discernment. 2.- Has neglected sufficient precautions to prevent the indicated persons from easily taking possession of said arms. 3.- Has carried a loaded rifle amid a gathering or public meeting.

Article 515.- Whoever, without permission of the competent authority, has discharged firearms or burned fireworks or explosive devices or made other dangerous or uncomfortable explosions in a inhabited place, in its vicinity, or along the direction of a public way, shall be punished with a fine up to two hundred bolívares; and in the more serious cases arrest up to one month may be imposed.

Article 516.- Whoever clandestinely or contrary to law or prohibitions of the authority has in his house or in another place some deposit of explosive or inflammable materials that are dangerous by reason of their nature or quantity, shall be punished with an arrest not less than three months.

Article 517.- Whoever, without permission of the competent authority, has carried from one place to another powder or other explosive materials in quantity that exceeds the needs of an industry or determined works, or who carries out the transport of the same materials without the precautions established by law or regulation, shall be punished with arrest up to one month or with a fine up to three hundred bolívares.

Article 518.- For the purposes of penal law, insidious weapons are considered those that are easily concealed and serve to offend by surprise or ambush, such as blades, rapiers, daggers, knives, short-barreled pistols and revolvers, explosive devices and bladed or firearms that are hidden or disguised in any manner in canes or other objects of lawful use.

Article 519.- Whoever has intervened in the plans or in the construction of some building, if it collapses or falls by negligence or lack of skill, even if it causes no harm or danger to the safety of third parties, shall be punished with a fine of one hundred bolívares as minimum and may also be with suspension of the exercise of his profession or art.

Article 519 (continued).- The provision of this Article applies in the case that bridges, scaffolds or other apparatus established for the construction or repair of buildings or for any similar work collapse or fall.

Article 520.- Whenever some building or other construction threatens to collapse, in whole or in part, with danger to personal security, the owner, his representative or whoever for any title is charged with the conservation, surveillance or construction of the building, shall be punished with a fine of ten to one hundred bolívares if he has not proceeded promptly to the necessary works to prevent the danger.
Article 520 (continued).- If he has transgressed the provisions of the competent authority, the fine may be up to one thousand bolívares.

Article 520 (continued).- Whenever it is a building or other construction totally or partially in ruin, and the one who must procure the convenient repair has neglected its timely execution or sufficient measures to prevent the danger resulting from the ruin, the fine shall be fifty to one thousand bolívares.

Article 521.- Any individual who has failed to put the signals and fences foreseen by ordinances to indicate the danger resulting from works being executed or objects left in places through which the public transits, shall be punished with a fine up to three hundred bolívares; and, moreover, in serious cases, with arrest up to ten days.
Article 521 (continued).- He who has arbitrarily removed the signals shall be punished with a fine of fifty to one thousand five hundred bolívares, and may also be with arrest up to twenty days.

Article 522.- Whoever, without right thereto, has extinguished the lights of public lighting, or removed the signs or apparatus other than those indicated in the preceding Article, and destined to public service, shall be punished with a fine up to two hundred bolívares.

Article 523.- Anyone who has thrown or cast in places open to public traffic or in private family enclosures things or substances capable of offending or soiling persons, shall be punished with arrest of ten days or with a fine up to one hundred bolívares.

Article 524.- Whoever, without the necessary precautions, places on windows, balconies, roofs, terraces or other similar places or hangs things that falling may offend or soil persons, shall be punished with a fine up to thirty bolívares.
Article 524 (continued).- When the author of the act is not known, culpability shall be applicable to the tenant or possessor of the house, provided he had been in capacity to prevent it.

Article 525.- Any individual who has allowed lunatics entrusted to his custody to wander, or has not given immediate notice to the authority when they have escaped, shall be punished with a fine up to two hundred bolívares.

Article 526.- Any individual who, without immediately giving notice to the authority or who without authorization, when necessary, has received for his custody known lunatics, or has released them, shall be punished with a fine of fifty to five hundred bolívares; and in serious cases, arrest up to thirty days may be imposed.

Article 527.- Concerning the infractions specified in the preceding Articles, when the guilty is director of an establishment for the insane, or some individual who exercises the art of healing, suspension of the exercise of his profession shall be applied as an accessory penalty.

Article 528.- Whoever, failing the precautions imposed by ordinances, has left free and without custody ferocious beasts or dangerous animals, his own or entrusted to his care, and any individual who in case said animals are attacked by rabies does not prevent the danger or has not immediately shared it with the authority, shall be punished with arrest up to one month.

Article 529.- Shall be punished with arrest up to thirty days: 1.- He who in unenclosed places has in some way left without surveillance or abandoned, loose or tied, draft or pack animals. 2.- He who, without being sufficiently capable, has driven or confined them to an inexperienced driver. 3.- He who, either by the manner of conducting or tying them, without adherence to the rules of ordinances, or by exciting or frightening them, has exposed people to some danger.

Article 529 (continued).- If the offender is a coachman or driver subject to a license, suspension of the exercise of his trade for a time of twelve days at most shall be imposed as an accessory penalty.

Article 530.- Whoever in a dangerous manner for persons or things leaves animals or vehicles in public ways or passages open to the public, shall be punished with a fine up to fifty bolívares; if the offender is a licensed coachman or driver, suspension of the exercise of his trade for a time up to fifteen days shall be imposed as an accessory penalty, without prejudice to what local ordinances provide on the matter.

Article 531.- Whoever by negligence or lack of skill has created in some manner the danger of harm against persons or serious damage to things, shall be punished with a fine up to two hundred bolívares or with arrest up to twenty days.

Article 531 (continued).- If at the same time the act constitutes an infraction of ordinances relating to the exercise of arts, commerce or industries, and provided the law does not provide otherwise, the penalty shall be arrest of three to thirty days and suspension of the art or profession for up to one month.

Article 532.- Any individual who in a public place or open to the public has a game of chance, staking or gambling, or who for that purpose has provided a local or founded establishment or house, shall be punished with arrest of five to thirty days and in case of recidivism may be imposed up to two months, or a fine not less than one hundred bolívares.

Article 532 (continued).- Arrest shall be of one to two months, and may extend up to six, in case of recidivism: 1.- If the act is habitual. 2.- If the one who has or directs the game is the banker of the meeting in which the fault is committed, and in this case suspension of the art or profession that the guilty has up to one month shall be imposed as accessory penalty.

Article 533.- Whoever, without having participated in the fault specified previously, is surprised participating in the game of chance, staking or gambling, shall be punished with a fine up to five hundred bolívares.
Article 534.- In any case of fault for game of chance and gambling, the money of the game and all objects destined to the effect shall be confiscated.
Article 535.- For determining the consequences of penal law, games of staking or chance are considered those in which gain or loss, for profit, depends entirely or almost entirely on luck.

Article 535 (continued).- Concerning the faults provided in the preceding articles, places public or open to the public shall be considered not only those properly such, but also the places destined for private meetings where something is paid to play, and those where, even without paying, any person who wishes to play has entrance.
Article 536.- Anyone who in a public place is in a manifest, annoying or repugnant state of drunkenness shall be punished with a fine up to thirty bolívares.

Article 536 (continued).- If the act is habitual, the penalty shall be arrest for one month and the authority may impose, moreover, that it be served in a house of labor or by rendering a service in some public utility enterprise.

Article 537.- Whoever in a public place or open to the public has caused another's drunkenness by making him take with that end drinks or substances capable of producing it, and likewise who has made an already drunk person take more, shall be punished with up to ten days' arrest.

Article 537 (continued).- If the act has been committed on a person under fifteen years or who manifestly was in an abnormal state due to weakness or alteration of his mental faculties, arrest shall be ten to thirty days.

Article 537 (continued).- As an accessory penalty, suspension of the exercise of the art, industry or profession shall be imposed according to the cases, if the contravener is a merchant in beverages or intoxicating substances.

Article 538.- Anyone who has presented himself in public indecently, or who with words, songs, gestures, signs or other improper acts offends public decency, shall be punished with arrest up to one month or a fine of ten to three hundred bolívares.
Article 539.- Whoever commits cruelties against animals, mistreats them without necessity or subjects them to manifestly excessive work, shall be punished with a fine up to one hundred bolívares.

Article 539 (continued).- Whoever only for a scientific or didactic purpose, outside places destined to study or teaching, has subjected animals to tests or experiments that cause disgust to persons who witness them, shall incur the same penalty.

Article 540.- Whoever having been convicted for begging, theft, robbery, extortion, fraud, kidnapping, or for the crime provided in Article 472, is in possession of money or objects not in relation with his condition or circumstances, and with respect to which he does not prove legitimate origin, shall be punished with arrest of fifteen days to two months.

Article 540 (continued).- If the guilty is found in possession of falsified or altered keys, or instruments suitable to open or force locks, without being able to justify their legitimate current destination, he shall be punished with arrest up to two months.
Article 540 (continued).- The money and suspicious objects shall be confiscated.

Article 541.- Any individual who, without having previously acquired certainty of a legitimate origin, has bought or received in pledge, in payment or deposit, objects that by reason of their nature or circumstances of the person who presents them or of the price demanded, or accepted, appear to come from a punishable act, shall be punished with a fine of twenty to one hundred bolívares.
Article 541 (continued).- If the contravener is one of the persons indicated in Article 540, he shall also be punished with arrest up to two months.
Article 541 (continued).- He who proves the legitimate origin of the objects shall be exempt from any penalty.

Article 542.- Any individual who after receiving money or having bought or procured objects coming from a crime, knows that they are of illegitimate origin, and has not given immediate notice to the authority, denouncing the fact, shall be punished with a fine of thirty bolívares at least, and may also be imposed arrest up to twenty days.

Article 543.- Whoever, devoted to commerce or to pawn operations of precious things or used things, does not observe for the purpose the prescriptions of law or regulations relative to his commerce or operations, shall be punished with a fine up to three hundred bolívares and in case of recidivism in the same infraction, arrest up to thirty days and suspension of the exercise of the profession or industry shall also be imposed.

Article 544.- The blacksmith, locksmith or other craftsman who sells or delivers to anyone picks or makes for someone who is not the owner of the premises or the object to which they are intended, or his known representative, keys of any class on wax molds or other designs or models, shall be punished with arrest up to one month or with a fine of ten to one hundred fifty bolívares.

Article 545.- The blacksmith, locksmith or other craftsman who opens locks of any class at the request of some individual, without being previously sure that the requester is the owner of the premises or house that is to be opened or his legitimate representative, shall be punished with arrest up to twenty days or a fine up to one hundred twenty bolívares.

Article 546.- Whoever in public exercise of commerce has in his establishment or market weights or measures different from those authorized by law shall be punished with a fine of ten to fifty bolívares, which in case of recidivism in the same fault may be one hundred bolívares.

Article 547 (Complementary Provision).- The provisions of this Book do not exclude nor limit the attributions that, by municipal laws or other special ones, correspond to officials and Corporations of the Public Administration, to issue Police Ordinances and public order edicts, as well as to correct administratively the contraventions or faults, in case that their repression is entrusted to them by the same laws.
Article 548 (Final Provision).- The Penal Code of June 30, 1915 is repealed.
Article 548 (continued).- This reformed Code shall begin to govern from its publication in the OFFICIAL GAZETTE.

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "malicious software" means a computer programme intentionally designed to— (a) gain unauthorised access to a computer, computer system or computer data;

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "malicious software" means a computer programme intentionally designed to— (c) deprive access to a computer or computer system; or
2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "malicious software" means a computer programme intentionally designed to— (d) interfere with normal computer or computer system usage;

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "monitor" means to observe and analyse digital activities including network traffic, system logs, or user behavior, with the goal of detecting and preventing cyber security threats or cyber crimes;
2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "penetration testing" has the meaning assigned to the words Act No. of in the Cyber Security Act, 2025; 2025

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "private communication" has the meaning assigned to the Act No. of words in the Cyber Security Act, 2025; 2025

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "sexual conduct" includes sexual intercourse whether between persons or between a person and an animal, masturbation, sexual sadistic or masochistic abuse or lascivious exhibition of the genitals or pubic area of any person;

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "telecommunication infrastructure" means infrastructure that facilitates the conveyance of signals by wire, radio, optical, or other electro-magnetic means, including satellite networks and electronic communication service provider networks;

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "traffic data" means digital data that— (b) is generated by a computer system that is part of the chain of communication; and

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "traffic data" means digital data that— (c) shows the communication’s origin, destination, route, time, date, size, duration or the type of underlying services.

3. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority or in excess of authority, infringe any security measure, or monitor a computer system or any part of a computer system of another person.

3. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1), commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding five hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, or to both.

4. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority, interfere with data or a computer system of another person in a way which causes the data or computer system to be modified, destroyed, altered or otherwise rendered ineffective;

4. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority, interfere with data or a computer system of another person in a way which obstructs, interrupts or interferes with another person’s lawful use of data;

4. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority, interfere with data or a computer system of another person in a way which denies access to data to a person who is authorised to access it;
4. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority, interfere with data or a computer system of another person in a way which causes data of another person to deteriorate;
4. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority, interfere with data or a computer system of another person in a way which deletes data of another person.

4. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding five hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, or to both.

5. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority, communicate, disclose or transmit data, information, a programme, an access code or a command relating to critical information or critical information infrastructure to any person not authorised to access such data, information, programme, access code or command.

5. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding seven hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not less than seven years and not exceeding fifteen years.
6. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority possess unauthorised data relating to critical information or critical information infrastructure.

6. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1), commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding seven hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not less than seven years and not exceeding fifteen years.

7. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority, using a computer or computer system acquire trade secrets or proprietary or confidential data by accessing or copying electronic files.

7. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1), commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding one million penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years, or to both.
8. (1) A person shall not intentionally introduce or spread malicious software into a computer or computer system of another person.

8. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding one million five hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fifteen years, or to both.
9. (1) A person commits an offence if that person intentionally and without lawful authority hinders or interferes with a computer or computer system of another person;
9. (1) A person commits an offence if that person intentionally and without lawful authority renders a computer or computer system incapable of providing normal services to its legitimate users.

9. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1), commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding five hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, or to both.

10. (1) A person commits an offence if that person, using a device, records a private conversation without notifying the parties to the conversation, whether or not that person is a party to the conversation without prior notice.

10. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1), commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding two hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, or to both.
10. (3) Despite subsection (1), it shall not be an offence to record a private conversation where the private conversation is unintentionally recorded through a device.

10. (3) Despite subsection (1), it shall not be an offence to record a private conversation where a law enforcement officer reasonably suspects that there is— (i) a threat to life or an imminent threat of serious violence to a person; (ii) a threat of substantial damage to property; or (iii) an offence under any written law that may be committed;
10. (3) Despite subsection (1), it shall not be an offence to record a private conversation where it is reasonably necessary for the protection of the lawful interests of a party to the conversation.

11. (1) A person commits an offence if that person, intentionally and without lawful authority, produces, sells, procures for use, imports, exports, distributes or makes available a device or a computer programme, that is designed or adapted for the purpose of committing an offence;

11. (1) A person commits an offence if that person, intentionally and without lawful authority, produces, sells, procures for use, imports, exports, distributes or makes available a computer password, access code or any other electronic authentication data by which the whole or any part of a computer or computer system is capable of being accessed;

11. (1) A person commits an offence if that person, intentionally and without lawful authority, produces, sells, procures for use, imports, exports, distributes or makes available software code that is capable of causing damage to a computer or computer system.

11. (2) A person convicted of an offence under subsection (1), is liable, to a fine not exceeding five hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, or to both.

12. (1) A person shall not intentionally and without lawful authority, input, alter, delete, or suppress computer data resulting in inauthentic data, with the intent that the inauthentic data be considered or acted on by another person as if it were authentic, regardless of whether the data is directly readable or intelligible.

12. (2) A person who contravenes subsection (1), commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding five hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, or to both.

12. (3) A person commits an offence if that person with intent to defraud or deceive another person for the purpose of procuring an economic benefit for oneself or another person inputs, alters, deletes or suppresses electronic data;

12. (3) A person commits an offence if that person with intent to defraud or deceive another person for the purpose of procuring an economic benefit for oneself or another person interferes with the functioning of a computer or computer system.
