Assistance by area civil protection officers IT is hereby notified that the Minister of Health and Child Care has, in terms of section 68 of the Public Health Act [Chapter 15:17], made the following regulations: — Title 1. (1) These regulations may be cited as the Public Health (COVID-19 Prevention and Containment) Regulations, 2020.
Interpretation 2. In these regulations — "area civil protection officer" means an area civil protection officer referred to in section 17 of the Civil Protection Act [Chapter 10:06]\;

2. In these regulations — "COVID-19" means the Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCov), which is an infectious disease caused by a virus which, having emerged during 2019, was declared a global pandemic by the World Health Organisation on the 11th March, 2020;
2. In these regulations — "enforcement officer" means — (a) a police officer, peace officer or member of the municipal police force established for any local authority;

2. In these regulations — "enforcement officer" means — (b) the Chief Health Officer, every Director (Health Services) of any local authority, every district health officer of any district, and every medical officer of health (in each case assisted by a police officer, peace officer or member of a municipal police force);
2. In these regulations — "enforcement officer" means — (c) anarea civil protectionofficers identified pursuant to section 10;
2. In these regulations — "FED declaration" means the declaration in terms of section 3(1) of COVID-19 as a formidable epidemic disease;
2. In these regulations — "gathering" means any assembly, concourse or procession of more than one hundred (100) persons, whether wholly or partially in open air or in a building;
2. In these regulations — "isolation" means separating a sick individual withCOVID-19 from healthy individuals in such a manner as to prevent the spread of infection or contamination by COVID-19;

2. In these regulations — "quarantine" means separating asymptomatic individuals potentially exposed to COVID-19 from non-exposed individuals in such a manner as to prevent the possible spread of infection or contamination by CO VID-19;
2. In these regulations — "school" means a Government school or a school registered under the Education Act [Chapter 25:04],

Declaration of COVID-19 as Formidable Epidemic Disease 3. (1) In terms of section 64(1) (a) of the Act, and for the purposes of Sub-PartC of Part IV ("Infectious Diseases") of the Act, COVID-19 is declared to be a formidable epidemic disease.

3. (2) The declaration of CO VID-19 as a formidable epidemic disease has effect till the 20th May, 2020, unless the Minister earlier, by general notice in the Gazette, extends these regulations by afurther month, and may, upon expiry of that extension, in like manner further extend them for a month at a time.
Object and scope of regulations 4. (1) The object of these regulations is to enable the implementation of measures to prevent, contain and treat the incidence of COVID-19.
4. (2) These regulations are enforceable whether or not a State of Disaster in relation to CO VID-19 is in force under the Civil Protection Act [Chapter l():06\.
Prohibition of gatherings 5. (1) In order to contain the spread of COVID-19, all gatherings for whatever purpose, are hereby prohibited during the period when the FED declaration is in force.
5. (2)(a) An enforcement officer must, where a gathering takes place in contravention of subsection (1), order the persons atthe gathering to disperse immediately;

5. (2)(b) An enforcement officer must, where a gathering takes place in contravention of subsection (1), if they refuse to disperse, take appropriate action, including (subject to the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Act) arrest and detention.

5. (3)(a) Subsection (2) does not apply to any school, unless a district health officer, in relation to any school within a district for which the district health officer is responsible, declares by any means likely to make such declaration known to the school or schools concerned, that any specified school or group or class of schools shall be regarded as a gathering for the purposes of this section.

5. (3)(b) Subsection (2) does not apply to any school, unless a Director (Health Services), in relation to any local authority for which the Director (Health Services) is responsible, declares by any means likely to make such declaration known to the school or schools concerned, that any specified school or group or class of schools shall be regarded as a gathering for the purposes of this section.

5. (3)(c) Subsection (2) does not apply to any school, unless the Minister, acting on the advice of the Chief Health Officer, declares by any means likely to make such declaration known to the school or schools concerned, that any specified school or group or class of schools shall be regarded as a gathering for the purposes of this section.

5. (3)(d) Subsection (2) does not apply to any school, unless the Chief Health Officer, after consulting the Minister, declares by any means likely to make such declaration known to the school or schools concerned, that any specified school or group or class of schools shall be regarded as a gathering for the purposes of this section.

5. (3)(a) Any person partaking at a gathering or convener thereof— partakes in or convenes a gathering knowing that such gathering is prohibited in terms of subsection (1); shall be guilty of an offence and liable to hue not exceeding level 12 or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year to both such Hue and such imprisonment.

5. (3)(b) Any person partaking at a gathering or convener thereof— refuses to disperse from a gathering after being ordered to disperse in terms of subsection (2)(a); shall be guilty of an offence and liable to hue not exceeding level 12 or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year to both such Hue and such imprisonment.

Compulsory testing, detention, etc. to contain COVID-19 6. (1)(a) An enforcement officer referred to in paragraph (b) of the deh nition of "enforcement officer" in section 2 may, in relation to any individual or group of individuals who are suspected of being infected with, or who may have recently been exposed to the risk of infection by, COVID-19, order any one or a combination of the following things — order the individual or individuals concerned to submit to a medical examination, instantly or at the time and place ordered, which examination may include but not be limited to the taking of any bodily sample by a health practitioner or other person acting underthe supervision of a health practitioner;

6. (1)(b) An enforcement officer referred to in paragraph (b) of the deh nition of "enforcement officer" in section 2 may, in relation to any individual or group of individuals who are suspected of being infected with, or who may have recently been exposed to the risk of infection by, COVID-19, order any one or a combination of the following things — order the mandatory treatment or prophylaxis of the individual or individuals concerned;

6. (1)(c) An enforcement officer referred to in paragraph (b) of the deh nition of "enforcement officer" in section 2 may, in relation to any individual or group of individuals who are suspected of being infected with, or who may have recently been exposed to the risk of infection by, COVID-19, order any one or a combination of the following things — order the sequestration or disinfection or both of the baggage and personal effects of the individual or individuals concerned;

6. (1)(d) An enforcement officer referred to in paragraph (b) of the deh nition of "enforcement officer" in section 2 may, in relation to any individual or group of individuals who are suspected of being infected with, or who may have recently been exposed to the risk of infection by, COVID-19, order any one or a combination of the following things — order the disinfection or evacuation (for a period not exceeding 24 hours) or both of the homes of the individual or individuals concerned or of any building or premises wherein they work or gather for any purpose;

6. (1)(e) An enforcement officer referred to in paragraph (b) of the deh nition of "enforcement officer" in section 2 may, in relation to any individual or group of individuals who are suspected of being infected with, or who may have recently been exposed to the risk of infection by, COVID-19, order any one or a combination of the following things — order the on-site detention, isolation or quarantining of the individual orindividuals concerned, ortheirremoval to a hospital or place of isolation or quarantine, and their detention at such site, hospital or place of isolation, pending the examination, treatment, prophylaxis or disinfection contemplated by paragraph (a) or (b), for a period expiring 48 hours after such order or until the certification of the individual or individuals concerned to be free of infection from COVID-19, which occurs the later.

6. (2)(a) An enforcement officer may order any individual or group individuals who have been confirmed, clinically or by a laboratory, as having COVID-19 to be quarantined for a period of up to 14 days within their homes or in a hospital or place of isolation and, during the period the quarantine is in force— to submit to further medical examination (including, but not limited to, the taking of any bodily sample by a health practitioner or other person acting under the supervision of a health practitioner);

6. (2)(b) An enforcement officer may order any individual or group individuals who have been confirmed, clinically or by a laboratory, as having COVID-19 to be quarantined for a period of up to 14 days within their homes or in a hospital or place of isolation and, during the period the quarantine is in force— to be admitted or removed to a hospital or place of isolation;

6. (2)(c) An enforcement officer may order any individual or group individuals who have been confirmed, clinically or by a laboratory, as having COVID-19 to be quarantined for a period of up to 14 days within their homes or in a hospital or place of isolation and, during the period the quarantine is in force— to undergo mandatory treatment or prophylaxis.
6. (3)(a) Orders made under subsection (1) or (2) — shall be communicated by any means (verbal, written, broadcast or electronic) likely to make them known to the persons affected by them;

6. (3)(b) Orders made under subsection (1) or (2) — that provide for the detention, isolation or quarantine of any individual or group of individuals must make reasonable provision for the individual or individuals concerned— (i) to have access to or be provided with basic necessities to enable them to maintainan acceptable standard of nutrition and hygiene;

6. (3)(b)(ii) Orders made under subsection (1) or (2) — that provide for the detention, isolation or quarantine of any individual or group of individuals must make reasonable provision for the individual or individuals concerned— (ii) to be released temporarily from such detention, isolation or quarantine under specified conditions with the knowledge or consent of an enforcement officer;
6. (3)(c) Orders made under subsection (1) or (2) — shall be enforced, as needed, with the assistance of persons referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition of "enforcement officer" in section 2;

6. (3)(d) Orders made under subsection (1) or (2) — shall be recorded and authenticated by the enforcement officers who issued them, and be kept for a period of at least twelve months in the event that they are required for the purposes of any audit or judicial proceedings.

6. (4)(a) Any person who— disobeys an order made under subsection (1) or (2); shall be guilty of an offence and liable to fine not exceeding level 12 or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year to both such fine and such imprisonment.

6. (4)(b) Any person who— having been ordered to be detained, isolated or quarantined in any place, removes himself or herself from such detention, isolation or quarantine without the knowledge or consent of an enforcement officer, or contrary to any conditions specified for any temporary release from such detention, isolation or quarantine; shall be guilty of an offence and liable to fine not exceeding level 12 or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year to both such fine and such imprisonment.
6. (5) Any person who escapes from any place of detention, isolation or quarantine may be arrested without warrant.

Places of quarantine and isolation 7. (1) The Minister may identify or approve sites to be used as isolation and quarantine facilities for the temporary confinement and treatment of individuals or groups of individuals who are suspected of being infected with, or who may have recently been exposed to the risk of infection by, or who have been confirmed as having CO VID-19.
7. (2) The Minister shall as soon as practicable specify the sites identified or approved under subsection (1) by general notice in the Gazette.

Ministerial orders 8. (1) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (a) impose restrictions of public traffic and of the movements of persons by means of curfews in any local authority;

8. (1)(b) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (b) close schools or regulate and restrict school attendance in any local authority;

8. (1)(c) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (c) close places of worship and restrict gatherings or meetings forthe purpose of public worship in any local authority;

8. (1)(d) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (d) regulate, restrict or, where deemed necessary, close in any local authority any place or places of public entertainment, recreation or amusement, or where intoxicating liquor is sold by retail, and regulate or restrict, or, where deemed necessary, prohibit the convening, holding or attending of entertainments, assemblies, meetings or other public gatherings of less than one hundred persons;

8. (1)(e) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (e) direct the making of inquiries into the cause of death of any person, apart from any inquiry by a magistrate under any other enactment;

8. (1)(f) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (f) order, when deemed necessary, post-mortem examinations or exhumations;

8. (1)(g) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (g) prohibit in special circumstances the burial of any dead body in any local authority except on a ccitilicate by a medical officer appointed to grant such ccrtilicates or after compliance with any other specified conditions;

8. (1)(h) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (h) regulate the mode of disposal, the times and places of burial of dead bodies and the manner of conducting removals and burials thereof in any local authority;

8. (1)(i) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (i) regulate and restrict and, if deemed necessary, prohibit the removal of merchandise or any article or thing into, out of or within any in any local authority or specified or defined area;

8. (1)(j) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (j) facilitate the provision of disinfecting plant and equipment, and the disinfection or, where disinfection is impossible, the destruction of any article or thing, or the disinfection of any premises which are or are believed to be contaminated with the infection of such disease;

8. (1)(k) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (k) authorise in any local authority the inspection of premises and articles and the discovery and remedying of sanitary or other defects likely to favour the spread or render difficult the eradication of COVID-19;

8. (1)(l) In pursuance of the object of these regulations the Minister may (in consultation with the President, and in conformity with any directions the President may give) by orders published in the Gazette— (1) authorise in any local authority the evacuation, closing, alteration or, if deemed necessary, the demolition or destruction of any premises the occupation or use of which is considered likely to favour the spread or render more difficult the eradication of such disease, and define the circumstances under which compensation may be paid in respect of any premises so demolished or destroyed and the manner of fixing such compensation;

8. (2) Any person who disobeys or fails to comply with an order made in terms of subsection (1) shall be guilty of an offence and liable to fine not exceeding level 12 or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year to both such fine and such imprisonment.

Certification of certain enforcement officers 9. (1) The chief executive officer of every local authority shall furnish each enforcement officer referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition of "enforcement officer" who is acting within the jurisdiction of the local authority with a certificate signed by or on behalf of the chief executive officer stating that he or she has been appointed as an enforcement officer for the purpose of these regulations.

9. (2) An enforcement officer referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition of "enforcement officer" shall, on demand by any person affected by the exercise of the powers conferred upon enforcement officers under these regulations, exhibit the certificate issued to him or her in terms of subsection (1).

Assistance by area civil protection officers 10. At the request of the Minister, the National Civil Protection Committee constituted under the Civil Protection Act [Chapter 10:06\ may identify area civil protection officers who, in any local authority and acting under the guidance in that local authority of any enforcement officer referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition of "enforcement officer", shall act as enforcement officers for the purposes of these regulations.

CAPITULO UNICO
GENERALIDADES
OBJETO
Art. 1.- The object of this Law is to regulate, supervise and oversee the activities related to the Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies sector, which includes the management of the radioelectric spectrum; access to essential resources; the numbering plan, the public telephony service; the efficient administration of networks; the quality, coverage and continuity of telecommunications services and the protection of the rights of users.

Art. 1.- The Superintendency General of Electricity and Telecommunications shall be the entity responsible for applying and ensuring compliance with the rules and regulations established in this Law and its regulation.

Art. 1.- The activities of telecommunications carried out by operators of the services of: a) free-to-air sound broadcasting; b) free-to-air television; c) subscription sound distribution, through cable or radioelectric means; and d) subscription television distribution through cable or radioelectric means; shall be subject to the special regime established in Title VIII of this Law.

Art. 1.- The SIGET, in the exercise of its functions, shall collect from commercial telecommunications network operators the technical information necessary to verify compliance with the law, its regulations and the standards that are applicable.

Art. 1.- The SIGET shall carry out, by itself or through experts or auditors authorized and designated for that purpose, and supervised by SIGET personnel, the inspections it deems necessary in order to verify the truthfulness of the information provided, insofar as it is necessary for the exercise of its functions.

Art. 1.- The SIGET is the entity in charge of administering, managing and monitoring the radioelectric spectrum; and is the competent authority to verify the regularity of the conditions of the enabling titles, as well as to apply the corresponding sanctions or corrective measures.

FINES
Art. 2.- The norms of this Law shall be applied pursuing the following purposes: a) To promote universal access, affordability and the apprehension of Information and Communication Technologies that allow the full exercise of the rights to freedom of expression, information, and dissemination of thought, to reduce the digital divide and contribute to social inclusion.

Art. 2.- The norms of this Law shall be applied pursuing the following purposes: b) Protection of the rights of users, of operators, providers of telecommunications services, as well as of persons in general.
Art. 2.- The norms of this Law shall be applied pursuing the following purposes: c) Development of a competitive telecommunications market at all levels.
Art. 2.- The norms of this Law shall be applied pursuing the following purposes: d) Rational and efficient use of the radioelectric spectrum.

Art. 2.- The norms of this Law shall be applied pursuing the following purposes: d) To guarantee the rational, efficient and equitable use of the radioelectric spectrum, as well as its updating, reordering or reorganization for its optimization, which allows the introduction of new services, improve existing ones, and harmonization with other countries, in accordance with the Constitution of the Republic and International Treaties subscribed, adhered to and ratified by the Republic of El Salvador that regulate the activities of the telecommunications sector.

PRINCIPLES GUIDING TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES
Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: a) Equality: operators and providers must provide users of telecommunications services under the same conditions of quality, content and place where they are used.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: b) Inclusion: real access of persons with special needs such as disability and older adults among others, to telecommunications services, under adequate conditions of quality and price, with the aim of contributing to the human development of vulnerable populations.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: c) Equity: equality of opportunities to access scarce resources, such as the radioelectric spectrum and numbering, necessary for broadcasting telecommunications services, including essential sound and television broadcasting services for the community.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: d) Privacy of Information: obligation of operators and providers to guarantee the right to privacy, freedom and secrecy of communications, as well as to protect the confidentiality of information they obtain from their users, providers or competitors, on the occasion of the provision of services, in accordance with Art. 24 of the Constitution of the Republic of El Salvador.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: e) Universality: referring to the provision of a set of telecommunications services, periodically reviewed and in accordance with technological progress, with the purpose that inhabitants of all zones and regions of the country, without discrimination, in adequate conditions of quality and price can access Information and Communication Technologies.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: f) Non-discrimination: to provide, by concessionaires, licensees and authorized holders, telecommunications services equitably in quantity, quality and coverage, without unequal treatment on grounds of gender, economic capacity, nationality, religion, ethnic origin, age or any other category contrary to the constitutional principle of equality before the Law.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: g) Maximum benefit to the user: establishment of guarantees and rights in favor of end users of telecommunications services, so that they can timely access quality services, receive information, exercise their right to freedom of choice and receive equitable, non-discriminatory treatment.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: h) Transparency: establishment of adequate conditions so that operators, providers and other interested parties can give opinions in the process of forming sectoral policies, resolutions and regulations.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: i) Publicity: every procedure must be public, except in cases the Law establishes otherwise or by reasoned resolution of the competent authority.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: j) Effective competition: application of suitable mechanisms so that in free concurrence all operators and providers in the market compete on equal terms, in order to seek the greatest benefit for inhabitants and the free exercise of the right to freedom of contract.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: k) Technological neutrality: freedom of network operators and service providers to choose and offer the technologies to be used, according to technological development, in a climate of free competition, complying with international standards that respond to quality requirements and user needs.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: l) Convergence: coordinated evolution and development of networks toward uniformity that allows common support of services and applications.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: m) Environmental sustainability: harmonization of the use and exploitation of networks and the provision of telecommunications services, facilitating a healthy and environmentally balanced environment and friendly to nature. Operators and providers must comply with applicable environmental legislation.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: n) Optimization of scarce resources: allocation and use of scarce telecommunications resources objectively, timely, transparently, non-discriminatorily and efficiently, with the dual objective of ensuring effective competition as well as expansion and improvement of networks, quality and continuity of service.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: o) Financial management of scarce resources: the valuation of scarce telecommunications resources is based on allocation and utilization, according to market behavior, free competition, financial sustainability, continuity of service and the public interest.

Art. 2-A.- The guiding principles of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies are the following: p) Freedom of expression: the right of every person to freedom of thought and expression. This right includes freedom to seek, receive and disseminate information and ideas of all kinds, without consideration of borders, whether orally, in writing or in print or by any other procedure of their choice. The application of this principle will be encouraged in institutional decisions and actions.

ÁMBITO DE APLICACIÓN
Art. 3.- The provisions of this Law are applicable to any natural or legal person, regardless as to the latter of its nature, degree of autonomy or regime of incorporation, who develops activities, provides or receives services in the telecommunications sector, such as broadcasting, telephony, data transmission, broadband services, sound and television broadcasting services of free reception essential to the community, as well as by subscription, convergence, access to essential resources, the numbering plan and the radioelectric spectrum as intangible, demanial and scarce property.

REGIME OF FREE COMPETITION
Art. 4.- Prices and conditions of telecommunications services between operators shall be freely negotiated, except with respect to access to essential resources, in accordance with the provisions of this Law.

TECHNICAL STANDARDS
Art. 5.- All telecommunications equipment shall be subject to the norms and standards recommended by the International Telecommunication Union or by other international organizations recognized by El Salvador.

Art. 5-A.- The SIGET shall establish technical regulations based on quality norms of public telecommunications services. Every commercial telecommunications network operator shall be obliged to: a) Have an auditable measurement system that allows verification of the quality of public telecommunications services and the verification of measurements, in accordance with the technical regulations based on quality norms issued by SIGET.

Art. 5-A.- The SIGET shall establish technical regulations based on quality norms of public telecommunications services. Every commercial telecommunications network operator shall be obliged to: b) Report in the periods indicated by SIGET, on the requirements established in the technical regulations based on Quality Norms of services, indicating non-compliances of the quality indicators related to the establishment and duration of telephone calls, data services, text and multimedia messaging, voice quality, tariff application, customer service, radioelectric coverage, network damages and failures and other services provided in telecommunications networks.

Art. 5-A.- The SIGET shall be responsible for defining the Measurement and control Methodology, the content and form of information exchange; being able to audit the information and processes when it deems necessary.
Art. 5-A.- Said technical regulations shall be issued by SIGET in coordination with the Salvadoran Organization of Technical Regulation (OSARTEC).

ABBREVIATIONS, DEFINITIONS AND ACRONYMS
Art. 6.- For the purposes of this Law the following abbreviations shall be used: the Superintendency General of Electricity and Telecommunications, "SIGET"; the International Telecommunication Union, "ITU"; and the Electricity and Telecommunications Registry attached to SIGET, "the Registry".

Art. 6.- For the purposes of this Law and its Regulation, all abbreviations, definitions and acronyms shall be understood as follows: BAND OF FREQUENCIES: which may be abbreviated "Band": the portion of the spectrum whose frequencies are between a minimum frequency and a maximum frequency.
Art. 6.- ACCESS CHARGE: minimum monthly charge that each user must pay to be connected to the network, not including the value of additional telephony services.

Art. 6.- LEASED CIRCUITS: means fixed telecommunications network installations between two or more designated points, which are set aside for dedicated use or availability for a particular client or for other users chosen by that client.

Art. 6.- PHYSICAL CO-LOCATION/CO-LOCATION: means the power of a telephony service operator to request from another the lease of the physical spaces necessary for the realization of network interconnection. The power of an operator to request the lease corresponds to the obligation of the requested operator to grant it. The requesting party shall have the right to enjoy conditions similar to those that the operator granting access has contracted with other operators.

Art. 6.- NATIONAL FREQUENCY ALLOCATION TABLE abbreviated "CNAF": document containing the allocation and assignment of the different bands of the radioelectric spectrum for the different radioelectric services, as well as classifications of use, norms and conditions for its use and exploitation.
Art. 6.- UNBUNDLING: the division into leasable elements of the different services that make up the interconnection service.

Art. 6.- ENCRYPTION: is the system by which, with the help of techniques or computer programs, certain information is ciphered or encoded in order to make it inaccessible or unintelligible to someone not authorized to access it.
Art. 6.- NETWORK ELEMENTS: the different components of a commercial telecommunications network.

Art. 6.- RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM: set of radioelectric waves that propagate unguided below 3,000 GHz and is divided into frequency bands, which may be allocated to different radioelectric services for use in different geographic areas and periods. The term "spectrum" will be used by default to refer to the radioelectric spectrum.
Art. 6.- FREQUENCIES OF EXCLUSIVE NATURE: those that for technical reasons are granted uniquely in the same geographic zone.

Art. 6.- FREQUENCIES OF NON-EXCLUSIVE NATURE: those applied to optimize use of the available radioelectric spectrum, when two or more frequencies for technical reasons can be effectively reused in the same band and geographic area without harmful interference.
Art. 6.- RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM FRAGMENTATION: division of a portion of the spectrum, in bandwidth, time and geographic space, whenever technically feasible.
Art. 6.- RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM DEFRAGMENTATION: integration of a portion of the spectrum, in bandwidth, time and geographic space, whenever technically and legally feasible.

Art. 6.- INTERCONNECTION: is the service that allows operators and users of different networks to route telecommunications traffic from one to another network so that all end users are able to communicate with each other, or so that end users connected to an access service network are able to obtain services provided by an intermediate service operator.
Art. 6.- LIBERATE FREQUENCIES: shall be understood as SIGET's power to free portions of the spectrum that were modified or reclassified, without reassigning existing stations, following due process.

Art. 6.- COMMUNITY MEDIA AND OTHER NON-PROFIT OPERATORS: those composed of sound and television broadcasting stations, intended to serve a determined audience, managed by an association or foundation without profit, of social interest, facilitating the right to information and communication as an exercise of freedom of expression, encouraging citizen participation to contribute to affordable, equitable, inclusive, sustainable development of communities and social sectors of the country.

Art. 6.- NON-USE OF FREQUENCIES: for purposes of this Law non-use of the frequency shall also be understood as: a) Non-provision to the end user or the public of a telecommunications service in accordance with the technical coverage conditions established in the contract; b) In broadcasting consists of the electromagnetic signal not carrying varied audio and/or video information. Likewise the verification of the transmitted electromagnetic signal will be only of the technical characteristics and parameters; c) Non-use of frequencies in telecommunications systems intended for official use or regulated private use. The foregoing, to the detriment of efficient use of the spectrum and depriving the end user of the right of access to information and communication, as well as limiting free competition.
Art. 6.- COMMERCIAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS NETWORK OPERATOR abbreviated "OPERATOR": natural or legal person who offers one or more commercial telecommunications services.
Art. 6.- NUMBERING PLAN: fundamental technical plan developed and administered by SIGET that allows by assignment of a number the unique and unequivocal identification of the user or end device.
Art. 6.- PRE-SUBSCRIPTION: system by which an access service operator grants its customers access to intermediate services without using the multi-carrier operator selection code.

Art. 6.- SIGNIFICANT PROVIDER: means a provider of public telecommunications services that has the capacity to materially affect, considering prices and supply, the terms of participation in the relevant market of telecommunications services, as a result of: a) controlling essential facilities; or b) making use of its market position.
Art. 6.- COMMERCIAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS NETWORK abbreviated "NETWORK": infrastructure or installation used by an operator to provide commercial telecommunications services.

Art. 6.- TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICE RESELLER: any natural or legal person who purchases telecommunications services wholesale, directly from network operators or other intermediaries, to resell to end users.
Art. 6.- REASSIGN FREQUENCIES: change of frequency of a radioelectric station, maintaining the same service and technical operating conditions following due process.

Art. 6.- SPECTRUM REORDERING OR REORGANIZATION: SIGET's power to re-assign, reclassify, reserve, reassign and free frequencies of the radioelectric spectrum for technical reasons and following due process.

Art. 6.- RE-ATTRIBUTE FREQUENCIES: shall be understood as the change in a certain portion of the radioelectric spectrum of the attributed service and record that change in the CNAF, following due process.
Art. 6.- RECLASSIFY FREQUENCIES: shall be understood as the change of the use classification of a portion of the radioelectric spectrum and record that change in the CNAF, following due process.

Art. 6.- RESERVE FREQUENCIES: shall be understood as the reservation of a portion of the spectrum for future uses or radioelectric services determined by technological advancement or for reasons of national security, and its respective notation in the CNAF, following due process.
Art. 6.- RADIOELECTRIC SERVICE: any service that uses radioelectric waves attributed in the CNAF.
Art. 6.- RADIOCOMMUNICATION SERVICE: radioelectric service that involves transmission, emission or reception of radioelectric waves for specific telecommunication purposes.

Art. 6.- BROADCASTING SERVICE: radiocommunication service whose emissions are intended to be received directly by the public in general. Such services cover sound emissions, television or other kinds.
Art. 6.- DIFFUSION SERVICE: communication made in one direction to several reception points simultaneously.

Art. 6.- INTERMEDIATE SERVICES: services provided by an operator to interconnect two or more access networks with each other, or to offer temporary services to end users of an access service network, through it.
Art. 6.- ACCESS SERVICES abbreviated "ACCESS": services that grant the end user the possibility to initiate or receive a communication using the commercial telecommunications network.

Art. 6.- AMATEUR RADIO SERVICE: radiocommunication service whose object is individual instruction, intercommunication and technical studies carried out by amateurs, that is by duly authorized persons interested in radiotechnics, exclusively personal and non-profit.

Art. 6.- PUBLIC TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICE: means any telecommunications service that the State requires by law, and that is offered to the general public. These services may include, among others, telephony and data transmission typically related to customer-provided information between two or more points, without any end-to-end change in the form or content of customer information, excluding information services.

Art. 6.- INFORMATION SERVICES: means offering a capacity to generate, acquire, store, transform, process, retrieve, use or make information available through telecommunications, and includes electronic advertising, excluding the use of any of these capacities for administration, control or operation of a telecommunications system or administration of a telecommunications service.

Art. 6.- MULTI-CARRIER SYSTEM: system by which an access service operator grants its customers access to intermediate services on a non-discriminatory basis, through dialing a predetermined number of digits.

Art. 6.- TELECOMMUNICATIONS: all transmission and reception of signals of any nature, typically electromagnetic, that contain among other data, sounds and images; includes any type of information to be communicated at a distance; including diffusion, broadcasting, fixed or mobile telephony and fixed or mobile internet and which constitute a social and economic factor of great impact, gaining importance in globalization and the information and knowledge society.

Art. 6.- INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES (ICT): set of resources, tools, equipment, software, applications, networks and media, that allow compilation, processing, storage, transmission of information such as: voice, data, text, video and images, that contribute to quality improvement and the country's economic growth toward the information and knowledge society.

Art. 6.- INTERNATIONAL MOBILE TELECOMMUNICATIONS abbreviated "IMT": international mobile telecommunications systems IMT, which offer access to a wide range of telecommunication services supported by mobile and fixed networks that increasingly use packet technology. Their key characteristics are: high degree of worldwide functionality; wide range of services and applications; mutual compatibility and with fixed networks; interworking with other radio access systems; high quality services; user equipment usable globally; applications, services and equipment easy to handle; worldwide roaming; increased maximum data speeds to support advanced applications and services, and others, whose characteristics may be updated according to ITU regulations on the subject.

Art. 6.- ENABLING TITLE: administrative act granted by SIGET for concession, authorization or license for the use and exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum; as well as for the provision of public telecommunications services.

Art. 6.- USE OF FREQUENCIES: shall be understood as the term that identifies the use to which a certain portion of the radioelectric spectrum corresponds; which shall be used according to the following classification: a) REGULATED USE: that which requires a concession. This includes: i) Commercial regulated use: those that provide public telecommunications services for profit, including essential broadcasting services to the community; ii) Community regulated use: those that provide essential broadcasting services to the community, non-profit; and iii) Private regulated use: those that do not provide public telecommunications services.
Art. 6.- USE OF FREQUENCIES: b) OFFICIAL USE: that used by state institutions and which requires authorization.

Art. 6.- USE OF FREQUENCIES: c) FREE USE: spectrum available to the general public, to operate radioelectric stations including among others some scientific research applications, low-power devices and radio amateurs. For this purpose SIGET will issue corresponding regulations for each band of this use, specifying technical operating conditions and where technically necessary issue corresponding licenses. All free use frequencies shall operate in a no protection/no interference regime.
Art. 6.- END USER OF THE SERVICE: is any natural or legal person who purchases telecommunications services for their own use.

TITULO II
CAPITULO I
CONCESSIONS FOR PUBLIC SERVICE
CONCESSION FOR THE PUBLIC TELEPHONY SERVICE
Art. 7.- Telephony is a public service.

Art. 7.- Operators interested in providing telephony services must request a concession from SIGET for the exploitation of the service, which shall be granted automatically for a period of thirty years upon compliance with the registration requirements to be established in the Regulation of this Law.
Art. 7.- Such concessions shall be granted without any limitation as to quantity and location, multiple concessions may exist in the same geographic area.

Art. 7.- Concessions for the exploitation of the public telephony service may be revoked only for one of the following causes: a) For failing to provide the public telephony service after two years from the grant of the concession, after hearing the interested party.

Art. 7.- Concessions for the exploitation of the public telephony service may be revoked only for one of the following causes: b) For having been sanctioned for committing three infractions classified as very serious in the Law within a period of three years.
Art. 7.- Concessions shall be extinguished by any of the following causes: a) By the operator's renunciation of said concession.
Art. 7.- Concessions shall be extinguished by any of the following causes: b) By expiration of the term for which they were granted.

Art. 7.- Concessions revoked or extinguished may be renewed by new application to SIGET; however, when the operator has renounced or committed infractions classified as very serious, a period of two years must elapse before SIGET may grant a new concession to them.

Art. 7.- In cases where a concession for the provision of the public telephony service is revoked or extinguished, SIGET must inform in advance and with sufficient time the Ministry of Economy, so as to guarantee continuity of the service.

APPROVAL OF PUBLIC SERVICE TARIFFS
Art. 8.- SIGET shall determine the maximum value of both the basic tariffs of public fixed and mobile telephony services, as well as the basic interconnection charges, in both cases already regulated by SIGET, according to regulatory norms based on cost studies and international price comparisons, whose methodology is recognized by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). Said methodology must be implemented within no more than nine months from the entry into force of this Decree.

Art. 8.- Operators shall be obliged to promptly and expeditiously submit to SIGET legally audited information requested by it for determination of tariffs and maximum charges provided in the preceding paragraph. Failure by operators to comply with this obligation shall be considered a very serious infraction for purposes of application of this law.

Art. 8.- SIGET shall carry out an annual review of maximum telephony tariffs and maximum interconnection charges. The first review SIGET is obliged to perform under this provision shall be carried out after one year has elapsed from the implementation of the cost-based methodology for establishing tariffs and charges.

Art. 8.- SIGET shall periodically publish the maximum tariffs of public telecommunications services, after the review referred to in the previous paragraph. Likewise, operators must publish at least quarterly, in a widely circulated national written medium, the tariffs for the public telephony services they provide.
Art. 8.- SIGET shall suspend approval of any tariff adjustment made while the affected operator is in breach of any final resolution of SIGET.

PREVENTION OF ANTICOMPETITIVE PRACTICES
Art. 8-A.- In order to prevent a significant provider from employing anticompetitive practices in its territory, SIGET shall collaborate with the Competition Superintendency so that corresponding measures are taken.

CAPITULO II
OWNERSHIP AND MANAGEMENT OF THE RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM
TITULARITY OF THE SPECTRUM
Art. 9- The radioelectric spectrum is a limited natural resource and is an intangible demanial asset, property of the State. Its exploitation and use must be carried out rationally, efficiently, economically, sustainably and equitably, seeking the common good and compliance with constitutional precepts.

Art. 9- The State may grant the right to exploit portions of the radioelectric spectrum to any natural or legal person for a period of twenty years, renewable but never automatically; conditions and procedures established by SIGET must be complied with in the forms provided in this Law.

RULES FOR REGISTRATION OF SECONDARY MARKET OPERATIONS
Art. 9-A.- Concessionaires may transfer at any title or lease the exploitation right of concessioned frequencies, subject to compliance with the following requirements: 1) That the contract between the concessionaire and the acquirer or lessee be authorized by SIGET regarding technical aspects.
Art. 9-A.- Concessionaires may transfer or lease exploitation rights subject to: 2) That the acquirer maintain solvency for obligations arising from the concession.

Art. 9-A.- Concessionaires may transfer or lease exploitation rights subject to: 3) That continuity in the provision of public services is not affected with respect to conditions originally offered to consumers.

Art. 9-A.- Concessionaires may transfer or lease exploitation rights subject to: 4) That the concessionaire and the interested party demonstrate financial feasibility for efficient operation of the concession.

Art. 9-A.- Concessionaires may transfer or lease exploitation rights subject to: 5) Efficient use of the spectrum relative to utilization of the entire assigned bandwidth and coverage area, to be determined by the respective technical analysis prepared by SIGET.
Art. 9-A.- Concessionaires may transfer or lease exploitation rights subject to: 6) That the interested party and applicant are solvent with respect to firm and enforceable State tax obligations.

Art. 9-A.- Concessionaires may transfer or lease exploitation rights subject to: 7) Compliance with the provisions of this Law regulating procedures, requirements and appropriate conditions for exploitation of the concession.

Art. 9-A.- Concessionaires may transfer or lease exploitation rights subject to: 8) When SIGET deems necessary, it shall request opinion from the Competition Superintendency, for which it shall have a maximum period of forty-five days. If the opinion determines that it does not generate concentration, the corresponding procedure shall proceed.
Art. 9-A.- In the case of partial transfer or lease of the concession, prior authorization from SIGET for the respective fragmentation must be obtained if applicable.

Art. 9-A.- In any total or partial transfer of the spectrum, the acquirer shall pay SIGET administrative and registration processing costs according to the current cost tariff structure in the Registry published by SIGET which shall be indexed annually with the CPI.

Art. 9-A.- Requirements to obtain authorization to transfer or lease shall be subject to the Law and its Regulation. SIGET shall authorize transfers and leases observing compliance with the guiding principles of telecommunications.
Art. 9-A.- Any sublease of frequencies shall be null and void.

SPECTRUM MANAGEMENT
Art. 9-B.- SIGET is the state entity responsible for management of the radioelectric spectrum. This management includes planning, administration, monitoring and technical control of the use and exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum, in a rational, efficient, sustainable and equitable manner, making use of procedures and resources required by SIGET for that purpose, including economic, financial, legal, scientific and technical types.

SPECTRUM MANAGEMENT TASKS
Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities for spectrum management: a) Manage efficient exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum within the law by granting administrative acts or enabling titles of operation as necessary.

Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities: b) Update technical regulations to execute the function of supervision and surveillance of the radioelectric spectrum, to ensure compliance with technical, legal and financial aspects of the concession.

Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities: c) Update the economic value of the radioelectric spectrum for new concessions in accordance with comparative market studies.

Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities: d) Administer the National Frequency Allocation Table (CNAF), including its timely update according to national needs and relevant international treaties of which the Republic of El Salvador is a signatory.
Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities: e) Administer the National Frequency Registry (RNF) and keep it updated.
Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities: f) Administer the national spectrum monitoring system.

Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities: g) Coordinate with other countries the use and harmonization of the radioelectric spectrum to prevent harmful interference preventively or correctively.

Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities: h) Order and reorganize the spectrum to guarantee its rational, efficient, economic and equitable use, in response to national needs and consistent with technological advances.

Art. 9-C.- SIGET as spectrum manager shall carry out, among others and following due process, the following activities: i) Re-attribute, reclassify, reserve, reassign and release frequencies of the radioelectric spectrum for reasons of feasibility, opportunity and convenience, objectively, timely, transparently and non-discriminatorily, in accordance with this Law, respecting third party rights, complying with due process and based on technical criteria.

Art. 9-C.- If in the exercise of the faculty in literal i) rights of exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum of broadcasting concessionaires are affected, SIGET must reassign new exclusive nature frequencies in favor of affected concessionaires, respecting their rights, the attributed service, the originally granted bandwidth and exploitation rights derived therefrom, maintaining the same conditions as originally granted.

CNAF UPDATE
Art. 10.- It is SIGET's attribution to prepare and keep updated the National Frequency Allocation Table (CNAF), a document that shall contain at least the allocation and assignment of different bands of the radioelectric spectrum for different services, conditions and use and exploitation classifications, according to national needs, without determining the type of technology to be used, under the principle of technological neutrality.
Art. 10.- The CNAF must be consistent with the ITU Radio Regulations. Therefore SIGET shall update the CNAF at least every four years.

PUBLIC AND MANDATORY CHARACTER OF THE CNAF
Art. 11.- The CNAF shall be public and of mandatory compliance and may be consulted by any person, subject to measures issued by SIGET for safeguarding and conservation of contained information.
Art. 11.- The document shall include frequencies, norms and technical conditions to be used by broadcasting service operators.

SPECTRUM CLASSIFICATION AND ENABLING TITLE
Art. 12.- The radioelectric spectrum is classified into free use spectrum, official use spectrum and regulated use spectrum.

Art. 12.- Free use spectrum is the set of frequency bands that can be used by the general public to operate radioelectric stations that include transmitters under conditions established by SIGET in the CNAF.

Art. 12.- Official use spectrum is the set of frequency bands destined for exclusive use by state institutions, bands that must be reserved for future applications, and those that must be protected by virtue of international Treaties, Agreements or Conventions. Official frequencies shall be recorded as such in the CNAF and except those assigned to state institutions shall be registered in the name of SIGET.

Art. 12.- Regulated use spectrum is the set of frequency bands not contemplated in this Law as free or official use, whose use requires concession; this use may be commercial regulated, community regulated, or private regulated. Regulated use includes frequencies of exclusive and non-exclusive nature.
Art. 12.- For exploitation of official use spectrum, state institutions must request corresponding authorization.
Art. 12.- Any person wishing to exploit part of regulated use spectrum must request the respective concession from SIGET.

Art. 12.- For exploitation of free use spectrum, no concession or authorization shall be required. However, SIGET shall qualify, for technical or planning reasons, free use bands that must have a license granted by it for use. Radio amateurs may use free use spectrum, prior qualification by SIGET and registration in the Registry.
Art. 12.- Frequency changes between different uses may only be made according to the method specified in Chapter V of Title VI of this Law.

CONCESSIONS, AUTHORIZATIONS AND LICENSES
Art. 13.- CLAUSE REPEALED.
Art. 13.- CLAUSE REPEALED.
Art. 13.- CLAUSE REPEALED.

Art. 13.- Authorizations, concessions and licenses for use of the spectrum shall incur fees payable annually to SIGET at the beginning of each year to cover administration, management and surveillance costs. The fee may also be paid in four quarterly installments, in which case the interested party shall recognize corresponding legal interest, calculated based on the period elapsed since the obligation was due and outstanding balances.

Art. 13.- Such fees shall be expressed in colones or US dollars per month and shall equal the product of the unit spectrum cost of eight colones and forty-eight cents or equivalent in dollars per MegaHertz per watt of nominal power per month of use, multiplied by the transmitter's bandwidth expressed in MegaHertz, multiplied by the transmitter's nominal power expressed in watts, multiplied by a service factor as indicated in the table.
Art. 13.- For any service not contemplated in this table the service factor shall be 0.2.

Art. 13.- For those frequency bands identified in the CNAF under fixed-mobile commercial, shared commercial repeaters and commercial trunked systems used for telephony, the service factor established for telephony shall be applied.
Art. 13.- The unit cost of spectrum of eight colones and forty-eight cents or equivalent in dollars shall be adjusted annually in January by the same percentage as the previous year's CPI.

Art. 13.- If the amount collected using this calculation method generates revenue exceeding three million four hundred thirty thousand US dollars or its equivalent in colones per year, SIGET shall transfer the excess amount to the General Fund of the Nation. This limit shall be adjusted annually as established above.

Art. 13.- SIGET is empowered to grant concessions for exploitation of regulated use spectrum for up to sixty days for experimental uses, scientific research or special events. SIGET in its resolution must justify granting such concession and publish it as established in this Law. Such concessions may not be renewed or extended and shall be subject to prior payment of a fee calculated based on the amount of fees established for administration, management and surveillance of the spectrum multiplied by a factor of two.

SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS
Art. 14.- All operators of satellite communication systems transmitting from national territory must comply with the following requirements: a) Conform their transmissions to ITU standards specified for satellite use frequencies.
Art. 14.- All operators of satellite communication systems transmitting from national territory must: b) Have rights to use orbital positions when required.
Art. 14.- All operators of satellite communication systems transmitting from national territory must: c) Register their transmitting equipment in accordance with requirements of this Law.

Art. 14.- All operators of satellite communication systems transmitting from national territory must: d) Have spectrum use rights clearly established by international conventions, treaties or agreements subscribed and ratified by El Salvador, or by obtaining a concession for spectrum use granted by SIGET.

Art. 14.- Installation and commissioning of earth stations for satellite communications shall require concession for frequencies they will use, except when rights to use such frequencies are clearly established in international conventions, agreements or treaties in force in El Salvador. Operators of earth stations shall be responsible for interference they cause in their exploitation.

Art. 14.- When by fortuitous event or force majeure a satellite transmitting toward national territory ceases operation, SIGET may grant affected operators a change to a new frequency without the need to obtain a new concession for spectrum use.

RIGHT OF EXPLOITATION
Art. 15.- The right to exploit the radioelectric spectrum derived from enabling titles granted by SIGET may be transferred or leased; and also fragmented in time, frequencies and geographic space, within the granted term.

Art. 15.- Requests for fragmentations and defragmentations of the radioelectric spectrum must be previously submitted by the holder of the exploitation right for SIGET approval, which shall evaluate according to the common procedure established in this Law. If procedent, pertinent amendments to the respective contract shall be made and registered; otherwise the request shall be denied.

Art. 15.- Transfers of the radioelectric spectrum must be previously submitted by the holder of the exploitation right for SIGET approval, which shall evaluate according to the common procedure established in this Law. If procedent, a new contract maintaining original conditions shall be made and registered; otherwise the request shall be denied.
Art. 15.- Third party rights derived from acts entered into with concessionaires extinguish as a consequence of concession termination, without prejudice to liabilities and effects where appropriate.
Art. 15.- In any case, holders of exploitation rights of the spectrum shall be responsible for violations derived from its use.
Art. 15.- Exploitation rights derived from authorizations for official use spectrum may only be transferred between state institutions, subject to SIGET evaluation and authorization.

REQUEST TO THE COMPETITION SUPERINTENDENCY
Art. 15-A.- SIGET may request the Competition Superintendency to issue an opinion, prior feasibility study in accordance with its legal framework and powers, regarding participation of certain natural or legal persons in processes for granting concessions for exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum, and transfers of exploitation rights in the secondary market, considering whether they would significantly limit desired competition levels or create obstacles to new entrants. The request shall be remitted to the Competition Superintendency for analysis which shall pronounce within no more than forty-five days, except for requests concerning non-exclusive radioelectric spectrum.
Art. 15-A.- If no response is received from the Competition Superintendency within the indicated period it shall be understood as favorable and SIGET may continue the respective procedure.

TERM OF AUTHORIZATIONS AND CONCESSIONS
Art. 16.- Concessions and authorizations for spectrum exploitation shall be granted for a term of twenty years.

Art. 16.- Concessions for exploitation of satellite systems shall be granted for the term stipulated in the contract between the satellite operator and the end user. If during the contract period the satellite operator makes a central frequency change for technical reasons justifiable to the end user, the concession may be modified respecting the contract period; if another technical parameter like bandwidth or nominal transmitter power is changed a new concession must be requested. If the contract is renewed without modifying technical conditions, SIGET may renew the concession for the new contract period; if technical conditions are modified it must be resubmitted to the concession process established by the Law.

EXTINCTION OF CONCESSION
Art. 17.- The concession is extinguished by: a) Expiration of the granted term.
Art. 17.- The concession is extinguished by: b) Renunciation by the concessionaire.
Art. 17.- The concession is extinguished by: c) Revocation.
Art. 17.- Leasing of frequency bands is extinguished by: a) Expiration of the concession term.
Art. 17.- Leasing of frequency bands is extinguished by: b) Insolvency in payment of obligations derived from the concession.
Art. 17.- Leasing of frequency bands is extinguished by: c) Non-compliance with obligations established in this Law and in the enabling title.

USE OF NATIONAL PUBLIC USE ASSETS
Art. 18.- Telecommunications service operators shall have the right to have aerial or underground lines in streets, plazas, parks, roads and other national public use assets for installing networks necessary for provision of services, subject to applicable norms.

TITULO III
TELECOMMUNICATIONS RESOURCES
CAPITULO I
ESSENTIAL RESOURCES
DESCRIPTION
Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: a) Interconnection at all levels or exchanges at any technically feasible point of the network, to terminate in one party's network telecommunications originated in any other commercial network, or to transfer telecommunications originated in one party's network to any other commercial telecommunications network selected by the end user, implicitly or explicitly.
Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: b) Signaling.
Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: c) Automatic transfer of the identification of the number of the user originating the communication.
Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: d) Billing data.

Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: e) Portability of the user's telephone number in case of change of access service operator, insofar as technically feasible.
Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: f) Registration of users of different operators regarding information publishable in the telephone directory.

Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: g) Right of access to public directory databases of operators' customers, solely for publication purposes in pages containing subscribers' directory data.
Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: h) Unbundling of the fixed network for interconnection of commercial telecommunications networks.
Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: i) Co-location for interconnection of commercial telecommunications networks.

Art. 19.- For purposes of this Law the following shall be considered essential resources: j) All installations of a fixed network for provision of public telecommunications service by fixed network that are exclusive or predominantly supplied by a single or limited number of providers and that are not economically or technically feasible to substitute for interconnection supply.

ASSOCIATED RESOURCES
Art. 19-A.- Providers of fixed network telecommunications services are obliged to provide access to associated resources at reasonable and non-discriminatory prices, terms and conditions. For the purposes of this Law, associated resources are: a) Circuit lease.

Art. 19-A.- Providers of fixed network telecommunications services are obliged to provide access to associated resources at reasonable and non-discriminatory prices, terms and conditions. For the purposes of this Law, associated resources are: b) Use of ducts, conduits, poles and rights of way when necessary for interconnection.

Art. 19-A.- Conflicts arising between operators in application of this provision shall be resolved through the access to essential resources procedure referred to in this Law to establish reasonable and non-discriminatory terms and conditions.

Art. 19-A.- Companies authorized by SIGET to operate a submarine cable system as a public telecommunications service shall be obliged to provide access to such systems, including platform facilities, under reasonable and non-discriminatory conditions guaranteeing access.

OBLIGATION TO PROVIDE ACCESS
Art. 20.- Any commercial telecommunications network operator shall provide access to essential resources to any operator who requests it upon payment and without discrimination, offering disaggregated interconnection charges as well as access to disaggregated network elements. Access must be granted with the quality and at switching nodes requested, insofar as technically feasible. Each operator requesting access to an essential resource shall have the right to similar contractual terms to those the granting operator has with other operators. Access shall not be granted when equipment to be interconnected could cause malfunction or damage to equipment in use.
Art. 20.- In case of conflict, interested parties may go to SIGET for alternative resolution according to established procedure.

Art. 20.- To facilitate interconnection and provision of disaggregated network elements among operators, the regulation shall develop how interconnection between networks will be made technically feasible and the level and form of network unbundling.

Art. 20.- Basic interconnection and access offers, applicable procedures for interconnection negotiations and interconnection contracts are public and shall be registered in SIGET's Registry; they shall incorporate all agreements governing interconnection and technical and economic conditions including duration, guarantees, renewal terms and conditions; contracts shall be established under non-discriminatory terms and conditions including technical norms and specifications, quality and charges.

CONDITIONS FOR SERVICE RESELLING
Art. 20-A.- Fixed network operators providing public telecommunications services shall not impose discriminatory or unreasonable prices, conditions or limitations for resale of those services. Significant fixed network providers shall not supply such services on less favorable prices and conditions than those supplied to their own end users.
Art. 20-A.- Resellers must register in the Registry attached to SIGET.

NEGOTIATION BETWEEN PRIVATE PARTIES
Art. 21.- Prices and technical conditions for access to any essential resource shall be negotiated between the parties.

Art. 21.- Any operator requiring access to essential resources of another commercial network operator shall submit to that operator a contracting offer specifying prices and technical conditions. The offer shall be sent with acknowledgement of receipt. A copy of every request must be sent to SIGET with proof of receipt by the operator to which it was sent.

Art. 21.- After forty days from the day following presentation of access request and absent agreement in whole or in part, interested parties may go to SIGET for conflict resolution. This term may be extended or reduced by mutual agreement.

TREATMENT OF SIGNIFICANT FIXED NETWORK PROVIDERS
Art. 21-A.- Any public telecommunications service operator shall have the right that any significant fixed network provider give treatment no less favorable than that granted to its subsidiaries, affiliates or non-affiliated operator regarding supply, availability, tariffs and quality of public telecommunications services; as well as availability of necessary technical interfaces for interconnection.

CAPITULO II
OTHER RESOURCES
INTERCONNECTION
Art. 22.- Network interconnection shall be freely negotiated, except regarding access to essential resources, as specified in Chapter I of this Title.

ACCESS TO THE MULTI-CARRIER SYSTEM
Art. 23.- Access service operators with more than ten thousand lines in service shall provide users, without discrimination, the possibility to select the intermediate service provider using an operator selection key according to the Numbering Plan. Access to intermediate services via multi-carrier system shall be free of charge.

PRE-SUBSCRIPTION SERVICE TO THE MULTI-CARRIER SYSTEM
Art. 24.- Access service operators may offer pre-subscription service to their users to access the multi-carrier system, respecting Article 107 of this Law.

SPECIFICATION OF INTERMEDIATE SERVICES OPERATOR
Art. 25.- When pre-subscription is offered by access service operators, users may specify to their access service operator the intermediate services operator they have chosen to subscribe to.

FREEDOM OF SELECTION
Art. 26.- Pre-subscription shall not prevent the user from accessing networks of intermediate services of other intermediate service operators that provide services through the multi-carrier system.

NUMBERING PLAN
Art. 27.- The numbering plan shall be developed and administered by SIGET.
Art. 27.- Operator selection keys for multi-carrier service shall be integral part of the numbering plan.

Art. 27.- Operators requiring assignment of telephone numbers for their users must request them from SIGET. SIGET shall allocate numbers in lots. Within five days following request presentation SIGET may grant what is requested or, if it considers risk of exhausting the numbering plan, must call a public auction for allocation according to Article 102 procedure.
Art. 27.- When specific numbers are requested SIGET shall allocate them through the auction method specified in Article 102.
Art. 27.- Any assignment of telephone numbers to an operator must be notified to other operators.
Art. 27.- All telecommunications operators must obey rules established in the Numbering Plan.

ALLOCATION OF OPERATOR SELECTION KEYS
Art. 28.- Operator selection keys shall be assigned by SIGET by auction according to procedure established in Article 102.

TITULO IV
PROTECTION OF THE USER
SINGLE CHAPTER
RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS
USER RIGHTS
Art. 29.- Users' rights are: a) To access the public telephony service and maintain communications without interference or intervention.
Art. 29.- Users' rights are: b) To the secrecy of their communications and confidentiality of their non-public personal data, taking into account Title V-Bis, Single Chapter of this Law.

Art. 29.- Users' rights are: c) To connect at network termination points any equipment or device of their property, leased or acquired by any title, without prior authorization of the access service operator.
Art. 29.- Users' rights are: d) That their service not be disconnected arbitrarily.
Art. 29.- Users' rights are: e) To be compensated for damages caused by operators according to applicable laws.

Art. 29.- Users' rights are: f) That the respective service contract clearly specify terms and conditions under which the service will be received, especially regarding quality, coverage, tariffs and continuity.

Art. 29.- The supply contract for public telephone or telecommunications service is independent from contract for provision of terminal equipment; service supply termination cannot be conditioned to provision contract nor vice versa.

Art. 29.- Nevertheless the client may choose to acquire telephone device by installment contract under postpaid modality with chosen operator; once the contractual term expires, if device is locked, operator is obliged to unlock it free of charge for the device owner.
Art. 29.- Users' rights are: g) To appear in their operator's Telephone Directory.
Art. 29.- Users' rights are: h) To be informed of tariffs charged by operators for public telephony services; and to be informed in advance of service outages for maintenance and estimated duration.

Art. 29.- Users' rights are: i) That operators resolve claims for contract breach of telecommunications services, for undue charges or any other cause established in Art. 98, according to procedure established in this legal body; telecommunications service shall be understood as concepts defined in this law.

Art. 29.- Users' rights are: j) To number portability; established as a user right and operator obligation; portability consists of voluntary user change of operator while retaining their mobile or fixed number at no cost. The origin operator must promptly and free of charge perform all procedures for migration to selected operator.

Art. 29.- SIGET shall be responsible for feasibility study for selection of portability types and system model to implement and issue corresponding regulation, all according to users' interests within no more than six months from this decree's entry into force.

Art. 29.- Users' rights are: k) Unlimited validity of prepaid card balances, pins, electronic recharges and balance transfers; without prejudice to line expiration for no incoming or outgoing call movement within three calendar months.

Art. 29.- Operators must notify users by appropriate procedure and technique of available balance on acquired cards, pins, electronic recharges and transfers, ensuring charges correspond to exact time used.

Art. 29.- Users' rights are: l) To be charged and billed to the exact second in all telephony services where time is unit of measure, except when agreed between operator and user to user-favoring different modality.

Art. 29.- Users' rights are: m) That telecommunications equipment be offered without locks or technical configurations electronic, software or physical that restrict use to the concessionaire's network providing the telephony service.

Art. 29.- When acquisition involves an installment contract, operator must unlock terminal free of charge once service contract term ends. In no case may device lock exceed contract term which may not be greater than 18 months from signature.
Art. 29.- Devices listed in stolen or robbed device databases may not be unlocked or activated for new service contracts.
Art. 29.- Failure to comply with this literal shall constitute a very serious infraction under Art. 34 literal n) of this Law.

Art. 29.- Mobile telephone device commercialization may be performed by any natural or legal person provided they have legally registered commercial registration and comply with legal requirements for such economic activity.

USER OBLIGATIONS
