Art. 30.- Users' obligations are: a) Pay installation fees and timely settle invoices derived from service provision.

Art. 30.- Users' obligations are: b) Be accountable before competent courts for malfunction or damage caused to operator networks by connection at network termination points of any equipment or device of their property obtained by any title.

Art. 30.- Users' obligations are: c) Obtain authorization from the access service operator prior to use or connection to its network, for which they must subscribe a service contract with said operator.
Art. 30.- Users' obligations are: d) Present documentation allowing identification of the service applicant in prepaid payment modality.
Art. 30.- Users' obligations are: e) Inform in writing the operator providing prepaid modality services of any change in service ownership.

OPERATOR OBLIGATIONS
Art. 30-A.- Access service operators are obliged to keep a registry of all users including prepaid users, and to maintain such information available to competent authority in criminal investigations requesting it.

Art. 30-A.- Delivery of information required by the Attorney General's Office related to line registration data under investigation, call records during a clearly determined period, and data on origin of any other electronic communication, and temporary suspension of lines, blocking of telephone devices and other electronic communications shall be carried out in accordance with Art. 238 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

SERVICE DISCONNECTION
Art. 31.- Operators may suspend services without prior notice to the user only in the following cases: a) When installation rights or invoices or installments of two or more months derived from service provision are pending payment.

Art. 31.- Operators may suspend services without prior notice when: b) Malfunction or damage to operator network is caused by connection at network termination points of any user-owned or otherwise obtained equipment or device.
Art. 31.- Operators may suspend services without prior notice when: c) Connected to the telecommunications network without prior authorization of the access service operator.
Art. 31.- Operators may suspend services without prior notice when: d) Service ownership in prepaid modality is transferred without respective written notification to the corresponding operator.
Art. 31.- Operators may suspend services without prior notice when: e) Ordered by judicial authority in context of criminal procedure or investigation; a copy of such order shall be sent to SIGET.
Art. 31.- Service disconnection does not invalidate operators' right to pursue judicial remedies.

TITULO V
REGIME OF INFRACTIONS AND SANCTIONS
CAPITULO I
REGIME OF INFRACTIONS
LESS SERIOUS INFRACTIONS
Art. 32.- Less serious infractions are: a) Causing users interference or interventions in their communications for technical reasons.
Art. 32.- Less serious infractions are: b) SUPPRESSED.
Art. 32.- Less serious infractions are: c) Arbitrarily disconnecting the public telephony service provided to the user.

Art. 32.- Less serious infractions are: d) Not specifying clearly in the respective telephony service contract the terms and conditions under which the service will be provided, especially regarding quality, coverage, tariffs and continuity.
Art. 32.- Less serious infractions are: e) Not including in the respective Telephone Directory the relevant data of more than one thousand users, except those who have requested exclusion.
Art. 32.- Less serious infractions are: f) Not informing of tariffs charged for public telephony services; as well as not informing in advance of service cuts for maintenance or estimated duration.

SERIOUS INFRACTIONS
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: a) Committing three or more infractions classified as less serious in one month, or twelve in one year.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: b) Not registering in the Registry when legally obligated to do so.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: c) Operating services when their tariffs have not been approved by SIGET.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: d) Failing to provide information to SIGET when legally obliged to do so, or providing false information.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: e) Refusing to pay SIGET rights corresponding to administration, management and surveillance of the spectrum.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: f) Operating networks or providing subscription television services without respective license, permit or authorization issued by SIGET.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: g) Causing harmful interference in exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: h) Using the radioelectric spectrum without respecting norms and technical conditions established in the CNAF.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: i) Not complying with Numbering Plan provisions.

Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: j) Noncompliance with technical regulations based on quality norms of public telecommunications services established by SIGET within the control period defined by that institution.
Art. 33.- Serious infractions are: k) Noncompliance in payment of compensations resulting from a claims process established in this law.

VERY SERIOUS INFRACTIONS
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: a) Violating secrecy of communications by intentional interference or intervention.

Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: b) Refusing to provide access to essential resources, altering essential resources provided to another operator or altering data necessary for billing such resources.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: c) Interconnecting or using a telecommunications network without due agreement of the network operator.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: d) Causing, by interconnection, damage or malfunction in another telecommunications operator's equipment by negligence or willful misconduct.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: e) Disconnecting interconnection of an operator without justified cause.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: f) Refusing to comply with SIGET resolutions according to procedures of this Law, including regarding anticompetitive practices.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: g) Increasing tariffs approved by SIGET without following procedures established in this Law.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: h) Breaching terms and conditions in service contracts for telephony including excessive or undue charges to more than one thousand users within one month.

Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: i) Denying access to SIGET officials or personnel accredited by it to operators' and users' facilities, and denying all facilities for verifications of compliance with this Law, the Regulation and other legal provisions, provided inspection is part of a complaints procedure initiated or filed with SIGET between operators and in case of users' facilities whenever by court order.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: j) Denying information required by SIGET to operators, especially related to their users.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: k) Providing public telephony services without appropriate concession.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: l) Refusing to pay experts' fees or costs ordered by SIGET at request of a party.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: m) Selling prepaid access services without complying with provisions contained in Title IV of this Law.

Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: n) Failing to comply with Art. 29 literal m) obligation and gratuity of device unlocking, not allowing connection at network termination points of any equipment or device of user's property or obtained by any title.

Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: o) Repeated noncompliance with technical regulations based on service quality norms established by SIGET regarding quality indicators related to establishment and duration of calls, data service, text and multimedia messaging, voice quality, tariff application, customer service, radioelectric coverage, network damages and failures and other services provided in telecommunications networks.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: p) Using radioelectric frequencies in regulated or official use spectrum without SIGET concession or authorization.
Art. 34.- Very serious infractions are: q) Transferring or leasing exploitation right of a concession without prior authorization of SIGET.

PRESCRIPTION
Art. 35.- Less serious and serious infractions shall prescribe after six months and very serious infractions shall prescribe after one year, provided that the alleged infractor has not been notified of initiation of the corresponding procedure before expiry.
Art. 35.- In cases of continued execution of acts constituting an infraction, prescription term shall begin from the date such activity ceases.

Art. 35.- If a sanction file has been initiated, infractions prescribe if the procedure is interrupted due to cause imputable to SIGET for more than three months. Prescription shall operate by operation of law.

CAPITULO II
SANCTION REGIME
SANCTIONS FOR LESS SERIOUS INFRACTIONS
Art. 36.- Less serious infractions shall be sanctioned with a fine of eleven thousand one hundred to one hundred eleven thousand US dollars or equivalent in colones per infraction, in addition to a fine of one thousand two hundred fifty US dollars or equivalent in colones for each day the infraction continues.

SANCTIONS FOR SERIOUS INFRACTIONS
Art. 37.- Serious infractions shall be sanctioned with a fine of one hundred eleven thousand to two hundred twenty-two thousand US dollars or equivalent in colones per infraction, in addition to a fine of two thousand five hundred US dollars or equivalent in colones for each day the infraction continues.

SANCTIONS FOR VERY SERIOUS INFRACTIONS
Art. 38.- Without prejudice to Art. 42 of this Law, very serious infractions shall be sanctioned with a fine of four hundred forty-four thousand to five hundred fifty-five thousand US dollars or equivalent in colones per infraction, in addition to a fine of five thousand US dollars or equivalent in colones for each day the infraction continues.

PRESCRIPTION
Art. 39.- Sanctions not made effective within two years from the date of resolution shall prescribe. Prescription shall operate by operation of law. This term is interrupted by acts aimed at enforcement or by initiation of enforcement.

ADJUSTMENT OF FINES
Art. 40.- Values of fines referred to in Arts. 36, 37 and 38 shall be adjusted based on the Consumer Price Index published by the Ministry of Economy. Adjustment shall be semiannual, starting the first business day of January and July. SIGET shall announce semiannually updated sanction values.

FUND REVENUES
Art. 41.- Funds from application of sanctions shall enter the General Fund of the Nation.

CAUSES FOR REVOCATION OF SPECTRUM CONCESSIONS
Art. 42.- Causes for revocation of radioelectric spectrum concessions are: a) Non-payment or incomplete payment of economic obligations associated with the concession after payment deadline according to Art. 63.

Art. 42.- Causes for revocation of radioelectric spectrum concessions are: b) Non-use of frequencies for more than a determined number of consecutive days or during a number of consecutive weeks according to contract terms when applicable, considering type of radiocommunication service and use classification, following due process.
Art. 42.- Causes for revocation of radioelectric spectrum concessions are: c) Noncompliance with conditions established in the respective enabling title.
Art. 42.- Causes for revocation of radioelectric spectrum concessions are: d) Noncompliance with provisions or orders of competent authority when it gravely affects public security.
Art. 42.- This Article does not apply to services mentioned in Title VIII "Special regime for free-to-air broadcasting services" as incorporated in Art. 124 of this Law.

TITULO V-BIS
SINGLE CHAPTER
COOPERATION WITH JUSTICE SYSTEM INSTITUTIONS
COOPERATION
Art. 42-A.- Commercial telecommunications network operators are obliged to cooperate with authorities and provide necessary facilities to investigate punishable acts.

CALL IDENTIFICATION INFORMATION
Art. 42-B.- Commercial telecommunications network operators shall provide information relating to origin, address, destination or termination of dialing or reception of telephone calls of their users' numbers that are under investigation and that were generated or received by means of operator's equipment, facilities or telecommunications services.

ACCESS TO STORED INFORMATION
Art. 42-C.- Commercial telecommunications network operators shall make available to authorities the databases containing information mentioned in the previous Article, without affecting network management, control or operations of the telephony service operator.

ENCRYPTION
Art. 42-D.- Commercial telecommunications network operators must decrypt or ensure authorities can decrypt any subscriber's or client's communication to obtain information referred to in the two previous Articles when encryption was provided by the service operator.

COMPETENT AUTHORITY
Art. 42-E.- Commercial telecommunications network operators shall ensure that requests for call identification information and access to stored information are issued by corresponding judicial order or Public Ministry.

FINE
Art. 42-F.- Non-cooperation by commercial telecommunications network operators shall be sanctioned with a fine equal to that established for very serious sanctions regulated in this law and shall be applied through administrative procedure, without prejudice to criminal liability incurred, not being applicable what is provided in Art. 7, literal b), third inciso, of this law.

GENERAL OBLIGATIONS OF TELEPHONY SERVICE OPERATORS
Art. 42-G.- Telephony service operators must establish policies and procedures necessary to process requests for call identification information and access to stored information, prevent such information being obtained without proper authorization and keep stored information secure.

CONFORMITY WITH CONSTITUTIONAL PROVISIONS
Art. 42-H.- The above legal provisions do not under any circumstance empower authorities to interfere or intervene telephone communications in the sense provided in Art. 24 of the Constitution of the Republic.

NOTE: THE TITLE V-BIS, SINGLE CHAPTER, COOPERATION WITH JUSTICE SYSTEM INSTITUTIONS, ARE BASED ON ART.3 OF D.L. Nº 282, FEBRUARY 9, 2001, PUBLISHED DO Nº 32, VOLUME 350, FEBRUARY 13, 2001: Art. 3.- Information obtained under this Title shall be evaluated by competent judicial authority pursuant to Art. 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

TITULO VI
PROCEDURES BEFORE SIGET
CHAPTER I
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION ONE
PROCEDURAL PRINCIPLES
PRINCIPLE OF ECONOMY
Art. 43.- In all SIGET actions it shall be sought that both it and individuals incur the least possible expenses and avoid demand or performance of unnecessary procedures.

PRINCIPLE OF CONCENTRATION
Art. 44.- Once procedure is initiated, all matters that by their nature admit simultaneous action and are not successively subordinated shall be agreed in the same resolution.

PRINCIPLE OF OFFICIOUS PROSECUTION
Art. 45.- Once procedure is initiated at request of an individual, it shall be directed and pursued ex officio by SIGET.

PRINCIPLE OF EFFECTIVENESS
Art. 46.- Procedural acts and the procedure itself must be sought to achieve their purpose, adopting measures to eliminate purely formal obstacles and remedy procedural vices that can be cured during same.

PRINCIPLE OF INTERPRETATION FAVORING THE INDIVIDUAL
Art. 47.- Procedural provisions shall be interpreted so as to favor admission of requests and enable final resolution on the merits.

INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC
Art. 48.- SIGET must inform the public about its purposes, competence, operation, services provided and location of its units or dependencies and working hours.

DESCRIBED FORM
Art. 49.- Petitions of individuals and SIGET resolutions must be in writing.

OBLIGATION TO ISSUE CERTIFICATIONS
Art. 50.- SIGET is obliged to issue certificates requested by individuals regarding acts affecting them, upon payment of corresponding fees.

TERMS: COMPUTATION AND EARLY COMPLIANCE
Art. 51.- Acts shall be performed within established terms counted in business days, being peremptory and non-extendable except for just cause, except sanction regime terms which are calendar days. Term shall be considered concluded if all acts for which it was intended are completed before its expiry.

SECTION TWO
ACTS OF INDIVIDUALS
COMMON REQUIREMENTS OF REQUESTS
Art. 52.- Every request to SIGET must contain: a) Name and particulars of applicant and, where appropriate, those of their representative.
Art. 52.- Every request to SIGET must contain: b) Reasons motivating request and precise relation of facts when appropriate.
Art. 52.- Every request to SIGET must contain: c) Offer and determination of means of proof to be produced when appropriate.
Art. 52.- Every request to SIGET must contain: d) The petition in precise terms; if several petitions are made they shall be separately formulated.
Art. 52.- Every request to SIGET must contain: e) Designation of place for receiving notifications.
Art. 52.- Every request to SIGET must contain: f) Place and date of request.
Art. 52.- Every request to SIGET must contain: g) Signature of applicant or their representative.

Art. 52.- Every request to SIGET must contain: h) Other requirements demanded by Law. In complaints and conflict resolution cases, with any writing or document, as many copies as interested parties plus one must be presented.

PROOF OF REPRESENTATION AND COMMON REPRESENTATION
Art. 53.- Powers to appear in representation before SIGET may be granted by public deed or private authenticated document. On first appearance the attorney must attach document proving authority. When several attorneys represent same interest they must designate a common representative.

EXPERTS
Art. 54.- Experts may be natural or legal persons and the regulation shall determine accreditation and SIGET's expert list administration. Experts must use confidentially information provided in cases where there is contention between parties as well as reports they generate.
Art. 54.- In cases of spectrum interference conflicts the complainant may attach an expert report issued by an expert accredited before SIGET or request SIGET to carry out the corresponding study.

MONITORING AND CONTROL OF RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM
Art. 54-A.- SIGET shall apply technical and legal mechanisms and procedures in force to carry out verification of technical quality of radioelectric emissions and shall take pertinent actions to ensure functioning of radioelectric services and efficient use of spectrum, including: detection and cessation of unauthorized emissions, identification and correction of harmful interferences to radioelectric services including broadcasting, verification of frequency use according to conditions defined in the respective concession contract.

SECTION THREE
ACTS OF THE ADMINISTRATIVE ENTITY
REGISTRY AND ACKNOWLEDGEMENT OF DOCUMENT PRESENTATION
Art. 55.- SIGET shall keep a registry recording date and time of presentation of requests, documents and writings as well as communications sent to other entities. For every writing or document presented to SIGET, receipt noting place, date and time shall be issued. Such receipt may also be affixed on copies of presented documents.

ORDER FOR PROCESSING FILES
Art. 56.- For procedures of same nature, the order of presentation shall be strictly observed for file processing, except in duly motivated urgent cases.

TIME FOR RESOLUTIONS OF MERE FORMALITY
Art. 57.- Unless Law establishes special term, SIGET must issue mere form resolutions within ten days.

INFORMATION TO INDIVIDUALS
Art. 58.- When during procedure or execution of SIGET decision a particular must comply with a requirement, process or obligation, the resolution shall inform precisely of requirement, term available and consequences of non-compliance.

MOTIVATION OF RESOLUTIONS
Art. 59.- Except for mere form resolutions, every SIGET resolution must be motivated with brief but sufficient justification, especially in cases of: a) definitive denial of a request; b) imposition of sanctions; c) revocation of concessions; d) conflict resolution; e) departure from criterion followed in similar acts or technical report.

TERM AND FORM OF NOTIFICATION
Art. 60.- Every resolution shall be notified within three days after its pronouncement. Notification shall be by delivering a notice containing the full text of the resolution to the interested party or representative personally or at address designated. SIGET may accept special notification forms proposed by applicant including electronic means provided proof of notification exists.

TERM AND FORM OF PUBLICATION
Art. 61.- When Law or regulation contemplate publication of SIGET resolution, it must be made within six days after pronouncement at the expense of interested parties. SIGET shall collect publication expenses within six days after final resolution. Publication shall contain text of resolution and be made at least in the Official Gazette and two national high-circulation newspapers, on two occasions with one day interval. Requests for spectrum exploitation concession and resolution admitting it, public auction notice and adjudication must also be published in an international financial newspaper.

EFFECTS OF SIGET RESOLUTIONS
Art. 62.- Any SIGET resolution shall produce effects from notification except when rights are granted or recognized, in which case they produce effects from pronouncement. Exceptionally effects may be subject to effectiveness requirements expressly set in the resolution according to Law.

ENFORCEMENT OF SIGET RESOLUTIONS
Art. 63.- When a SIGET resolution imposes economic obligations on a particular, they must comply within ten days. If complied the SIGET must initiate executive lawsuit according to common rules; SIGET certification of resolution shall serve as executive title. When resolution orders a particular to perform or observe behavior a reasonable compliance term not exceeding ten days must be stipulated. If obliged refuses compliance SIGET may impose fines per this Law and inform the Attorney General's Office to promote criminal process.

RECUSAL AND ABSTENTION FROM KNOWLEDGE
Art. 64.- The Superintendent may be recused by motivated writing at any state of procedures when there is a serious and reasonable motive that impairs impartiality. Similarly, if the official considers such motives exist he shall inform interested parties. From date of recusal filing or abstention manifestation the official may not intervene in decision but acts previously performed remain valid. Knowledge and decision on recusal or abstention correspond to the President of the Republic. If either circumstance is upheld, knowledge and decision of matter correspond to the Ministry of Economy.

CAPITULO II
PROCEDURES COMMON TO ALL PROCEDURES
INITIATION
Art. 65.- Procedure may be initiated ex officio or at request of a particular. Ex officio initiation may occur when indispensable for SIGET's functions. For initiation at request the applicant must have interest in the resolution to be issued.

PREVENTION
Art. 66.- If request or any writing does not meet legal requirements SIGET shall prevent applicant to correct within ten days. The prevention shall inform that failure to comply will lead to inadmissibility.

INADMISSIBILITY
Art. 67.- If interested does not comply within legal term with prevention, request or writing shall be declared inadmissible the next day, without prejudice to right to present new petition if appropriate.

IMPROCEDENCE
Art. 68.- In ten days after presentation SIGET shall declare petition inadmissible in following cases: a) When requested matter is not SIGET's attribution; b) When requested right per SIGET's records has been granted to another; c) When minimum forty-day negotiation period for access to essential resources has not elapsed except by parties' agreement to shorten; d) When request refers to already prescribed infraction; e) When request concerns dispute between two parties over access to essential resource for which SIGET issued resolution in last twelve months. For these cases Art. 75 shall not apply.

TECHNICAL REPORT
Art. 69.- When prior technical report of Telecommunications Manager is necessary, it shall be required in the admission resolution. The report must be rendered within period set by Superintendent not exceeding twenty days.

RIGHT TO A HEARING
Art. 70.- In complaints, conflict resolution or when procedure nature requires, the alleged infractor or any operators in conflict shall be granted a hearing for ten days.

EXEMPTION FROM PROBATIVE TERM
Art. 71.- Except where Law expressly orders expert report, if SIGET has sufficient elements from request, writings and documents it shall resolve matter without further proceedings.

EVIDENCE: ADMISSIBILITY, PRACTICE AND VALUATION
Art. 72.- When procedure nature requires, evidence period not less than ten days nor more than fifteen shall be opened to practice relevant evidence. Facts may be proven by any means. Interested parties shall be notified at least two days before evidence practice date. Interested parties shall bear costs for evidentiary diligences produced at their instance. Where Law establishes specific criteria for evidence valuation SIGET must strictly adhere; otherwise evidence appreciated according to rules of sound criticism.

COMMON HEARING TO INTERESTED PARTIES
Art. 73.- When evidence reception is procedent and files are instructed, a common five-day period shall be granted to interested parties to argue and present pertinent documents.

RESOLUTION
Art. 74.- SIGET may not abstain from resolving by alleging vacancy or obscurity of the Law or matter. Requests not involving conflict of interests shall be resolved within ten days of presentation; if technical report requested, within ten days after expiration of report period. After common hearing period SIGET shall resolve within ten days.

ADMINISTRATIVE SILENCE
Art. 75.- Unless Law determines otherwise, if SIGET does not resolve requested matter within terms set in this Law it shall be understood resolved in favor of applicant, who is empowered to exercise his right. When SIGET decisions relate to matters where there is contention of parties, the
Art. 74.- The SIGET may not refrain from resolving by arguing a gap or obscurity of the Law or in the matter it knows.

Art. 74.- In cases of requests that do not imply a conflict of interest between private parties, the SIGET shall resolve within ten days after filing; or, in cases in which a technical report has been requested, with or without it, within ten days after the expiration of the period for the submission of the same.
Art. 74.- Once the common period of hearing to the interested parties has concluded, as applicable, the SIGET shall resolve within ten days.

Art. 75.- ADMINISTRATIVE SILENCE: Unless this Law provides otherwise, if the SIGET does not resolve what was requested within the time limits indicated in this Law, it shall then be understood as resolved in favor of the applicant, the same being empowered to exercise his right.

Art. 75.- When the decisions of the SIGET fall on matters in which there is contention between parties, it shall be understood that administrative silence will favor that party by means of whose request the proceeding that gave rise to the contention was initiated.
Art. 75.- In cases of a request for modification to the numbering plan and assignment of selection keys to the multi-carrier system, administrative silence shall operate in a negative sense.
Art. 75.- Under no circumstances shall rights be deemed acquired by administrative silence against what is provided in the legal system.
Art. 76.- PROCEDURES FOR THE GRANTING OF CONCESSIONS OF THE RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM may be initiated ex officio or at the request of a private party.

Art. 76 a) DEL PROCEDIMIENTO DE OFICIO: The procedure may be initiated ex officio when the provisions and conditions of the CNAF and the Registry identify a portion of spectrum available and the SIGET establishes that said portion has market conditions and economies of scale convenient for its grant and exploitation.

Art. 76 a) DEL PROCEDIMIENTO DE OFICIO: Subsequently a public consultation shall be carried out for a period of ten days, with the objective of determining whether there are interested parties to continue with the process.

Art. 76 b) DEL PROCEDIMIENTO A SOLICITUD DE UN PARTICULAR: The interested party shall submit an application to the SIGET, in which he shall clearly specify the portion of the spectrum required, the technical conditions and characteristics of the radioelectric service he intends to exploit; in such a way that the SIGET determines that there are no harmful interferences with authorized stations.

Art. 76 b) DEL PROCEDIMIENTO A SOLICITUD DE UN PARTICULAR: This application shall proceed when the rules and conditions established in the CNAF indicate that the portion of spectrum requested is available for its grant.
Art. 77.- CAUSES OF IMPROCEDENCE OF THE APPLICATION FOR A PRIVATE PARTY: The following are causes of improcedency of the application to obtain a concession:

Art. 77 a) When the portion of the spectrum or the radioelectric service requested in concession does not comply with the provisions of the current regulations, in particular the contents of the CNAF.
Art. 77 b) When the portion of the spectrum requested in concession presents electromagnetic incompatibility with other already assigned radiocommunication stations.
Art. 77 c) When the interested party requests frequencies that do not require a concession pursuant to this Law.
Art. 77 d) When the applicant has pending compliance with any sanction imposed under this Law and it is final.

Art. 77-A.- TECHNICAL REPORT: The Superintendent, with the aim of stimulating the telecommunications, Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) sector and efficiently managing the radioelectric spectrum, shall request the Telecommunications Management to prepare a report on the technical feasibility, timeliness, market conditions convenient for the granting and exploitation of a portion of the radioelectric spectrum according to use. In the case of regulated commercial use, this report shall define the frequency allocation modality. For the preparation of the report multidisciplinary studies shall be carried out with the competent entities, within a maximum period of sixty days.

Art. 77-A.- Said report may additionally recommend a fragmentation of the requested portion of the spectrum, both in its bandwidth and in time and geographic space, if this would promote competition and efficient use of the spectrum.

Art. 78.- MODALITIES FOR THE ALLOCATION OF FREQUENCY CONCESSIONS: Within the process for the allocation of concessions for exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum, the SIGET shall apply one of the following modalities:

Art. 78 a) Direct assignment: this modality shall apply to all regulated-use spectrum that is of a non-exclusive nature and that the corresponding technical study determines can operate without causing harmful interference to other radioelectric stations and services.
Art. 78 b) Public auction: this modality may be applied to all regulated-use spectrum of an exclusive nature, except community regulated spectrum.
Art. 78 c) Tender: this modality may be applied to all regulated-use spectrum of an exclusive nature.

Art. 79.- START OF THE SELECTION PROCESS: Once the final report has been completed and delivered by the Telecommunications Management to the Superintendent, he shall decide within a maximum period of ten days on the initiation of the procedure for the award of the concession for exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum and the modality thereof.

Art. 80.- TERMS OF REFERENCE: As part of the procedure, the Telecommunications Management shall prepare the terms of reference of the concession within a period of up to sixty days. They shall include the following:

Art. 80 1) Nature of the invitation: it consists of the description of the telecommunications service to be provided, including public and essential ones, establishing the requirements necessary to become its concessionaire, as well as the requirements, aptitudes, qualities of an economic, technical or professional nature that lead to a better fulfillment of the public interests to which the demanial good must serve.
Art. 80 2) The frequency bands object of the concession, allocation modality, quality of the radioelectric service object of the concession, transmission schedules and coverage area.
Art. 80 3) Date, time and place for submission of offers.
Art. 80 4) Publication of notice for the withdrawal of the terms of reference.
Art. 80 5) The requirements that interested parties must meet and the supporting documents.
Art. 80 6) Obligations related to the efficient use of the frequencies to be concessioned.
Art. 80 7) Special conditions including those related to universal access and social inclusion, if applicable.
Art. 80 8) Deadlines for consultations and clarifications of the terms of reference.
Art. 80 9) Technical, financial and legal requirements for participation.
Art. 80 10) Methodology to be used for evaluation and qualification of offers.
Art. 80 11) The conditions, term and form of payment of the concession when applicable.
Art. 80 12) The guarantees to be rendered.
Art. 80 13) Concession contract to be signed with the concessionaire.

Art. 81.- APPROVAL AND PUBLICATION OF THE TERMS OF REFERENCE: The Superintendent shall approve by resolution within a maximum of thirty days the terms of reference, which shall be made available on the SIGET website and an order shall be made for the publication of the call notice in at least two national newspapers, one international financial newspaper and on the SIGET website inviting the download of the terms of reference.

Art. 82.- OBSERVATIONS: Interested parties who have met the requirements established in the terms of reference may submit observations within the period established therein, which shall not exceed thirty days.
Art. 83.- MODIFICATIONS: Based on the observations received, the SIGET may issue a resolution with addenda or amendments to the terms of reference within a maximum period of twenty days.
Art. 83.- Addenda or amendments shall form an integral part of the terms of reference.

Art. 84.- RECEPTION AND OPENING OF OFFERS: The reception and opening of offers shall be carried out on the date indicated in the relevant terms of reference, addenda or amendments. The conduct of the reception and opening of offers shall be supervised by a firm of external auditors and shall have the presence of a representative of the Attorney General's Office.

Art. 85.- EVALUATION OF OFFERS: The evaluation shall be carried out within a maximum period of thirty days, in order to determine the offers that meet the requirements. The Telecommunications Management shall render a report to the Superintendent with the results of such evaluation for the issuance of the corresponding resolution.

Art. 85-A.- ADMINISTRATIVE AWARD: The concessionaire shall be selected among the offers submitted that met the requirements, following the selection procedure and the allocation modality established in the terms of reference.

Art. 85-B.- PAYMENT FOR THE CONCESSION: In the event that an economic offer was required, the corresponding payments shall be made within the terms established in the contract and shall be by certified or cashier's check, electronic payment or bank transfer. The effects of the award shall be conditioned upon payment of the economic offer. When the awardee does not make the payment within the stipulated period, he shall lose the respective guarantee presented, these funds entering the patrimonio of the SIGET and the process shall be declared deserted.
Art. 85-B.- Once payment has been made, the concession shall enter into force on the day of the signing of the concession contract; which must be registered in the Registry.

Art. 85-B.- The SIGET shall retain fifty percent of the final amount resulting from the auction, which shall enter its patrimonio, transferring the remainder to the Special Fund of Resources from the Privatization of the National Telecommunications Administration.

Art. 85-C.- CONCESSION CONTRACT: The Superintendent shall sign with the awardee the respective concession contract, which shall specify the conditions and obligations that the concessionaire must fulfill in accordance with this Law, its Regulation and the terms of reference, addenda and amendments, which shall also form part of the concession contract.
Art. 85-C.- The concession contract shall contain the following obligations:
Art. 85-C a) Name and general information of the parties.
Art. 85-C b) Period of validity of the exploitation right.
Art. 85-C c) Complete description of the service to be provided in accordance with the provisions of the CNAF.
Art. 85-C d) The technical conditions granted: central frequency, bandwidth, geographic coverage area and others that the SIGET deems appropriate to include.
Art. 85-C e) Terms and conditions for renewal, if applicable.
Art. 85-C f) Criteria for setting and adjusting tariffs, if applicable.
Art. 85-C g) The minimum expansion plan and quality parameters of the service, if applicable.
Art. 85-C h) Rights and obligations of the parties.
Art. 85-C i) Sanctions for breach of the concession contract.
Art. 85-C j) Amounts of the rights to be paid arising from the concession and their form of payment, if applicable.
Art. 85-C k) The performance guarantee and the criteria and procedures for its adjustment and renewal, if applicable.
Art. 85-C l) Limitations and conditions for the transfer of the concession, if applicable.
Art. 85-C m) The form of extinction of the contract, its causes and consequences.
Art. 85-C n) Obligations related to the efficient use of the frequencies to be concessioned.
Art. 85-C o) Special conditions, including those related to universal access and social inclusion, if applicable.
Art. 85-C p) Conditions and obligations to guarantee the continuity of services and causes of force majeure and fortuitous event.
Art. 85-C q) Any other that the SIGET has previously established in the Terms of Reference, if applicable.

Art. 85-D.- SECTION II: PROCEDURES FOR THE GRANTING OF TITLES AUTHORIZING THE EXPLOITATION OF RADIOELECTRIC SPECTRUM OF A NON-EXCLUSIVE NATURE: APPLICATION: The interested party shall submit an application to the SIGET, in which he shall clearly specify the portion of the spectrum required, the technical conditions and characteristics of the radioelectric service he intends to exploit; in such a way that the SIGET determines that there are no harmful interferences with authorized stations.
Art. 85-D.- This application shall proceed when the rules and conditions established in the CNAF indicate that the portion of spectrum requested is available for its grant.
Art. 85-E.- CAUSES OF IMPROCEDENCE OF THE APPLICATION FOR A PRIVATE PARTY: The following are causes of improcedency of the application to obtain an enabling title:
Art. 85-E a) When the portion of the spectrum or the radioelectric service requested does not comply with the provisions of the current regulations, in particular the contents of the CNAF.
Art. 85-E b) When the portion of the spectrum requested presents electromagnetic incompatibility with other already assigned radiocommunications stations.
Art. 85-E c) When the applicant has pending compliance with any sanction imposed in accordance with this Law and it is final.
Art. 85-F.- ADMISSION OF THE APPLICATION: If there is no cause of improcedency and the application meets all the requirements it shall be admitted.

Art. 85-G.- TECHNICAL REPORT: The Superintendent shall request the Telecommunications Management to prepare a report on the technical feasibility of the requested, which shall be rendered within a maximum period of twenty days.
Art. 85-G.- Said report may additionally recommend a fragmentation of the requested portion of the spectrum, both in its bandwidth and in time and geographic space.

Art. 85-H.- GRANTING OF THE CONCESSION AND AUTHORIZATION: If the technical report is favorable the Superintendent shall issue a resolution granting the requested; the concession shall enter into force once payment has been made and in the case of authorizations they shall enter into force on the date of issue of the resolution.
Art. 85-I.- PAYMENT FOR THE CONCESSION: The amount to be paid for the concession shall be calculated based on what is established in the regulation of this Law.
Art. 85-I.- Payment shall be made by certified or cashier's check, electronic payment or bank transfer, these funds entering the patrimonio of the SIGET.
Art. 85-I.- This Article does not apply to concessionaires who request to initiate the extension procedure established in Art. 129-A of this Decree.
Art. 85-J.- The procedure established in this Chapter shall have legal effects from the entry into force of this reform, for new concessions of the radioelectric spectrum.
Art. 85-K.- PAYMENT FOR THE CONCESSION: The effects of the award shall be conditioned upon payment for the concession, which shall be made within a period of five days.
Art. 85-K.- Payment shall be by certified or cashier's check, electronic payment or bank transfer.

Art. 85-K.- When the awardee does not make the payment within the stipulated period, he shall lose the guarantee presented as a condition of participation in the auction, these funds entering the patrimonio of the SIGET. In turn the SIGET shall revoke the award without further procedure.

Art. 85-K.- The SIGET shall retain fifty percent of the final amount resulting from the auction, which shall enter its patrimonio, transferring the rest to the Special Fund of Resources from the Privatization of the National Telecommunications Administration.

Art. 86.- CHAPTER IV: PROCEDURE FOR ALTERNATIVE RESOLUTION OF DISPUTES FOR ACCESS TO ESSENTIAL RESOURCES: APPLICATION: In the case of negotiation for access to essential resources, the parties may resort to the SIGET if, after forty days from the filing of the initial application or the term they have agreed upon, there is no agreement on all or some of the points. The request for alternative resolution may be submitted jointly or separately.

Art. 86.- If submitted separately, the party wishing to apply to the SIGET shall give notice to the other party at least five days in advance, with acknowledgment of receipt, delivering a copy of the application that it will submit to the SIGET and stipulating the date on which it will submit the application to the SIGET.

Art. 86.- In the application to the SIGET, the interested party shall specify each of the points in dispute, presenting a final proposal for each of the points, which may not differ from what was delivered to the other party as notice.

Art. 87.- HEARING: If the application is admitted, the other party shall submit its final proposal for each of the points raised in the application on the date stipulated in the notice; and if it remains silent on all or some points, it shall be understood that it accepts the applicant's proposal, and the SIGET shall so resolve.

Art. 88.- SELECTION AND APPOINTMENT OF THE EXPERT: After the period indicated in the previous article has elapsed, the SIGET shall grant the interested parties a period of five days for them to select an expert by mutual agreement.
Art. 88.- If the interested parties do not reach an agreement for the selection of the expert, the SIGET shall propose a shortlist within five days following the expiration of said period.
Art. 88.- Each of the interested parties shall have the right to strike one of them the day after the presentation of the shortlist.
Art. 88.- The next day, the SIGET, with or without the presentation of the strike or without it, shall appoint the expert.

Art. 88.- The expert's fees and expenses shall be borne by the interested parties in equal parts, which shall be paid to the SIGET within five days of being appointed. In the event that one of the interested parties does not pay its share, the decision shall be in favor of the other party.
Art. 88.- Experts, in order to make their payment effective, must present to the SIGET a bond that guarantees the faithful fulfillment of their obligation.

Art. 89.- TERM: Once the parties have paid to the SIGET the fees and expenses of the expert, he shall have thirty days counted from the day following payment to present the expert report to the SIGET.

Art. 89.- If within the indicated term he does not render the required report, he shall be excluded from the list of experts kept by the SIGET for that purpose and the performance bond shall be enforced.

Art. 90.- CRITERIA FOR RESOLUTION OF DISPUTES FOR ACCESS TO ESSENTIAL RESOURCES: The expert in the preparation of the study, and the SIGET in its resolution, shall take into account prior SIGET resolutions, and use the following criteria:

Art. 90 (Economic aspects) a) All fixed costs directly attributable by access to the essential resource shall be borne by the party requesting such access. Directly attributable access costs shall be only those in which efficient companies, with costs and equipment efficiently adapted to the market in which they operate, must incur; The charge for access to the essential resource shall be the long-run average incremental cost of providing access to such resources by an efficient company.

Art. 90 (Economic aspects) b) With respect to interconnection contracts between two companies, directly attributable costs shall be those costs that one of the companies may cause the other by the use of the networks. To calculate the costs caused to the other operator the procedure established in this Law shall be used.

Art. 90 (Economic aspects) Second paragraph: For the purposes of the foregoing paragraph, the company that causes the costs shall be understood as that chosen by the user for the realization of a communication.
Art. 90 (Technical aspects) a) Standards recommended by the ITU and other international telecommunications organizations.
Art. 90 (Technical aspects) b) Standards accepted by telecommunications regulatory bodies of countries with which El Salvador has greater commercial exchange.
Art. 90 (Technical aspects) c) Standards used by regional professional associations in telecommunications.

Art. 90 (Technical aspects) d) Standards accepted by the telecommunications sector in the country. For this purpose, operators shall coordinate their respective Fundamental Technical Plans and register them with the SIGET.
Art. 90.- The SIGET may also issue instructions containing minimum technical parameters on which expert studies must be based.

Art. 91.- CRITERIA FOR RESOLUTION IN CASE OF INTERCONNECTION CONFLICTS: In the case of interconnection conflicts, expert studies must base their cost analyses on the concept of Long-Run Average Incremental Cost, LRAIC, which must be calculated for each element considered of the network.

Art. 91.- For each element considered of the network, the base level of demand or volume for that element shall be estimated, base volume, taking into account the temporal and geographical distribution of demand and service.

Art. 91.- The LRAIC is the average cost of providing the base volume of the considered network element in an incremental manner, which is equivalent to dividing the Long-Run Total Incremental Cost, LRTIC, by the units of base volume.

Art. 91.- The Long-Run Total Incremental Cost, LRTIC, is the cost of the network that includes provision of the base volume of the considered element, minus the cost of the network without provision of said base volume of the same considered element, for an efficient company.
Art. 91.- In all cases, the cost of the network of a company efficiently adapted to the market in which it operates shall be calculated using:
Art. 91 a) The most economical and efficient available technology.
Art. 91 b) A quantity of employees for an efficient company.
Art. 91 c) The cost of equipment and personnel expenses at market level.
Art. 91 d) The cost of money that reflects the real financing cost of a telecommunications business, including the cost of equity and average indebtedness, adjusted for inflation.

Art. 91.- To calculate the cost of capital the average cost of capital of telecommunications companies with equity up to one billion US dollars, listed on all United States stock exchanges shall be used.

Art. 91.- The cost of capital of each company shall be calculated based on the yield rate of the thirty-year United States Treasury bonds; increased by the product of the company's systematic risk and the market risk premium. This market risk premium corresponds to the difference between the return of a diversified portfolio of investments listed on the referenced stock exchanges and the yield rate of the thirty-year US Treasury bonds.

Art. 91.- The systematic risk of each company shall be calculated as the covariance of the company's return with the return of a diversified portfolio, divided by the variance of the return of a diversified portfolio of investments.

Art. 91.- To that average cost of capital shall be added the difference in the yield of longer-term bonds of the Government of El Salvador, denominated in US dollars, compared with bonds of equal term of the US Government.
Art. 91.- The average cost of indebtedness shall be calculated based on the average return of the bonds of telecommunications companies listed on US stock exchanges.
Art. 91.- For the purposes of this article, a telecommunications company shall be understood as any company whose sales from telecommunications services exceed eighty percent of its total sales.
Art. 91 e) The cost of all types of taxes that telecommunications service operators must incur.
Art. 91 f) In the calculation of costs economic depreciation of fixed assets shall be used.
Art. 91 g) Capitalization of costs whose benefits will be received for more than one year, such as concessions and customer acquisition costs.
Art. 91 h) Network upgrades necessary to grant access shall not be considered as costs directly attributable to access.

Art. 91-A.- CRITERIA FOR RESOLUTION OF CONFLICTS FOR ACCESS TO ASSOCIATED RESOURCES: For the leasing of circuits, the expert shall apply the rules contained in Article 90 of this Law. For other associated resources, the expert shall base his opinion on criteria of reasonableness and non-discrimination.
Art. 92.- BINDING EXPERT OPINION OF THE SIGET: Having delivered the expert report within the term established by this Law, the SIGET shall pronounce its opinion within the following ten days.

Art. 92.- If the report was not presented by the expert within the term established in this Law, the SIGET shall contract within the five days following the expiration of the term the services of a new expert for him to prepare the expert report within a maximum period of thirty days.
Art. 92.- Once the expert opinion has been obtained, the SIGET shall give its decision within the ten days following its submission.

Art. 92.- For each point in dispute, the decision shall be based on the final proposal of that interested party whose proposal is closest to the expert report, not being able to take an intermediate decision between the two final proposals.
Art. 92.- If the second expert hired does not deliver the required report, the SIGET shall pronounce its decision in the following terms:
Art. 92 a) In technical aspects, it shall be resolved in favor of the party to which access to the essential resource was requested.
Art. 92 b) In economic aspects, it shall be resolved in favor of the party that requested access to the essential resource.

Art. 92.- If, once the term indicated in this article has elapsed, the SIGET does not pronounce a decision, positive administrative silence shall operate, meaning that it has been pronounced in the terms of the preceding paragraph.

Art. 93.- NATURE OF THE DECISION: The decision pronounced by the SIGET may be modified by mutual agreement of the interested parties, notifying the SIGET within ten days following the taking of the agreement.

Art. 94.- CHAPTER V: MODIFICATION OF THE CLASSIFICATION OF SPECTRUM USE: The Telecommunications Management of the SIGET may recommend to the Superintendent the modification of the classification of the use of the different bands of the spectrum. To be able to carry out this modification, the SIGET shall publish the intention of said modification and an incident shall be opened for the sole purpose of determining its procedence, in which the procedures and deadlines contemplated shall be indicated; in accordance with due process.
Art. 94.- If the recommendation is approved, the SIGET shall make the corresponding update in the CNAF.

Art. 94.- If in the exercise of this faculty the exploitation rights of broadcasting concessionaires were affected, the SIGET shall reassign the new exclusive nature frequencies in favor of the affected concessionaires, respecting their rights, assigned service, the bandwidth originally granted and the exploitation rights derived therefrom, maintaining the same conditions in which they were granted.
Art. 95.- MODIFICATION FROM OFFICIAL USE TO REGULATED USE: REPEALED.
Art. 96.- MODIFICATION FROM REGULATED USE TO FREE USE: REPEALED.
Art. 97.- PUBLICATION: Any resolution ordering modification of the classifications of use of frequency bands of the spectrum shall be published in the manner established in this Law.

Art. 97-A.- REGULARIZATION OF OFFICIAL FREQUENCIES: Official frequencies shall be regulated by the SIGET, and it shall verify their use for a better utilization of the radioelectric spectrum. If it is determined that said frequencies are not being used for a period of six months, the institution that holds their title shall be notified. If there is no valid justification for non-use, said frequencies shall become available to SIGET, revoking their authorization, following due process.
Art. 97-A.- Said frequencies may be maintained within the official use spectrum, being authorized to another State institution.

Art. 98.- CHAPTER VI: OTHER PROCEDURES: USER COMPLAINT RESOLUTION: The operator shall resolve, within a maximum period of ten business days and at no cost, the complaints filed by users of fixed and mobile telephony services.
Art. 98.- The causes for which users may file a complaint are the following:

Art. 98 a) BILLING: Amounts appearing on the bill or payment receipt being contested and regarding which the user does not recognize the consumption of the service or the title from which the operator company derives the right to bill them. In the case of complaints for billing of supplemental or additional services, the billing complaint shall include the amounts for the claimed concept that were billed, including in bills prior to the bill regarding which the complaint is filed.

Art. 98 b) CHARGING FOR SERVICE WITHOUT ANY COST: Amounts charged to the user for the public telephone service, fixed and mobile, that correspond to concepts different from those timely billed, and regarding which the user does not know the consumption of the service or the title from which the operator company derives the right to charge them.

Art. 98 c) INSTALLATION OR ACTIVATION OF THE SERVICE: Failure of the operator company to perform the installation or activation of the service to which it had committed at the time of contracting or when the operator company established a period longer than that permitted by current regulations to proceed with such installation or activation. It also includes the operator company's failure to activate or deactivate supplemental or additional services that had been requested by the user.

Art. 98 d) TRANSFER OF THE SERVICE: Failure of the operator company to carry out the transfer of the service on the date it had committed or when, faced with a request for transfer, there is no response or it does not conform to it.
Art. 98 e) SUSPENSION OR CUT OF THE SERVICE: Cases in which the user considers that he has suffered an unjustified suspension or that his service has been cut without justified cause.

Art. 98 f) QUALITY OF FITNESS IN THE PROVISION OF THE SERVICE INCLUDING TRUTHFULNESS OF THE INFORMATION PROVIDED TO THE USER: problems arising from inadequate network operation that generate user dissatisfaction, such as imperceptible communication, noise and interference on the line, inability to be heard and intermittent service. Likewise, problems of quality of public fixed and mobile telephone services shall be considered those that arise as a consequence of the provision of the service itself or the failure to inform users truthfully about the service or the status of reports they may have filed.
Art. 98 g) Failure to deliver the bill or a copy thereof requested by the user.
Art. 98 h) Failure by the Operator Company to make refunds ordered by the SIGET in favor of users.

Art. 98 i) PHYSICAL OR VIRTUAL PAYMENT CARDS: Problems arising from the provision of services through payment card systems, such as service enablement, the credit granted by the payment card, among others.
Art. 98 j) Refusal of the Operator Company to contract with the service applicant.
Art. 98 k) Other measures indicated by the SIGET.
Art. 98 l) For non-compliance in the provision of telecommunications services established in technical regulations based on the quality of service standards established by the SIGET.
Art. 98.- Operator companies shall have a Complaints Registration System, in which general data of complaints made by users are recorded.

Art. 98.- The complaint filed, as well as notifications, means of proof and other documents related to it, shall form a file whose organization and preservation shall be the responsibility of the operator companies. Operator companies shall assign the file a code or complaint number, which shall be maintained throughout the administrative procedure.
Art. 98.- Operator companies shall adopt the necessary measures to preserve the unity and integrity of the complaint file.

Art. 98.- The parties have the right to know at any time the status of the processing of their complaints, as well as to have access to the corresponding file. The parties may request to be issued a simple or certified copy of the pieces of the file corresponding to the complaint procedure.

Art. 98.- The solution to the complaint, favorable or unfavorable, shall be grounded and signed by the responsible official(s), with express indication of each of the means of proof acted upon that support his decision and of the legal norms applied in the resolution of each case and the notification of the solution of the complaint shall be communicated in writing to the affected user, the day after the expiration of the term, sending a copy thereof to the SIGET; such notification shall be made at the address where bills for the complained service are sent or at the one the user has indicated in writing during the complaint procedure.

Art. 98.- If the user does not receive any communication within the established term, the solution shall be considered in his favor, the operator being obliged to compensate him for the damages it has caused him. In case of undue charges, he shall reimburse the amount that the user has paid to the operator, without prejudice to the corresponding legal actions.
Art. 98.- If the user does not accept the solution to his complaint proposed by the operator, he may file a complaint with the Consumer Protection Agency.

Art. 98.- The SIGET, at the request of the Consumer Protection Agency, shall present a technical report on the complaint within a maximum period of eight business days. For this purpose the operator shall be obliged to provide the SIGET, at its request and within no more than three business days after receipt of the request, the documentary support of the charges or conditions of service provision, as the case may be. Likewise, the operator shall send the complaint file.

Art. 98.- If the resolution issued by the authorities that oversee consumer protection is favorable to the user, the operator shall be obliged to compensate him for the damages it has caused him. In cases of undue charges, he shall reimburse the amount that the user has paid to the operator, without prejudice to the corresponding legal actions.
Art. 99.- RENEWAL PROCEDURE: The procedure for the renewal of enabling titles shall be initiated at the request of the holder, within a period from three to two years before expiration.

Art. 99-A.- TECHNICAL REPORT: The Superintendent shall request the Telecommunications Management to render a technical report within sixty days on compliance with all the conditions established in Art. 124 of this Law; it shall also include an analysis of technical feasibility and market conditions convenient for the renewal of the enabling title.
Art. 99-A.- If the technical report is favorable the Superintendent shall issue the corresponding resolution within ten days.

Art. 99-A.- If the report is approved, the Superintendent by resolution shall instruct the Telecommunications Management to initiate the procedure for the renewal of the frequency concession. Conversely he shall notify the denial of the renewal.

Art. 99-B.- TERMS OF RENEWAL OF THE ENABLING TITLE: The terms of renewal of the enabling title shall be prepared by the Telecommunications Management of the SIGET and shall include at least the following:
Art. 99-B 1. Technical, financial and legal requirements for the renewal of the enabling title.
Art. 99-B 2. The payment conditions and term, if applicable.
Art. 99-B 3. Other special conditions and obligations including those related to universal access and social inclusion, if applicable.
Art. 99-B 4. Renewal contract to be signed with the holder.
Art. 99-B 5. Investment plan in the management of the goods and technological resources involved in the provision and continuity of the service including essential services.
Art. 99-C.- APPROVAL OF THE RENEWAL TERMS: If procedent, the Superintendent by resolution shall approve the renewal terms proposed by the Telecommunications Management.

Art. 99-D.- PAYMENT EXECUTION OF RENEWAL: The corresponding payments, when applicable, shall be made within the terms established in the renewal contract and shall be by certified or cashier's check, electronic payment or bank transfer. The effects of the renewal shall be conditioned on payment; in case of non-payment, the renewal request shall be voided. Proof of such payment shall be presented on the day of signing the renewal contract.

Art. 99-E.- RENEWAL CONTRACT OF THE ENABLING TITLE: Once the notification of the resolution has been received, within ten days, the Superintendent and the holder shall sign the respective renewal contract of the enabling title which shall specify the conditions and obligations to be fulfilled in accordance with this Law and its regulation. The renewal of the title shall enter into force on the day of signing the contract and must be updated in the Registry.

Art. 100.- MANDATORY AUCTION: If one year before the expiration of the concession the concessionaire has not requested its early renewal, the SIGET shall initiate the public auction process according to the procedure established in this Law and its regulation. The SIGET shall have a maximum period of six months from that date to carry out the auction. The new concession shall take effect the day after the expiration of the current concession.
Art. 101.- MODIFICATION TO THE NUMBERING PLAN: Changes to the numbering plan shall be carried out as follows:
Art. 101 a) The Telecommunications Manager, ex officio or at the request of the interested party, shall timely recommend to the SIGET a change to the numbering plan.
Art. 101 b) The SIGET shall publish the proposal. Interested parties shall have a period of twenty days to submit observations.

Art. 101 c) The SIGET shall consider the observations received and decide on the new plan within twenty days after the end of the preceding period. This decision shall be published and notified to all network operators.
Art. 101 d) The new numbering plan shall enter into force within no more than six months after its publication.
Art. 102.- AUCTION: The assignment of selection keys for the multi-carrier system as well as the assignment of specific numbers shall be carried out by auction according to the following procedure:

Art. 102 a) Within five days of receipt of the application, the SIGET shall order its publication and the intention to hold an auction within ten days following said publication, detailing the elements to be auctioned, the place and the auction procedure.
Art. 102 b) Interested operators shall register with the SIGET until the business day prior to the date of the auction.

Art. 102 c) If no other operator registers, the SIGET shall deliver the elements to the applicant without conducting the auction. In the event that there are other interested parties, the auction shall take place on the designated date.
Art. 102 d) The auction shall be held in a public act, in the presence of the interested parties, the Superintendent or his representative and representatives of the Attorney General's Office.

Art. 103.- TRANSITORY PROVISIONS DURATION: The transitory provisions shall be in force from the date of publication in the Official Gazette, except for the exceptions specified, and shall expire within a period of one year.

Art. 104.- REGULARIZATION OF OFFICIAL FREQUENCIES: Official frequencies shall be regulated by the SIGET, and it shall verify their use for a better utilization of the radioelectric spectrum. Upon finding frequencies that are not being used, after notifying the institution that holds their title, and there being no valid justification for their lack of use, said frequencies shall become available to the SIGET without further procedure, their assignment being revoked.

Art. 105.- EXISTING CONCESSIONS AND AUTHORIZATIONS: All concessions, authorizations, licenses, agreements or permits for the provision of telecommunications services existing prior to the entry into force of this Law shall maintain the term for which they were granted.

Art. 105.- Concessions, contracts, authorizations, licenses or permits for the exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum in force at the time of entry into force of this Law shall maintain the conditions and exploitation restrictions with which they were granted. To eliminate such conditions and restrictions the respective holder must request early renewal of the concession, in accordance with the procedure already established.

Art. 105.- In order to monitor compliance with the conditions and restrictions of exploitation of all the aforementioned concessions, contracts, authorizations, licenses or permits, the SIGET is empowered to exercise the administration and management of the aforementioned instruments, as well as to comply with and enforce all rights and obligations arising therefrom.

Art. 105.- From the revenues generated by the administration and management of the aforementioned instruments, the SIGET shall retain amounts equivalent to the payment of the rights referred to in Art. 13. The remainder of those revenues shall be transferred to the Electricity and Telephony Investment Fund, the SIGET additionally retaining as administrative expenses one and a half percent of the total amount.

Art. 106.- DISAGGREGATION OF ACCESS SERVICE OPERATORS' NETWORKS: Access service providers with more than one hundred thousand users shall offer other operators a disaggregated interconnection tariff, as well as the leasing of disaggregated network elements.
Art. 106.- In addition to essential resources, the following network elements shall be offered disaggregated in the form of leasing, provided that the operator's network contains such elements:
Art. 106 a) Links consisting of network elements that go from the end user's equipment to the operator's first switching mode.
Art. 106 b) Ports at all levels.
Art. 106 c) Switching at all levels.
Art. 106 d) Billing services.
Art. 106 e) Access to the user registry.
Art. 106.- Charges for each disaggregated element shall be negotiated between the interested parties.
Art. 106.- In case of conflict, the interested parties may go to the SIGET for alternative resolution thereof, in accordance with the procedure already established.
Art. 106.- When an operator requests more than one disaggregated element, the total price of these may not be less than the total sum of the prices of each of the disaggregated elements.
Art. 107.- START OF PRESUBSCRIPTION: Access service providers may offer the presubscription service from the first business day of October nineteen ninety-eight.

Art. 108.- INVESTMENT CONTRACTS: The SIGET is authorized to supervise and monitor compliance with investment contracts in force at the date of amendment of this Law, using the necessary means of proof, the customer database and through audits for the reliable verification of such obligations, in order to ensure that tariff increases resulting from these contracts contain the correct amounts.

Art. 108.- Operators who have not signed an investment contract with SIGET may opt for the tariffs that result from the application of said contract with another operator, in order to maintain national tariff equality.

Art. 109.- INTERCONNECTION CHARGES: From the entry into force of this Law and until the first business day of October nineteen ninety-eight, the interconnection charges that operators shall charge, in Salvadoran colones per minute of use, shall be as follows:
Art. 109 a) From or to terminal exchanges: ten centésimas of a colón.
Art. 109 b) From or to tandem exchanges: fifteen centésimas of a colón.
Art. 109 c) From or to interurban exchanges: twenty centésimas of a colón.
Art. 109 d) From or to international exchanges: one colón and eighty centésimas of a colón.

Art. 109.- Interconnection charges referred to in this article shall be adjusted by a composite index of fifty percent by the Consumer Price Index published by the Ministry of Economy and fifty percent by the devaluation of the legal currency in El Salvador in relation to the legal currency in the United States of America. Indexation shall be performed quarterly, from the first business day of January, April, July and October.
Art. 109.- These charges do not include direct interconnection costs, such as ports and links.

Art. 110.- PROHIBITION OF SERVICE SUSPENSION: Access service operators that at the date of entry into force of this Law were operating may not discontinue the services they were providing to the public in any population of the Republic, except as provided in Art. 31.
Art. 111.- REGULATION OF PRACTICES RESTRICTIVE TO COMPETITION: REPEALED.
Art. 112.- ACCESS TO THE MULTI-CARRIER SYSTEM: Access service operators with more than ten thousand lines shall provide access to the multi-carrier system.

Art. 113.- CHANGES TO THE CNAF: Changes and updates in the CNAF may be made by the SIGET ex officio or at the request of an interested party when such request is to adapt to ITU norms or for general benefit in the use of the spectrum.

Art. 114.- TITLE VII SPECIAL REGIME FOR FREE-TO-AIR AND SUBSCRIPTION BROADCASTING SERVICES SCOPE: This special regime applies to operators of sound broadcasting services and television broadcasting services, both free-to-air and by subscription.

Art. 115.- CONCESSIONS AND LICENSES: The exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum for the provision of sound broadcasting services and television broadcasting services, both free-to-air and by subscription, requires a concession.

Art. 115.- The application for this concession shall be made in accordance with the general rules applicable to regulated-use frequencies, specifying the service to be provided and its coverage area. These concessions shall be granted for a period of twenty years, automatically renewable for equal periods.
Art. 115.- Sound and television broadcasting services by wired means require a license, which shall be granted by the SIGET.

Art. 115.- For the use of these concessions and licenses, concessionaires and licensees shall prove to the SIGET that they have the permissions or authorizations of program owners to proceed with their transmission.

Art. 115-A.- RULES FOR REGISTRATION OF SECONDARY MARKET OPERATIONS: Concessionaires may transfer by any title or lease the right to exploitation of concessioned frequencies prior compliance with the following requirements:
Art. 115-A 1. That the contract made between the concessionaire and the purchaser or lessee be authorized by the SIGET with respect to technical aspects.
Art. 115-A 2. That the purchaser maintain solvency of obligations arising from the concession.
Art. 115-A 3. That continuity in the provision of service not be affected with respect to the conditions originally offered to consumers.

Art. 115-A 4. Efficient use of the spectrum relative to the utilization of the entire assigned bandwidth and the entire area of coverage granted, which shall be determined by the respective technical analysis prepared by SIGET.
Art. 115-A 5. That the interested party and the applicant be solvent with respect to firm and enforceable state tax obligations.
Art. 115-A 6. Compliance with the provisions of this law regulating procedures, requirements and appropriate conditions for the exploitation of the concession.

Art. 115-A 7. Where applicable, when the Superintendency considers it necessary, it shall request an opinion from the Competition Superintendency, for which it shall have a maximum period of forty-five days. If the opinion determines that it does not generate concentration, the corresponding procedure shall proceed.

Art. 115-A.- In any total or partial transfer of the spectrum the purchaser shall pay SIGET the administrative processing and registration costs according to the cost tariff structure in force in the Registry published by SIGET which shall be indexed annually with the CPI.
Art. 115-A.- Any sublease of frequencies shall be null.

Art. 116.- ANNUAL FEE FOR SPECTRUM MANAGEMENT OF BROADCASTING STATIONS AND THEIR LINKS: Enabling titles for use of the radioelectric spectrum for sound and television broadcasting services shall incur fees whose amount shall be paid annually to the SIGET to cover costs related to management, administration and surveillance of the radioelectric spectrum. Payments shall be made in October of each year; values to be paid are the result of the following formula: TA = CUE * Fs * AB * Pac * n.

Art. 116.- Where: TA = Annual Fee; CUE = Unit Cost of the Spectrum, in colones ¢11.9358, in dollars = USD$1.36408/MHz/hab/month, whose value shall be indexed annually with the official CPI factor; Fs = Service Factor, for AM equals 0.003, FM equals 0.00029, TV equals 0.000122; AB = Bandwidth in MHz; Pac = Population to cover; n = Months of the year, 12.
Art. 116.- In no case, applying the above formula, shall the values for the annual fee be less than $250 in Amplitude Modulation (AM), $500 in Frequency Modulation (FM) and $1,500 in Television.

Art. 116-A.- ANNUAL FEE FOR ADMINISTRATION, SUPERVISION, AND RIGHT OF COMMERCIAL EXPLOITATION OF BROADCASTING AND SOUND AND/OR TELEVISION BROADCASTING SERVICES TERRESTRIAL AND SATELLITE BY SUBSCRIPTION: The calculation of the Annual Fee charge is directly related to the number of subscribers to whom the licensee provides the services in a given system according to the license granted, such that as the diversification of convergent services is achieved, payments shall be annual and payable in advance during January and February of each year and is determined by the formula: TA = Fe * # subscribers, where Fe = Economic factor per year/subscriber, being USD$1.80 per subscriber; # = Number of subscribers reported as of October 31 of each year to the SIGET.
Art. 116-A.- Licensees of sound and television broadcasting by subscription shall submit a sworn declaration of the number of subscribers.

Art. 116-A.- Subscribers of service packages reported by licensees shall be included within the subscriber portfolio only if the television by subscription service is provided in the package, in any of its modalities.
Art. 116-A.- Values shall be indexed annually according to the official CPI factor.

Art. 116-A.- The above formula shall be reviewed by the SIGET according to the methodology developed in the Regulation of this Law, and updated by means of an instruction at least every 3 years, in accordance with technological advances.

Art. 116-A.- Any operator of subscription television broadcasting services that provides nationwide coverage shall incorporate into its programming grid free of charge and without any condition the channels that operate on frequencies of national coverage free-to-air television broadcasting services, whether this spectrum is regulated use or official use.

Art. 116-A.- The subscription television broadcasting operator that provides nationwide coverage is released from the foregoing obligation when, in its bilateral relationship, any free-to-air broadcasting frequency operator establishes a price for inclusion of its channel in the programming grid. If no agreement on the price exists between the aforementioned parties, the subscription television broadcasting operator may not transmit the respective channel in its grid.

Art. 116-A.- Channels of official and regulated use spectrum of national coverage shall maintain their same spectral location in the programming grid; this provision applies to terrestrial and satellite subscription television broadcasting operators.

Art. 116-A.- In the case of regional and local free-to-air television channels, their inclusion in the programming grid shall be by agreement between the parties and according to the area of operation of each system.
Art. 116-A.- The SIGET shall guarantee compliance with the provisions of this Article.

Art. 117.- CLASSIFICATION: Free-to-air sound broadcasting stations, 88–108 MHz, are classified according to the extent of the coverage area or service area, which are delimited by the field strength contour of 54 dBu, 0.5 mV/m, equal to 500 microvolts/meter, as follows:
Art. 117 a) LOCAL STATIONS. Stations intended to provide services to towns or cities and adjacent rural areas.

Art. 117 b) REGIONAL STATIONS. Stations intended to provide service mainly in extensive areas and include important cities contiguous to such cities; their coverage area is delimited to the Western Zone, Central Zone and Eastern Zone.
Art. 117 c) NATIONWIDE COVERAGE STATIONS. Stations intended to provide service throughout the national territory.

Art. 118.- FREQUENCY SEPARATION: Frequencies assigned to free-to-air broadcasting services or sound and television broadcasting shall be used effectively and rationally; for this the SIGET shall prepare the utilization plan of the Spectrum Bands attributed for such service by the ITU.

Art. 118.- In order to avoid harmful interference problems and promote better use of the Spectrum attributed to the free-to-air broadcasting service in sound broadcasting, the minimum separation between adjacent channels shall be 30 KHz in Amplitude Modulation, AM, 525–1705 KHz; and 400 KHz in Frequency Modulation, 88–108 MHz.
