Art. 118.- Respecting service areas according to station classification under Art. 117, the first assignment within the 88–108 MHz band shall be 88.1 MHz.

Art. 118.- The frequency 88.1 MHz is declared Official Use and its use is authorized to the Legislative Assembly of El Salvador, which prior to its use shall inform the SIGET of the technical operating parameters, which shall be electromagnetically compatible and free of interference with other legally established stations.

Art. 118.- Frequency 88.1 MHz may not begin operations until the SIGET carries out an inspection to verify that the installations comply with the technical parameters that guarantee electromagnetic compatibility with other legally established stations and allow the start of operations, in accordance with Art. 123 of the Regulation of this Law.

Art. 119.- SUPERVISION AND MONITORING OF FREQUENCIES: For the assignment of channels or broadcasting frequencies, the SIGET shall issue the necessary rules and regulations, avoiding causing harmful interference to broadcasting stations operating legally.

Art. 119.- The SIGET shall monitor, inspect and audit the operation of broadcasting stations permanently, as well as require concessionaires to provide the necessary information in order to verify the adequate exploitation of the frequency, the provision of the assigned service and compliance with other parameters and conditions established in the contract and this Law.
Art. 119-A.- INFRINGEMENTS AND SANCTIONS FOR BROADCASTERS: The following are infringements by broadcasters:
Art. 119-A 1) Failure to register in the Registry when there is a legal obligation to do so.
Art. 119-A 2) Failure to provide information to the SIGET when there is a legal obligation to do so, or providing false information.
Art. 119-A 3) Causing harmful interference in the exploitation of the radioelectric spectrum.
Art. 119-A 4) Using the radioelectric spectrum without respecting the norms and technical conditions established in the CNAF.

Art. 119-A.- The above infringements shall be sanctioned with a fine whose amount shall be between USD 1,700 and USD 33,000, in addition to a fine of USD 57.14 for each day that the infringement continues.
Art. 119-A.- The Regulation of this law shall determine the form of application of this Article.

Art. 120.- OPERATORS OF SUBSCRIPTION BROADCASTING SERVICE: Natural or legal persons wishing to provide subscription broadcasting services, sound or television, must obtain a prior enabling title from the SIGET and comply with the requirements established by the SIGET and the respective Regulation. The foregoing regardless of the medium used whether by radio waves or by wired networks.

Art. 121.- FACILITY FOR INSPECTION: Every subscription broadcasting operator, sound or television, is obliged to facilitate SIGET's inspection tasks, through access to its facilities as requested, as well as to provide all technical information directly related to the operation.

Art. 122.- PROHIBITION OF INTERFERENCE: Operation of subscription television broadcasting systems, wired or wireless, shall not in any way interfere with the reception of open television signals that are broadcast in the same service area.

Art. 123.- SHARE CAPITAL: Concessions and licenses for Free-to-Air Broadcasting services shall only be granted to natural persons by birth or Salvadoran legal entities. In the case of Salvadoran legal entities, the share capital shall be constituted by at least fifty-one percent Salvadorans. This share capital and its amendments shall be reported to the SIGET.
Art. 124.- CAUSES FOR REVOCATION OF ENABLING TITLES: The following are specific causes of revocation of enabling titles:

Art. 124 a) Failure to pay or incomplete payment of the annual fee established in Art. 116 of this Law, twenty days after the end of the term, prior hearing to the concessionaire; without contravening Art. 129 of this Law.
Art. 124 b) Non-use of assigned frequencies for a period of six months, except force majeure or fortuitous event.
Art. 124 c) Non-compliance with what is stipulated in the concession contract regarding the conditions and technical parameters concessioned and what is stipulated in the current legislation.

Art. 124 d) Failure to operate and provide the subscription television broadcasting service by wired and wireless means in the entirety of the schedules, enabled coverage areas and as established in this Law.
Art. 124 e) Not having the respective permits and SIGET authorizations for licenses of the subscription television distribution service.
Art. 124 f) Failure to present the annual declaration of number of subscribers and channels transmitted or presenting it with false information.

Art. 124.- Once the common process established by this Law has been completed by which revocation is declared and the enabling title has lapsed, the subscription television system shall cease provision of the service.

Art. 124.- Likewise, once the concession is revoked and the contract has lapsed, the involved transmitting stations shall cease their emissions and the corresponding frequencies shall be subject to the rules applicable to regulated-use spectrum.
Art. 125.- RESIGNATION: The concessionaire may renounce his exploitation right of the spectrum at any stage during the term of the concession.
Art. 125.- In such case, the rules set for early renewal shall apply.

Art. 125-A.- REGULARIZATION OF LINK FREQUENCY CONCESSIONS: When the concessionaire submits an application for link frequencies to transmit signals to the main or repeater transmitting stations in the authorized zones, the SIGET shall carry out the technical feasibility study. If the result of the study is favorable, the SIGET shall grant the corresponding concessions within the period established in the Law.

Art. 126.- TRANSITORY: The SIGET shall grant concessions for link frequencies used for transmission. Authorization for these link and repeater frequencies for radio and television shall not cause any additional payment.
Art. 126.- Third-party rights arising from acts entered into with concessionaires who have requested the extension shall be subject to the second paragraph of Art. 15 of this law.

Art. 127.- NATIONAL CHAIN: The President of the Republic shall have the right to convene all radio and television stations of the country to a national radio and television chain for reasons of war, invasion of territory, rebellion, sedition, catastrophe, epidemic or other calamity, serious disturbances of public order or a message of national interest. The Supreme Electoral Tribunal may do so in the cases established in the Electoral Code.

Art. 127.- Concessionaires shall be obliged to transmit, at the requested time, the Presidency's pilot signal, without cuts or modifications of any kind. If for technical reasons some concessionaire cannot transmit what is requested, it shall cease to transmit its regular programming while the national chain lasts.

Art. 127.- Except in the case of duly proven force majeure or fortuitous event, the refusal of a concessionaire to transmit the national chain shall make him liable to a fine equivalent to the value of three times the annual fee for the first and second time; and six times for the third time or more.
Art. 128.- INSPECTIONS AND SUPERVISIONS: Inspections and supervisions provided by the SIGET to concessionaires and licensees referred to in this regime shall not cause any fee.

Art. 129.- PAYMENT EXCEPTIONS: State broadcasting stations, and community including religious, ethnic, among others, that are non-profit shall be exempt from payment of the annual fee in respect of spectrum management of broadcasting stations and their links referred to in Art. 116 of this Law.

Art. 130.- TITLE IX: REGULATION, MISCELLANEOUS, REPEALS AND ENTRY INTO FORCE: REGULATION: The reform to the Regulation of this Law shall be issued within a maximum period of nine months counted from the entry into force of this Decree.
Art. 131.- INITIAL ASSIGNMENT OF FREQUENCIES: REPEALED.

Art. 131-A.- GENERAL PROVISION: For purposes of this Law it shall be understood that reference to Superintendent and Managers implicitly covers masculine and feminine gender, except where a specific provision states otherwise.

Art. 132.- REPEAL: The following provisions are repealed from the Administration of Telecommunications, ANTEL Law: Article 3 literal p) first paragraph, regarding the determination of tariffs by the National Telecommunications Administration, ANTEL; Article 3 literal p) second, third and fourth paragraphs; Article 3 literals q) and r); Articles 34 to 43; and Articles 49 to 55.

Art. 132.- Likewise, the Telecommunications Services Law issued by Legislative Decree No. 367 of October 9, 1975, published in the Official Gazette No. 196, Tome 249, of the 22 of the same month and year and its reforms; the Telecommunications Law, Legislative Decree No. 807 of September 12, 1996, published in the Official Gazette No. 189, Tome 333, of October 9, 1996, and all its reforms; Article 38 of Legislative Decree No. 960 of February 5, 1997, published in the Official Gazette No. 42, Tome 334, of March 4, 1997, as well as any provision that contradicts this Law are repealed.
Art. 132.- In the provision of telecommunications services, the National Telecommunications Administration, ANTEL, shall be subject to the provisions of this Law.
Art. 133.- ENTRY INTO FORCE: This Decree shall enter into force eight days after its publication in the Official Gazette.
DADO IN THE BLUE HALL OF THE LEGISLATIVE PALACE: San Salvador, on the sixth day of the month of November nineteen ninety-seven. (Signatures omitted in translation notes)

Concessionaires shall submit application within twelve months before expiry and update Registry legal and technical information. If application not submitted before expiry, concession shall extinguish at expiry and SIGET may dispose of spectrum applying legal framework and due process.
The concessionaire must update in the Register the respective legal and technical information.

If, upon expiry of the term, the concessionaire does not submit the request for extension, it shall be understood that the concessionaire does not have an interest in continuing to exploit the spectrum; consequently, the concession shall be extinguished on its date of expiry, in which case SIGET may dispose of the spectrum that was assigned to said concessions, applying the current legal framework and following due process.
SIGET, through the Telecommunications Management, shall render ex ante a technical report on compliance with the aforementioned conditions.
If the technical report is favorable, the Superintendent shall issue the corresponding resolution within a period of ten days, in the terms and technical conditions duly updated in the Register.
If the resolution is unfavorable, the concessionaire shall have the corresponding legal remedies available.

Once the notification of the resolution has been received, within a period of ten days the Superintendent and the concessionaire shall sign the respective concession extension contract which shall specify the terms and technical conditions duly updated in the Register to be complied with in accordance with the aforementioned judgment, this Law and its regulations.

Art. 35.- Empower the General Superintendency of Electricity and Telecommunications to prepare within a period not greater than one year from the entry into force of this decree the National Terrestrial Digital Television Plan; said plan shall include the process for selecting the standard to be adopted in the country, the respective Transition Plan from Analog Television to Digital Television, and associated thereto the implementation of the Digital Dividend, and the corresponding regulations, for which SIGET may carry out technical consultations with international organizations recognized by means of treaties in force.

Art. 35.- SIGET shall relocate the new frequencies to the television operators affected by Terrestrial Digital Television; ensuring in the aforementioned relocation respect for the rights of the affected concessionaires who must migrate to other frequencies, the bandwidth originally granted and the exploitation rights derived therefrom, with legal certainty of maintaining their broadcasts in equal or similar conditions to those in which they had been developing; and ensuring to the affected concessionaires who must migrate to other frequencies the enjoyment of preference in the reassignment of the same frequency bandwidth and registration in the National Frequency Allocation Table, with respect to those concessionaires whose frequencies will not suffer any alteration with the implementation of Terrestrial Digital Television.

Ordinance n° 95-11 of 25 Ramadhan 1415 corresponding to 25 February 1995 modifying and completing ordinance n° 66-156 of 8 June 1966 bearing the penal code.

The President of the State, Having regard to the Constitution, notably its article 115; Having regard to the platform carrying national consensus on the transitional period, notably its articles 5, 25 and 26 (paragraph 5); Having regard to ordinance n° 66-156 of 8 June 1966, as amended and completed, bearing the penal code; After adoption by the National Council of Transition, Promulgates the ordinance the tenor of which follows:

Article 1. — A section four (4) bis entitled "Of crimes qualified as terrorist or subversive acts" is inserted in Chapter I of Title I of Book III of ordinance n° 66-156 of 8 June 1966 as amended and completed bearing the penal code, comprising the following articles:

Art. 87 bis. — Is considered as a terrorist or subversive act, any act aimed at the security of the State, the integrity of the territory, the stability and normal functioning of institutions by any action having for object to:

— spread terror among the population and create a climate of insecurity, by morally or physically attacking persons or putting their life, liberty or security in danger, or by attacking their goods; — hinder circulation or freedom of movement on roads and occupy public squares by gatherings; — assault the symbols of the Nation and the Republic and profane graves; — attack means of communication and transport, public and private properties, seize them or occupy them illicitly; — harm the environment or introduce into the atmosphere, on the soil, in the subsoil or in the waters including territorial sea waters, a substance likely to endanger the health of humans or animals or the natural milieu; — block the action of public authorities or the free exercise of worship and public freedoms as well as the functioning of establishments contributing to the public service; — hamper the functioning of public institutions or harm the life or property of their agents, or obstruct the application of laws and regulations."

Art. 87 bis 1. — For the acts referred to in article 87 bis above, the penalty incurred is: — death penalty, when the penalty provided by law is life imprisonment; — life imprisonment, when the penalty provided by law is fixed-term imprisonment of ten (10) to twenty (20) years; — fixed-term imprisonment of ten (10) to twenty (20) years, when the penalty provided by law is fixed-term imprisonment of five (5) to ten (10) years; — doubled, for penalties other than those mentioned above."

Art. 87 bis 2. — For all acts not falling under any of the categories provided in article 87 bis above, the penalty incurred is doubled from that provided in the penal code or other special texts not incorporated therein, when these same facts are linked to terrorism and subversion."

Art. 87 bis 3. — Whoever creates, founds, organizes or directs any association, body, group or organization whose purpose or activities fall under the provisions of article 87 bis of this ordinance, shall be punished with life imprisonment. Any adhesion or participation, under any form whatsoever, to the associations, bodies, groups or organizations referred to in the preceding paragraph, with knowledge of their purpose or activities, shall be punished with fixed-term imprisonment of ten (10) to twenty (20) years."

Art. 87 bis 4. — Whoever praises, encourages or finances, by any means whatsoever, the acts referred to in this section, shall be punished with fixed-term imprisonment of five (5) to ten (10) years and a fine of 100,000 DA to 500,000 DA."

Art. 87 bis 5. — Whoever reproduces or knowingly distributes documents, printed matter or recordings praising the acts referred to in this section, shall be punished with fixed-term imprisonment of five (5) to ten (10) years and a fine of 100,000 DA to 500,000 DA."

Art. 87 bis 6. — Any Algerian who becomes active or enlists abroad in a terrorist or subversive association, group or organization, whatever their form or denomination, even if their activities are not directed against Algeria, shall be punished with fixed-term imprisonment of ten (10) to twenty (20) years and a fine of 500,000 DA to 1,000,000 DA. When the acts defined above aim to harm the interests of Algeria, the penalty is life imprisonment."

Art. 87 bis 7. — Whoever possesses, diverts, carries, trades, imports, exports, manufactures, repairs or uses without authorization from the competent authority, prohibited weapons and the related munitions, shall be punished with fixed-term imprisonment of ten (10) to twenty (20) years and a fine of 500,000 DA to 1,000,000 DA."

Art. 87 bis 8. — In all cases, the fixed-term imprisonment sentences pronounced under this ordinance cannot be less than: — twenty (20) years of fixed-term imprisonment, when the pronounced sentence is life imprisonment; — half, when the pronounced sentence is fixed-term imprisonment."

Art. 87 bis 9. — In case of conviction to a criminal sentence in application of the provisions of this ordinance, the accessory penalties provided in article 6 of the penal code must be pronounced for a duration of two (2) years to ten (10) years. In addition, confiscation of the convict's goods may be ordered."
Art. 2. — All provisions contrary to this ordinance notably legislative decree n° 92-03 of 30 September 1992 relating to the fight against subversion and terrorism, are repealed.

Art. 3. — This ordinance shall be published in the Official Journal of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria. Done at Algiers, 25 Ramadhan 1415 corresponding to 25 February 1995. Liamine ZEROUAL.
Ordinance n° 95-12 of 25 Ramadhan 1415 corresponding to 25 February 1995 bearing measures of clemency.

The President of the State, Having regard to the Constitution, notably its articles 74 paragraph 8 and 115; Having regard to the platform carrying national consensus on the transitional period, notably articles 5, 13-8, 25 and 26 (paragraph 5); Having regard to ordinance n° 66-156 of 8 June 1966, as amended and completed, bearing the penal code; After adoption by the National Council of Transition, Promulgates the ordinance the tenor of which follows:

Article 1. — In accordance with the provisions of articles 52 and 92 of the penal code, this ordinance aims to determine clemency measures as well as the rules, conditions and modalities applicable to persons prosecuted for crimes of terrorism or subversion and who have spontaneously surrendered to the competent authorities and who have notified them that they cease all terrorist or subversive activity.

CHAPTER I MEASURES OF CLEMENCY Art. 2. — Shall not be prosecuted the one who was part of one of the organizations referred to in article 87 bis 3 and who has not committed an offence provided in article 87 bis of the penal code having caused death, permanent disability, impairment to the moral and physical integrity of citizens or destruction of public goods.
Art. 3. — Shall not be prosecuted the person who has held weapons, explosives or other material means and has voluntarily handed them over to the authorities.

Art. 4. — In the case where persons referred to in article 1 above have committed crimes having caused death or permanent disability the penalty incurred shall be: — fixed-term imprisonment of fifteen (15) to twenty (20) years when the penalty provided by law is death;
Art. 5. — Besides the aforementioned clemency measures, the persons referred to in article 1 of this ordinance may also benefit from gracious measures provided by the Constitution.

CHAPTER II PROCEDURE Art. 6. — Persons referred to in articles 2 and 3 of this ordinance may present themselves spontaneously to the judicial or administrative authorities, civil or military, accompanied where appropriate by their tutor and/or their counsel. They shall be immediately given a receipt called a presentation receipt. Within a period not exceeding thirty (30) days from the delivery of the receipt, they shall be handed by the judicial authorities a document bearing the mention "beneficiary of the clemency provisions" provided by this ordinance. If necessary and at the request of the interested party, temporary measures of physical protection shall be taken in his favor by the competent authorities. In all cases, the judicial authorities must be kept informed.

Art. 7. — Persons referred to in articles 4, 8, 9, 10 and 11 of this ordinance are immediately brought before the competent court to be presented to the Public Prosecutor. The Public Prosecutor must establish on the spot a report of finding and institute public action. The aforementioned persons may be subjected, at their request, to a medical examination.

CHAPTER III PARTICULAR PROVISIONS Art. 8. — When the person referred to in article 1 of this ordinance is a minor aged 16 to 18 years and has committed offences qualified as subversion or terrorism, the maximum penalty incurred is fixed-term imprisonment of ten (10) years.

Art. 9. — When the person referred to in article 1 of this ordinance is a young adult aged 18 to 22 years and has committed offences qualified as terrorism or subversion, the maximum penalty incurred is fixed-term imprisonment of fifteen (15) years.

Art. 10. — The person referred to in article 1 of this ordinance who, after the delivery of the document referred to in article 6 above, commits a subsequent offence qualified as terrorism or subversion, is excluded from the benefit of the provisions of this ordinance and from the extenuations provided by the penal code. Moreover, the penalty incurred is increased to the maximum for the repression of the considered offence.

Art. 11. — The persons referred to in articles 4, 8 and 9 of this ordinance who have subsequently, at their trial, committed an offence qualified as terrorism or subversion, are excluded from the benefit of the provisions of this ordinance and from the extenuations provided by the penal code.

Art. 12. — This ordinance shall be published in the Official Journal of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria. Done at Algiers, 25 Ramadhan 1415 corresponding to 25 February 1995. Liamine ZEROUAL.

Art. 1.- Object.- The present law has as its object to establish the principles, the legal framework, the institutionality, the guidelines, as well as the protection policies that allow structuring, regulating, auditing and overseeing the measures of cybersecurity and information security in the possession of public institutions.

Art. 2.- Scope of application.- The organs of Government, their dependencies, official autonomous institutions, municipal authorities or any other entity or organism, regardless of their form, nature or legal situation, through which public resources are administered, State assets, acts of public administration in general are carried out or that have an incidence on the nation's critical infrastructures, are obliged to comply with this law.

Art. 2.- Scope of application.- Resources from Agreements or Treaties that the State of El Salvador enters into with other States or with International Organizations are included within public resources, unless the Agreement or Treaty determines superior requirements in the matter of cybersecurity or information security.

Art. 2.- Scope of application.- Consequently, all public servants, inside or outside the territory of the Republic, and the persons who work in the entities mentioned in this article, are obliged to full compliance with the present law.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: a) Security by design: the subjects established within the scope of application of the present law shall apply a security by design approach in the development, purchase, provisioning, implementation and management of computer systems or technological equipment and in the administration processes of these, so that cybersecurity and information security are the original, transversal and permanent objective during the operation or use of the same.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: b) Resilience, continuity and availability: the measures or actions adopted pursuant to the present law shall have as purpose the reduction of the adverse effects of cybersecurity or information security incidents, recovery in the shortest possible time and the continuity and promotion of the resilience of the critical activities that depend on the compromised information systems.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: c) Risk management: to continuously evaluate and manage cybersecurity or information security risks, identifying potential threats and applying appropriate mitigation measures.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: d) Cooperation: consisting in the duty to support reciprocally with the competent authority in order to prevent, detect and respond to cybersecurity or information security threats or incidents. Such cooperation may materialize through interconnection, interdependence of information systems or other appropriate measures for that purpose.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: e) Damage control: the measures or actions in the face of cybersecurity or information security threats or incidents shall be adopted and carried out in a timely and diligent manner, in order to avoid the increase of damages and breaches to systems, information and services, as well as the possible affectation of other areas or operations.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: f) Security in cyberspace and its annexes: the subjects obligated by the present law shall carry out all possible and necessary measures to safeguard the security of the networks, equipment and information systems that are used for the exercise of their activities and functions, as well as those in which they store, process and manage their information or that of their users.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: g) Rationality, responsibility and proportionality: the measures or actions implemented in the face of cybersecurity or information security threats or incidents shall be applied equitably, fairly and appropriate to the level of exposure to the inherent risks, the damages they produce or their eventual social and economic impact.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: h) Confidentiality: implement the measures, actions or necessary tools to guarantee that computer systems, networks or information are only accessible to the employees, officials, authorities or users authorized for it, thereby protecting the privacy of citizens.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: i) Integrity: to accredit the reliability and accuracy of the information that the subjects obligated by the present law manage or administer, avoiding any modification over time, alteration, corruption or unauthorized deletion.

Art. 3.- Governing principles.- The present law contemplates the following principles: j) Technological neutrality: which supports the non-discrimination between technologies, insofar as they consist of secure and efficient means through which it is possible to comply with the provisions of the present law.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: a) Threat: any action, behavior or event, real or potential, that allows attack, invasion, breach or disabling of the computer systems, equipment, networks or infrastructures of the subjects obligated by the present law.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: b) Event: observable fact derived from an occurrence in a computer system, equipment, network or infrastructure, which if materialized would change a particular set of circumstances of the same.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: c) Incident: any action, behavior or event that harms or compromises the confidentiality or integrity of information, the availability, resilience or integrity of computer systems, equipment, networks, infrastructures or processes executed or implemented in them.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: d) Critical infrastructures: computer systems, equipment, networks or infrastructures or technological services that support or assist in the provision of essential services to the citizenry and that in case of failure could have an impact on them.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: e) Cyberspace: digital environment that has no physical and/or geographic limits and allows the interconnection or communication between computer systems, equipment or infrastructures.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: f) Cyber or IT risk: measure of the probability of occurrence and potential negative results, derived from a failure or breach of IT security or information security measures, that may affect the privacy, integrity or availability of the data and/or services that are safeguarded in the computer system.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: g) Essential service: any service necessary for national security, defense of the country's sovereignty, national economy, foreign relations, maintenance of public order, health, welfare of the citizenry and the performance of crucial social activities.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: h) Computer System: an element or group of interconnected or related elements, which may be electronic, software programs, communication links or the technology that in the future may replace them, oriented to the processing and management of data and information.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: i) Vulnerability: any weakness of a computer system, equipment, network or infrastructure or in the security measures or policies applicable thereto, which could result in a threat or incident.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: j) Information asset: any element valuable for the subjects obligated by the present law and that has incidence in the processes or functions that they perform.
Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: k) Authentication: property of information that accounts for its legitimate origin.

Art. 4.- Definitions.- For the purposes of the present law the following shall be understood as: l) Telecommunications infrastructure: set of techniques, equipment, systems and processes that allow the remote transmission of information, whether in the form of voice, data, text, images or any other form between users.

Art. 5.- On cyber risk.- For the purposes of the present law, it shall be understood that there is a cyber risk when the subjects regulated in Article 2 fail to comply with the regulations, protocols, guidelines, standards and technical criteria established by the State Cybersecurity Agency, which shall be based on national or international standards in the matter of cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 5.- On cyber risk.- The provisions referred to in the preceding paragraph shall have as a reference framework the technical requirements or standards issued by organizations that have the recognition of the industry in which they are intended to be applied, for their contributions to the standardization of the sector in question, or that have proven international experience, provided that the functionality, efficiency and benefit of said requirements or standards in the matter of cybersecurity and information security are demonstrated.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: a) To implement a permanent cybersecurity and information security management system in order to determine and mitigate those risks that may affect the security of computer systems and infrastructures, covering equipment, networks, telecommunications infrastructures or processes executed or implemented in them.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: b) To prepare a computer and information security strategy aligned with national and international standards or reference frameworks.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: c) To maintain an updated record of all actions carried out that compose the cybersecurity and information security management system.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: d) To prepare and implement operational continuity and cybersecurity plans, which shall be approved by the competent authority and shall be submitted to periodic reviews in accordance with the applicable guidelines.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: e) To continuously carry out review operations, exercises, drills and analyses of the measures, computer systems, equipment, networks, infrastructures or processes executed or implemented in them; all, in order to detect elements or risks that compromise cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: f) To apply and comply immediately and effectively with the necessary measures to prevent, report and resolve cybersecurity and information security threats, in accordance with the legal provisions established in this regard.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: g) To timely, expeditiously and efficiently adopt the necessary actions to reduce the impact and propagation of a cybersecurity or information security incident.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: h) To remit, in the time, form and specificity, the reports related to cybersecurity and information security that are demanded by the competent authority.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: i) To create or designate an area or areas responsible for the implementation, monitoring, review and adaptation of the actions and measures related to cybersecurity and information security, granting them internally independence and the necessary attributions to execute their functions without obstacles or prior procedures, but in close coordination with the competent authority in matters of cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: j) To comply with the information requirements or instructions issued by the competent authority, in the corresponding time, form and specificities.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: k) To facilitate the management, audit and inspection tasks carried out by the competent authority in matters of cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: l) To inform potential affected parties, insofar as they can be identified and when so determined by the State Cybersecurity Agency, about the occurrence of incidents that could compromise or gravely compromise their information, as well as the possible measures that they may adopt to mitigate the risks caused by the same, if any. This obligation to inform shall be fulfilled through the means or mechanisms determined by the referred authority.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: m) To carry out the planning, management and procedures necessary to implement the obligations that derive from the present law, as well as from the provisions that are issued pursuant to this, in a timely manner.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The subjects to whom this law applies in accordance with Article 2 shall have the following obligations: n) Any other obligations established by the provisions contained in policies, regulations, protocols, guidelines, standards and technical criteria in matters of cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 6.- Obligations.- The competent authority shall issue the pertinent provisions in the matter of cybersecurity and information security in accordance with what is established in letter b) of Article 8 of the present law, with the purpose that the subjects obligated by the present law remain in strict coordination with it and comply with the obligations established in this article.

Art. 7.- Creation of the Agency.- The State Cybersecurity Agency is hereby created, which hereinafter shall be denominated "ACE" or the "Agency", as a dependency of the State, of Public Law, with a technical character, with legal personality and its own assets, of indefinite duration, with administrative and financial autonomy.
Art. 7.- Creation of the Agency.- The ACE shall have its domicile in the capital of the Republic and shall be empowered to establish offices in any place of the national territory.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: a) To draft the Nation's Cybersecurity and Information Security Policy, which shall contain the guidelines, plans and action programs that shall be applied for its compliance, and to submit it for approval to the President of the Republic.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: b) To issue the regulations, protocols, guidelines, standards and technical criteria, both general and specific, based on the best practices and international reference frameworks in matters of cybersecurity and information security; in accordance with what is established in Article 5 and in concordance with the Nation's Cybersecurity and Information Security Policy.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: c) To create and implement the action programs necessary to respond to cybersecurity or information security threats or incidents that involve the subjects obligated by the present law.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: d) To require from the entities obligated by the present law whose computer systems, equipment, networks or infrastructures have been affected by a cybersecurity or information security incident, the actions that are necessary for the fulfillment of its ends.
Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: e) To create and administer a National Registry of Cybersecurity Threats and Incidents.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: f) To qualify, by reasoned resolution, the operators of critical infrastructures, and to submit it for ratification by the President of the Republic.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: g) To withdraw the qualification, by reasoned resolution, from the operators of critical infrastructures, and to submit it for ratification by the President of the Republic.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: h) To require from the entities obligated by the present law that have suffered a cybersecurity or information security incident that they deliver to the potentially affected parties or investigative authorities truthful, sufficient and timely information about such circumstance, in accordance with what is provided in letter l) of Article 6.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: i) To design and implement plans and campaigns of civic education, training, strengthening, dissemination and promotion of the culture in cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: j) To require from the subjects obligated by the present law access to the information necessary to prevent the occurrence of cybersecurity or information security incidents and to manage threats or incidents that have already occurred. When the referred information includes personal data, these shall be treated with the purpose of anonymizing their holders, whenever this is possible, without hindering incident management.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: k) To establish the coordination and collaboration mechanisms between the area or areas responsible for the implementation, monitoring, review and adaptation of the actions and measures related to cybersecurity and information security established by the subjects obligated by the present law.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: l) To establish the technical requirements and the manner of carrying out the audits and risk assessments on cybersecurity and information security that it must perform to guarantee compliance with the present law and other provisions that are issued on said scope.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: m) To carry out reviews of the measures and actions of cybersecurity and information security implemented by the subjects obligated by the present law, in order to establish mechanisms of improvement and risk prevention, ensuring the use of adequate and updated measures or tools, to respond to threats derived from the use of new technologies.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: n) To promote cooperation with international organisms and foreign authorities on issues related to cybersecurity and information security.
Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: o) To represent the country before International Organizations related to cybersecurity and information security policies.
Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: p) To impose sanctions in accordance with the present law.
Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: q) To issue, modify or annul provisional measures as provided in the Law of Administrative Procedures.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: r) To study and submit to consideration of the Executive Branch through the Ministry of Justice and Public Security, proposals of law or reforms to provisions in force in matters of cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: s) To approve the internal regulations, as well as the manuals and other instruments necessary for the administration of the Agency.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: t) To propose the special budget projects and the ACE salary system and remit them to the Ministry of Finance for their respective approval in the Legislative Assembly.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: u) To assist the Attorney General's Office, the Judicial Branch and other public institutions that request it, in forensic expertise activities related to the functions it performs.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: v) To notify the Attorney General's Office within a maximum period of seventy-two hours, when in the exercise of its powers or on occasion of them, it becomes aware that there are elements that could configure any crime contemplated in the Special Law against Computer and Related Crimes or other criminal laws.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: w) To define and coordinate the implementation of training and awareness programs related to cybersecurity and information security; for which it may be supported by other public institutions or private entities or national or international organisms.

Art. 8.- Attributions.- The Agency shall have the following attributions: x) To exercise the other attributions or powers that legally correspond or are necessary for the compliance with the present law or others that apply to it.

Art. 9.- Legal representation and administrative organization.- The ACE shall have, at minimum, the following administrative organization: a Director General, a Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security and the dependencies or administrative units that its internal regulations establish, according to the needs to guarantee the application of the present law and the availability of State resources.

Art. 9.- Legal representation and administrative organization.- The Director General shall be the highest authority and the legal representative of the Agency, and shall exercise the attributions and powers that correspond to the ACE, except for the power to impose sanctions. Said official shall be appointed by the President of the Republic, and shall serve for a period of three years renewable.

Art. 9.- Legal representation and administrative organization.- In the same manner the Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall be appointed, who shall assist the Director General in the exercise of his attributions and powers, in compliance with the present law.

Art. 9.- Legal representation and administrative organization.- The Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall be cognizant of the administrative proceedings to impose the sanctions established by the present law, and may delegate the instruction and substantiation of these proceedings, but not the imposition of the sanction, to an employee or official of the ACE different from the Director General.
Art. 9.- Legal representation and administrative organization.- The Agency shall establish the dependencies or administrative units of its structure and their functioning in an internal regulation.
Art. 10.- Requirements.- To be Director General of the ACE it is required: a) To be over thirty-five years of age.

Art. 10.- Requirements.- To be Director General of the ACE it is required: b) To have a university degree, national or foreign, preferably in computer science, computer engineering, systems engineering, telecommunications or other related areas.
Art. 10.- Requirements.- To be Director General of the ACE it is required: c) To accredit professional and laboral experience in matters of cybersecurity or information security.
Art. 10.- Requirements.- To be Director General of the ACE it is required: d) To be of recognized honorability and probity.
Art. 10.- Requirements.- To be Director General of the ACE it is required: e) To have performed in a distinguished manner in professional, public service or academic matters.
Art. 10.- Requirements.- The Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall comply with the requirements established in this article, except for what is established in letter a).

Art. 11.- Disqualifications and incompatibilities.- The following persons may not be appointed to the office of Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security: a) The spouse or relatives within the fourth degree of consanguinity or second of affinity of the President or Vice President of the Republic.

Art. 11.- Disqualifications and incompatibilities.- The following persons may not be appointed to the office of Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security: b) The spouse or relatives within the fourth degree of consanguinity or second of affinity of the ministers or vice ministers of State.

Art. 11.- Disqualifications and incompatibilities.- The following persons may not be appointed to the office of Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security: c) The spouse or relatives within the fourth degree of consanguinity or second of affinity of any of the holders or members of the governing bodies of the subjects obligated by the present law.

Art. 11.- Disqualifications and incompatibilities.- The following persons may not be appointed to the office of Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security: d) Those who hold positions in the governing bodies of political parties, business associations, trade unions or consumer associations.

Art. 11.- Disqualifications and incompatibilities.- The following persons may not be appointed to the office of Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security: e) The directors or administrators of commercial companies.

Art. 11.- Disqualifications and incompatibilities.- The performance of both positions shall be of exclusive dedication and is incompatible with the exercise of any public office, professional or commercial activity, both national and international, except for university teaching, provided that this does not impair the development of their functions.

Art. 12.- Termination of office.- The Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall cease in the exercise of the office by resignation or removal made by the President of the Republic, when: a) A serious noncompliance of their obligations is proven.

Art. 12.- Termination of office.- The Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall cease in the exercise of the office by resignation or removal made by the President of the Republic, when: b) A willful omission of their obligations is proven.

Art. 12.- Termination of office.- The Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall cease in the exercise of the office by resignation or removal made by the President of the Republic, when: c) Supervening physical or mental incapacity that makes it impossible to exercise the same.

Art. 12.- Termination of office.- The Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall cease in the exercise of the office by resignation or removal made by the President of the Republic, when: d) Final conviction for an intentional crime.

Art. 12.- Termination of office.- The Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall cease in the exercise of the office by resignation or removal made by the President of the Republic, when: e) For notoriously immoral private or professional conduct.

Art. 12.- Termination of office.- The Director General or Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall cease in the exercise of the office by resignation or removal made by the President of the Republic, when: f) For making use of the office to exercise undue influences.

Art. 13.- Temporary substitution.- In cases of temporary physical or mental incapacity, resignation or dismissal of the Director General, the Director of Cybersecurity and Information Security shall substitute the same until the President of the Republic appoints another person to the exercise of the office.

Art. 14.- Budget.- The ACE shall have a special budget and its own salary system. The respective projects shall be prepared in accordance with what is established in the Organic Law of State Financial Administration and shall be submitted for approval to the Legislative Assembly.
Art. 15.- Assets.- The assets of the Agency shall be constituted by: a) The resources that the State initially grants it.
Art. 15.- Assets.- The assets of the Agency shall be constituted by: b) The allocations that are annually established charged to its special budget.
Art. 15.- Assets.- The assets of the Agency shall be constituted by: c) The resources that it receives by virtue of assistance programs from national and international governments or organisms.
Art. 15.- Assets.- The assets of the Agency shall be constituted by: d) The movable and immovable goods, securities or rights that it acquires by any title.

Art. 15.- Assets.- The ACE shall be subject to the oversight of the Court of Accounts of the Republic; additionally it shall annually contract the services of a specialized firm to carry out an external audit of its actions.

Art. 16.- Confidentiality.- The officials and employees of the Agency shall have the obligation to keep secret and strict confidentiality of the information to which they have access by virtue of the functions and work activities they perform; this obligation shall remain even after having ceased in the office for a minimum period of five years.

Art. 16.- Confidentiality.- It is prohibited for the authorities, officials, employees, delegates, experts, agents or persons who provide services to the Agency, in any capacity, whether temporary or permanent, to reveal any information that they have obtained in the performance of their office or to take advantage of such information for personal ends or third parties.

Art. 16.- Confidentiality.- In the case of public servants who provide their services to the Agency, the noncompliance with what is established in the present article shall constitute grounds for dismissal or removal without liability for the referred authority, without prejudice to the civil, criminal or any other nature responsibility that may arise.

Art. 17.- Principles of legality, culpability and proportionality.- The infringements of the provisions of the present law shall be sanctioned administratively, in the cases and in the manner regulated in the articles of this title, without prejudice to the civil, criminal or other responsibilities in which they may incur.

Art. 17.- Principles of legality, culpability and proportionality.- The subjects obligated by the present law shall be responsible for the administrative infringements established in this chapter, by action or omission, with intent, negligence or any other title determined by the legal system.

Art. 17.- Principles of legality, culpability and proportionality.- To the infringements and sanctions imposed by virtue of the present law shall be applicable the principles of the sanctioning power provided in the Law of Administrative Procedures; especially that of proportionality, by virtue of which it shall be necessary to maintain the due adequacy between the gravity of the act constituting an infringement and the sanction applied.
Art. 18.- Classification of infringements.- The infringements referred to in this law are classified as: minor, serious or very serious.

Art. 19.- Minor infringements.- The following shall be considered minor infringements: a) To remit, outside the term, the reports or information related to cybersecurity and information security that are required by the Agency, provided that such information is not related to any incident or is necessary for its management.

Art. 19.- Minor infringements.- The following shall be considered minor infringements: b) To present, without the required specifications, the reports or information related to cybersecurity and information security that are required by the ACE, provided that such information is not related to any incident or is necessary for its management.

Art. 19.- Minor infringements.- The following shall be considered minor infringements: c) To fail to comply with the provisions contained in the policies, technical regulations, guidelines and instructions in matters of cybersecurity and information security, when these do not have incidence in the implementation of the cybersecurity and information security management system or the management of incidents.

Art. 19.- Minor infringements.- The holders, senior management and any other official or employee shall also incur liability for the preceding infringements when these materialize by virtue of the order, instruction, negligence or omission of the same.

Art. 20.- Serious infringements.- The following shall be considered serious infringements: a) Not to have an updated record of all the actions executed that compose the cybersecurity and information security management system.

Art. 20.- Serious infringements.- The following shall be considered serious infringements: b) Not to prepare and remit, in time and form, the operational continuity and cybersecurity plans for the approval of the Agency.
Art. 20.- Serious infringements.- The following shall be considered serious infringements: c) Not to implement the operational continuity and cybersecurity plans approved by the ACE.

Art. 20.- Serious infringements.- The following shall be considered serious infringements: d) Not to continuously carry out the review operations, exercises, drills and analyses of the measures, computer systems, equipment, networks, infrastructures or processes executed or implemented in them.

Art. 20.- Serious infringements.- The following shall be considered serious infringements: e) To fail to comply with the provisions contained in the policies, technical regulations, guidelines and instructions in matters of cybersecurity and information security, when these relate to the implementation of the cybersecurity and information security management system or the management of incidents.

Art. 20.- Serious infringements.- The following shall be considered serious infringements: f) To obstruct or prevent the work of the area or areas responsible for the implementation, monitoring, review and adaptation of the actions and measures related to cybersecurity and information security.
Art. 20.- Serious infringements.- The following shall be considered serious infringements: g) To present to the ACE incomplete, erroneous or inaccurate information.

Art. 20.- Serious infringements.- The holders, senior management and any other official or employee shall also incur liability for the preceding infringements when these materialize by virtue of the order, instruction, negligence or omission of the same.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: a) To remit, outside the term, the reports or information related to cybersecurity and information security that are required by the competent authority, when such information is related to any incident or is necessary for its management.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: b) To present, without the required specifications, the reports or information related to cybersecurity and information security that are required by the competent authority, when such information is related to any incident or is necessary for its management.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: c) Not to implement a permanent cybersecurity and information security management system, without justified cause, in accordance with what is established by the Agency.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: d) To fail to comply with the necessary measures to prevent, report and resolve cybersecurity and information security threats, immediately and effectively.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: e) Not to adopt, in a timely, expeditious and efficient manner, the necessary actions to reduce the impact and propagation of a cybersecurity or information security incident.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: f) Not to create or designate an area or areas responsible for the implementation, monitoring, review and adaptation of the actions and measures related to cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: g) To obstruct or prevent the management, audit and inspection tasks carried out by the Agency in matters of cybersecurity and information security.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: h) Not to inform the potential affected parties, insofar as they can be identified and when so determined by the ACE, about the occurrence of incidents that could compromise or gravely compromise their information, as well as the possible measures that they may adopt to mitigate the risks caused by the same, if any.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The following shall be considered very serious infringements: i) To fail to comply with prohibitory orders to use the computer systems or any of their parts, in the time and manner communicated by the Agency.

Art. 21.- Very serious infringements.- The holders, senior management and any other official or employee shall also incur liability for the preceding infringements when these materialize by virtue of the order, instruction, negligence or omission of the same.

Art. 22.- Penalty for minor infringements.- Minor infringements shall be sanctioned with a written admonition or a fine of between one to ten monthly minimum wages of the commerce sector, as corresponds to the obligated subject.

Art. 22.- Penalty for minor infringements.- The official or employee who receives three or more written admonitions in a period of less than one year shall be terminated from their employment or office without liability for the Public Administration.

Art. 23.- Penalty for serious infringements.- Serious infringements shall be sanctioned with dismissal or removal from office without liability for the Public Administration and a fine of between eleven to fifty monthly minimum wages of the commerce sector when the infringer is linked to the public sector.

Art. 23.- Penalty for serious infringements.- In the case that the infringer belongs to the private sector, the sanction shall be a fine of between eleven to fifty monthly minimum wages of the commerce sector.

Art. 24.- Penalty for serious infringements.- The serious infringements shall be sanctioned with dismissal or removal from office without liability for the Public Administration and a fine of between fifty-one to one hundred monthly minimum wages of the commerce sector when the infringer is linked to the public sector.

Art. 24.- Penalty for serious infringements.- In the case that the infringer belongs to the private sector, the sanction shall be a fine of between fifty-one to one hundred monthly minimum wages of the commerce sector.

Art. 25.- Inability to belong to the public sector.- The official or employee who is dismissed or removed from their office for the commission of any of the infringements contemplated by the present law, may not work for the public administration for a period of ten years following the imposition of the respective sanction.

Art. 26.- Additional measures.- Once the sanction is determined as merited, the Agency may order the infringer or the related obligated subject to adopt the measures that are necessary to restore the legality altered by the infringement or that allow the correction of the rights or situations violated.

Art. 26.- Additional measures.- All sanctions determined in the present law do not exempt the infringer from civil or criminal responsibilities derived from the corresponding investigations that they give rise to.

Art. 27.- Coercive fine.- In order to achieve the execution of its acts, the Agency may impose coercive fines of between one to ten minimum wages of the commerce sector for each working day that elapses without compliance with what is ordered.
Art. 27.- Coercive fine.- This sanction shall be independent and compatible with the other sanctions contemplated in this law.

Art. 28.- Sanctioning procedure.- The procedure for the determination of the infringements and sanctions established by the present law shall be carried out in accordance with the simplified procedure contemplated in the Law of Administrative Procedures.

Art. 28.- Sanctioning procedure.- The procedure may be initiated ex officio, by notice, by complaint or by any other means. When the information on the alleged commission of the infringement is received verbally or in such a manner that there is no written record thereof, the Agency shall draw up an act with all pertinent data for the processing of the procedure.
Art. 29.- Prescription.- The infringements and sanctions contemplated in the present law shall prescribe in five years.

Art. 30.- Specialty and subsidiarity.- The present law, by its special character, shall prevail over any other legal provision that contradicts it, including those that regulate the labor relationship between employees, servants and public officials; however, the constitutional guarantees of the same shall always be respected. In all that is not foreseen, the provisions of the Law of Administrative Procedures shall apply subsidiarily.

Art. 31.- Issuance of applicable regulations and provisions.- The ACE shall draft the regulations, protocols, guidelines, standards and technical criteria, both general and specific, in matters of cybersecurity and information security, in concordance with what is established in Article 5, no later than ninety days counted from the entry into force of the present law.
Art. 32.- Entry into force.- The present law shall enter into force eight days after its publication in the Official Gazette.

CHAPTER VII USURPATION

Article 351. (DISPOSSESSMENT). Anyone who, for his own benefit or that of a third party, through violence, threats, deceit, breach of trust or any other means, deprives another of the possession or holding of a property, or of the exercise of a real right constituted over it, whether the dispossession occurs by invading the property, remaining in it or expelling the occupants, will incur a deprivation of liberty of six (6) months to four (4) years.

Article 352. (ALTERATION OF BOUNDARIES). Anyone who, with the purpose of taking possession, in whole or in part, of another's real estate, suppresses or alters the terms or boundaries, shall be punished with imprisonment of three (3) months to two (2) years.

Article 353. (DISTURBANCE OF POSSESSION). Anyone who, through violence or threats against persons, disturbs the quiet and peaceful possession of a property, shall incur a penalty of imprisonment of three (3) months to three (3) years.

Article 354. (USURPATION OF WATERS). Anyone who, in order to obtain for himself or another some illicit benefit and to the detriment of a third party, diverts public or private waters that do not belong to him or does so in a greater quantity than is due, shall be punished with imprisonment of three (3) months to two (2) years.
Article 354. (USURPATION OF WATERS). The same penalty shall be incurred by anyone who hinders or impedes in any way the exercise of the rights that a third party may have over said waters.
Article 355. (AGGRAVATED USURPATION). The penalty shall be increased by one third if, in the cases of the preceding articles, the acts were committed by several persons and with weapons.

Article 356. (PROHIBITED HUNTING AND FISHING). Anyone who violates the provisions relating to hunting and fishing or does so in fiscal reserve areas or on another's property, which is cultivated or fenced, without the consent of the owner, will incur a penalty of one (1) month to one (1) year of work and a fine of up to sixty (60) days.
CHAPTER VIII DAMAGES

Article 357. (SIMPLE DAMAGE). Anyone who in any way deteriorates, destroys, renders useless, causes to disappear or damages another's property shall incur a penalty of imprisonment of one (1) month to one (1) year and a fine of up to sixty (60) days.

Article 358. (QUALIFIED DAMAGE). The penalty will be deprivation of liberty from one (1) to six (6) years: 1) When the damage occurs to means or routes of communication or transit, to bridges or canals, to production plants or water, electricity or energy substance conduits.

Article 358. (QUALIFIED DAMAGE). The penalty will be deprivation of liberty from one (1) to six (6) years: 2) When it is committed in an uninhabited area and in a gang or group, or with violence against people or serious threats.

Article 358. (QUALIFIED DAMAGE). The penalty will be deprivation of liberty from one (1) to six (6) years: 3) When it falls on things of artistic, archaeological, scientific, historical, religious, military or economic.

Article 358. (QUALIFIED DAMAGE). The penalty will be deprivation of liberty from one (1) to six (6) years: 4) When it is carried out by fire, destruction or deterioration of valuable documents estimable.

Article 358. (QUALIFIED DAMAGE). The penalty will be deprivation of liberty from one (1) to six (6) years: 5) When the destruction of forests, jungles, pastures, crops, or crops occurs, or the act affects purebred animals.

Article 359. (EXEMPTION FROM PENALTY). No penalty shall be applied, without prejudice to the civil action that may be applicable to the injured party, for the crimes of theft, robbery, extortion, fraud, embezzlement, misappropriation and damage, which are mutually caused: 1) Spouses who are not divorced, those who are not legally separated or those who live together.

Article 359. (EXEMPTION FROM PENALTY). No penalty shall be applied, without prejudice to the civil action that may be applicable to the injured party, for the crimes of theft, robbery, extortion, fraud, embezzlement, misappropriation and damage, which are mutually caused: 2) Ascendants, descendants, adopters and adopted children and relatives in a straight line.

Article 359. (EXEMPTION FROM PENALTY). No penalty shall be applied, without prejudice to the civil action that may be applicable to the injured party, for the crimes of theft, robbery, extortion, fraud, embezzlement, misappropriation and damage, which are mutually caused: 3) Brothers and sisters-in-law, if they live together.
CHAPTER IX USURY

Article 360. (USURY). Anyone who, taking advantage of the need, frivolity or inexperience of a person, gives in any way, for himself or for others, securities or goods in exchange for interest higher than that established by law or other pecuniary advantages evidently disproportionate to the benefit, shall be punished with imprisonment of three (3) months to two (2) years and a fine of thirty (30) to one hundred (100) days.
Article 360. (USURY). The same penalty shall apply to anyone who knowingly acquires, transfers or asserts usurious credit, or to an intermediary, front man or collaborator.

Article 361. (AGGRAVATED USURY). The sanction will be aggravated by one half and a fine of up to one hundred (100) days: 1) If the author is a professional or habitual usurious lender or commission agent.

Article 361. (AGGRAVATED USURY). The sanction will be aggravated by one half and a fine of up to one hundred (100) days: 2) When any artifice or deception has been used to obtain the consent of the victim.

Article 361. (AGGRAVATED USURY). The sanction will be aggravated by one half and a fine of up to one hundred (100) days: 3) If the fact is concealed by other forms of contract, even by way of a penalty clause that sets interest.
Article 361. (AGGRAVATED USURY). The sanction will be aggravated by one half and a fine of up to one hundred (100) days: 4) If the fact constitutes any of the forms of a natocism.
CHAPTER X CRIMES AGAINST COPYRIGHT

Article 362. (CRIMES AGAINST INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY). Whoever, for profit, to the detriment of another, reproduces, plagiarizes, distributes, publishes on screen or on television, in whole or in part, a literary, artistic, musical, scientific, television or cinematographic work, or its transformation, interpretation, artistic performance through any means, without the authorization of the owners of the intellectual property rights or their concessionaires, or imports, exports or stores copies of said works, without the aforementioned authorization, shall be punished with imprisonment from three (3) months to two (2) years and a fine of sixty (60) days.

Article 363. (VIOLATION OF THE PRIVILEGE OF INVENTION). Anyone who violates the right of privilege of invention or discovery shall be punished with imprisonment from three (3) months to two (2) years and a fine of thirty (30) to sixty (60) days, in the following cases: 1) Manufacturing objects or products covered by a privilege without the authorization of the dealer.

Article 363. (VIOLATION OF THE PRIVILEGE OF INVENTION). Anyone who violates the right of privilege of invention or discovery shall be punished with imprisonment from three (3) months to two (2) years and a fine of thirty (30) to sixty (60) days, in the following cases: 2) Using a means or procedure that is the subject of a privilege.
CHAPTER XI COMPUTER CRIMES

Article 363 Bis. (COMPUTER MANIPULATION). Anyone who, with the intention of obtaining an undue benefit for himself or a third party, manipulates a processing or transfer of computer data that leads to an incorrect result or avoids such a process whose result would have been correct, thereby causing a transfer of assets to the detriment of a third party, shall be punished with imprisonment of one (1) to five (5) years and a fine of sixty (60) to two hundred (200) days.

Article 363 Ter. (ALTERATION, ACCESS AND IMPROPER USE OF COMPUTER DATA). Whoever, without authorization, takes possession of, accesses, uses, modifies, deletes or renders useless data stored in a computer or any computer medium, causing harm to the owner of the information, will be sanctioned with work for up to one (1) year or a fine of up to two hundred (200) days.
FINAL TITLE TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS
Article 364. (REPEAL OF CRIMINAL LAWS). The Criminal Code of November 6, 1834 and all other laws and provisions that are contrary to this Law are hereby repealed.

Article 152. (Lesser penalty). If the death penalty or life imprisonment is provided for in the requesting State for the crime that motivates the extradition request, the latter may only be granted if said State undertakes to commute them to a prison sentence of no more than thirty (30) years.

Article 153. (Deferred execution). The execution of the extradition granted shall be deferred when: 1) The requested person is subject to the criminal jurisdiction of the Republic for a crime other than that for which extradition was requested, until the conclusion of the procedure or execution of the imposed sentence, except in the case provided for in numeral 5) of article 21 of this Code.

Article 153. (Deferred execution). The execution of the extradition granted shall be deferred when: 2) The woman is pregnant or has a child under one (1) year of age at the time the extradition resolution is executed; and,

Article 153. (Deferred execution). The execution of the extradition granted shall be deferred when: 3) The person seeking extradition is seriously ill and the immediate execution of the extradition would endanger his life, according to the forensic medical opinion.
When these circumstances cease, extradition will become effective immediately.

Article 154. (Powers of the competent court). The Supreme Court of Justice, when resolving extradition requests, shall have the power to: 1) Order the preventive detention of the extraditable person for a maximum period of six (6) months provided that the existence of a conviction or judicial resolution of detention is proven.

Article 154. (Powers of the competent court). The Supreme Court of Justice, when resolving extradition requests, shall have the power to: 2) Order the provisional detention of the extraditable person for a maximum period of ninety (90) days when all the documents required for the extradition to proceed have not been presented; and,

Article 154. (Powers of the competent court). The Supreme Court of Justice, when resolving extradition requests, shall have the power to: 3) Order the delivery to the requesting State of all or part of the movable assets instruments of the crime, seized or kidnapped from the extraditable.

Article 155. (Competition of requests). When two (2) or more States request the extradition of the same person, preference will be given to the request of the State where the most serious crime was committed and, if the crime is of equal gravity, to the request of the State that requested it first.

Article 156. (Active extradition). The request for extradition shall be decreed by the judge or court of the proceedings, at the request of the prosecutor or the plaintiff, when there is a formal charge of the crime and, also ex officio, when there is a conviction.

Article 157. (Passive extradition). Every request for extradition shall be submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Worship, accompanied by the most precise identification of the person to be extradited, the data that contribute to determining the place where he or she is located and the authenticated text of the legal provision that defines the crime. All required documentation must be accompanied by an official translation into Spanish.
When the person is being prosecuted, the original or certified copy of the judicial resolution of the charge containing the classification of the crime must also be attached, including a reference to the time and place of its commission and the arrest warrant issued by a competent judicial authority.
When the person has been convicted, the original or certified copy of the conviction and the corresponding certification of its execution, indicating, where applicable, the remainder of the sentence that remains to be served, must also be attached.

Article 158. (Procedure). Once the extradition request has been filed with the Supreme Court of Justice, the background information will be forwarded to the Attorney General's Office of the Republic, so that within ten (10) days, it may request information on its admissibility or inadmissibility. The Supreme Court of Justice Justice, within twenty (20) days following receipt of the request, will resolve by granting or denying the requested extradition.

Article 159. ( Preference). In the event of a contradiction between the rules provided for in this Code and those stipulated in an extradition Convention or Treaty, the latter shall apply preferentially.

Article 160. ( Notifications). The purpose of notifications is to inform the parties or third parties of judicial decisions.
