Decisions must be notified on the day after they are issued, unless the law or the judge provides for a shorter period. Decisions issued during oral hearings must be notified at the same time by reading them.

Article 161. ( Means of notification). Notifications shall be made by any legal means of communication that the interested party has expressly accepted or proposed, except for personal notifications.
When the interested party has not indicated a specific means of communication, these may be carried out by any other means that ensures their reception.

Article 162. ( Place of notification). State prosecutors and defenders shall be notified at their offices and the parties at the address they have established in their first appearance or, failing that, in court; except in the case of personal notifications.
Article 163. ( Personal notification). The following shall be notified personally: 1) The first resolution issued regarding the parties;
Article 163. ( Personal notification). The following shall be notified personally: 2) Final judgments and resolutions;
Article 163. ( Personal notification). The following shall be notified personally: 3) Resolutions imposing personal precautionary measures; and,

Article 163. ( Personal notification). The following shall be notified personally: 4) Other resolutions that, pursuant to the provisions of this Code, must be notified personally.
Notification shall be effected by delivering a copy of the decision to the interested party and a written warning about the possible appeals and the deadline for filing them, leaving a record of receipt. The accused deprived of his liberty shall be notified at the place of his detention.

Article 163. ( Personal notification). The following shall be notified personally: If the interested party is not found, the procedure will be carried out at his or her actual address, leaving a copy of the resolution and the warning in the presence of a suitable witness who will sign the procedure.

Article 164. (Notification requirements). The notification process shall state the place, date and time of service, the name of the person notified, the resolution, the signature and seal of the official responsible for carrying it out, and shall also expressly record the means used.

Article 165. ( Notification by edicts). When the person to be notified has no known address or whereabouts are unknown, he or she shall be notified by edict, which shall contain: 1) The full names and surnames of the notified party;

Article 165. ( Notification by edicts). When the person to be notified has no known address or whereabouts are unknown, he or she shall be notified by edict, which shall contain: 2) The name of the notifying authority, its headquarters and the identification of the process;

Article 165. ( Notification by edicts). When the person to be notified has no known address or whereabouts are unknown, he or she shall be notified by edict, which shall contain: 3) The notified resolution and the corresponding warning;

Article 165. ( Notification by edicts). When the person to be notified has no known address or whereabouts are unknown, he or she shall be notified by edict, which shall contain: 4) The place and date on which it is issued; and, 5) The secretary's signature.
The edict will be published in a national circulation written media and in one of the places where the case is being followed, two (2) times with an interval of five (5) days between both publications.
In localities where these means do not exist, the edict must be posted in the most crowded public places.
In all cases, the dissemination will be recorded.

Article 165. ( Notification by edicts). When the person to be notified has no known address or whereabouts are unknown, he or she shall be notified by edict, which shall contain: The edict shall summon the accused to appear to assume his defense, within a period of ten (10) days, with the warning of being declared a rebel.
Article 166. (Nullity of notification). The notification shall be null: 1) If there has been an error regarding the identity of the person notified or the place of service;
Article 166. (Nullity of notification). The notification shall be null: 2) If the resolution has been notified incompletely;

Article 166. (Nullity of notification). The notification shall be null: 3) If the date and time of its performance are not stated in the diligence and, where required, the delivery of the copy and the corresponding warning;
Article 166. (Nullity of notification). The notification shall be null: 4) If any of the required signatures are missing; and,

Article 166. (Nullity of notification). The notification shall be null: 5) If there is a discrepancy between the original and the copy or if the latter is illegible.
The notification will be valid when, despite the defects stated, it has fulfilled its purpose.

Article 167. (Principle). Acts performed in violation of the forms and conditions provided for in the Political Constitution of the State, international Conventions and Treaties in force and in this Code may not be assessed to justify a judicial decision or used as a basis for such a decision, unless the defect can be remedied or validated.
In the cases and forms provided for by this Code, the parties may only challenge, based on the defect, judicial decisions or procedural omissions that cause them harm.

Article 168. (Correction). Whenever possible, the judge or court, ex officio or at the request of a party, having noticed the defect, must immediately correct it by renewing the act, rectifying the error or carrying out the omitted act.

Article 169. (Absolute defects). Defects concerning the following shall not be subject to validation: 1) The intervention of the judge and the prosecutor in the procedure and their participation in the acts in which it is mandatory;

Article 169. (Absolute defects). Defects concerning the following shall not be subject to validation: 2) The intervention, assistance and representation of the accused, in the cases and forms that this Code establishes;

Article 169. (Absolute defects). Defects concerning the following shall not be subject to validation: 3) Those that imply non-observance or violation of rights and guarantees provided for in the Political Constitution of the State, the international Conventions and Treaties in force and in this Code; and,
Article 169. (Absolute defects). Defects concerning the following shall not be subject to validation: 4) Those that are expressly sanctioned with nullity.
Article 170. (Relative defects). Relative defects will be validated in the following cases: 1) When the parties have not requested that they be corrected in a timely manner;

Article 170. (Relative defects). Relative defects will be validated in the following cases: 2) When those who have the right to request it have accepted, expressly or tacitly, the effects of the act; and,
Article 170. (Relative defects). Relative defects will be validated in the following cases: 3) If, despite its irregularity, the act has achieved its purpose with respect to all the interested.

Article 171. (Freedom of evidence). The judge shall admit as evidence all lawful elements of conviction that may lead to knowledge of the historical truth of the fact, of the responsibility and of the personality of the accused.
Other means may be used in addition to those provided for in this Book. Their incorporation into the process shall be subject to an analogous means of proof provided for.
A means of evidence will be admitted if it refers, directly or indirectly, to the object of the investigation and is useful for discovering the truth. The judge will limit the means of evidence offered when they are manifestly excessive or irrelevant.

Article 172. ( Evidentiary exclusions). Acts that violate rights and guarantees enshrined in the Political Constitution of the State, in current international Conventions and Treaties, this Code and other laws of the Republic, as well as evidence obtained by virtue of information originating in an illicit procedure or means, shall have no evidentiary value.
Evidence incorporated into the process without observing the formalities provided for in this Code will also not have probative value.

Article 173. ( Assessment). The judge or courts shall assign the corresponding value to each of the elements of evidence, applying the rules of sound judgment, justifying and adequately justifying the reasons for which a certain value is given to them, based on the joint and harmonious assessment of all the essential evidence produced.

Article 174. (Search of the crime scene). The police shall guard the crime scene and shall check, by searching the place and things, for traces and other material effects resulting from the crime.
The police officer in charge of the search will draw up a report describing in detail the state of affairs and, where possible, will collect and preserve useful evidence, leaving a record.
If the event produced material effects, the current state of the objects will be described, attempting to record the previous state, the manner, time and cause of their disappearance or alteration and the means of proof from which this knowledge was obtained.
A competent witness shall be summoned to witness the registration and sign the minutes; under these formalities, the minutes may be included in the trial by being read. Exceptionally, when it is not possible to have a witness, his presence may be dispensed with, and the reasons must be recorded in the minutes.
The prosecutor will go to the scene of the incident, conduct the search and sign the report; these actions may only be carried out without his presence in urgent cases.

Article 175. ( Search of person). The prosecutor may order searches of person, provided there are sufficient grounds to presume that one or more persons are concealing among their belongings or carrying inside their body or attached to it, objects related to the crime.
Before proceeding with the search, the person must be warned about the suspicion and the objects sought, and ordered to show it.
The search will be carried out by persons of the same sex and with respect for the modesty of the person being searched.
The warning and the search shall be carried out in the presence of a competent witness and shall be recorded in a record signed by the officer involved, the person searched and the witness. If the person searched does not sign, the reason shall be recorded. Under these formalities, the record may be incorporated into the trial by being read.
In the case of drug trafficking offences, exceptionally, the Special Force against Drug Trafficking may carry out the search ex officio without the presence of a witness or without a request from the prosecutor, recording in the minutes the reasons that prevented the presence of the witness or the request from the prosecutor.

Article 176. ( Search of vehicles). A vehicle may be searched whenever there are sufficient grounds to presume that a person is concealing objects related to the crime in it, following the procedure provided for personal searches.

Article 177. ( Removal and identification of corpses). The police will carry out a preliminary body inspection and a description of the situation or position of the body and the nature of the injuries or wounds in accordance with the provisions of Article 174 of this Code.
He will proceed to remove the body, arranging its transfer to the forensic medical offices or to the place where the autopsy will be performed, its final identification and its delivery to the relatives.

Article 178. ( Autopsy or necropsy). The prosecutor shall order the autopsy or necropsy in accordance with the rules of expertise and under these formalities it may be introduced at the trial by reading it.
If the prosecutor has not ordered the autopsy or necropsy to be performed, the parties may request the judge to order it in accordance with articles 307 et seq. of this Code.

Article 179. ( Visual inspection and reconstruction). The prosecutor, judge or court may order an ocular inspection and/or reconstruction of the event, in accordance with the statements received and other evidence, to verify whether the event was or could have been carried out in a certain manner.
If the accused voluntarily decides to participate in the reconstruction, the rules provided for his statement will apply. His refusal to participate will not prevent the act from being carried out.
For the participation of witnesses, experts and interpreters, the provisions established by this Code shall apply.
When determining the modalities of reconstruction, the prosecutor, judge or court shall make appropriate arrangements to ensure that it takes place in a manner that does not offend or endanger the integrity of persons or public safety.
A record of all the actions taken will be drawn up and signed by those involved, noting those who did not want to or were unable to do so.

Article 180. ( Search of a home). When a search must be carried out at a home, a reasoned decision by the judge and the obligatory participation of the prosecutor will be required.
The search of a home or private residence at night is prohibited and may only be carried out during working hours of the day, except in the case of a flagrant crime. Nighttime hours are understood to be the time between seven (19) hours and seven (7) hours of the following day.

Article 181. ( Coercive powers). In order to carry out the search, the authority may order that the persons found at the location not be absent during the procedure or that any other person appear immediately.
Those who disobey will be compelled by the public force, without prejudice to any corresponding responsibility.
The restriction of freedom will not last more than eight (8) hours; after this period, an order from the investigating judge must necessarily be obtained.

Article 182. ( Warrant and content). The search warrants shall contain the following requirements: 1) The name and position of the judge or court ordering the search and a brief identification of the process;
Article 182. ( Warrant and content). The search warrants shall contain the following requirements: 2) The precise indication of the place or places to be searched;
Article 182. ( Warrant and content). The search warrants shall contain the following requirements: 3) The authority designated for the search;

Article 182. ( Warrant and content). The search warrants shall contain the following requirements: 4) The specific reason for the search, its respective justification, the steps to be taken and, if possible, the identification of the persons or objects sought; and, 5) The date and the signature of the judge.
The warrant will be valid for a maximum of ninety-six (96) hours, after which it expires. The prosecutor who attends the search will be in charge of directing the proceedings.

Article 183. (Procedure and formalities). The resolution ordering the search shall be brought to the attention of the person who lives or is in possession or custody of the premises, who is over fourteen (14) years of age, so that he may witness the search and be given a copy of the warrant. In the absence of these persons, a copy of the warrant shall be posted on the door of the property searched.
Once the search has been carried out, the results shall be recorded in the minutes, ensuring that the place is closed and protected from other persons, if there are reasonable grounds for doing so. The minutes shall be signed by all those involved in the act and by the person who witnessed the search. If the latter does not do so, the reasons shall be recorded.

Article 184. (Delivery of objects and documents. Seizures). The objects, instruments and other pieces of evidence will be collected, secured and sealed by the police or the prosecutor for their retention and preservation, leaving a record of this fact in the minutes. If due to their nature it is impossible to keep the objects in their original form, the prosecutor will arrange the best way to preserve them.
Anyone who has in his possession objects or documents of those previously mentioned will be obliged to present and deliver them, when requested, for which purpose they may be compelled by the public force, without prejudice to the corresponding liability.
Persons who are not required by law to testify as witnesses are exempt from this obligation.

Article 185. ( Objects not subject to seizure). Medical examinations or diagnoses related to legally established duties of secrecy and confidentiality, or communications between the accused and his defense attorney, may not be seized.

Article 186. ( Procedure for seizure). The procedure established for the search shall apply. Seized objects shall be inventoried and placed under safe custody in the warehouses of the Prosecutor's Office or in places specially designated for this purpose, under the responsibility and at the disposal of the prosecutor.
Cattle, vehicles and goods of significant value will be delivered to their owners or to those who prove legitimate possession or ownership, as judicial depositaries after the verification and description procedures have been carried out.
If the seized objects are at risk of being altered, disappearing, are difficult to preserve or are perishable, reproductions, copies or certifications of their condition will be ordered and they will be returned to their owners.
After six (6) months without a claim or identification of the owner or possessor, the objects may be delivered in judicial deposit to a health establishment or a public entity who may only use them to fulfill the service they provide to the public. In the case of the National Police and other investigative agencies, they will be the custodians of those assets that by their nature can only be used in investigative work.
If these assets are subject to seizure, once used by the prosecutor for evidentiary purposes, the regime established for seized assets will be applied to them.

Article 187. ( Public premises). For searches in state departments, commercial premises, or those intended for public recreation, a court order for search may be waived when there is authorization from the owner or person responsible for the same, except in the case of a flagrant crime. In the event of refusal or material impossibility of obtaining consent, a court order for search shall be requested and public force may be used to enforce it.
The person in charge or person in charge of the place will be present at the registration or, in the absence of this person, any dependent adult.
The search of persons or furniture in these places shall be subject to the provisions of this Title. A detailed record of the search shall be drawn up observing the formalities provided for in article 174 of this Code and any useful evidence shall be kept.

Article 188. ( Seizure and destruction of controlled substances). Illicit controlled substances shall be publicly destroyed or extinguished within a maximum period of six (6) calendar days following their seizure, in the presence and under the responsibility of the prosecutor in charge of the investigation; separating a representative sample that shall be placed under custody in the District Attorney's Office warehouses, for use as evidence. A detailed report shall be drawn up of the seizure and destruction or extinction that must be incorporated into the trial by its reading.
Controlled substances seized that may be used for lawful purposes will not be destroyed and will be subject to the seizure regime.

Article 189. (Return). Seized objects that are not subject to seizure, confiscation or embargo shall be returned by the prosecutor to the person from whose possession they were obtained as soon as they can be disposed of.
This return may be ordered provisionally as a judicial deposit and the possessor may be required to exhibit them.
In the event of a dispute concerning the ownership, possession or dominion of a thing or document, in order to deposit it or return it, a separate incident will be processed before the competent judge and the respective rules of the civil process will be applied.

Article 190. (Seizure of correspondence, documents and papers). Whenever it is considered useful for the discovery of the truth, the judge or court shall order, by reasoned resolution under penalty of nullity, the seizure of private or public correspondence, documents and papers.
The limitations on the seizure of documents or objects will apply.

Article 191. ( Opening and examination). Once the correspondence, documents or papers have been received, the judge or court in the presence of the prosecutor shall proceed to open and examine them, and this shall be recorded in the minutes. If they are related to the proceedings, the judge or court shall order their seizure; otherwise, the judge shall keep their contents confidential and order their delivery to the recipient or sender or to their owner.

Article 192. (Closure of Premises). The judge or court shall order, by means of a reasoned resolution for a maximum term of ten (10) days, the closure or securing of a premises or the immobilization of movable property that due to its nature or size cannot be kept in storage, applying the rules of seizure.

Article 193. (Obligation to testify). Any person who is summoned as a witness shall have the obligation to appear before the judge or court to declare the truth of everything he or she knows and is asked, except for the exceptions established by law.
The witness may not be forced to testify about facts from which his criminal liability may arise.

Article 194. (Capacity to testify and assessment). Every person shall be capable of testifying, including police officers regarding their actions; the judge shall evaluate the testimony in accordance with the rules of sound judgment.

Article 195. (Special treatment). The following shall not be required to appear before a judge or court: the President and Vice President of the Republic, Presidents of the Legislative Chambers, President of the Supreme Court, President of the Constitutional Court, Attorney General of the Republic, Ombudsman, representatives of diplomatic missions, Parliamentarians and Ministers of State, who shall testify at the place where they perform their duties, at their domicile or in writing.

Article 196. (Right to abstain). Those who may abstain from testifying against the accused, his or her spouse or partner, blood relatives up to the fourth degree or by adoption, and relatives by affinity up to the second degree may abstain from testifying against the accused.
Before the start of the statement, the judge must inform these persons of their right to abstain from testifying in whole or in part.

Article 197. (Duty to abstain). Persons must abstain from testifying about facts that have come to their knowledge by reason of their trade or profession and that relate to legally established duties of secrecy and confidentiality.
These persons may not refuse to give testimony when they are released by the interested party from the duty to maintain secrecy.
If they are summoned, they must appear and explain the reasons for their abstention. If the judge considers that the witness wrongly invokes this duty with respect to a fact that cannot be included in it, he will order their statement by reasoned resolution.

Article 198. ( Compulsion). If the witness does not appear at the first summons, an arrest warrant will be issued, without prejudice to his prosecution. If after appearing he refuses to testify, his arrest will be ordered for up to twenty-four (24) hours, after which, if he persists in his refusal, criminal proceedings will be initiated.

Article 199. ( Statement by commission). When the witness does not reside in the judicial district where he must give his statement and it is not possible to count on his presence, his statement shall be ordered by summons or order issued to the judicial authority of his residence.

Article 200. ( Form of the statement). At the beginning of the statement, the witness will be informed of his obligations, of the responsibility for non-compliance and, according to his belief, he will take an oath or promise to tell the truth.
Each witness will be questioned separately, about his or her name, surname and other personal details, family ties and interests with the parties and any other circumstance that may serve to assess his or her veracity. He or she will then be questioned about the event.
If the witness fears for his or her physical safety or that of another person, he or she may only provide his or her address confidentially.

Article 201. ( False Testimony). If the witness contradicts himself, he shall be required to explain the reason for his contradictions.
If he does not do so and his statement reveals signs of false testimony, the act shall be suspended and the background information shall be sent to the Public Prosecutor's Office for the corresponding criminal action.
Article 202. ( Police informants). Information provided by police informants may not be incorporated into the proceedings except when they are questioned as witnesses.

Article 203. ( Special Testimonies). Persons who are unable to attend court due to physical incapacity shall be questioned at their home or at their place of hospitalization.
When testimony must be received from sexually assaulted persons or from minors under sixteen (16) years of age, regardless of the phase in which the process is found, the judge or court will arrange for it to be received in private with the assistance of relatives or experts specialized in the treatment of these persons to guarantee respect for the conditions inherent to the declarant.
Article 204. ( Expertise). An expert opinion shall be ordered when specialized knowledge in a science, art or technique is required to discover or assess an element of evidence.

Article 205. ( Experts). Experts will be appointed who, according to state regulations, demonstrate suitability in the matter.
If the science, technique or art is not regulated or if it is not possible to have an expert at the place of the proceedings, a person of manifest suitability shall be appointed. The rules of this Title shall apply to translators and interpreters.

Article 206. ( Medical examination). The prosecutor shall order forensic medical examinations of the accused or the victim when these are necessary for the investigation of the reported incident, which shall be carried out in a manner that preserves the health and modesty of the person being examined.
Only the lawyer or a trusted person of the person being examined may attend the event, who will be previously informed of this right.

Article 207. ( Technical Consultants). The judge or court, according to the rules applicable to experts, may authorize the intervention in the process of technical consultants proposed by the parties.
The technical consultant may attend the expert report and make observations during its course, without issuing an opinion. At the hearings, they may advise the parties on the acts inherent to their function, directly question the experts, translators or interpreters and conclude on the expert evidence, always under the direction of the party they assist.
The Prosecutor's Office will appoint its technical consultants directly, without the need for judicial authorization.

Article 208. ( Impediments). Those who have been witnesses to the fact that is the subject of the proceedings and those who must or may abstain from testifying as witnesses will not be designated as experts.

Article 209. ( Designation and scope). The parties may propose experts, who will be designated by the prosecutor during the preparatory stage, provided that it is not a jurisdictional advance of evidence, or by the judge or court at any stage of the process.
The number of experts will be determined according to the complexity of the issues to be assessed.
The prosecutor, judge or court shall precisely determine the topics of the expert report and the deadline for the submission of the opinions. The parties may propose or object to the topics of the expert report.

Article 210. (Excuse and Recusal). Experts may excuse themselves or be recused for the same reasons established for judges, except for their participation in any stage of the process. The judge or court shall decide what is appropriate, after a summary inquiry into the reason invoked without further appeal.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 211. ( Summoning and acceptance of office). Experts shall be summoned in the same manner as witnesses.
They shall have the duty to appear and perform the duties for which they were appointed, after taking an oath or promise. If they are impeded or unsuitable, they must inform the prosecutor, judge or court, so that after a summary investigation, they may decide what is appropriate, without further recourse.
The provisions of Article 198 of this Code apply.

Article 212. ( Execution). The judge or court shall resolve all issues raised during the expert operations and shall provide the necessary judicial assistance.
If there are several experts, whenever possible, they will carry out the examination together. The parties and their technical advisors may attend the examination and request the relevant clarifications, but must leave when the experts begin their deliberation.
The prosecutor, judge or court shall order the replacement of any expert who fails to perform expert operations within the established period or who performs his or her duties negligently.
The expert must keep confidential everything he learns in connection with his work.

Article 213. ( Opinion). The opinion shall be reasoned and shall contain in a clear and precise manner the detailed account of the operations carried out and their results, the observations of the parties or their technical consultants and the conclusions formulated with respect to each expert matter.
Experts may issue separate opinions when there is a difference of opinion among them.
The opinion shall be submitted in writing, signed and dated.

Article 214. ( New opinion. Extension). When the opinions are ambiguous, insufficient or contradictory, their extension or the performance of a new expert report by the same experts or by different ones will be ordered.

Article 215. ( Preservation of objects). The prosecutor, judge or court and the experts shall ensure that the objects examined are preserved so that the expert examination can be repeated.
If it is necessary to destroy or alter the objects being analysed, the experts must inform the authorities before proceeding.

Article 216. ( Documents). All documentary evidence lawfully obtained shall be admitted.
The accused may not be forced to acknowledge private documents held against him, and the judge or court must ask him whether he is willing to testify about their authenticity, without his refusal being prejudicial to him. In this case, the parties may prove their authenticity by other means.

Article 217. ( Documents and evidence). Documents, objects and other evidence incorporated into the proceedings may be shown to the accused, witnesses and experts so that they may examine them and report on them. Those that are confidential shall be examined privately by the judge or court and, if they are useful for discovering the truth, they shall be incorporated into the proceedings.

Article 218. ( Reports). The prosecutor, judge or court may request reports from any person or public or private entity regarding data contained in their records.
The reports will be requested by any means, indicating the process in which they are required, the deadline for submission and the consequences in case of non-compliance.

Article 219. ( Recognition of persons). When it is necessary to identify the accused, his recognition will be ordered as follows: 1) The person carrying out the identification will describe the person mentioned and say whether he saw him again after the event, where, for what reason and with what object;

Article 219. ( Recognition of persons). When it is necessary to identify the accused, his recognition will be ordered as follows: 2) The person undergoing examination will be placed with others of similar physical appearance;

Article 219. ( Recognition of persons). When it is necessary to identify the accused, his recognition will be ordered as follows: 3) The person carrying out the recognition will be asked if the person he/she mentioned is among those present and, if so, he/she will be invited to indicate the person precisely; and,

Article 219. ( Recognition of persons). When it is necessary to identify the accused, his recognition will be ordered as follows: 4) If he has recognized it, he will express the differences and similarities that he observes between the state of the person indicated and the one he had at the time to which his statement refers.
The recognition will proceed even without the consent of the accused, with the presence of his defense attorney.
Precautions will be taken to ensure that the accused is not disfigured.
The identification will be carried out from a place where the witness cannot be observed, when this is considered convenient for his or her safety.
When several people must recognize one person, each recognition will be practiced separately, without communicating with each other.
When the accused cannot be located, photographs or other means may be used for identification, observing the same rules.
A detailed record of the recognition shall be drawn up with the formalities provided for by this Code, which shall be incorporated into the trial upon reading.

Article 220. ( Confrontation). When there is a contradiction in the statements of witnesses, the persons who issued them may be confronted and their attention will be drawn to the contradictions noted.
The rules of testimony and declaration of the accused shall apply respectively.

Article 221. ( Purpose and scope). Personal freedom and other rights and guarantees recognized to every person by the Political Constitution of the State, the international Conventions and Treaties in force and this Code, may only be restricted when it is indispensable to ensure the discovery of the truth, the development of the process and the application of the law.
The regulations authorizing restrictive measures of rights shall be applied and interpreted in accordance with article 7 of this Code. These measures shall be authorized by a reasoned judicial resolution, as regulated by this Code, and shall only last as long as the need for their application subsists.
The freedom of the accused may not be restricted in order to guarantee compensation for civil damages, payment of costs or fines.

Article 222. ( Character). Precautionary measures of a personal nature shall be applied with restrictive criteria and shall be executed in such a way as to cause the least possible harm to the person and reputation of those affected.
The precautionary measures of a real nature will be those provided for in the Code of Civil Procedure, and will be imposed only in the cases expressly indicated by this Code, as well as the payment of costs and fines.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 223. (Spontaneous presentation). The person against whom proceedings have been initiated may appear in person, proving his identity, before the prosecutor in charge of the investigation, requesting that his statement be taken, that his freedom be maintained, or that he make a statement regarding the application of a precautionary measure.
If the prosecutor does not make a decision within forty-eight (48) hours, the accused will appear before the investigating judge to decide on the appropriateness of his release or any of the precautionary measures.
Spontaneous presentation, by itself, does not negate the procedural dangers that motivate the application of precautionary measures.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Amendments to the Criminal Law System)
Article 224. (Summoning). If the accused summoned does not appear within the time periods set, nor does he justify a legitimate impediment, the competent authority shall issue an arrest warrant.

Article 225. (Arrest). When at the first moment of the investigation it is impossible to identify the authors, participants and witnesses, and it must be done urgently so as not to harm the investigation, the prosecutor or the police may order that those present do not leave the place, do not communicate with each other before reporting, nor modify the state of things and places and, if necessary, they will order the arrest of all for a period of no more than eight (8) hours.

Article 226. ( Arrest by the Prosecutor). The prosecutor may order the arrest of the accused, when his presence is necessary and there are sufficient indications that he is the author or participant in a crime of public action punishable by a prison sentence, the minimum legal term of which is equal to or greater than two (2) years and that he may hide, flee or leave the place or hinder the discovery of the truth, except in the crimes provided for and punished by articles 132 bis, 185, 254, 271 first paragraph and 331 of the Penal Code.
The arrested person will be placed at the disposal of the judge, within twenty-four (24) hours, so that he may decide within the same period, on the application of any of the precautionary measures provided for in this Code or decree his release due to lack of evidence.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 227. (Arrest by the police). The National Police may arrest any person in the following cases: 1) When caught red-handed; 2) In compliance with an arrest warrant issued by a competent judge or court; 3) In compliance with an order issued by the prosecutor, and, 4) When the person has escaped while legally detained.
The police authority that has arrested a person must communicate and make him available to the Prosecutor's Office within a maximum period of eight (8) hours.

Article 228. ( Freedom). Under no circumstances may the prosecutor or the police order the release of persons arrested. They must be placed at the disposition of the judge, who will determine their procedural situation.

Article 229. (Arrest by private individuals). In accordance with the provisions of the Political Constitution of the State, in the case of flagrante delicto, private individuals are authorized to carry out the arrest, and must immediately hand over the arrested person to the police, the Prosecutor's Office or the nearest authority.
The individual who makes an arrest will also collect the objects and instruments that were used to commit the act or are relevant to its discovery and will hand them over to the corresponding authority.

Article 230. ( Flagrant crime). Flagrant crime is considered to exist when the perpetrator of the act is surprised at the moment of attempting to commit it, or immediately afterwards while being pursued by the public force, the victim or eyewitnesses of the act.

Article 231. ( Incommunicado). Incommunicado detention may not be imposed except in cases of notorious gravity when there are reasons to fear that the accused will otherwise hinder the discovery of the truth. In no case may it exceed twenty-four (24) hours and it shall not prevent the accused from being assisted by his defense attorney before carrying out any act that requires his personal intervention.
The incommunicado detention shall be ordered by the prosecutor in charge of the investigation, duly justified on the grounds indicated in article 235 of this Code, who shall immediately notify the investigating judge so that he may ratify or revoke the incommunicado detention.
The person held incommunicado shall be allowed to use books and writing materials, and may also perform unavoidable civil acts that do not harm the investigation.

Article 232. ( Inadmissibility of preventive detention). Preventive detention is not appropriate: 1) In private action crimes; 2) In those who do not have a prison sentence; and, 3) In crimes punishable by imprisonment whose legal maximum is less than three years.
In these cases, only the measures provided for in Article 240 of this Code may be applied.
In the case of pregnant women and nursing mothers of children under one (1) year of age, preventive detention will only be appropriate when there is no possibility of applying another alternative measure.

Article 233. ( Requirements for preventive detention). Once the formal charge has been made, the judge may order the preventive detention of the accused, at the reasoned request of the prosecutor or the victim, even if the victim has not been constituted as a complainant, when the following requirements are met: 1. The existence of sufficient elements of conviction to sustain that the accused is, with probability, author or participant in a punishable act.
2. The existence of sufficient evidence that the accused will not submit to the process or hinder the discovery of the truth.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 235. ( Danger of O bstruction). The danger of obstruction is understood to be any circumstance that allows us to sustain, with good reason, that the accused's behavior will hinder the discovery of the truth. In order to decide on its occurrence, a comprehensive evaluation of the existing circumstances will be carried out, taking into account especially the following:
1. That the accused destroys, modifies, hides, suppresses, and/or falsifies evidence;
2. That the accused negatively influences the participants, witnesses or experts, in order that make false reports or behave in a reticent manner;
3. That the accused illegally or illegitimately influences judges of the Supreme Court, judges of the Plurinational Constitutional Court, members, technical judges, citizen judges, prosecutors and/or officials and employees of the justice administration system.
4. That the accused induces others to carry out the actions described in numerals 1, 2, and 3 of the present article.
5. Any other duly accredited circumstance that allows us to reasonably maintain that the accused, directly or indirectly, will hinder the discovery of the truth.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 235 Bis. (Danger of Recidivism). Precautionary measures including preventive detention may also be applied when the accused has been convicted in Bolivia or abroad by a final judgment if a period of five (5) years has not elapsed since the sentence was served.
(Incorporated by article 16 of Law No. 2494 of August 4, 2003, of the National System of Citizen Security)

Article 236. ( Jurisdiction, form and content of the decision). The preventive detention order shall be issued by the judge or court of the proceedings and shall contain: 1) The personal data of the accused or, if unknown, those that serve to identify him/her; 2) A brief statement of the fact or facts attributed to him; 3) The express justification of the reasons that motivate the detention, citing the applicable legal regulations; and, 4) The place of its fulfillment.

Article 237. ( Treatment). Persons held in preventive detention shall be held in special establishments, different from those used for convicted persons, or at least in separate sections from those provided for the latter, and shall be treated at all times as innocent persons who are detained for the sole purpose of ensuring the normal development of the criminal proceedings. Preventive detention must be carried out in the penal precinct of the place where the proceedings are being conducted.

Article 238. ( Control). The judge of criminal enforcement shall be responsible for controlling the treatment given to the detainee. Any permission to leave or transfer shall only be authorized by the trial judge. In case of extreme urgency, this measure may be ordered by the judge of criminal enforcement, with immediate notice to the trial judge.
When the judge of criminal enforcement verifies a violation of the legal regime of preventive detention, he will immediately notify the trial judge, who will resolve without further proceedings within twenty-four (24) hours.
A convicted person who is serving a prison sentence and is simultaneously subject to preventive detention shall follow the regime imposed by his sentence, without prejudice to the judge in charge of the trial taking the necessary measures to guarantee his defence.

Article 239. ( Cessation of Preventive Detention). Preventive detention shall cease: 1. When new elements of judgment demonstrate that the reasons that founded it do not exist or make it appropriate for it to be replaced by another measure; 2. When its duration exceeds the minimum legal penalty established for the most serious crime that is judged; and 3. When its duration exceeds eighteen (18) months without an indictment having been issued or thirty-six (36) months without a sentence having been issued.
Once the deadlines provided for in sections 2) and 3) have expired, the judge or court shall apply the corresponding precautionary measures provided for in article 240 of this Code, provided that the delay is not attributable to the dilatory acts of the accused.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 241. (Purpose and determination of bail). Bail shall have the exclusive purpose of ensuring that the accused will comply with the obligations imposed upon him and the orders of the judge or court.
The bail will be set taking into account the financial situation of the accused; in no case will a bail be set that is impossible to meet.
The accused and the guarantor may replace the bail with another equivalent bail, subject to prior authorization from the judge or court.

Article 242. ( Sworn Bail). Sworn bail shall be applicable when it is foreseeable that the accused will be granted conditional suspension of the sentence, judicial pardon, or when he or she demonstrates a state of poverty that makes it impossible for him or her to post real or personal bail. The accused who benefits from this measure must comply with the following obligations: 1. Appear before the prosecutor or judicial authority as many times as required; 2. Attend all relevant procedural actions; and 3. Not to change the address indicated for this purpose, for which the accused is obliged to periodically present the certificate of domiciliary registration issued by the competent authority, nor to leave the country without prior authorization from the judge or court of the case, who will order the corresponding grounding.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 243. ( Personal Bail). Personal bail consists of the obligation assumed by two (2) or more solvent persons with independent assets to present the accused before the judge who is hearing the case as many times as required.
In the event of the defendant's failure to appear, the guarantor will pay the sum determined by the judge for this purpose, which will be sufficient to cover the costs of capture and the procedural costs.
When there are several guarantors, they will assume the obligation jointly.
The guarantors may not present personal bail to any other defendant, while the bail offered and accepted lasts.
The judge, at the request of the guarantor, may accept his substitution.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 244. ( Real surety). Real surety is constituted with real or personal property, securities or money.
If real estate is offered, whether owned by the owner or a third party, the title deed, cadastral appraisal and certificate from the corresponding Registry must be presented to prove that there is no encumbrance on it, or that if encumbered, it constitutes sufficient guarantee, and the owner's consent is required.
In the case of movable property or jewellery, their value will be verified by means of an expert appraisal. The judge or court will verify the authenticity and veracity of this transaction and will appoint the corresponding depositary.
In the case of property subject to registration, the lien must be registered in the corresponding registry, and the officials in charge must give priority to the registration, carrying it out upon presentation of the document, under their responsibility within the term of twenty-four (24) hours.
The money will be deposited in a bank account at the order of the judge or court, with value maintenance and interest generation.
Article 245. (Effectiveness of freedom). Freedom will only become effective after bail has been granted.

Article 246. (Minutes). Before proceeding to the execution of these measures, minutes shall be drawn up, which shall include: 1) The specification of the obligations that the accused must fulfill and the warning about the consequences of non-compliance; 2) The identification of the persons involved in the execution of the measure and the acceptance of the obligation imposed on them; 3) The actual address indicated by all of them; and, 4) The formal promise of the accused to comply with the issued summons.

Article 247. (Reasons for Revocation). Measures alternative to preventive detention may be revoked for the following reasons: 1) When the accused fails to comply with any of the obligations imposed; 2) When it is proven that the accused carries out preparatory acts of escape or obstruction in the discovery of the truth; 3) When a new criminal proceeding is initiated against the accused for the commission of another crime.
Revocation will lead to preventive detention in cases where this precautionary measure is appropriate.
(Modified by Article 15 of Law No. 2 494 of August 4, 2003, Law of the National Citizen Security System)

Article 248. (Execution of bonds). In the case of rebellion or when the accused evades the execution of the sentence, the guarantor shall be notified, warning him that if the accused does not appear within ten (10) days following notification, the bond will be executed upon expiration of this period.
Once the deadline has expired, the judge or court will order the sale, by public auction, of the assets comprising the bond.
The liquid sums will be deposited in an interest-bearing bank account at the order of the judge or court that executed the bail for the purposes of the civil liability declared in the criminal proceedings. If within three (3) months of the final judgment of conviction or the judgment imposing a security measure, the civil liability is not claimed before the criminal sentencing judge, these sums will be transferred to the Compensation Fund.

Article 249. (Cancellation). The bond shall be cancelled and the assets assigned to the guarantee shall be returned, plus the interest generated in the bank account, provided that it has not been executed previously, when: 1) The decision to post bail is revoked; 2) The accused is acquitted or dismissed or the proceedings are archived by a final resolution; and, 3) The person submits to the execution of the sentence or it should not be executed.
Article 250. (Nature of decisions). The order imposing a precautionary measure or rejecting it is revocable or modifiable, even ex officio.

Article 251. (Appeal). The resolution that orders, modifies or rejects precautionary measures may be appealed, with non-suspensive effect, within a period of seventy-two (72) hours.
Once the appeal has been filed, the relevant proceedings will be sent to the Superior Court of Justice within twenty-four (24) hours.
The appeal court will decide, without further proceedings and in a hearing, within three (3) days after receiving the proceedings, without further appeal.
(Modified by Article 15 of Law No. 2 494 of August 4, 2003, Law of the National Citizen Security System)

Article 252. (Real Precautionary Measures). Without prejudice to the legal mortgage established by article 90 of the Penal Code, real precautionary measures shall be ordered by the trial judge at the request of a party, to guarantee the repair of damages and losses, as well as the payment of costs or fines, for which purpose the seizure of the bail may be requested provided that the defendant's own assets are involved.
The procedure will be governed by the Code of Civil Procedure, without requiring counter-security from the victim in any case.
The preventive annotation of the accused's own assets may be ordered directly by the prosecutor from the first moment of the investigation, through a reasoned resolution, which must be reported to the judge who exercises jurisdictional control within twenty-four (24) hours of having been made effective, and the judge must ratify, modify or revoke the measure within three (3) days of having been notified of the same.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 253. (Request for Seizure). Seizure shall be applied to the assets, means and instruments for the commission or financing of the crime, which belong to the accused or possible instigators and accomplices of the conduct described by the prosecutor.
Upon learning of the fact through any of the forms of initiation of the criminal investigation, the prosecutor within the period of preliminary proceedings for the alleged commission of the crime or in the event of flagrancy provided for in article 230 of Law No. 1970, will request before the investigating judge the seizure of the assets, means and instruments that belonged to the accused, possible instigators and accomplices of the conduct classified as a crime.
The prosecutor must request from the investigating judge the retention of funds in bank accounts and/or national and foreign financial entities that belong to the accused, possible instigators and accomplices, as well as request a report of financial banking performance that they have made in the last twelve (12) months.
Movable and immovable property will remain under the custody of the Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Property – DIRCABI.
In the event that controlled substances are found in airplanes, boats and motor vehicles, these assets will be confiscated and immediately handed over to the Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets – DIRCABI, an entity that, after registration and technical expert report, will proceed to the final handover to the Armed Forces in the case of airplanes and boats, and to the Public Prosecutor's Office or other public institutions in the case of motor vehicles so that they remain under their administration and custody.
(Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 253 Bis. (Seizure Procedure in Corruption Crimes). In the case of corruption crimes that cause serious damage to the State, from the beginning of the investigations, prior to the Fiscal requirement to the competent jurisdictional authority and within a peremptory period of five (5) days, the seizure of the goods and assets that are reasonably presumed to be the means, instrument or result of the crime will be carried out, with a complete inventory in the presence of a Notary Public, designating the depositary in accordance with the Law, and once the proceedings of the case have been concluded, the jurisdictional body will order, in a sentence, the confiscation of such goods and assets in favor of the State if corresponds.
(Incorporated by article 36 of Law No. 004 of March 31, 2010, on the Fight Against Corruption, Illicit Enrichment and Investigation of Fortunes “Marcelo Quiroga Santa Cruz”)

Article 254. (Seizure resolution). If there are sufficient indications regarding the status of assets subject to seizure or confiscation, the investigating judge shall, by means of a reasoned resolution, order: 1) Its seizure and inventory, indicating its nature and state of conservation; 2) The preventive annotation of the seizure resolution in the case of property subject to registration; and, 3) Its delivery to the Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Property for its administration in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter.
Movable property that is essential for the accused's home or objects for personal use by the accused and his family will not be subject to seizure.
Recording of seizures in public records shall be exempt from payment of judicial and administrative fees.

Article 255. (Incidents regarding the quality of the assets). I ) During the process, until before the sentence is issued, the owners of seized assets may promote an incident before the investigating judge who ordered the seizure, in which the following will be discussed: 1) If the seized property is subject to confiscation or forfeiture according to law; 2) If the seized property was acquired prior to the seizure order and without knowledge of its illicit origin or its use as the object of the crime. In any case, its origin must be justified.
The accused may only base his incident on the cause established in numeral one of this paragraph.
II) The investigating judge, by means of a reasoned decision: 1) Ratify the seizure of the property that is the subject of the incident; or, 2) Revoke the seizure, ordering, where appropriate, the cancellation of the preventive annotation and order the Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets to return the assets or the money from their sale, plus the interest accrued to date.
This resolution may be appealed by means of an incidental appeal, without further appeal.

Article 256. (Incident on debts). The investigating judge, in the event of liens on the seized assets, legally registered prior to the seizure resolution, shall notify the creditors so that within five (5) days following notification, they may file an incident requesting authorization to proceed with the execution of the asset in the appropriate manner. Once the substantiation of the incident has concluded, the investigating judge shall rule on the admissibility or inadmissibility of the requested authorization, a resolution that may be appealed by means of an incidental appeal, without further appeal.
Once the enforcement process has been concluded, if there is a remainder, the competent judge or court will order its deposit in the name of the Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets.

Article 257. (Dependency and Powers of the Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets). The Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets, dependent on the Ministry of Government, shall have the following powers: 1) Direct or delegated administration to private companies contracted for this purpose of seized and confiscated assets until their monetization; 2) The registration and inventory of the seized assets, which will specify their nature and condition. conservation; 3) The creation and updating of the register of qualified management companies; 4) The signing of the corresponding administration contracts; 5) The supervision and monitoring of the management companies during the execution of the contract; and, 6) Those established in the corresponding regulations.

Article 259. (Form of administration). The Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Property, by means of a reasoned resolution, shall provide: 1) The execution of the administrative measures indicated in numerals 1) to 3) of article former. 2) The execution of the administration measures indicated in numerals 4) to 7) of the previous article, through the contracting of private companies selected in accordance with the provisions of section III of this chapter, unless it is decided to execute them directly for reasons of impossibility or economic inconvenience of this contract.

Article 260. (Administration and destination of confiscated and forfeited property). I. The judge or court, at the time of issuing a sentence, shall decide the destination of the seized property that was not returned due to the incident before the investigating judge.
II. The Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets shall comply with the destination of the assets determined in the judgment that acquires the status of res judicata and, as the case may be, shall order or direct the management company to: 1) The return of the seized assets and, where applicable, the money and interest from their sale, to the persons who prove ownership rights over them and will execute the cancellation of the preventive annotations; 2) The sale at public auction of seized or confiscated property that was not previously disposed of, a procedure that will begin within thirty days following the enforcement order.
3) The deposit in the name of the National Council for the Fight against Illicit Drug Trafficking, of the seized and confiscated money and the proceeds from the sale of confiscated and forfeited goods, in a bank of the national system.
4) Payment to creditors with real guarantees on the confiscated or forfeited property, registered prior to the seizure resolution and judicially recognized, with the amount from its sale.
III. The National Council for the Fight against Illicit Drug Trafficking will use the resources from the sale of confiscated and forfeited goods to: 1) Compliance with the purposes of prevention, interdiction, rehabilitation and penitentiary regime established in the Coca and Controlled Substances Regime Law; and, 2) Covering administration costs.

Article 261. (Vacant property). Seized property shall be considered vacant if it has not been confiscated or forfeited and its owners do not request its return within sixty (60) days following the moment in which the judgment acquired the status of res judicata.
After this period, the Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets will, as complainant, promote the voluntary procedure on vacant and stray assets, of the Code of Civil Procedure, with the aim of these assets becoming the property of the State.

Article 262. (Registry of Management Companies). The Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets, within sixty (60) days following the validity of this regime, will publicly call, establishing the required requirements, private companies that wish to join the registry of companies qualified for the administration of seized assets.
The Directorate for Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets, after having qualified and evaluated the background of the interested companies, will arrange for the registration of those that meet the required requirements, with the approval of the competent authority of the Ministry of Government. It may arrange for new calls to keep the registry up to date.

Article 263. ( Selection of the Management Company). The Directorate of Registration, Control and Administration of Seized Assets, after a competition of prices and guarantees for the execution of the contract, offered in a sealed envelope, in the event that there is an economically convenient offer, will select, through a reasoned resolution, from among the registered companies, the one that will be in charge of the administration of the seized assets, signing the corresponding administration contract for this purpose.

Article 264. (Content). The costs of the proceedings include: 1) Expenses incurred during the processing of the process such as the cost of the paper sealing, stamps and others that correspond to the judicial action; 2) The fees of lawyers, experts, technical consultants, translators and interpreters; and, 3) The remuneration of citizen judges, which will be imputed in favor of the State.
Article 265. (Imposition). Any decision that ends criminal prosecution or resolves any incident, even during the execution of the sentence, shall determine who must bear the costs of the process.

Article 266. (Costs to the accused and the State). Costs shall be imposed on the accused when convicted and on the State whenever the acquittal is based on the innocence of the accused or the case is dismissed because the act did not occur, does not constitute a crime or the accused did not participate in it, unless the proceedings have been opened exclusively on the basis of the accusation of the plaintiff.
Article 267. (False or reckless complaint). When the complainant has provoked the process by means of a false or reckless complaint, the judge or court shall impose upon him the payment of costs.

Article 268. (Incidents). The costs shall be imposed on the plaintiff when the decision is unfavorable to him; otherwise, they shall be covered by those who have opposed his claim, to the extent set by the judge.

Article 269. (Appeals). If the appeal is unsuccessful or is withdrawn, the costs shall be borne by the party who filed it. If the appeal is successful, the costs shall be covered by the party who opposed it or by the State, as the case may be.

Article 270. (Private action). Unless otherwise agreed by the parties, in the procedure for a private action offence, in the event of acquittal, dismissal, withdrawal or abandonment, the costs shall be borne by the plaintiff; in the event of conviction and retraction, by the accused.

Article 271. (Resolution). The judge or court shall decide, with reasons, on the imposition of costs.
When it is necessary to divide the costs between several parties, the percentage to be borne by each of those responsible shall be precisely established, in relation to the percentages of the expenses that each of them has caused.

Article 272. (Liquidation and execution). The judge or court shall order the preparation of the cost sheet within twenty-four (24) hours of the resolution becoming final.
Observations on the form will be processed incidentally. The decision of the judge or court will have executive force and will become effective in the same process, without further appeal, within three (3) days.
Article 273. (Free benefit). Anyone seeking the benefit of free benefit must request it from the judge or court of the process, who will apply the rules provided for in the Code of Civil Procedure.

Article 274. ( Review). When, due to a review of a sentence, due to a judicial error, the convicted person is acquitted or a lesser sentence is imposed, he or his heirs shall be compensated according to the time of deprivation of liberty or disqualification actually served and shall be compensated according to the time of deprivation of liberty or disqualification actually served. will proceed to return the fine unduly paid.
The provision shall also apply in the event that the review is intended for a security measure.

Article 275. (Determination). The unjustly convicted person may choose to claim compensation in the same proceedings or in another appropriate proceeding.
In the first case, the judge or court of the process will determine the compensation based on the following parameter: one (1) day of imprisonment, of compliance with a security measure that entails deprivation of liberty or of disqualification that entails suspension of professional practice, is equivalent to one day of salary or income received by the injured party.
In the event that it is not possible to establish this amount, the amount equivalent to one (1) day of the minimum living wage will be taken into account.

Article 276. (Compensation Fund). The Judicial Council shall administer a permanent fund to cover the payment of compensation to victims of judicial error in accordance with the provisions of this Code.
The resources of this Fund will consist of: 1) Ordinary funds allocated by the State; 2) Fines imposed and bonds executed; 3) Costs in favor of the State; 4) Compensation resulting from crimes affecting collective or diffuse interests; and, 5) Donations and legacies to the State made in favor of the Fund.
The administration of these resources will be regulated by the Judicial Council.

Article 277. ( Purpose). The purpose of the preparatory stage shall be to prepare for the oral and public trial by gathering all the elements that will support the accusation of the prosecutor or the plaintiff and the defense of the accused.
The Prosecutor's Office will be in charge of investigating all public crimes and will act with the assistance of the National Police and the Institute of Forensic Investigations.

Article 278. ( Public criminal prosecution and fiscal investigation). When the prosecutor becomes aware of the commission of a crime, he shall promote and direct his investigation.
When the law conditions criminal prosecution to a particular instance or any form of preliminary trial, the prosecutor will exercise it once the instance or authorization is produced by the means provided by law, without prejudice to carrying out essential acts to preserve evidence.
The prosecutor will refrain from charging when he finds no grounds for doing so.

Article 279. ( Jurisdictional control). The Public Prosecutor's Office and the National Police shall always act under jurisdictional control.
Prosecutors may not carry out jurisdictional acts nor judges carry out investigative acts that compromise their impartiality.

Article 280. ( Investigation documents). During the preparatory stage, a judicial file shall not be created.
The actions of the prosecutor and the documents obtained will be accumulated in an investigation notebook, following criteria of order and utility only.
The actions recorded in the notebook will not have probative value in themselves to establish the conviction of the accused, with the exception of the evidence that this Code authorizes to be introduced into the trial by reading it.
Judicial decisions will be recorded in the corresponding book.

Article 281. ( Confidentiality of proceedings). When it is essential for the effectiveness of the investigation, the judge, at the request of the prosecutor, may decree the confidentiality of the proceedings, even for the parties, for one time only and for a period not exceeding ten (10) days.
In the case of crimes linked to criminal organizations, this reservation may be authorized up to two (2) times for the same period.

Article 282. ( Undercover agent). In the investigation of crimes related to the illicit trafficking of controlled substances, in the event of absence or insufficiency of evidence, the prosecutor may request, under his/her own responsibility, from the investigating judge, authorization for the intervention, as undercover agents, of highly qualified members of the National Police, with no criminal or disciplinary record, who give their consent for this purpose.
The decision of the investigating judge authorizing the intervention of the undercover agent will record the alleged identity of the agent, which will be kept confidential and will be kept outside the proceedings with due security in a sealed envelope that will also contain the true identity of the agent.
The undercover agent will keep the prosecutor in charge of the investigation informed about the activities carried out and to be carried out during the course of the investigation and about the information obtained.
The testimony of the undercover agent will not be sufficient to establish a conviction if there is no additional evidence validly incorporated into the proceedings.
The undercover agent will not be exempt from the corresponding responsibility if, during the course of the investigation, he carries out acts other than those specifically assigned or with evident excess or disproportionality, in relation to the needs or purposes of the investigation.

Article 283. (Controlled delivery). Controlled delivery shall be understood as the technique consisting of allowing consignments of controlled substances to circulate within national territory or enter or leave it without interference from the competent authority and under its surveillance, in order to discover or identify the persons involved in the commission of the crime, provide evidence to the process and, where appropriate, provide assistance to foreign authorities for these same purposes.
In the investigation of crimes related to the illicit trafficking of controlled substances, in the event of the absence or insufficiency of evidence, the prosecutor may, under his or her responsibility, request from the investigating judge, on grounds for authorization for highly qualified members of the National Police, without criminal or disciplinary records, who give their consent to this effect, to participate in controlled deliveries, on which effective surveillance and monitoring can be carried out.
The decision of the investigating judge authorizing controlled delivery shall be kept confidential and kept outside the proceedings with due security, in a sealed envelope.
The police officers involved will keep the prosecutor in charge of the investigation informed about the activities carried out and to be carried out during the course of the investigation and about the information obtained.

Article 284. (Reporting). Any person who is aware of the commission of a crime of public action may report it to the Public Prosecutor's Office or the National Police.
In localities where there is no Prosecutor's Office or Police, it will be presented to the Sub Prefect or Mayor, who must inform the nearest prosecutor within twenty-four (24) hours.

Article 285. (Form and content). The complaint may be submitted in writing or verbally.
When it is verbal, it will be recorded in a document signed by the complainant and the intervening official.
In both cases, the official who receives the report will verify and record the identity and address of the complainant; at the request of the complainant, this information may be kept confidential, which may be lifted in order to enforce his liability for false or reckless reporting.
In all cases you will be given a copy of the original.
The complaint shall contain, as far as possible, a detailed account of the event, indicating the perpetrators and participants, victims, injured parties, witnesses and other elements that may lead to its verification and classification.

Article 286. (Obligation to report). The following shall be obliged to report crimes of public action: 1) Public officials and employees who become aware of the fact in the exercise of their duties; and, 2) Doctors, pharmacists, nurses and other persons who practice any branch of medical sciences, provided that they are aware of the fact in the exercise of their profession or trade.
The complaint will cease to be mandatory if it gives rise to criminal prosecution of the person, the spouse, partner or relative within the fourth degree of consanguinity or adoption, or second degree of affinity, or when the facts were known under professional secrecy.

Article 287. (Participation and responsibility). The complainant shall not be a party to the proceedings and shall not incur any liability, except when the accusations are false or the complaint was reckless.
When the complaint is classified as false or reckless, the complainant will be required to pay the costs, without prejudice to the corresponding liability.

Article 288. (Complaint to the police). When the complaint is filed with the police, the latter shall inform the prosecutor within twenty-four (24) hours and shall begin the preventive investigation in accordance with the provisions of Section III of this Chapter.

Article 289. (Complaint to the Prosecutor's Office). The prosecutor, upon receiving a complaint or reliable information about the commission of a crime, shall conduct the investigation in accordance with the provisions of this Code, requesting the assistance of the Police and the Forensic Research Institute. In all cases, he shall inform the investigating judge of the commencement of the investigation within twenty-four hours.

Article 290. (Complaint). The complaint shall be submitted in writing to the prosecutor and shall contain: 1) The name and surname of the complainant; 2) Your actual and procedural address; 3) In the case of legal entities, the company name, address and name of its representative legal; 4) The detailed account of the event, its known antecedents or consequences and, if possible, the indication of the alleged perpetrators or participants, victims, injured parties and witnesses; 5) The details of the data or evidence; and, 6) Documentary evidence or indication of the location where it is located.
The complainant will have full participation in the process by simply filing the complaint, which will be brought to the attention of the accused.

Article 291. (Objection). The prosecutor or the accused may object to the admissibility of the complaint and the legal status of the complainant. The objection shall be made before the judge within three (3) days from its notification.
The judge will summon the parties to an oral hearing that must take place within three (3) days of the objection being filed and will resolve it immediately after the hearing is over.
When it is based on the omission or defect of the formal admissibility requirements, the judge will order its correction within three (3) days, otherwise it will be considered not presented.
The rejection of the complaint will not prevent the investigation from continuing, when it involves public action crimes.

Article 292. (Withdrawal and abandonment). The complainant may withdraw or abandon his complaint at any time during the proceedings, with costs at his expense and subject to the final decision.
The complaint will be considered abandoned when the complainant: 1) Do not appear to give testimony without just cause; 2) Do not attend the final hearing; 3) Fail to accuse or offer evidence to support his accusation; or, 4) Fail to attend the trial or be absent from it without authorization from the court.
The complaint will also be considered abandoned when the representative or successor of the complainant does not appear to continue the process within sixty (60) days following his incapacity or death.
Abandonment will be declared by the judge or court ex officio or at the request of a party.
Withdrawal and abandonment will prevent any further prosecution by the plaintiff, by virtue of the same fact that constituted the object of his complaint and in relation to the defendants who participated in the process.

Article 293. ( Preliminary proceedings). Police officers and agents who have reliable knowledge of the commission of a public crime shall report, within eight (8) hours of their first intervention, to the Prosecutor's Office. Under the direction of the prosecutor in charge of the investigation, they shall carry out preliminary proceedings to gather or secure the elements of conviction and prevent the escape or concealment of suspects.
The accused and his/her defense attorney may participate in all proceedings carried out by the Police and will have access to all investigations carried out, except when they are confidential, as established in this Code.
