Article 294. ( Medical Care). Police officers shall protect the health and physical integrity of persons under their custody and, where applicable, of the victim.

Article 295. (Powers). Members of the National Police, when performing judicial police functions, within the framework of the provisions established in this Code, shall have the following powers: 1) Receive complaints by keeping minutes of verbal complaints, as well as statements from the whistleblowers; 2) Receive statements from those who witnessed the commission of the acts and identify them; 3) Carry out the procedures aimed at identifying the alleged perpetrators and participants of the crime. crime; 4) Collect data that can be used to identify the accused; 5) Arrest the alleged perpetrators and participants in the crime; 6) Practice recording people, objects and places; 7) Provide the assistance required by victims and protect witnesses; 8) Monitor and protect the scene of the crime so that the traces and traces of the crime are not erased. crime; 9) Draw up plans, take photographs and make video recordings; 10) Collect and preserve objects and instruments related to the crime; 11) Seize, with the authorization of the prosecutor, documents, accounting books, photographs and any material element that may be useful for the investigation; and, 12) Keep custody, under inventory, of the objects kidnapped.

Article 296. ( Apprehension). In cases where this Code authorizes the apprehension of defendants, members of the police must comply with the following basic principles of action: 1) Use force only when strictly necessary; 2) Do not use weapons, except when: a) There is resistance that endangers the life or physical integrity of persons; and, b) In the event of escape, less extreme measures to achieve the apprehension of the accused are insufficient, after prior warning about their use. 3) Not to inflict, instigate or tolerate any act of humiliation, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, whether at the time of apprehension or during the period of detention; 4) Not to allow detainees to be presented to any media without their express consent, which will be given in the presence of the defense attorney and will be recorded in the respective proceedings; 5) Identify yourself, through your credentials at the time of arrest, as a police authority, stating your first and last name and verify the identity of the person or persons against whom the proceedings are being carried out; 6) Inform the person, at the time of arrest, of the reason for it, that he has the right to remain silent without prejudice to the right to appoint a defense attorney; 7) Inform relatives or other persons related to the accused of the arrest and the establishment where he will be taken; and, 8) Record in an unalterable register the place, day and time of the arrest.
Failure to comply with the rules contained in this article will give rise to the corresponding administrative and criminal liability.

Article 297. (Functional Direction). The Prosecutor's Office exercises functional direction of police action in the investigation of crime. This direction has the following scope: 1) Compulsory compliance by police officers with all orders relating to the investigation of crimes issued by the Prosecutor's Office or judges. The police administrative authority may not revoke or modify the order issued or delay its compliance; 2) At the request of the prosecutor, the direct and obligatory assignment of police officers to investigate the criminal act. Once the officers have been assigned, the police administrative authority may not remove them from the investigation or assign them other functions that impede them from exercising their special commission, without the authorization of the prosecutor; 3) The removal of the assigned police officer from the investigation, with notification to the police authority, when he

Article 297. (Functional D irection). The Prosecutor's Office exercises functional direction of police action in the investigation of crime. This direction has the following scope: 1) Compulsory compliance by police officers with all orders relating to the investigation of crimes issued by the Prosecutor's Office or judges. The police administrative authority may not revoke or modify the order issued or delay its compliance;

Article 297. (Functional D irection). The Prosecutor's Office exercises functional direction of police action in the investigation of crime. This direction has the following scope: 2) At the request of the prosecutor, the direct and obligatory assignment of police officers to investigate the criminal act. Once the officers have been assigned, the police administrative authority may not remove them from the investigation or assign them other functions that impede them from exercising their special commission, without the authorization of the prosecutor;

Article 297. (Functional D irection). The Prosecutor's Office exercises functional direction of police action in the investigation of crime. This direction has the following scope: 3) The removal of the assigned police officer from the investigation, with notification to the police authority, when he or she does not comply with a judicial or fiscal order, acts negligently or is not efficient in the performance of his or her duties;

Article 297. (Functional D irection). The Prosecutor's Office exercises functional direction of police action in the investigation of crime. This direction has the following scope: 4) Where appropriate, the prosecutor may request the competent police authority, through the District Prosecutor's Office, to apply disciplinary sanctions to police officers removed from the investigation.

Article 298. (Report t o t he p rosecutor). The police communication to the prosecutor regarding the start of a preventive intervention or receipt of a complaint shall contain the following data: 1) Place, date and time of the incident and of the arrest;

Article 298. (Report t o t he p rosecutor). The police communication to the prosecutor regarding the start of a preventive intervention or receipt of a complaint shall contain the following data: 2) The identification of the complainant and his/her address;

Article 298. (Report t o t he p rosecutor). The police communication to the prosecutor regarding the start of a preventive intervention or receipt of a complaint shall contain the following data: 3) The name and address of the victim;

Article 298. (Report t o t he p rosecutor). The police communication to the prosecutor regarding the start of a preventive intervention or receipt of a complaint shall contain the following data: 4) The identification or description of the accused, his address and the name of the defense attorney if he has already appointed or proposed;

Article 298. (Report t o t he p rosecutor). The police communication to the prosecutor regarding the start of a preventive intervention or receipt of a complaint shall contain the following data: 5) The subject of the investigation or the complaint, the names of witnesses and any other information that may facilitate subsequent investigation;

Article 298. (Report t o t he p rosecutor). The police communication to the prosecutor regarding the start of a preventive intervention or receipt of a complaint shall contain the following data: 6) The order number in the police log book; and,

Article 298. (Report t o t he p rosecutor). The police communication to the prosecutor regarding the start of a preventive intervention or receipt of a complaint shall contain the following data: 7) The identification of the police officer in charge of the investigation and the department to which belongs.

Article 298. (Report t o t he p rosecutor). Once the report has been received, the prosecutor will give instructions to the investigators and will inform the investigating judge about the start of the investigation, within the next twenty-four (24) hours.
Article 299. ( Control). Once the prosecutor has arrived at the police station, he will control: 1) The physical condition of the accused and strict respect for all his rights;
Article 299. ( Control). Once the prosecutor has arrived at the police station, he will control: 2) Compliance with obligations related to the rights of the victim;
Article 299. ( Control). Once the prosecutor has arrived at the police station, he will control: 3) That the place, date and time of the arrest have been recorded; and,

Article 299. ( Control). Once the prosecutor has arrived at the police station, he will control: 4) The veracity of the inventory of seized or delivered goods, indicating the place of storage of the objects and their form of conservation.

Article 299. ( Control). Once the prosecutor has arrived at the police station, he will control: If any abnormality is detected, the corresponding report shall be drawn up for the purposes indicated in sections 3) and 4) of article 297 of this Code.

Article 300. (Term of the Preliminary Investigation). The preliminary investigations carried out by the Police must be concluded within a maximum period of twenty (20) days from the start of the investigation. (Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Amendments to the Criminal Law System)

Article 301. ( Study of police actions). Once the police actions have been received, the prosecutor will analyze their content to: 1. Formally charge the alleged crime, if the legal requirements are met.

Article 301. ( Study of police actions). Once the police actions have been received, the prosecutor will analyze their content to: 2. Order the completion of police proceedings, setting a reasonable period that will not exceed ninety (90) days, except in complex investigations, in which case communication of the extension to the investigating judge is mandatory.

Article 301. ( Study of police actions). Once the police actions have been received, the prosecutor will analyze their content to: 3. Order the rejection of the complaint, the claim or the police actions and, consequently, your file; and,

Article 301. ( Study of police actions). Once the police actions have been received, the prosecutor will analyze their content to: 4. Request the investigating judge to conditionally suspend the proceedings, apply a criterion of opportunity, conduct an abbreviated procedure or reach conciliation.

Article 301. ( Study of police actions). Once the police actions have been received, the prosecutor will analyze their content to: The period established in article 134 of this Code will begin to run from the last notification with the charge to the accused or accused. Article 302. ( Formal charge). If the prosecutor considers that there are sufficient indications regarding the existence of the act and the participation of the accused, he will formalize the charge by means of a reasoned resolution, which must contain: 1) The identification data of the accused and the victim, or their most precise identification;

Article 302. ( Formal charge). If the prosecutor considers that there are sufficient indications regarding the existence of the act and the participation of the accused, he will formalize the charge by means of a reasoned resolution, which must contain: 2) The name and procedural address of the defender;

Article 302. ( Formal charge). If the prosecutor considers that there are sufficient indications regarding the existence of the act and the participation of the accused, he will formalize the charge by means of a reasoned resolution, which must contain: 3) The description of the fact or facts that are imputed and their provisional qualification; and, 4) The request for precautionary measures if applicable.

Article 303. ( Detention at police headquarters). If the accused is detained and the prosecutor considers that he should continue to be deprived of liberty, he will formalize the charge by requesting the investigating judge to provide preventive detention within twenty-four (24) hours from the date he became aware of the arrest. If the prosecutor does not request it within this period, the investigating judge shall order, ex officio or at the request of a party, the immediate release of the detainee, unless the complainant has requested preventive detention and the judge considers it appropriate.

Article 304. ( Rejection). The prosecutor, by means of a reasoned resolution, may reject the complaint, the claim or the police actions, when: 1) It turns out that the fact did not exist, that it is not classified as a crime or that the accused has not participated in it;
Article 304. ( Rejection). The prosecutor, by means of a reasoned resolution, may reject the complaint, the claim or the police actions, when: 2) The accused could not be identified;

Article 304. ( Rejection). The prosecutor, by means of a reasoned resolution, may reject the complaint, the claim or the police actions, when: 3) The investigation has not provided sufficient elements to support the accusation; and, 4) There is any legal obstacle to the development of the process.

Article 304. ( Rejection). The prosecutor, by means of a reasoned resolution, may reject the complaint, the claim or the police actions, when: In the cases provided for in paragraphs 2), 3) and 4), the resolution may not be modified as long as the circumstances underlying it do not change or the obstacle preventing the development of the process remains.

Article 305. ( Procedure and effects). The parties may object to the rejection resolution, within five (5) days from its notification, before the prosecutor who issued it, who will forward the background information to the higher-ranking prosecutor within the following twenty-four (24) hours.

Article 305. ( Procedure and effects). The highest ranking prosecutor, within ten (10) days following receipt of the proceedings, will determine the revocation or ratification of the rejection. If he orders the revocation, he will order the continuation of the investigation and, in the event of ratification, the archiving of the proceedings. The filing of proceedings will not prevent the conversion of actions at the request of the victim or the complainant.

Article 306. (Proposal of proceedings). The parties may propose acts or proceedings at any time during the preparatory stage. The prosecutor may accept them if he considers them lawful, pertinent and useful. Any refusal must be justified. When the prosecutor rejects the proposal for proceedings that are considered essential, the parties may object to the rejection before the hierarchical superior, who will resolve what is appropriate within a maximum period of seventy-two (72) hours.

Article 307. (Advance of evidence). When it is necessary to carry out an examination, registration, reconstruction or expert opinion, which due to their nature or characteristics are considered to be definitive and irreproducible acts, or when a statement must be received which, due to some obstacle, is presumed not to be able to be produced during the trial, the prosecutor or any of the parties may request the judge to carry out these acts. The judge will carry out the act, if he considers it admissible, citing all parties, who will have the right to participate with the powers and obligations provided for in this Code. If the judge rejects the request, the matter may be addressed directly to the appeal court, which must decide within twenty-four (24) hours of receiving the request, ordering the performance of the act, if it considers it admissible, without further appeal.
Article 308. (Exceptions). The parties may oppose the criminal action by means of the following exceptions of prior and special pronouncement: 1) Prejudiciality;
Article 308. (Exceptions). The parties may oppose the criminal action by means of the following exceptions of prior and special pronouncement: 2) Incompetence;

Article 308. (Exceptions). The parties may oppose the criminal action by means of the following exceptions of prior and special pronouncement: 3) Lack of action, because it was not legally promoted or because there is a legal impediment to continue it;

Article 308. (Exceptions). The parties may oppose the criminal action by means of the following exceptions of prior and special pronouncement: 4) Extinction of the criminal action as established in articles 27 and 28 of this Code; 5) Res judicata; and, 6) Lis pendens.

Article 308. (Exceptions). The parties may oppose the criminal action by means of the following exceptions of prior and special pronouncement: If two or more exceptions occur, they must be raised jointly.

Article 309. (Prejudiciality). This exception will only apply when, through the substantiation of an extra-criminal procedure, the existence of the constituent elements of the criminal type can be determined. If the admissibility of the decision is accepted, the criminal proceedings will be suspended and, where appropriate, the accused will be released until the sentence becomes final in the extra-criminal proceedings, without prejudice to the performance of essential acts for the preservation of evidence. Otherwise, the criminal proceedings will continue their course. A final judgment in extra-criminal jurisdiction will produce the effect of res judicata in the criminal process, and the judge or court must resume hearing the case and decide on the termination of the criminal action or the continuation of the process.

Article 310. (Incompetence). This exception may be raised before the judge or court that is considered competent, or before the judge or court that is considered incompetent and that is hearing the case. In the latter case, it must be resolved before any other exception. The civil procedural provisions relating to the inhibitory and declinatory exceptions shall apply.

Article 311. (Conflict of jurisdiction). If two (2) or more judges or courts declare themselves simultaneously and contradictorily competent or incompetent, the conflict will be resolved by the Superior Court of the judicial district of the judge or court that has prevented it. The conflict of jurisdiction between Superior Courts of Justice will be resolved by the Supreme Court of Justice. Once the proceedings have been received, the court competent to resolve the conflict will resolve it within the following three (3) days. If the production of evidence is required, an oral hearing will be convened within five (5) days and the court will resolve the conflict at the same time. The resolution that resolves the conflict of jurisdiction does not admit further appeal.

Article 312. (Lack of action). When the exception of lack of action is declared proven, the proceedings shall be archived until it is legally promoted or the legal impediment disappears. If the criminal proceedings depend on any form of preliminary hearing, the prosecutor will request the investigating judge to request its processing before the corresponding authority, without prejudice to the performance of essential acts of investigation and preservation of evidence. This provision shall also apply when the consent of a foreign government is required and the procedure shall be initiated through diplomatic channels. The decision will only exclude from the process the accused who benefits from it.

Article 313. (Other exceptions). When the exception of lis pendens is declared proven, the proceedings shall be sent to the judge who had jurisdiction to hear the case. In other cases, the criminal action will be declared extinguished and the case will be closed.

Article 314. (Procedure). Exceptions and requests or arguments of the parties that, due to their nature or importance, must be debated or require the production of evidence, shall be processed through incidental proceedings, without interrupting the investigation, and shall be proposed in writing with reasons in the preparatory stage and orally in the trial, offering evidence and accompanying the corresponding documentation. Once the exception or incident has been raised, the judge or court will forward it to the other parties so that, within three (3) days following notification, they may respond and offer evidence.

Article 315. (Resolution). If the exception or incident is purely legal, or if the production of evidence has not been offered or ordered, the judge or court, without further proceedings, shall issue a reasoned resolution within three (3) days after the expiration of the term provided for in the previous article. If the production of evidence has been arranged, an oral hearing will be called within five (5) days for its reception and, in it, the exception or incident will be resolved in a reasoned manner. The rejection of exceptions and incidents will prevent them from being raised again for the same reasons.

Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 1) Having intervened in the same process as a judge, prosecutor, lawyer, agent, complainant, plaintiff, expert or witness;
Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 2) Having expressed his or her opinion on the process out of court, as documented;

Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 3) Being a spouse or cohabitant, relative within the fourth degree of consanguinity or second degree of affinity or adoption, of any interested party or of the parties;

Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 4) Be a guardian or curator or have been under the guardianship or curatorship of any of the interested parties or of the parts;
Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 5) Have an interest in the process, or their relatives in the indicated degrees;

Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 6) Have pending proceedings, or their relatives in the aforementioned degrees with any of the interested parties or parties, initiated prior to the criminal proceedings;

Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 7) Be a partner, or his/her relatives, in the degrees indicated above of any of the interested parties or of the parties, except in the case of public limited companies;

Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 8) Be a creditor, debtor or guarantor, or their parents or children or another person who lives under their care, of any of the interested parties or of the parties, except in the case of banking and financial entities; Be ascendant or descendant of the judge or any member of the court who issued the sentence or ruling appealed against;

Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 9) Having acted as a complainant or accuser of any of the interested parties or parties, or having been denounced or accused by them, before the start of the proceedings;

Article 316. (Grounds for excuse and recusal). The following are grounds for excuse and recusal of judges: 10) He, his spouse or partner, parents or children or other persons living under his care, have received benefits; and, 11) Having a close friendship, which is expressed through frequent dealings, or manifest enmity with any of the interested parties or the parties. In no case will separation be allowed for attacks or offenses inflicted on the judge after he has begun to hear the proceedings.

Article 317. (Interested parties). For the purposes of the previous article, interested parties shall be considered to be the victim and the person civilly liable, when they have not been constituted as a party, as well as their representatives, attorneys and agents.

Article 318. (Processing and resolution of the excuse). The judge included in any of the causes established in article 316 of this Code, is obliged to excuse himself, by means of a reasoned resolution, immediately withdrawing from the hearing of the process. The judge who recuses himself shall refer the case to the judge who is to replace him, who shall immediately take cognizance of the proceedings and continue their course, without prejudice to raising the background of the excuse for consultation before the higher court, if he deems that it is unfounded. If the higher court accepts or rejects the excuse, as the case may be, it shall order the replacing judge or the replaced judge to continue with the proceedings, without further appeal, and all the actions of both judges shall remain valid. When the judge who excuses himself is a member of a tribunal, he shall ask the tribunal to remove him from the proceedings. The tribunal shall decide whether to accept or reject the excuse, with the effects established in the previous paragraph. When the number of excuses prevents the existence of a quorum or the excuse of one of its members is accepted, the court will be completed in accordance with the provisions of the organic provisions.
Article 319. (Opportunity of recusal). A recusal may be filed: 1) In the preparatory stage, within ten days of the judge having assumed knowledge of the cause;

Article 319. (Opportunity of recusal). A recusal may be filed: 2) At the trial stage, within the period established for the preparatory acts of the hearing; and, 3) In the appeals, within the deadline to express or respond to grievances. When the challenge is based on a supervening cause, it may be raised before the sentence or resolution of the appeal is issued.

Article 320. (Processing and resolution of recusal). The recusal shall be presented before the judge or court hearing the proceedings, by means of a reasoned written statement, offering evidence and accompanying the corresponding documentation. If the recused judge admits the challenge, the procedure established for the excuse will be followed. In case of rejection, the following procedure will apply: 1) In the case of a sole judge, he/she shall forward the background information to the higher court within twenty-four (24) hours of the challenge being filed, attaching the written submission together with his/her reasoned rejection decision. The higher court, after a hearing in which the evidence and report of the parties will be received, shall decide within the following forty-eight (48) hours on the acceptance or rejection of the challenge, without further appeal. If it accepts the challenge, it shall replace the challenged judge in accordance with the provisions of the organic provisions; if it rejects it, it shall order the judge to continue with the proceedings, who may no longer be challenged for the same reasons; 2) When it is a judge who is part of a court, the rejection will be formulated before the same court, which will resolve within the period and in the manner established in the previous section. When the number of challenges prevents the existence of a quorum or the challenge of one of its members is accepted, the court will be completed in accordance with the provisions of the organic provisions.

Article 321. (Effects of excuse and recusal). Once an excuse has been made or a recusal has been filed, the judge may not perform any act in the proceedings, under penalty of nullity. Once the excuse or recusal has been accepted, the judge's dismissal will be definitive even if the causes that determined it subsequently disappear. Excuses and recusals must be rejected in limine when: 1. It is not a supervening cause; 2. It is manifestly inappropriate; 3. It is presented without proof in cases where it is necessary; or 4. Having been rejected, it is reiterated in the same terms. (Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 322. (Removal of secretaries). Secretaries must excuse themselves and may be challenged for the same reasons established for judges. The judge or court on which the case depends will summarily process the cause invoked and will resolve within forty-eight (48) hours what is appropriate, without further appeal.

Article 323. (Conclusive acts). When the prosecutor concludes the investigation: 1) He will present the accusation to the investigating judge if he considers that the investigation provides basis for public prosecution of the accused;

Article 323. (Conclusive acts). When the prosecutor concludes the investigation: 2) Request from the investigating judge the conditional suspension of the proceedings, the application of the abbreviated procedure or a criterion of opportunity or the promotion of conciliation;

Article 323. (Conclusive acts). When the prosecutor concludes the investigation: 3) The court shall issue a reasoned order to dismiss the case when it is evident that the act did not occur, that it does not constitute a crime or that the accused did not participate in it, and when it considers that the evidence is insufficient to support the accusation. In the cases provided for in paragraphs 1) and 2), the proceedings and evidence shall be forwarded to the judge or court. (Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 324. (Challenge of Dismissal). The prosecutor shall inform the parties of the decreed dismissal, which may be challenged within five (5) days following its notification. Once the challenge has been received, or ex officio in the case where there is no complainant, the prosecutor will forward the background information within the following twenty-four (24) hours to the higher-ranking prosecutor, so that he may make a decision within a period of five (5) days. If the higher-ranking prosecutor revokes the dismissal, he will order the lower prosecutor or any other prosecutor to report to the sentencing judge or court within a maximum period of ten (10) days. If he ratifies it, he will order the conclusion of the process in relation to the accused in whose favor the dismissal was issued, the cessation of the precautionary measures and the cancellation of his criminal record. An uncontested or ratified dismissal will prevent a new criminal proceeding for the same act, without prejudice to the victim's claim for compensation for damages in civil proceedings, unless the dismissal is based on the non-existence of the act or the non-participation of the accused.

Article 325. (Conclusive hearing). Once the conclusive request has been submitted in the case of numerals 1) and 2) of article 323 of this Code, the judge, within the following twenty-four (24) hours, will summon the parties to an oral and public hearing that must be held within a period of not less than six (6) nor more than twenty (20) days, computed from the notification with the call. Once the summons has been notified, the parties will have a common period of five (5) days to examine the conclusive request, the proceedings and evidence gathered in the investigation and to offer the necessary means of proof. At the hearing, the parties may: a) Observe the public or private accusation for formal defects, requesting their correction; b) To deduce exceptions and incidents, when they have not been raised previously or are based on new facts; c) Request the resolution of pending exceptions and incidents; d) Raise incidents of exclusion of evidence or observations on the admissibility of evidence, for which the parties must present the documentary and material evidence offered in the accusation. e) Propose facts that are not in dispute and that the judge will consider proven, ignoring the need for evidence in the trial. They may also propose agreements regarding the means of proof that will be necessary for certain facts to be considered proven. The investigating judge, however, may disassociate himself from these agreements by stating the reasons that justify it. The hearing will be conducted by the investigating judge and no written submissions will be allowed during the hearing. Once the hearing has been held, the investigating judge will give the floor for a short time and in that order to the prosecutor, the private prosecutor and the defence, who will debate the admissibility of the questions raised and the relevance of the evidence offered. The prosecutor may clarify or correct the accusation at the same hearing. If the correction requires further analysis by the Public Prosecutor, the judge will order the return of the accusation and suspend the hearing for five (5) days for its new request. If there are no further observations, the accusation will be considered corrected. (Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)
Article 326. (Powers of the parties). At the final hearing, the parties may: 1) In the case of the victim or the complainant, state with reason their willingness to accuse;

Article 326. (Powers of the parties). At the final hearing, the parties may: 2) To raise the exceptions provided for in this Code, when they have not been raised previously or are based on new facts; 3) Propose the application of a criterion of opportunity; the accused may only do so when he alleges that it has been applied to cases similar to his own, provided that he proves this circumstance;

Article 326. (Powers of the parties). At the final hearing, the parties may: 4) Request the application of the conditional suspension of the process; 5) Request the application or revocation of a precautionary measure; 6) Request the jurisdictional advance of evidence; 7) Propose the application of the abbreviated procedure in accordance with the provisions of articles 373 and following of this Code; and, 8) Promote conciliation by proposing comprehensive reparation for damages.

Article 327. (Development). On the day of the hearing, the production of evidence shall be arranged, allowing the necessary time for each party to justify its claims. Where appropriate, the judge will promote the conciliation of the parties by proposing full reparation for the damage. Minutes of the final hearing will be drawn up.

Article 328. (Resolution). At the hearing, the judge, by means of a reasoned resolution: 1) Conditionally suspend the process or apply opportunity criteria; 2) Ratify, revoke, replace or impose precautionary measures; 3) Order the receipt of evidence in advance; 4) Sentence will be handed down according to the summary procedure; 5) Approve the agreements of the parties regarding civil compensation and order everything necessary for its execution; and, 6) Resolve any exceptions raised; The resolution will be notified at the hearing by reading it.

Article 329. ( Purpose). The trial is the essential phase of the process. It will be conducted on the basis of the accusation; in an adversarial, oral, public and continuous manner, to verify the crime and the responsibility of the accused, with full jurisdiction.

Article 330. ( Immediacy). The trial will be held with the uninterrupted presence of the judges and all parties. If the defense attorney does not appear at the hearing or withdraws from it, the defense will be considered abandoned and his or her replacement will be required. If the prosecutor does not attend the hearing or withdraws from it without justification, the hearing will be suspended and the hierarchical superior of the Prosecutor's Office will be immediately informed so that another prosecutor can be assigned to the trial, without prejudice to the corresponding sanction. If the complainant does not attend the hearing or withdraws from it without authorization, his complaint will be deemed abandoned, without prejudice to the fact that he may be required to appear as a witness.

Article 331. ( Participation of the media). The judge or court shall authorize the installation of recording, photography, radio, filming or other equipment in the room, so that these means of information do not harm the development of the debate, provided that it is not a trial of minors.

Article 332. ( Prohibitions on access). The following may not enter the courtroom: 1) Minors under twelve (12) years of age, except when accompanied by an adult who is responsible for their conduct; and, 2) Persons carrying banners, union, party or association insignia, or members of the Armed Forces or the National Police who are in uniform, unless they are performing surveillance functions.

Article 333. ( Orality). The trial will be oral and the following may only be incorporated by reading: 1) Evidence that has been received in accordance with the rules on the advance of evidence, without prejudice to the parties or the court requiring the personal appearance of the witness or expert, when possible;

Article 333. ( Orality). The trial will be oral and the following may only be incorporated by reading: 2) Statements or opinions produced by a commission or report, when the act has been produced in writing, in accordance with the provisions of law, without prejudice to the parties or the court requiring the appearance of the witness or expert when possible; 3) The complaint, documentary evidence, reports and records of recognition, registration or inspection carried out in accordance with the provisions of this Code. Any other evidence that is introduced into the trial by reading it will have no value. The court's decisions during the hearing will be issued verbally, and all decisions will be notified by its pronouncement, and this will be recorded in the minutes.

Article 334. ( Continuity). Once the trial has begun, it will be held without interruption every working day until a sentence is handed down and may only be suspended in the cases provided for in this Code. The hearing will be held without interruption during all working hours of the day. The judge or the president of the court will order the daily recesses, setting the time at which the hearing will resume.

Article 335. ( Cases of suspension). The trial hearing shall be suspended only when: 1) Witnesses, experts or interpreters whose intervention is indispensable do not appear; or when the need to produce extraordinary evidence arises; 2) Any judge or other procedural subject has a duly proven physical impediment that prevents them from continuing their role in the trial, except in the case of the prosecutor or the defense attorney and they may be replaced immediately; 3) The prosecutor or the complainant, due to the discovery of new facts, requires that the accusation be expanded, or the accused or his defense attorney requests it after it has been expanded, provided that, due to the characteristics of the case, it cannot be continued immediately.

Article 336. ( Resumption of the hearing). The judge or court shall order the suspension of the hearing for a period of no more than ten (10) calendar days, setting the day and time of the new hearing, with the value of a summons for all those appearing. If the cause for suspension remains on the day the hearing resumes: 1) The separation of the trial in relation to the impeded party may be ordered and the proceedings may continue with the other co-defendants; and, 2) The trial will continue until its conclusion with the evidence provided. In the event of the absence of a member of the court, the interruption of the trial will only be ordered when it does not have at least three (3) of its members and provided that the number of citizen judges is not less than that of technical judges. Judges and prosecutors may intervene in other trials during the suspension period provided that the complexity of the new case allows it.

Article 337. ( Inability to attend). Persons who are unable to attend the hearing due to an insurmountable impediment shall be questioned at the place where they are, by the trial judge or by commission to another judge, with the intervention of the parties, when they so request. Minutes shall be kept of the statement to be read at the hearing.

Article 338. ( Direction of the hearing). The judge or the president of the court shall direct the hearing and order the acts necessary for its development, guaranteeing the full exercise of the prosecution and the defense. The full court will decide when a decision of the president is challenged.

Article 339. ( Ordering and disciplinary power). The judge or the president of the court in exercising his ordering and disciplinary power may: 1) Adopt the measures necessary to maintain order and proper development of the hearing, imposing, where appropriate, disciplinary measures on the parties, lawyers, defenders, officials, witnesses, experts and persons not involved in the process; and, 2) Request the assistance of the public force to enforce its decisions and suspend the debate when it is not possible to restore the disturbed order or an incident occurs that prevents its continuation.

Article 340. ( Preparation of trial). The judge or the president of the court, within forty-eight (48) hours of receiving the accusation and the evidence offered by the prosecutor, will file the case and notify the plaintiff to present the private accusation and offer the evidence within the term of ten (10) days. After this period has expired, the accused will be informed of the accusation of the prosecutor and, where applicable, that of the complainant and the evidence offered, so that within ten (10) days following notification, he may offer his evidence in his defense. After this period, the court will issue an order to open the trial.
Article 341. ( Content of the accusation). The accusation shall contain: 1) Data used to identify the accused and his procedural address; 2) The precise and detailed account of the crime attributed;

Article 341. ( Content of the accusation). The accusation shall contain: 3) The basis of the accusation, with the expression of the elements of conviction that it supports; 4) The applicable legal provisions; and, 5) The offering of evidence that will be produced in the trial. The complainant shall have the autonomy to specify the facts of the private accusation, its legal qualification and to offer evidence, although he may adhere to that presented by the prosecutor, without this being considered abandonment of the complaint.

Article 342. (Basis of the trial). The trial may be opened on the basis of the accusation of the prosecutor or that of the plaintiff, without distinction. When the prosecution's accusation and the private accusation are contradictory and irreconcilable, the court will specify the facts on which the trial is opened. In no case may the judge or court include facts not included in any of the accusations, produce evidence ex officio, or open the trial if there is not at least one accusation. The order opening the trial may not be appealed. The accusation may be withdrawn at any time during the trial, even before the court's deliberation.

Article 343. (Scheduling of the hearing). The judge or court in the order to open the trial will indicate the day and time of its celebration, which will take place within the following twenty (20) to forty-five (45) days. The secretary shall immediately notify the parties, summon witnesses, experts and citizen judges when appropriate; request objects and documents and arrange any other measures necessary for the organization and development of the public trial.

Article 344. (Opening). On the appointed day and time, the judge or members of the court shall appear in the courtroom. Once the presence of the parties, witnesses, experts or interpreters has been verified, the citizen judges shall be sworn in and the hearing shall be declared open. The reading of the accusation and the opening order shall be ordered immediately and the prosecutor and the complainant shall be required to justify it.

Article 344 Bis. (Oral Trial Procedure in Absentia for Corruption Crimes). In the event that the defendant's failure to appear for corruption crimes is verified, he shall be declared in rebellion and a new date shall be set for the oral trial hearing to be held in his absence, with the participation of his public defender. In this case, the rebel shall be notified of this resolution by means of edicts. (Incorporated by article 36 of Law No. 004 of March 31, 2010, on the Fight Against Corruption, Illicit Enrichment and Investigation of Fortunes “Marcelo Quiroga Santa Cruz”)

Article 345. (Processing of incidental matters). All incidental matters shall be dealt with in a single act, unless the court decides to do so in a judgment. In the discussion of incidental issues, the parties will be given the floor only once, for the time established by the judge or the president of the court.

Article 346. (Statement of the accused and presentation of the defense). Once the arguments of the prosecutor and the plaintiff have been presented and, where appropriate, the incidents have been resolved, the accused shall be heard. Beforehand, the charge against him shall be explained to him in clear and simple terms, with the warning that he may abstain from testifying and that the trial will continue its course, even if he does not testify. The accused may state what he deems appropriate in his statement. Only in this case will he be questioned by the prosecutor, the plaintiff's lawyer, the defence counsel and the members of the court, in that order. Once the statement is finished, the judge or the president of the court will order the defender to present his defense, and then the evidence will be received in accordance with the provisions of this Code.

Article 347. (Power of the accused). During the course of the hearing, the accused may make any statements he considers appropriate, provided that they relate to his defense. He may speak with his defense attorney at any time except when he is testifying.

Article 348. (Extension of the accusation). During the trial, the prosecutor or the plaintiff may extend the accusation by adding new facts or circumstances that have not been mentioned in the accusation and that modify the typical adequacy or the sentence. Once the judge or court has admitted the extension of the accusation, a new statement will be taken from the accused and the parties will be informed of their right to request the suspension of the trial in order to offer new evidence or prepare their intervention, in accordance with the provisions of article 335 of this Code.

Article 349. (Expertise). Whenever possible, the judge or court shall order that expert operations be carried out in a hearing. The judge or court will order the reading of the conclusions of the reports of all the expert opinions carried out in the process.

Article 350. (Testimonial evidence). Testimonial evidence shall be received in the following order: that offered by the prosecutor, the complainant, and finally the accused. Before testifying, witnesses must not communicate with each other or with other people, nor must they see, hear or be informed of what is happening at the hearing. Failure to comply with the incommunicado detention will not prevent the witness from testifying, but the judge or court will take this circumstance into account when assessing the evidence. Witnesses shall explain the reason and origin of the content of their statements and, where appropriate, identify as precisely as possible the persons who informed them.

Article 351. (Interrogation). After the judge or the president of the court questions the expert or witness about his personal identity and the general circumstances in order to assess his statement, direct examination shall begin, beginning with the person who proposed it, continuing with the other parties, and then they may be questioned by the judge or the president and the other members of the court. Deponents will directly answer the questions asked of them. Only experts will have the power to consult documents, written notes, publications and to use technical means during their testimony. Witnesses may not be questioned by technical consultants. Once the statement has been made, the judge or the president of the court may order the declarant to attend the hearing, remain in the anteroom or leave.

Article 352. (Moderation of questioning). The judge or the president of the court shall moderate the questioning, ensuring that it is conducted without undue pressure and without offending the dignity of the declarant. The parties may request the revocation of the decisions of the judge or the president of the court that limit the questioning or object to the formulation of leading, suggestive or impertinent questions.

Article 353. (Testimony of minors). Witnesses under sixteen years of age shall be questioned by the judge or president of the court based on questions submitted by the parties in writing. During the questioning, the judge or the president of the court shall be assisted by a relative of the minor or a psychology expert, following the rules provided for in Article 203 of this Code.

Article 354. (Contradictions). If witnesses contradict their previous statements, the judge or the president of the court may order them to be read provided that the rules provided for in this Code have been observed in their reception. If the contradictions persist and false testimony results, the provisions of Article 201 of this Code shall apply.

Article 355. (Other evidence). Literal evidence shall be read and exhibited at the hearing, with an indication of its origin. The judge or the president of the court, based on the agreement of the parties, may order partial reading of the evidence. The seized objects and other evidence will be exhibited for examination by witnesses, experts or the accused. Recordings and audiovisual evidence will be reproduced in the usual manner. Confrontations, reconstructions, judicial inspections and the identification of the accused may be carried out.

Article 356. (Final discussion and closure of the debate). Once the evidence has been received, the prosecutor, the complainant and the defendant's defense attorney, in that order, will formulate their conclusions orally. They may use technical means and notes to support their presentation, and the reading of written briefs and documents will not be permitted. If two or more prosecutors, plaintiffs or defenders intervened, all may speak, avoiding repetitions or delays. The parties may reply, but the defence shall have the final say. The reply shall be limited to refuting the opposing arguments that have not been previously discussed. In the event of manifest abuse of the word, the judge or the president of the court will call the speaker's attention and, if he persists, may limit the time of the argument taking into account the nature of the facts under examination, the evidence received and the issues to be resolved. If the victim is present and wishes to speak, he or she will be given the floor, even if he or she has not participated in the proceedings. Finally, the president will ask the accused if he has anything else to say. Immediately afterward he will declare the debate closed.
Article 357. (Sentencing Judge). Once the debate has concluded and during the same hearing, the judge shall issue a sentence. All provisions of this Chapter shall apply as appropriate.

Article 358. (Deliberation). Once the debate has concluded, the members of the court shall immediately and without interruption proceed to deliberate in a secret session, which may only be attended by the secretary. The deliberation may not be suspended unless one of the judges is seriously ill. In this case, the suspension may not last more than three days, after which the judge must be replaced and the trial held again, unless the remaining judges form a majority.

Article 359. (Rules for deliberation and voting). The court shall evaluate the evidence produced during the trial in a comprehensive manner in accordance with the rules of sound criticism and shall set forth the reasons on which its decision is based. The judges shall deliberate and vote on all issues in the following order: 1) Those relating to any incidental matter that has been deferred until this time; 2) Those relating to the commission of the punishable act and the acquittal or conviction of the accused; and, 3) The imposition of the applicable penalty. Decisions shall be taken by majority vote. The judges shall give their reasons separately or jointly when they agree. Any disagreements must be expressly justified in writing. In the event of a tie, the decision that most favors the accused will be adopted.

Article 360. (Requirements for judgment). The judgment shall be pronounced in the name of the Republic and shall contain: 1) The mention of the court, place and date on which it is issued, the name of the judges, the parties and the personal data of the accused; 2) The statement of the facts and circumstances that were the subject of the trial;

Article 360. (Requirements for judgment). The judgment shall be pronounced in the name of the Republic and shall contain: 3) The vote of the members of the court on each of the issues raised in the deliberation, with an exposition of the factual and legal reasons on which they are based; 4) The operative part, with mention of the applicable rules; and, 5) The signature of the judges. If one of the members cannot sign the judgment due to a subsequent impediment to deliberation and voting, this will be noted and the judgment will be valid without that signature.

Article 361. (Drafting and reading). The judgment shall be drafted and signed immediately after deliberation. Without interruption, the court shall reconvene in the courtroom for the reading of the judgment by the president of the court. Due to the complexity of the process or the lateness of the hour, the drafting of the grounds of the judgment may be deferred and only the operative part will be read, setting a day and time for the hearing for its full reading, which will take place within a maximum period of three (3) days after the pronouncement of the operative part. The judgment will be notified in its entirety and the parties will receive a copy of it.
Article 362. (Consistency). The accused may not be convicted for a fact other than that attributed in the accusation or its extension.

Article 363. (Acquittal judgment). An acquittal judgment shall be issued when: 1) The charge has not been proven or has been withdrawn from the trial; 2) The evidence provided is not sufficient to generate in the judge or court the conviction regarding the criminal liability of the accused; 3) It is proven that the act did not occur, does not constitute a crime or that the accused did not participate in it; either, 4) There is any cause exempting from criminal liability.

Article 364. (Effects of acquittal). The acquittal judgment shall order the immediate release of the accused, the cessation of all personal precautionary measures, and shall set the costs and, where appropriate, shall declare the accusation to be reckless or malicious for the purposes of the corresponding liability. The release of the accused will be ordered even when the acquittal judgment is not final and will be carried out directly from the courtroom. The judge or court, at the request of the acquitted person, shall order the publication of the operative part of the acquittal judgment in a written medium of national circulation at the expense of the state or the private plaintiff.

Article 365. (Conviction). A conviction shall be issued when the evidence provided is sufficient to convince the judge or court of the criminal liability of the accused. The sentence will precisely determine the corresponding sanctions, the manner and place of their fulfillment and, where appropriate, will determine the judicial pardon, the conditional suspension of the sentence and the obligations that the convicted person must fulfill. The date on which the sentence ends will be precisely set. The time spent in custody for that crime, even at a police station, will be counted as part of the sentence applied. The manner and time limit for paying the fine will be established, and the sentences or penalties will be unified. The judgment will also decide on costs and on the delivery of seized objects to the person the court deems to have the best right to possess them. It will decide on the confiscation, confiscation and destruction provided for by law. A conviction or a judgment imposing an enforceable security measure will enable the special procedure for claiming the corresponding damages.

Article 366. (Conditional Suspension of Sentence). The judge or court, after having made the necessary reports and taking into account the motives or causes that led to the crime, the nature and modality of the act, may conditionally suspend the execution of the sentence when the following requirements are met: 1) That the person has been sentenced to a prison sentence not exceeding three (3) years of duration; 2) That the convicted person has not been the subject of a previous conviction for a willful crime, in the last five (5) years. Conditional suspension of sentence is not applicable in corruption crimes. (Modified by article 37 of Law No. 004 of March 31, 2010, on the Fight Against Corruption, Illicit Enrichment and Investigation of Fortunes «Marcelo Quiroga Santa Cruz»)

Article 367. ( Effects). Once the sentence imposing a conditional sentence becomes final, the beneficiary must comply with the obligations imposed in accordance with Article 24 of this Code. Once the probationary period has expired, the sentence will be extinguished. If during the probationary period the beneficiary violates, without just cause, the rules of conduct imposed, the suspension will be revoked and he or she must serve the imposed sentence. The suspension of the sentence will not release the convicted person from the fines or disqualifications imposed on him in the sentence.

Article 368. ( Judicial Pardon). The judge or court, when issuing a conviction sentence, shall grant judicial pardon to the perpetrator or participant who, for a first offense, has been sentenced to a prison term of no more than two (2) years. Judicial pardon will not be applicable, under any circumstances, for corruption crimes. (Modified by article 37 of Law No. 004 of March 31, 2010, on the Fight Against Corruption, Illicit Enrichment and Investigation of Fortunes «Marcelo Quiroga Santa Cruz»)
Article 369. ( Civil Liability). The conditional suspension of the sentence and judicial pardon do not include civil liability, which must always be satisfied.

Article 370. ( Defects in the judgment). The defects in the judgment that enable a restricted appeal shall be the following: 1) Non-observance or erroneous application of substantive law; 2) That the accused is not sufficiently identified; 3) That the statement of the fact that is the subject of the trial or its detailed determination is missing; 4) That is based on means or evidence not legally incorporated into the trial or incorporated by reading them in violation of the rules of this Title; 5) That there is no justification for the judgment or that it is insufficient or contradictory; 6) That the judgment is based on non-existent or unproven facts or on a faulty assessment of the test; 7) That the conviction in the ordinary process is based on the admission of guilt made in the abbreviated procedure that was denied; 8) That there is a contradiction in its operative part or between it and the consideration part; 9) The date is not recorded and cannot be determined, or the signature of one of the judges is missing and it cannot be determined whether he or she participated in the deliberation, except in exceptional cases provided for by law; 10) Non-compliance with the rules provided for the deliberation and drafting of the judgment; and, 11) Failure to observe the rules relating to consistency between the sentence and the accusation.

Article 371. (Forms of registration). The trial may be recorded by means of a written record or by audiovisual means. When the trial is recorded in minutes, it shall contain: 1) Place and date of its performance, indicating the start and end time, as well as of suspensions and resumptions; 2) Name of the judges, parties, defenders and representatives;

Article 371. (Forms of registration). The trial may be recorded by means of a written record or by audiovisual means. When the trial is recorded in minutes, it shall contain: 3) Summary of the development of the hearing, indicating the names of the witnesses, experts and interpreters, the reference of the documents read and of the other evidence reproduced with mention of the conclusion of the parties; 4) Requests and decisions made during the trial, the objections of the parties, their protests to appeal and the mentions that expressively request their registration; 5) Compliance with essential formalities, leaving a record of the publicity or if it is was excluded, in whole or in part; 6) Other actions that the judge or court orders to be recorded; 7) The record of the reading of the judgment and the minutes with the formalities provided for; and, 8) The signature of the judge or members of the court and the secretary. When the trial is recorded by audiovisual means, the judge or president of the court shall order the appropriate measures to ensure its preservation, fidelity and authenticity, which must be recorded in minutes that will be signed by the judge or members of the court, the secretary and the parties. The judge or the president of the court may allow the parties, at their own expense, to record the progress of the trial by any means.
Article 372. ( Value of records). The means of recording the trial shall only have probative value to demonstrate the manner in which it was carried out for the purposes of the corresponding appeals.

Article 373. ( Origin). Once the investigation has been concluded, the prosecutor in charge may request the investigating judge, in his final request, to apply the abbreviated procedure. For it to be admissible, it must have the agreement of the accused and his defense attorney, which must be based on the admission of the fact and his participation in it. In the event of well-founded opposition from the victim or if the common procedure allows for a better understanding of the facts, the judge may deny the application of the abbreviated procedure. The existence of several defendants in the same procedure shall not prevent the application of these rules to any of them.

Article 374. ( Processing and resolution). In an oral hearing, the judge will listen to the prosecutor, the accused, the victim or the complainant, after verifying: 1) The existence of the fact and the participation of the accused; 2) That the accused voluntarily waives the ordinary oral trial; and, 3) That the recognition of guilt was free and voluntary. Once the procedure has been accepted, the sentence will be based on the facts admitted by the accused, but the conviction may not exceed the penalty requested by the prosecutor. In the event of inadmissibility, the request for punishment does not bind the prosecutor during the debate. The judge or court may not base the conviction on the defendant's admission of the facts.

Article 375. ( Private accusation). Anyone who intends to bring charges for a private action crime must present his accusation before the sentencing judge, either himself or through a special representative, in accordance with the provisions of this Code. When the complainant requires the performance of a preparatory act for the presentation of his complaint, he will request the judge to order the competent authority to carry it out.

Article 376. ( Dismissal). The complaint shall be dismissed by a reasoned decision when: 1) The act is not classified as a crime; 2) There is a need for some prior preliminary hearing; or, 3) Any of the requirements provided for the complaint are missing. In the case contemplated in numeral 3), the complainant may repeat the complaint only once, correcting its defects, mentioning the previous dismissal.

Article 377. ( Conciliation). Once the complaint has been admitted, a conciliation hearing shall be convened within the following ten (10) days. When the defendant does not appear, the procedure shall continue its course. If at this time or at any subsequent stage of the trial, the parties reach an agreement, the action shall be declared extinguished and the costs shall be imposed in the order incurred, unless otherwise agreed by the parties.

Article 378. ( Retraction). If the defendant accused of a crime against honor retracts his statement at the conciliation hearing or when answering the complaint, the action will be extinguished and the costs will be his responsibility. If the complainant does not accept the retraction because he considers it insufficient, the judge will decide the incident. If the complainant so requests, the judge will order that the retraction be published in the same manner as the offence occurred, with costs.
Article 379. ( Subsequent procedure). If conciliation is not achieved, the judge shall convene a trial in accordance with the provisions of this Code and shall apply the rules of ordinary trial.

Article 380. ( Withdrawal). The plaintiff may withdraw the action at any stage of the proceedings, but shall remain subject to liability arising from his prior acts. Withdrawal shall result in the extinction of the criminal action.

Article 381. ( Abandonment of the complaint). In addition to the cases provided for in this Code, the complaint shall be considered abandoned and the proceedings shall be archived when the complainant or his representative fails to appear at the conciliation hearing without just cause.

Article 382. ( Procedure). Once the sentence of conviction or the sentence imposing a security measure due to non-imputability or semi-imputability has become final, the complainant or the prosecutor may request the sentencing judge to order the repair of the damage caused or the corresponding compensation. The victim who has not intervened in the process may opt for this route, within three (3) months of being informed of the final judgment.

Article 383. ( Claim). The claim must be directed against the convicted person or against the person to whom a security measure was applied due to non-imputability or semi-imputability and/or against third parties who, by legal provision or contractual relationship, are responsible for the damages caused.

Article 384. ( Content). The claim must contain: 1) The identity details of the plaintiff or his legal representative and his procedural address; 2) The identity of the defendant and the address where he should be summoned; 3) The specific and detailed expression of the damages suffered and their direct relationship with the illegal act checked; 4) The basis of the right invoked; and, 5) The specific request for compensation sought or the amount of compensation sought. The application shall be accompanied by a certified copy of the sentencing judgment or the judgment imposing the security measure. If the defendant's identification data is unknown or the content of the contract for which a third party is responsible is unknown, the plaintiff may request the judge to take preliminary steps in order to prepare the claim.

Article 385. (Admissibility). The judge will examine the claim and if any of the requirements established in the previous article are missing, he will order the plaintiff to correct the formal defects, within a period of five (5) days, under penalty of dismissing it. Once the deadline has expired, if the defects observed have not been corrected, the judge will dismiss the claim. The dismissal of the claim will not prevent the extension of the compensatory action in the civil court. Once the claim is admitted, the judge will summon the parties to an oral hearing that will take place within five (5) days following notification, ordering, where appropriate, technical expertise to determine the causal relationship and evaluate the damages and the real precautionary measures that he considers appropriate.

Article 386. (Hearing and resolution). At the hearing, the judge shall seek the conciliation of the parties and approve the agreements reached. Otherwise, he shall order the production of the evidence offered only with reference to the legitimacy of the parties, the assessment of the damage and its direct relationship with the event. Once the evidence has been produced and the parties have been heard, the judge, at the same hearing, will issue a resolution rejecting the claim or requesting compensation for damages with a specific and detailed description and the exact amount of compensation. The non-appearance of the plaintiff will result in the abandonment of the claim and its filing. The non-appearance of the defendant or any of the defendants will not suspend the hearing, but will be bound by the results of the proceedings.

Article 387. (Appeals and enforcement). The decision may be appealed with a devolutionary effect, without further appeal, and the plaintiff shall be exempt from posting a bond for the results. The judge will execute the decision subject to the rules of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Article 388. (Expiration). The action to demand reparation or compensation for damages, through this special procedure, will expire two (2) years after the sentence of conviction or the one imposing the security measure becomes final.

Article 389. (Imputable minors). When a person over sixteen (16) and under eighteen (18) years of age is accused of committing a crime, the investigation and trial shall proceed in accordance with the ordinary rules of this Code, with the exception of those established below: 1) The Prosecutor's Office will act through specialized prosecutors, or failing that, the prosecutor will be assisted by professionals who are experts in minors;

Article 389. (Imputable minors). When a person over sixteen (16) and under eighteen (18) years of age is accused of committing a crime, the investigation and trial shall proceed in accordance with the ordinary rules of this Code, with the exception of those established below: 2) When preventive detention of a minor under eighteen (18) years of age is appropriate, it will be carried out in a special establishment or in a special section within common establishments; 3) The judge or court may order the reservation of judgment in a reasoned manner when it considers that the advertising may harm the interest of the minor; 4) Parents or those who have had the child under their care, guardianship or tutelage may attend the trial and participate in the defense of the accused; and, 5) The judge or court will be assisted in the development of the debate by an expert specialized in minority.

Article 390. (Domestic violence). In the case of the crime of injury, the impediment to which is less than eight (8) days, the victim may choose to apply the common procedure provided for by this Code or the procedure established in the Law Against Violence in the Family or Domestic Violence. In no case may both methods be chosen.

Article 391. (Cultural diversity). When a member of an indigenous people or indigenous or peasant community is accused of committing a crime and must be prosecuted in the ordinary jurisdiction, the ordinary rules of this Code and the following special rules shall be observed: 1) The prosecutor during the preparatory stage and the judge or court during the trial shall be assisted by an expert specializing in indigenous issues; who may participate in the debate; and, 2) Before sentencing, the expert will prepare a report that will allow a more in-depth understanding of the accused's referential patterns of behavior in order to substantiate, mitigate or extinguish his criminal liability; this report must be supported orally in the debate.

Article 392. ( Trial of judges). Judges shall be tried in accordance with the common procedure. They shall only be suspended from office by the Judicial Council when they are formally charged before the investigating judge. (Modified by article 1 of Law No. 007 of May 18, 2010, on Modifications to the System Criminal Regulations)

Article 393. ( Constitutional privilege). For the trial of public officials included in article 66, paragraph 1) and article 118, paragraphs 5) and 6) of the Political Constitution of the State, for crimes committed in the exercise of their functions, the procedure shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Political Constitution of the State, and the rules for oral and public trials established in this Code shall apply.

Article 393 Bis. ( Origin). In the formal charge resolution, the prosecutor may request the investigating judge to apply the immediate procedure for flagrant crimes in accordance with the provisions of this Title, when the accused is surprised or apprehended in the commission of a crime in flagrante delicto. If the case is against several defendants, it will only be possible if they are all in the situation provided for in the previous paragraph and are involved in the same act. Related crimes in which other defendants are involved will not be added to the immediate procedure for flagrancy.

Article 393 Ter. ( Hearing). In an oral hearing, the investigating judge shall listen to the prosecutor, the accused and his defense attorney, the victim or the complainant, verify compliance with the conditions of admissibility provided for in the preceding article and decide on the application of the procedure. If the judge accepts the application of the immediate procedure for flagrancy, in the same hearing the prosecutor may: 1. Request the application of an alternative exit, including the abbreviated procedure when the requirements set forth in this Code are met; 2. If the prosecutor requires carrying out additional investigative or evidence recovery acts, he/she will request the judge to provide the period he/she considers necessary, which may not exceed forty-five (45) days. The judge will decide on the prosecutor's request, after the intervention of the victim and the defense; 3. If the complainant considers that he has sufficient evidence, he will present the accusation and offer the evidence at the same hearing. The complainant may adhere to the accusation of the prosecutor or make a private accusation at the same hearing and will offer his evidence of the charge. The public accusation, and if applicable the private accusation, will be made known to the accused at the same hearing, so that within a maximum period of five (5) days he may offer his evidence of exonerating the accused. Once this period has expired, the investigating judge will immediately set a date and time for the trial preparation hearing, which will take place within the following three (3) days. However, at the reasoned request of the defense, the judge may extend the period for the presentation of evidence in defense for a maximum period of forty-five (45) days. 4. Request the preventive detention of the accused, when any of the requirements established in article 233 of this Code are met, in order to guarantee his presence at the trial. The request may not be denied by the investigating judge, except in cases where preventive detention is inadmissible. The resolutions issued by the judge regarding numerals 2 and 3 in accordance with the provisions of this Article shall not be subject to any appeal.

Article 393 Quater. ( Immediate Trial Preparation Hearing). At the trial preparation hearing, the parties may: a) Observe the public or private accusation for formal defects, requesting their correction; b) To raise exceptions and other means of defense, when they have not been raised previously or are based on new facts; c) Raise incidents of exclusion of evidence or observations on the admissibility of evidence, for which the parties must present the documentary and material evidence offered in the accusation; (d) Propose facts that are not in dispute and that the judge will consider proven, ignoring the need for evidence in the trial. They may also propose agreements on the means of proof that will be necessary for certain facts to be considered proven. The investigating judge, however, may disassociate himself from these agreements by stating the reasons that justify it; e) Raise any other issue or incident that tends to better prepare the trial. The hearing will be conducted by the investigating judge and during the hearing the presentation or reading of written documents will not be allowed. Once the hearing has been held, the investigating judge will give the floor for a short time and in order to the prosecutor, the private prosecutor and the defense, who will debate the admissibility of the questions raised and the relevance of the evidence offered. The prosecutor may, during the same hearing, with the obligation to present the respective document within a maximum period of twenty-four (24) hours following the hearing, clarify or correct the accusation in what is not substantial; the judge will then forward the information to the other procedural subjects. If there are no further observations, the case will be considered corrected. Once the hearing is over, the investigating judge will immediately resolve all the issues raised, unless due to the lateness of the hour or the complexity of the matters to be resolved, the reasoning of the decision is postponed for up to forty-eight (48) non-extendable hours. Decisions on the admissibility of evidence and the exclusion of evidence are not subject to appeal. In the same resolution on the issues raised, the investigating judge will issue an order to open the trial, ordering the submission of the public and private prosecution, the written offer of defence and the documentary and material evidence offered to the sentencing judge.

Article 393 Quinquer. (Immediate Trial). Once the case has been filed, the sentencing judge will set the date and time for the hearing to substantiate the trial, which will take place within a period of no more than five (5) days. On the day and time of the hearing, once the parties are present, the judge will give the floor to the prosecution to present the grounds for its accusation; later, he will give the floor to the private prosecutor to justify his accusation and to the victim if he so requests; then to the accused in order to determine whether he will use his material defense at that time and finally he will give the floor to the technical defense to present its case. The accusations will not be read out nor will the defense offer evidence. Once the debate has been opened, the evidence from the Public Prosecutor's Office will be received, then the evidence from the private prosecution and finally the evidence from the defence, in the order in which each party considers appropriate for its presentation. If the accused decides to testify as part of the defence's evidence, this will be treated according to the rules for witness testimony in oral trials. Once the production of evidence has been completed, each party, starting with the Public Prosecutor, will have the opportunity to make their closing arguments, ultimately giving the floor to the victim and the accused, in that order, so that they may make their final statement. In all other respects, the rules provided for ordinary trials shall apply, in accordance with the provisions of this Code.

Article 393 Sexter. (Judgment).
