Once the parties have concluded their arguments, the sentencing judge shall proceed to issue judgment immediately, in accordance with the provisions of articles 361 et seq. of this Code. However, the drafting of the grounds may not be deferred, and the judgment must be read in its entirety.

Article 394. ( Right to appeal). Judicial decisions may be appealed in the cases expressly established by this Code. The right to appeal shall correspond to anyone expressly permitted by law, including the victim even if he or she has not been constituted as a plaintiff.
Article 395. ( Adhesion). Anyone who has the right to appeal may adhere, with reasons, to the appeal granted to any of the parties, within the period of service of notice.

Article 396. ( General rules). Appeals shall be governed by the following general rules: 1) They will have suspensive effect, unless otherwise provided; 2) They may be withdrawn with costs by the party that filed them, without prejudice to the other appellants or those who have duly joined. In order to withdraw an appeal, the defense attorney must have an express mandate from the accused; 3) Appeals shall be filed within the time and manner determined in this Code, with specific indication of the contested aspects of the resolution; and, 4) Except for the appeal for review, the appeals will be filed before the court that issued the contested resolution, which will not rule on its admissibility.
Article 397. ( Extensive effect). When there are co-defendants in a case, the appeal filed by one of them will favor the others, unless the reasons on which it is based are exclusively personal.
Article 398. ( Jurisdiction). Appellate courts shall limit their decisions to the contested aspects of the decision.

Article 399. ( Rejection without procedure). If there is a defect or omission of form, the appellate court shall notify the appellant, giving him a period of three days to expand or correct it, under penalty of rejection. If the appeal is inadmissible, it will be rejected without ruling on the merits.

Article 400. ( Amendment to the detriment of the accused). When the resolution has only been challenged by the accused or his defense attorney, it may not be amended to the detriment of the accused. The appeals filed by any of the parties will allow the resolution to be modified or revoked even in favor of the accused, unless the appeal refers exclusively to costs.

Article 401. ( Admissibility). The appeal for reconsideration shall only be applicable against procedural decisions, so that the same judge or court, having been warned of its error, may revoke or modify them.

Article 402. ( Processing and resolution). This appeal shall be filed in writing, with reasons, within twenty-four (24) hours of the order being notified to the appellant and verbally when it is presented at the hearings. The judge or court must resolve it without substantiation within twenty-four (24) hours or in the same act if it is raised in a hearing, without further appeal.

Article 403. ( Appealable resolutions). The incidental appeal shall apply against the following resolutions: 1) The one that resolves the conditional suspension of the process; 2) The one that resolves an exception; 3) The one that resolves precautionary measures or their substitution; 4) The one that dismisses the complaint in private action crimes; 5) The one that resolves the objection of the complaint; 6) The one that declares the extinction of the criminal action; 7) The one that grants, revokes or rejects conditional release; 8) The one that denies or revokes the request for extension of the preparatory stage in crimes related to criminal organizations; 9) The one that admits or denies the suspension or extinction of the sentence, 10) The one that resolves the repair of the damage; and; 11) The others indicated by this Code.

Article 404. ( Filing). The appeal shall be filed in writing, duly substantiated, before the same court that issued the resolution, within three (3) days of the resolution being notified to the appellant. When the appellant attempts to produce evidence in the second instance, he shall attach and offer it together with the appeal brief, specifically indicating the fact he intends to prove.

Article 405. (Service and referral). Once the appeal has been filed, the judge will summon the other parties to respond to the appeal within three (3) days and, where appropriate, to submit and offer evidence. If there are any objections during the service, the other parties will be notified so that they may respond to the objection within the same period. With or without a response, within the following twenty-four hours, the proceedings will be forwarded to the Superior Court of Justice for a decision.

Article 406. (Procedure). Once the proceedings have been received, the Superior Court of Justice shall decide, in a single resolution, the admissibility of the appeal and the admissibility of the issue raised, within the following ten (10) days, except as provided in article 399 of this Code. If any of the parties has offered evidence and the court deems it necessary and useful, it will schedule an oral hearing within fifteen (15) days of receiving the proceedings and will resolve in the same hearing, applying the rules of oral and public trial, as appropriate, only with the evidence that is incorporated and with the witnesses that are present.

Article 407. (Reasons). A restricted appeal shall be filed for failure to observe or erroneous application of the law. When the legal provision that is invoked as being unobserved or erroneously applied constitutes a defect in the procedure, the appeal will only be admissible if the interested party has duly requested its correction or has reserved the right to appeal, except in cases of an absolute nullity or when it concerns defects in the judgment, in accordance with the provisions of articles 169 and 370 of this Code. This appeal may only be brought against judgments and with the limitations established in the following articles.

Article 408. (Filing). The restricted appeal shall be filed in writing within fifteen (15) days of notification of the judgment. The legal provisions that are considered violated or erroneously applied shall be specifically cited and the application sought shall be stated. Each violation must be indicated separately with its grounds. No other violation may be invoked subsequently. The appellant must state whether he will orally justify his appeal.

Article 409. (Summoning and referral). Once the appeal has been filed, it shall be brought to the attention of the other parties so that they may respond to it with reasons within a period of ten days. If an adhesion has been made, you will be required to respond to it within five (5) days. Once the deadlines have expired, with or without a response, the proceedings will be sent within three (3) days to the appellate court and the parties will be summoned to appear within ten (10) days from the date of the referral.

Article 410. ( Offering of evidence). When the appeal is based on a defect in form or procedure, evidence may be submitted and offered for that purpose. The evidence will be offered when filing the appeal, when answering it or when adhering to it. The rules provided for the production of evidence in the incidental appeal shall apply.

Article 411. ( Procedure). Once the proceedings have been received, if evidence has been offered or a hearing on the grounds has been expressly requested, the court shall convene a public hearing within ten (10) days of receiving the proceedings. Once the hearing is concluded or if it was not convened, the resolution will be issued within a maximum period of twenty (20) days.

Article 412. ( Hearing of evidence or reasoning). The hearing of evidence or reasoning shall be governed, as appropriate, by the rules provided for oral proceedings. Whoever has offered evidence must present it at the hearing and the court will decide only on the evidence that is incorporated and on the witnesses who are present. At the hearing for additional reasoning, the members of the court may freely question the appellants about the insufficient aspects of the reasoning or the proposed solution, the doctrine that supports their claims or the jurisprudence that was used, without implying prejudgment. Failure to attend the hearing will not result in the abandonment of the appeal, but the person who requested it and did not attend will be responsible for the costs.

Article 413. ( Resolution of the appeal). When it is not possible to directly remedy the non-compliance with the law or its erroneous application, the appellate court shall annul the judgment in whole or in part and order the trial to be re-tried by another judge or court. When the annulment is partial, the specific object of the new trial will be indicated. When the appeal has been filed only by the accused or, in his favor, in the retrial, a more serious sanction than that imposed in the annulled sentence may not be imposed, nor may the benefits granted in it be ignored. When it is evident that a new trial is not necessary to issue a new sentence, the appellate court will decide directly.

Article 414. ( Rectification). Errors of law in the reasoning of the contested decision, which have not influenced the operative part, shall not annul it, but shall be corrected in the new judgment, as well as formal errors or omissions and those referring to the imposition or calculation of penalties. The court may also provide additional reasoning without annulling the contested judgment.
Article 415. ( Freedom of the accused). When the accused's detention must cease as a result of the sentence, the appellate court shall directly order his release.

Article 416. ( Admissibility). The appeal for cassation is available to challenge judgments issued by the Higher Courts of Justice that are contrary to other precedents issued by other Higher Courts of Justice or by the Criminal Chamber of the Supreme Court. The conflicting precedent must be invoked by the appellant at the time of filing the restricted appeal. A contradiction will be deemed to exist when, faced with a similar factual situation, the legal meaning assigned to it by the contested Order of Review does not coincide with that of the previous one, either because different rules have been applied or the same rule has a different scope.

Article 417. ( Requirements). The appeal must be filed within five (5) days following notification of the contested Order of Review before the chamber that issued it, which will forward the background to the Supreme Court of Justice within the following forty-eight (48) hours. The appeal shall state the contradiction in precise terms and, as the only admissible evidence, a copy of the restricted appeal in which the precedent was invoked shall be attached. Failure to comply with these requirements will result in inadmissibility.

Article 418. ( Admission of the appeal). Once the background information has been received, the criminal chamber of the Supreme Court of Justice, within the following five (5) days, will determine whether the required conditions are met, in which case it will admit the appeal. If it declares it inadmissible, it will return the proceedings to the court that issued the appealed Order. Once the appeal has been admitted, the criminal chambers of all the High Courts of Justice will be informed of the background of the case so that they may refrain from issuing Hearing Orders in appeals in which the same legal issues are debated, until they are informed of the resolution of the appeal for cassation.

Article 419. (Resolution of the appeal). Once the appeal has been admitted, without further proceedings and within the following ten (10) days, the criminal chamber of the Supreme Court of Justice will issue a resolution by absolute majority of votes determining whether or not there is a contradiction in the terms of article 416 of this Code. If there is a contradiction, the resolution will establish the applicable legal doctrine; otherwise, it will declare it unfounded and return the records to the High Court of Justice. In the first case and when the ruling that motivated the appeal is annulled, the proceedings will be returned to the Criminal Chamber of the High Court that issued the appealed Hearing Order so that it may issue a new resolution in accordance with the established legal doctrine.

Article 420. ( Effects). The Criminal Chamber of the Supreme Court shall inform the lower courts and judges of the resolutions of the appeals in which the applicable legal doctrine is established. The established legal doctrine will be binding on the lower courts and judges and may only be modified by means of a new resolution issued on the occasion of another appeal.

Article 421. ( Admissibility). An appeal for review of final judgments of conviction shall be admissible at any time and in favor of the convicted person in the following cases: 1) When the facts considered as the basis of the judgment are incompatible with the established by another final criminal judgment; 2) When the contested judgment is based on evidence whose falsity was declared in a subsequent ruling executed; 3) When the conviction sentence has been pronounced as a result of crimes inherent to the judicial function, the existence of which has been declared in a subsequent final judgment; 4) When after the sentence new facts arise, pre-existing facts are discovered or there is evidence that demonstrates: a) That the act was not committed, b) That the convicted person was not the author or participant in the commission of the crime, or, c) That the act is not punishable. 5) When it is appropriate to apply a more lenient criminal law retroactively; and, 6) When a ruling of the Constitutional Court has a repealing effect on the type or criminal norm that founded the conviction.

Article 422. ( Legitimacy). The following may file an appeal: 1) The convicted person or his/her legal representative. If the convicted person is incapable, his/her legal representatives; 2) The spouse, partner or relative within the fourth degree of consanguinity or second degree of affinity, or by adoption, if the convicted person has died; 3) The Public Prosecutor's Office and the judge of criminal enforcement; and, 4) The Ombudsman.

Article 423. ( Procedure). The appeal for review shall be filed in writing, accompanied by the relevant evidence and shall contain, under penalty of inadmissibility, a specific reference to the grounds on which it is based and the applicable legal provisions. The court may order all inquiries and proceedings it considers useful and delegate their execution to one of its members. You may also produce evidence ex officio at the hearing. For the processing of the appeal for review, the rules of the restricted appeal shall apply, insofar as they are applicable.

Article 424. ( Judgment). The court shall resolve the appeal: 1) Rejecting it when it is inappropriate; 2) Annulling the contested judgment, in which case it will issue the appropriate judgment or order a new trial.

Article 425. ( New trial). If a new trial is ordered, the same judges who issued the sentence may not participate. In the new trial, the sentence may not be based on a new assessment of the evidence that gave rise to the annulled sentence. The verdict issued in the new trial may not contain a more serious sanction than that imposed in the first sentence.

Article 426. ( Effects). When the sentence is an acquittal or declares the extinction of the sentence, the immediate release of the unjustly convicted person shall be ordered, as well as the full rehabilitation of the unjustly disqualified person, payment of compensation and/or the return of the amount paid as a pecuniary penalty and the confiscated objects. When the sentence reduces the time of imprisonment remaining to be served by the convicted person, it will contain the new calculation, specifying the date on which the sentence will end. The judgment shall provide for the publication of the operative part of the judgment that declared the acquittal or extinction of the sentence in a national media outlet.
Article 427. (Rejection). The rejection of the appeal for review shall not prevent the filing of a new appeal based on different grounds.

Article 428. ( Jurisdiction). Sentences of conviction shall be executed by the judge of criminal enforcement, who shall have jurisdiction to resolve all questions or incidents that arise during the execution. Sentences of acquittal and those granting judicial pardon and conditional suspension of sentence shall be executed by the judge or court that issued them. The court may commission one of its judges to carry out the necessary proceedings.

Article 429. ( Rights). During the execution of the sentence, the convicted person shall have the rights and guarantees granted to him by the Constitution, the international Conventions and Treaties in force and the laws. To this end, he shall submit to the judge of criminal execution the requests he deems appropriate.

Article 430. ( Execution). Once the conviction has been executed, certified copies of the proceedings shall be sent to the judge of criminal enforcement so that he may proceed according to this Code. If the convicted person is at liberty, his arrest shall be ordered. The judge or the president of the court shall order the implementation of all measures necessary to comply with the accessory effects of the judgment.

Article 431. (Deferred execution). Before the execution of a custodial sentence, the judge or court that issued the sentence shall defer the execution of the sentence and shall order the appropriate precautionary measures to ensure its execution, in the following cases: 1) When it must be fulfilled by a pregnant woman or one who has a child under one (1) year of age at the time of execution of the sentence; 2) When the convicted person is seriously ill and immediate execution is a precondition life-threatening, according to the forensic medical opinion. When these conditions cease, the sentence shall be executed immediately.

Article 432. (Incidents). The Prosecutor's Office or the convicted person may raise incidents relating to the execution of the sentence. The incident will be resolved by the criminal enforcement judge, in an oral and public hearing, which will be convened within five (5) days following its promotion. The decision may be appealed before the Superior Court of Justice.

Article 433. (Conditional release). The judge of criminal enforcement, by means of a reasoned resolution, following a report from the management of the penitentiary establishment, may grant conditional release once only to a person sentenced to a custodial sentence, in accordance with the following requirements: 1) Having served two-thirds of the sentence imposed; 2) Having observed good conduct in the penitentiary establishment in accordance with the regulations; and, 3) Having demonstrated a vocation for work. The order for conditional release will indicate the address indicated by the released person and the conditions and instructions that must be met, in accordance with the provisions of article 24 of this Code. The judge will monitor compliance with the imposed conditions, which may be amended ex officio or at the request of the prosecutor or the convicted person.

Article 434. (Procedure). The incident of conditional release must be formulated before the judge of criminal enforcement. It may be promoted at the request of a party or ex officio. The criminal enforcement judge will order the director of the establishment to submit the corresponding reports within ten (10) days. The judge may reject the request without processing when it is clearly inappropriate.

Article 435. (Revocation of conditional release). The criminal enforcement judge may revoke conditional release for failure to comply with the conditions imposed. The revocation incident will be promoted ex officio or at the request of the Prosecutor's Office. The convicted person must be present for the incident to be processed, and the judge of criminal enforcement may order his or her arrest if he or she does not appear, despite his or her legal summons. When the incident takes place in the presence of the convicted person, the judge may order that he or she be kept in custody until the incident is resolved. The revocation will force the released person to serve the remainder of the sentence. The order revoking parole is appealable.
Article 436. (Fine). The fine shall be enforced in accordance with the provisions of the Penal Code.

Article 437. (Disqualification). If the sentence is disqualification, once the final calculation has been made, the judge will order the corresponding communications and registrations, indicating the date of completion of the sentence.

Article 438. (Forgiveness of the offended party). The forgiveness of the victim, in crimes of private action, extinguishes the penalty. The judge of criminal enforcement, in his merit, will immediately order the release of the convicted person. This rule will also apply to cases of conversion of shares.
Article 439. (Security Measure). The judge or court that issued the sentence shall determine the appropriate establishment for confinement as a security measure.

Article 4 37. (Disqualification). If the sentence is disqualification, once the final calculation has been made, the judge will order the corresponding communications and registrations, indicating the date of completion of the sentence.

Article 4 38. (Forgiveness of the offended party). The judge of criminal enforcement, in his merit, will immediately order the release of the convicted person.

Article 4 39. (Security Measure). The judge or court that issued the sentence shall determine the appropriate establishment for confinement as a security measure.

Article 4 39. (Security Measure). The judge or court that issued the sentence shall, at least once (1) every six (6) months, examine the situation of the person to whom this measure has been imposed, an examination that will be carried out in an oral hearing, behind closed doors, after a report from those responsible for the establishment and from experts; the decision will be on the cessation or continuation of the measure and, in the latter case, may modify the treatment or change the establishment in which it is executed.

TITLE I II RECORDS Article 4 40. (Criminal Records Registry). The Judicial Registry of Criminal Records, dependent on the Judicial Council, shall be in charge of the centralized registry of the following resolutions: 1) Final convictions;

Article 4 40. (Criminal Records Registry). The Judicial Registry of Criminal Records, dependent on the Judicial Council, shall be in charge of the centralized registry of the following resolutions: 2) Those who declare rebellion; and,

Seventh. (Modifications). Art. 80. CONFINEMENT. When the accused is declared not responsible and acquitted for this reason in accordance with article 17, the judge may, following the opinion of experts, order his confinement in the corresponding establishment, if due to his condition there is a danger that he may harm himself or others. If there is no suitable facility, the non-imputable person will be placed in the facility that can most readily fulfil this purpose or will be placed in the care of his or her family, if in the judge's opinion the latter offers sufficient guarantees for the same purpose. This confinement will last as long as required for safety, education or healing. The judge of criminal enforcement, at least once (1) every six (6) months, will examine the situation of the person to whom this measure has been imposed, an examination that will be carried out in an oral hearing, behind closed doors, after a report from those responsible for the establishment and from experts; the decision will be on the cessation or continuation of the measure and, in the latter case, may modify the treatment or change the establishment in which it is executed.

1. This Act may be cited as the Prevention of Discrimination Act. Short title.
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "commission agent" means an agent who is remunerated by commission;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "contract worker" means a person who performs work for another person pursuant to a contract between the employer of the first-mentioned person and that other person;

2. In this Act- Interpretation. "de facto spouse" in relation to a person, means a person of the opposite sex to the first-mentioned person who lives with the first-mentioned person as a husband or wife of that person although not legally married to that person;

2. In this Act- Interpretation. "dependent contractor" means a person, whether or not employed under a contract of employment, who performs work or service for another person for compensation or reward on such terms and conditions that the first-mentioned person is, in relation to that other person, in a position of economic dependence on, and under an obligation to perform duties for that other person more as an employee than an independent contractor;

2. In this Act- Interpretation. "disabled person" means an individual whose prospects of securing, retaining, and advancing in suitable employment are substantially reduced as a result of a duly recognised physical or mental impairment;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "educational authority" means a body of persons administering an educational institution;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "educational institution" means a school, a college, university or other institution at which education or training is provided;

2. In this Act- Interpretation. "employee" means a person who offers his services to an employer under a contract of employment, a managerial employee or a dependent contractor and includes, where appropriate, a former employee;

2. In this Act- Interpretation. "employer" means any person or undertaking, corporation, company, public authority or body or persons who or which employs any person under a contract or employment or uses the services of a dependent contractor, commission agent or a contract worker; and includes the heirs, successors and assigns or an employer;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "employment" includes— (i) part-time employment, temporary employment and employment under a contract or service or of apprenticeship;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "employment" includes— (ii) employment under a contractor services;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "employment" includes— (iii) engagement as a commission agent;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "employment agency" means any person who, whether for payment or not, assists persons find employment or assists employers to find employees;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "family responsibilities" means the responsibilities in respect of any dependent family member;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "marital status" means the status or condition of being (i) single;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "marital status" means the status or condition of being (ii) married;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "marital status" means the status or condition of being (iii) married but living separately and apart from one’s spouse;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "marital status" means the status or condition of being (iv) divorced;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "marital status" means the status or condition of being (v) widowed;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "marital status" means the status or condition of being (vi) the de facto spouse of another person;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "principal" means (i) in relation to a commission agent, a person for whom work is done by that commission agent;
2. In this Act- Interpretation. "principal" means (ii) in relation to a contract worker, a person for whom a contract worker performs work otherwise than under a contract of employment;

2. In this Act- Interpretation. "remuneration" means any money or other thing, whether called salary, wage, allowance or by any other name, had or contracted to be paid, delivered or given as recompense, reward or remuneration for any work or labour done or to be done, whether within a certain time or to a certain amount, or for a time or an amount uncertain, increment or other increment in such remuneration;

2. In this Act- Interpretation. "sexual harassment" means unwanted conduct or a sexual nature in the workplace or in connection with the performance or work which is threatened or imposed as a condition of employment on an employee or which creates a hostile working environment for the employee.
3. The provisions of this Act shall apply to employers and employees in the public and private sectors who are engaged in an employment relationship. Application of Act.

4. (1) For the purposes of this Act, a person discriminates against another person if the first mentioned person makes, on any or the grounds mentioned in subsection (2), any distinction, exclusion or preference the intent or effect of which is to nullify or impair equality of opportunity or treatment in any employment or occupation. Prohibited grounds of discrimination.

4. (2) The grounds referred to in subsection (1) are— (a) race, sex, religion , colour, ethnic origin, indigenous population, national extraction, social origin, economic status, political opinion, disability, family responsibilities, pregnancy, marital status or age except for purposes of retirement and restrictions on work and employment of minors; Prohibited grounds of discrimination.

4. (2) The grounds referred to in subsection (1) are— (b) any characteristic which appertains generally or is generally imputed to persons or a particular race, sex, religion, colour, ethnic origin, indigenous population, national extraction, social origin, political opinion, disability, family responsibility, pregnant state, marital status, or age except for purposes of retirement and restriction on work and employment of minors. Prohibited grounds of discrimination.

4. (3) Any act or omission or any practice or policy that directly or indirectly results in discrimination against a person on the grounds referred to in subsection (2), is an act of discrimination regardless of whether the person responsible for the act or omission or the practice or policy intended to discriminate. Prohibited grounds of discrimination.

5. (1) It shall be unlawful for any person who is an employer or any person acting or purporting to act on behalf of a person who is an employer, in relation to recruitment, selection or employment or any other person for purposes of training, apprenticeship or employment, to discriminate against that other person on the grounds listed in section 4(2) - (a) in the advertisement of the job; Unlawful discrimination in employment.

5. (1) It shall be unlawful for any person who is an employer or any person acting or purporting to act on behalf of a person who is an employer, in relation to recruitment, selection or employment or any other person for purposes of training, apprenticeship or employment, to discriminate against that other person on the grounds listed in section 4(2) - (b) in the arrangements made for the purpose of determining who should be offered that employment; Unlawful discrimination in employment.

5. (1) It shall be unlawful for any person who is an employer or any person acting or purporting to act on behalf of a person who is an employer, in relation to recruitment, selection or employment or any other person for purposes of training, apprenticeship or employment, to discriminate against that other person on the grounds listed in section 4(2) - (c) in determining who should be offered employment; Unlawful discrimination in employment.

(1) It shall be unlawful for any person who is an employer or any person acting or purporting to act on behalf of a person who is an employer, in relation to recruitment, selection or employment or any other person for purposes of training, apprenticeship or employment, to discriminate against that other person on the grounds listed in section 4(2) - (d) in the terms or conditions on which employment is offered; Unlawful discrimination in employment.

(1) It shall be unlawful for any person who is an employer or any person acting or purporting to act on behalf of a person who is an employer, in relation to recruitment, selection or employment or any other person for purposes of training, apprenticeship or employment, to discriminate against that other person on the grounds listed in section 4(2) - (e) the creation, classification or abolition of jobs. 5. (2) It shall be unlawful for an employer to discriminate against an employee on the grounds listed in section 4(2) (a) in terms or conditions or employment afforded to that employee by this employer; Unlawful discrimination in employment.

5. (2) It shall be unlawful for an employer to discriminate against an employee on the grounds listed in section 4(2) (c) in the provision or facilities related to or connected with employment; Unlawful discrimination in employment.

(2) It shall be unlawful for an employer to discriminate against an employee on the grounds listed in section 4(2) (d) by denying access, or limiting access to opportunities for advancement, promotion, transfer or training, or to any other benefits, facilities or services associated with employment; Unlawful discrimination in employment.

5. (2) It shall be unlawful for an employer to discriminate against an employee on the grounds listed in section 4(2) (e) by retrenching or dismissing the employee; Unlawful discrimination in employment.

5. (2) It shall be unlawful for an employer to discriminate against an employee on the grounds listed in section 4(2) (f) by subjecting the employee to any other disadvantage. Unlawful discrimination in employment.

6. (1) Nothing in section 5 shall apply to any distinction, exclusion, or preference based on the grounds listed in section 4 (2) where a genuine occupational qualification exists. Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (a) the essential nature of the job calls a for a person of particular race, sex, religion, national extraction, indigenous population, ethnic origin, social origin, disability, pregnancy, family responsibilities, marital status or age for reasons or physiology (excluding physical strength or stamina) or, in dramatic performance or other entertainment for reasons of authenticity, so that the essential nature of the job would be materially different if carried out by a person or the opposite sex or a person with an occupational qualification which is different from any stated aforesaid; or Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (b) in a religious Institution, the essential nature of the job calls for a particular religious affiliation or belief and the essential nature of said job would be materially different or could not be carried out if performed by a person of a different religious affiliation or belief; or Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (c) the job needs to be held by a person of a particular sex to preserve decency or privacy because- (i) it is likely to involve physical contact with persons of the same sex as he employees in circumstances where those persons might reasonably object to its being carried out by persons of the opposite sex; Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (c) the job needs to be held by a person of a particular sex to preserve decency or privacy because- (ii) the holder of the job is likely to do work in circumstances where persons of the same sex might reasonably object to the presence of a person of the opposite sex because they are in a state of undress or use the same sanitary facilities; Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (d) the nature or location of the establishment makes it impracticable for the holder of the job to live elsewhere than in promises provided by the employer and- (i) the only such promises which are available for persons holding that kind or job are occupied or normally occupied, by persons of the sex and are not equipped with separate sleeping accommodation and sanitary facilities for persons of the opposite sex; and Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (d) the nature or location of the establishment makes it impracticable for the holder of the job to live elsewhere than in promises provided by the employer and- (ii) it is not reasonable to expect the employer either to equip these premises with such accommodation and facilities or to provide other premises for persons of the opposite sex or to work out a practicable the use of such facilities for members of both sexes; or Bonafide occupational qualifications.
6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (e) the job requires a married couple; or Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (f) the nature of the establishment, or the part of it where the work is carried out, requires the job to be held by a person of a particular sex because- (i) it is, or is part of, a hospital, prison, or other establishment for persons requiring special care, supervision or attention; and Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (f) the nature of the establishment, or the part of it where the work is carried out, requires the job to be held by a person of a particular sex because- (ii) those persons are all of the same sex (disregarding any person of the opposite sex whose presence is exceptional); and Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (f) the nature of the establishment, or the part of it where the work is carried out, requires the job to be held by a person of a particular sex because- (iii) it is reasonable, having regard to the essential character or the establishment or that part, that the job should not be held by a person of the opposite sex; or Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (g) the holder of the job provides individuals with personal services promoting their health, welfare or education, and those services can most effectively be provided by a person of a particular sex; or Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (h) on the grounds or disability when it is shown that- (i) the disability in question was a relevant consideration in relation to the particular requirements of the employment concerned and the performance of the job could not be carried out as a result of the disability; or Bonafide occupational qualifications.

6. (2) For the purposes of this Act a genuine occupational qualification for a job exists where- (h) on the grounds or disability when it is shown that- (ii) special facilities or modifications, whether physical, administrative, or otherwise, are required to be made at the workplace to accommodate the disabled person which the employer cannot reasonably be expected to provide. Bonafide occupational qualifications.

7. Special measures taken by employers of a temporary nature to promote equality of opportunity in employment based on the grounds set out in section 4(2) shall not be deemed to be unlawful discrimination within the meaning of section 5 of this Act. Special measure to promote equality.

9. (1) Every employer and every person acting on behalf of such employer shall be obligated to pay equal remuneration to men and women performing work of equal value for such employer. Equal remuneration.

1. Short title This Act may be cited as the Communications Act.

2. Objectives The objectives of this Act are— (a) to recognize the convergence of technologies and services for telecommunications, broadcasting, and information through the establishment of technology and service-neutral licensing regimes;
2. Objectives The objectives of this Act are— (b) to remove unnecessary barriers to entry, and attract investment, in the communications sector;
2. Objectives The objectives of this Act are— (c) to facilitate the deployment and use of communications services;
2. Objectives The objectives of this Act are— (d) to encourage the adoption of new services and technologies within the communications sector;
2. Objectives The objectives of this Act are— (e) to encourage the participation of indigenous Malawians in the communications sector;
2. Objectives The objectives of this Act are— (f) to facilitate the provision of affordable communication services;
2. Objectives The objectives of this Act are— (g) to facilitate technology neutrality;
2. Objectives The objectives of this Act are— (h) to ensure consumer protection.

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "access" means making available facilities or services of any licensee under defined conditions, on exclusive or non-exclusive basis, for the purpose of providing communications services, including access to— (a) network elements and associated facilities, which may involve the connection of equipment by fixed or non-fixed means, and includes access to the local loop, facilities and services necessary to provide services over the local loop; (b) physical infrastructure, including buildings, cable engineering networks, ducts, masts and poles; (c) relevant software systems, including operational support systems; (d) number translation facilities, or to systems offering equivalent functionality; (e) fixed and mobile networks, in particular for roaming; (f) conditional access systems for digital television services; or (g) virtual network services;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "allocation" means the apportionment of a given scarce resource for the purpose of its use by one or more communications services under given conditions;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "apparatus" means equipment, an instrument, or any other object for use in the provision or the reception of communications services, and includes a fitting to, or accessory of, the equipment, instrument or object;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "Authority" means the Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority established under section 4;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "broadcasting" means any form of transmission of content intended for reception by the public whether conveyed by means of radio or electronic communications;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "broadcasting service" means any service that consists of broadcasting, but does not include— (a) a service that provides only data or text, whether with or without associated still images;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "broadcasting service" means any service that consists of broadcasting, but does not include— (b) a service in which the provision of audio-visual material or audio material is incidental to the provision of that service;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "broadcasting service" means any service that consists of broadcasting, but does not include— (c) a service or a class of service that the Authority may, by regulation, prescribe;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "broadcasting signal distribution" means the process whereby the output signal of a broadcasting service is taken from the point of origin, being the point where such signal is made available in its final content format, and is conveyed to any broadcast target area by means of electronic communications, and includes multi-channel distribution;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "class assignment" means an assignment issued by the Authority pursuant to this Act, granting entities, subject to certain rules, the right to use frequencies or numbers, as specified by the Authority;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "class assignee" means the holder of a class assignment;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "class licence" means a licence issued by the Authority, as distinct from an individual licence, issued on the same terms to each applicant of a category of users in respect of the operation of a type of an electronic communications network or communications service that does not require the use of scarce resources;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "class licensee" means the holder of a class licence;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "commercial broadcasting" means a broadcasting service operating for profit or as part of a profit entity, but excludes any public broadcasting service;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "common carrier" means an entity licensed to provide electronic communications network services and is obliged to provide signal distribution for broadcasting services on a non-discriminatory and non-exclusive basis;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "communications service" refers to any electronic communications service, broadcasting service or postal service;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "communications technology" means the application of communications and computing technologies to the creation, management and use of information through the use of hardware, software, networks, as well as media for the collection, storage, processing, transmission and presentation of information and related services;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "community" includes a geographically founded community or a group of entities or sector of the public, having a specific and ascertainable common interest;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "community broadcasting service" means a content service that— (a) serves a particular community;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "community broadcasting service" means a content service that— (b) is carried on for non-profitable purposes;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "community broadcasting service" means a content service that— (c) is fully controlled by a non-profit making entity;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "consumer" means a person who uses or seeks to obtain broadcasting, postal or electronic communications services for personal use;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "content" means information in the form of sound, data, text or images, whether still or moving, except where transmitted in private communications;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "content service licensee" means a holder of a content service licence;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "convey" includes transmit and transport, and "conveyance" shall be construed accordingly;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "courier service" means an individualized and time sensitive service for collection, acceptance, conveyance and delivery of postal articles on a door to door basis;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "coverage area" means an area in which a communication service is intended to be received;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "dominant market player" means an entity that holds, either on its own or in conjunction with other entities, a significant market power;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications" means the emission, transmission or reception of signals, including content or intelligence of any nature, partially or fully transmitted by any radio, electromagnetic, photo electronic or photo optical system, but does not include— (a) wire or direct oral communication;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications" means the emission, transmission or reception of signals, including content or intelligence of any nature, partially or fully transmitted by any radio, electromagnetic, photo electronic or photo optical system, but does not include— (b) communications made through a tone-only paging device;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications" means the emission, transmission or reception of signals, including content or intelligence of any nature, partially or fully transmitted by any radio, electromagnetic, photo electronic or photo optical system, but does not include— (c) communication from a tracking device;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications" means the emission, transmission or reception of signals, including content or intelligence of any nature, partially or fully transmitted by any radio, electromagnetic, photo electronic or photo optical system, but does not include— (d) electronic funds transfer information stored by a financial institution in a communications system used for electronic storage and the transfer of funds;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications" means the emission, transmission or reception of signals, including content or intelligence of any nature, partially or fully transmitted by any radio, electromagnetic, photo electronic or photo optical system, but does not include— (e) postal or broadcasting service;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications licence" means a network service licence and an application service licence;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications market" means an area of activity identified by the Authority, as constituting a single market within the communications technology sector;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications network" means transmission systems and, where applicable, switching or routing equipment and other resources that permit the conveyance of signals by wire, radio, optical or other electronic means;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications numbering" means a number, sign or other mark that an electronic communications licensee, in the delivery of electronic communications services, uses to identify electronic communications facilities in order to connect between the place of transmission and the place of reception, or identify the type of content or transmission that the electronic communications facility is to deliver;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "electronic communications services" means a service provided by one or more electronic communications network;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "essential facilities" means facilities of an electronic communications network or service that— (a) are exclusively or predominantly provided by a single or limited number of suppliers;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "essential facilities" means facilities of an electronic communications network or service that— (b) are economically or technically difficult to substitute or duplicate in order to provide a service;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "exempted licensee" means a licensee who is exempted from certain conditions in order to operate its activities;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "exempted service" means a licensed service for which certain conditions and fees are not required by the Authority in order for the service provider to commence its operations;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "facility services" means any services comprising electronic communication infrastructure, including earth station, fixed links and cables, radio communication transmitters and links, satellite hubs, satellite control station, submarine cables, and cable landing station;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "frequency" means electromagnetic waves of radio communications frequencies propagated in space without artificial guide;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "frequency allocation" means the reservation of one or more radio frequency bands for a particular use or uses;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "frequency assignment" means the reservation of one or more radio frequencies for use by a particular entity in accordance with the national frequency plan;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "frequency spectrum licence" means a licence issued to grant the right to use the radio-frequency spectrum to operate a network facility or radio communication equipment of a specified kind at a specified frequency, or in any specified frequency band or bands, and which may include spectrum assignments and apparatus assignments;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "frequency spectrum service" means a service involving the transmission, emission or reception of radio waves for specific communications purposes;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "individual licence" means a licence issued by the Authority to a particular entity on terms specific to that entity;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "interconnexion" means the physical and logical connexion of two or more electronic communications networks;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "interconnexion agreement" means an agreement between licensees in relation to the interconnexion of their services;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "interconnexion provider" means a person providing an interconnexion service to other licensees in accordance with a licence issued by the Authority;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "licence area" means the geographical area specified in a licence;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "message" means any communication sent, received or made by communications systems or services, or given to any entity to be sent or delivered by electronic communications networks or services;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "multi-channel distribution service" means a broadcasting signal distribution service that provides broadcasting signal distribution for more than one channel at the same time on the same signal;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "postal service" means any system for the collection, dispatch, conveyance, handling and delivery of letters, postcards, printed papers, commercial papers, samples, parcels or other similar articles;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "post office" means any building, house, room, receptacle, vessel, vehicle or place where postal articles are received, sorted, dispatched or delivered;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "postage" means the amount chargeable for the transmission of an article by post, and includes any special charges or fees for supplementary services supplied in connexion with the transmission of an article by post;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "postal article" means any article in the course of transmission by post, including any letter, postcard, newspaper, book, document, pamphlet, pattern, sample packet, small packet, parcel package, or any other article tendered for dispatch, or specified as a postal article by the Universal Postal Union or in a postal licence;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "postal services licensee" means any entity licensed to provide postal services;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "postal tariff" means any charges raised by the postal services licensee for the provision of postal services;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "public content service" means any content service provided by the Malawi Broadcasting Corporation, or any other public state-owned enterprise holding a broadcasting service licence to this purpose;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "public postal service" means any postal service provided by the Malawi Posts Corporation, or other state-owned enterprise holding a postal services licence;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "scarce resources" means finite resources required in the operation of electronic communication, including radio spectrum, numbers and rights of ways;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "subscriber" means a person having a contract with an authorized provider of a communications service in order to obtain any communications services;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "subscription content service" means a content service provided under a subscription contract;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "television content service" means a content service consisting of the transmission of visual images or other visible signals, with or without accompanying sounds, where the visual images are such that their sequences are seen as moving pictures;

Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "type approval" is a procedure where the Authority certifies the acceptability of an electronic equipment or product based on conformity of the equipment or the product to minimum regulatory technical and safety requirement before the equipment or the product is used;
3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "universal access" means access to publicly available communications services;

3. Interpretation In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— "Universal Service Fund Committee" means the committee to be established by the Authority under section 159.
4. Establishment of the Authority (1) There is hereby established an authority to be known as the Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority.
4. Establishment of the Authority (2) The Authority shall— (a) be a body corporate with perpetual succession and shall have a common seal;
4. Establishment of the Authority (2) The Authority shall— (b) be capable of suing and being sued in its corporate name;

4. Establishment of the Authority (2) The Authority shall— (c) be capable of acquiring and disposing of any movable or immovable property and do such things and perform such acts as bodies corporate may, by law, do or perform;
4. Establishment of the Authority (2) The Authority shall— (d) perform such functions and exercise such powers as are conferred by this Act.
5. Ministerial policy directions (1) The Authority may, where necessary, seek the general direction of the Minister as to the manner in which it is to carry out its duties under this Act.
5. Ministerial policy directions (2) The directions given by the Minister under subsection (1) shall be in writing and shall be published in the Gazette.
5. Ministerial policy directions (3) Except as provided for under this Act or any other law, the Authority shall be independent in the performance of its functions.

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (1) The Authority shall regulate and monitor the provision of communications services and ensure that, as far as it is practicable, reliable and affordable communications services are provided throughout Malawi and are sufficient to meet the demand for such services in accordance with the principles of transparency, certainty, market orientation, efficiency, and consumer satisfaction.

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (a) be vested with the legal ownership of spectrum on behalf of the Republic of Malawi;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (b) grant licences for the provision of communications services;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (c) protect the interests of consumers, purchasers and other users of communications services;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (d) promote access to information and the development of human resources in the communications sector;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (e) promote efficiency and competition among entities engaged in the provision of communications services or in the supply of communication equipment;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (f) encourage the introduction of new technology and communications services in accordance with recognized international standard and applicable international law;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (g) promote research and development in communications services;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (h) foster the development of communication service technologies in accordance with recognized international standards and applicable international law;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (i) advise the Government on policy issues relating to the communications sector;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (j) monitor the activities of licensees to ensure compliance with the Act and the terms and conditions of their licences;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (k) establish a type approval regime for terminal equipment or any other electronic equipment;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (l) collect and publish information with respect to communications services;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (m) develop and publish technical standards for regulated communications goods and services;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (n) receive and investigate complaints relating to communications services and to take the necessary action;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (o) carry out projects to promote the development of the communications sector;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (p) provide technical support and represent the Government at international communications fora;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (q) ensure compliance with national and international communications standards and obligations laid down by international communication agreements and treaties to which Malawi is a party and to issue certificates of compliance in relation thereto;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (r) ensure the safety and quality of service for communications services;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (s) protect public health and safety;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (t) negotiate with the relevant Ministries, local authorities and private land owners with respect to rights of way;

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (u) render technical assistance on communication matters to the Minister; and

6. Duties, functions and powers of the Authority (2) Notwithstanding the generality of, and subject to the principles referred to in, subsection (1), the Authority shall— (v) generally implement the objectives of this Act and do all such things as are necessary, incidental or conducive to the better carrying out of the functions of the Authority.

7. Membership of the Authority The Authority shall consist of— (a) six members, appointed in accordance with section 8; and— (b) the following ex officio members— (i) the Secretary for Information or his representative; (ii) the Secretary to the Treasury or his representative; and (iii) the Solicitor General or his representative.

8. Appointment of members of the Authority (1) The President shall appoint members of the Authority, other than ex officio members, and each appointment shall be subject to confirmation by the Public Appointments Committee of Parliament.

8. Appointment of members of the Authority (2) A person to be appointed as a member of the Authority shall— (a) be a citizen of, and resident in, Malawi; (b) possess qualifications, expertize and experience in any of the fields of posts, telecommunications technology, electronic communications, broadcasting, frequency planning, law, information communication technology, economics or finance; and (c) not be a person who has, within the last three years, been convicted by a competent court of a crime which is punishable with imprisonment without an option of a fine.

8. Appointment of members of the Authority (3) In appointing members of the Authority under subsection (1), the President shall have regard to gender equality and the need for continuity of service on the Authority and balance representation in terms of qualifications referred to in subsection (2).
8. Appointment of members of the Authority (4) The names of all members of the Authority, and every change of membership, shall be published in the Gazette.

9. Disqualification from membership A person shall be disqualified from being appointed as a member Authority if the person— (a) is a Member of Parliament; (b) is a Minister or Deputy Minister; (c) holds a position in a political party; (d) is an undischarged bankrupt; (e) has, within the last three years, been convicted by a competent court of a crime which is punishable with imprisonment without an option of a fine; (f) is a minor; or (g) holds or has a direct or indirect interest of five per cent shareholding in an entity holding a licence or authorization issued under this Act, or has any other direct or indirect financial interest in any licensee.
10. Chairperson of the Authority (1) The President shall appoint one of the members of the Authority as Chairperson.

10. Chairperson of the Authority (2) In the event of the office of the Chairperson becoming vacant, members of the Authority shall elect one amongst themselves to exercise the powers and perform the duties of the Chairperson, until a new Chairperson is appointed.

11. Tenure and vacation of office of members of the Authority (1) A member of the Authority, other than an ex officio member, shall hold office for a period of three years and shall be eligible for re-appointment for one more term.

11. Tenure and vacation of office of members of the Authority (2) Subject to section 13, the office of a member of the Authority, other than an ex officio member, shall become vacant— (a) if he resigns; (b) upon his death; (c) if he knowingly fails to declare a conflict of interest relating to any matter under consideration by the Authority; (d) if he has been absent from three consecutive meetings of the Authority, of which he has had prior notice, without a reasonable cause; (e) if he becomes, by reason of mental or physical infirmity, incapable of efficiently performing his duties as a member of the Authority; (f) if he becomes disqualified by reason of section 9; or (g) if he is guilty of conduct that brings disrepute to the Authority.

12. Filling of vacancies A vacancy on the membership of the Authority shall be filled by the appointment of a new member in accordance with section 7 as read with section 8, and the member so appointed shall hold office for the unexpired period of his predecessor’s term of office, but the vacancy may not be filled if the unexpired period is less than six months.

13. Removal from office of a member of the Authority A member of the Authority shall not be removed from office on grounds set out in section 11 (2) (c), (d), (e), (f), and (g), except after due inquiry, and only upon a decision of the appointing authority.

14. Meetings of the Authority (1) The Authority shall meet to conduct the business of the Board at least once every three months, at such places and times as the Chairperson may, in consultation with the Director General, determine.

14. Meetings of the Authority (2) The Chairperson of the Authority shall convene meetings of the Authority by giving the members at least seven days written notice, unless the Chairperson notifies the members in writing that the urgency of the matter to be discussed requires a shorter period of notice.
14. Meetings of the Authority (3) The quorum for any meeting of the Authority shall be two-thirds of all members of the Authority.

15. Committees of the Authority (1) The Authority may, for the purpose of performing its functions under this Act, establish committees of the Authority, and delegate to any such committees any of its functions as it considers necessary.
15. Committees of the Authority (2) The Chairperson of every committee shall be a person who is a member of the Authority, but an ex officio member shall not be a Chairperson.
15. Committees of the Authority (3) The Chairperson of the Authority shall not be a member of a committee.

15. Committees of the Authority (4) The Authority shall pay a member of a committee, from the funds of the Authority, an allowance that the Minister responsible for public service may, on recommendation of the Board, approve for attendance at meetings of the committee.

15. Committees of the Authority (5) Subject to the general or special directions of the Authority and to the provisions of this Act, every committee of the Authority shall have power to determine its own procedure.

16. Co-opted persons The Authority may, at its discretion, invite any person with specific knowledge, information or expertize to attend any of its meetings and address it on a matter, but such person shall not be eligible to vote at the meeting on any decision of the Authority.
17. Governance powers of the Authority Without prejudice to the generality of section 6, the Authority shall have the power to— (a) issue guidance, and give directions to the Director General;

17. Governance powers of the Authority Without prejudice to the generality of section 6, the Authority shall have the power to— (b) approve strategic plans, action plans and budget support programmes submitted by the Director General;

17. Governance powers of the Authority Without prejudice to the generality of section 6, the Authority shall have the power to— (c) approve annual reports and financial reports submitted by the Director General;

17. Governance powers of the Authority Without prejudice to the generality of section 6, the Authority shall have the power to— (d) hire consultants to assist the Authority in the discharge of its functions, where necessary; and

17. Governance powers of the Authority Without prejudice to the generality of section 6, the Authority shall have the power to— (e) issue rules, directives, opinions and make recommendations on any recurrent question related to the regulated missions of the Authority as defined under this Act.

18. Honoraria of members of the Authority (1) A member of the Authority shall be paid such allowances or other benefits as the Minister responsible for public service may, on recommendation of the Authority, from time to time, approve.
18. Honoraria of members of the Authority (2) The allowances and other benefits referred to in subsection (1) shall be paid from the funds of the Authority.

19. The Director General of the Authority (1) The Authority shall, appoint the Director General who shall be the chief executive officer of the Authority and shall, subject to the general supervision of the Authority, be responsible for the day to day operations of the Authority.

19. The Director General of the Authority (2) The Director General of the Authority shall be a person with sufficient experience and qualifications in any of the following areas— (a) communications industry; (b) finance; (c) economics; (d) engineering; (e) accountancy; (f) commerce; (g) law; or (h) administration, and shall be required to demonstrate knowledge and excellence in one or more of the areas of electronic communications, postal and broadcasting services.

20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (1) The Director General of the Authority shall be appointed to a term of office of three years, and may be re-appointed for further two terms of three years each.
20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (2) The Director General of the Authority shall be removed from office on any of the following grounds — (a) incompetence;

20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (2) The Director General of the Authority shall be removed from office on any of the following grounds — (b) misconduct that brings the Authority into disrepute;
20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (2) The Director General of the Authority shall be removed from office on any of the following grounds — (c) undischarged bankruptcy;
20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (2) The Director General of the Authority shall be removed from office on any of the following grounds — (d) non-disclosure of interest;

20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (2) The Director General of the Authority shall be removed from office on any of the following grounds — (e) if he has been convicted by a competent court of a crime which is punishable with imprisonment without an option of a fine;

20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (2) The Director General of the Authority shall be removed from office on any of the following grounds — (f) involvement in active politics; or

20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (2) The Director General of the Authority shall be removed from office on any of the following grounds — (g) incapability to perform his duties as Director General by reason of mental or physical infirmity.
20. Tenure of office of the Director General of the Authority (3) The Director General of the Authority shall not be removed from office unless he has been given an opportunity to be heard.

21. Powers and functions of the Director General of the Authority (1) The Director General of the Authority shall be in charge of the overall administration of the Authority and, in particular, shall have the following powers and functions— (a) implementing the decisions of the Authority;

21. Powers and functions of the Director General of the Authority (1) The Director General of the Authority shall be in charge of the overall administration of the Authority and, in particular, shall have the following powers and functions— (b) keeping the Authority informed of the activities of the Authority;

21. Powers and functions of the Director General of the Authority (1) The Director General of the Authority shall be in charge of the overall administration of the Authority and, in particular, shall have the following powers and functions— (c) submitting strategic plans, action plans and budget support programmes to the Authority for approval;

21. Powers and functions of the Director General of the Authority (1) The Director General of the Authority shall be in charge of the overall administration of the Authority and, in particular, shall have the following powers and functions— (d) implementing the strategic plans, action plans and budget support programmes;

21. Powers and functions of the Director General of the Authority (1) The Director General of the Authority shall be in charge of the overall administration of the Authority and, in particular, shall have the following powers and functions— (e) ensuring that activities of the Authority comply with the relevant laws, policies and regulations;
