ARTICLE 1
(Principle of legality)
1. Only the act described and declared punishable by law prior to the time of its commission may be criminally punished.
2. Security measures can only be applied to the states or the security measure that corresponds to them.
3. The use of analogy or interpretation is not permitted.

ARTICLE 2
(Application in time)
1. Penalties and security measures are determined according to the crime and the time of its commission.
2. Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph 4, whenever the criminal provisions in force at the time the act was committed differ from those established in subsequent laws, the regime that is specifically more favorable to the perpetrator shall apply. If a conviction has been handed down, even if final, the execution and its criminal effects shall cease as soon as the portion of the sentence that has been served reaches the maximum penalty limit provided for in the assumptions on which they depend.
3. When the act ceases to be a crime by virtue of a subsequent law, the conviction, even if final, shall not be executed or, if execution has already begun, the execution and all its effects shall cease immediately.
4. An act committed during the validity of a law that is in force only for a specific period or is to be in force during a period of emergency shall be judged under the terms of which Angola is a Party.

ARTICLE 3
(Time of the act)
The act is considered to have been committed at the time the agent acted or, in the case of omission, at the time he should have acted, regardless of the time at which the typical result occurred.

ARTICLE 4
(Place where the act was committed)
The act is considered to have been committed both in the place where, in whole or in part, the agent acted, and under any form of participation, or, in the case of omission, should have acted, and in the place where the typical result was obtained.

ARTICLE 5
(Subsidiary application of the Penal Code)
The rules of this Code apply to acts punishable by special legislation, unless otherwise provided.

ARTICLE 6
(Act and omission)
1. When a legal type comprises a certain result, the fact encompasses both the action appropriate to produce it and the omission of the action appropriate to avoid it.
2. The legal duty to act referred to in the previous paragraph arises from a contractual obligation to act, or when the person who fails to act has created a situation of danger to the legal interest by virtue of a previous action or omission.
3. In the event that the crime was committed by omission, the sentence may be specially mitigated.

ARTICLE 7
(Criminal liability of legal entities)
1. Legal persons, with the exception of the State and international organizations under public law, are susceptible to criminal liability.
2. Legal entities and similar entities, even if irregularly constituted, are liable for offences committed in their name, on their behalf and in their interest, or for their benefit, this, individually or in the performance of functions, by their bodies, representatives, or by persons holding a leadership position within them.
3. The legal persons referred to in the previous number are also liable for crimes committed in their name, on their behalf and in their interest, or for their benefit, by natural persons acting under the authority of the persons referred to in the previous number, whenever the crime has become possible due to a willful breach of the duties of supervision or control incumbent upon the latter.

ARTICLE 8
(Action and omission)
1. When a legal type comprises a certain result, the fact encompasses both the action appropriate to produce it and the omission of the action appropriate to avoid it.
3. The legal duty to act referred to in the previous paragraph arises from a contractual obligation to act, or when the person who fails to act has created a situation of danger to the legal interest by virtue of a previous action or omission.

ARTICLE 9
(Principle of legality)
1. Only the act described and declared punishable by law prior to the time of its commission may be criminally punished.
2. Security measures can only be applied to the states or the security measure that corresponds to them.
3. The use of analogy or interpretation is not permitted.

ARTICLE 10
(Acting on behalf of others)
Anyone who acts as a holder of bodies of a collective entity or in legal or voluntary representation of another person is punishable, even if the qualities or relationships required by the legal type of the crime do not concur with the person in whose name they act, but rather with the person in whose name they act.

ARTICLE 11
(Subjective imputation)
Only acts committed with intent or, in cases where especially provided for by law, with negligence.

ARTICLE 12
(Deception)
1. Acts with intent, in the form of intent, whoever, representing an act that constitutes a type of crime, acts with the intention of committing it.
2. Acts with intent, in the form of necessary intent, whoever represents the performance of an act that constitutes a type of crime as a necessary consequence of his or her conduct.
3. Acts with intent, in the form of eventual intent, whoever represents the realization of an act that constitutes a type of crime as a possible consequence of his conduct and, despite acting in conformity with that realization.

ARTICLE 13
(Neglect)
Anyone who acts negligently, by failing to exercise the care to which, according to the circumstances, he is obliged and capable:
1. Representing as possible the realization of an act that constitutes a type of crime and acting without conforming to that realization; 2. Not even representing the possibility of that act being carried out.

ARTICLE 14
(Error about the circumstances of the fact)
1. An error in the elements, of fact or law, of a strong type of crime excludes intent.
2. The provisions of the previous number cover the error about a state of affairs which, if it existed, would exclude the unlawfulness of the fact.
3. The punishability of negligence is reserved, under the terms we see Articles 11 and 13 making a decision.

ARTICLE 15
(Error about unlawfulness)
1. He who acts without awareness of the unlawfulness of the act acts without guilt, if the error is not reprehensible to him.
2. If in any of the cases provided for in the previous numbers, the error is reprehensible, the agent shall be punished with the penalty applicable to the respective intentional crime, which may be specially mitigated.
3. An error is reprehensible when, given the circumstances, it is reasonable to demand other behavior from the agent.

ARTICLE 16
(Aggravation of the penalty by the result)
When the penalty applicable to an act is increased by a result, pre-conditioned by the possibility of imputing that result to the agent, at least, as negligence.

ARTICLE 17
(Imputability due to age)
1. Criminal liability is acquired, without prejudice to the following numbers, at 16 years of age.
2. Minors under the age of 16 are subject to the jurisdiction of the Juvenile Courts and, in relation to them, only assistance, education or correction measures provided for in special legislation may be taken.

ARTICLE 18
(Non-imputability due to mental anomaly)
1. Anyone who, due to a mental anomaly, is incapable, at the time of committing the act, of assessing its unlawfulness or of making a decision in accordance with that, is not liable for criminal liability.
2. Imputability is not excluded when the mental anomaly was caused by the agent with the intention of committing the act.
3. The Court may, in particular, mitigate the sentence when the perpetrator, due to a serious mental disorder at the time of committing the act, has significantly reduced capacity to assess the unlawfulness of the act or to make a decision in accordance with that assessment.

ARTICLE 19
(Preparatory acts)
1. Preparatory acts are external acts intended to facilitate or prepare the execution of the act, but which do not yet constitute the beginning of execution under the terms of the following article.
2. Preparatory acts are not punishable, unless otherwise provided.

ARTICLE 20
(Attempt)
1. There is an attempt when the agent intentionally carries out acts of execution of a crime, without it reaching consummation.
2. The following are acts of execution:
a) Those that fulfill a constitutive element of a type of crime; b) Those who are suitable for producing the typical result; c) Those which, according to common experience and except in unforeseeable circumstances, are of a nature to give rise to the expectation that acts of the types indicated in the previous paragraphs will follow.

ARTICLE 21
(Punishable attempt)
1. Unless otherwise provided, an attempt is only punishable if the completed crime in question carries a penalty of more than 3 years' imprisonment.
2. The attempt is punishable by the penalty applicable to the completed crime, especially mitigated.
3. The attempt is not punishable when it is manifest:
a) The ineptitude of the means employed by the agent; b) The absence of the essential object for consummation of the crime.

ARTICLE 22
(Withdrawal)
1. An attempt is not punishable when the perpetrator voluntarily desists from continuing with the execution of the crime or prevents its completion, or even when, despite the circumstances independent of the conduct of the person desisting, the attempt is not punishable if he makes a serious effort to avoid one or the other.
2. In the case referred to in the previous number: a) If there is a relationship of specialty between the incriminating norms, the special incriminating norm shall apply; b) In other cases, the incriminating rule that establishes the most serious penalty applies.

ARTICLE 23
(Withdrawal in case of co-participation)
If several agents participate in the act, the attempt of the one who voluntarily prevents the act is not punishable.

ARTICLE 24
(Authorship)
The following are punishable as perpetrators:
a) Carry out the act, by himself; b) Execute the act, using as an instrument another person; c) Taking direct part in its execution, by agreement or together with another person or others; d) Intentionally instructing another person to carry out the act, provided that there is execution or the beginning of execution.

ARTICLE 25
(Complicity)
1. Anyone who, outside the cases provided for in the previous article, directly and intentionally provides material or moral assistance to the commission by another of a willful act is punishable as an accomplice.

ARTICLE 26
(Unlawfulness of co-participation)
1. The special qualities or relations of the agent, especially attenuated, to the other participants for the purpose of determining the penalty applicable to them, unless the law intends otherwise or something different results from the nature of the crime.

ARTICLE 27
(Guilt in participation)
Each participant is punished according to their guilt, regardless of the punishment or degree of guilt of the other participants.

ARTICLE 28
(Crime competition)
1. The number of crimes is determined by the number of types of crime actually completed, or by the number of times the same type of crime is committed by the agent's conduct.
2. There is no competition of crimes when the fact is, as a whole, criminal incrimination.
3. In the case referred to in the previous number:
a) If there is a relationship of specialty between the incriminating norms, the special incriminating norm shall apply; b) In other cases, the incriminating rule that establishes the most serious penalty applies.

ARTICLE 29
(Continuing crime)
1. The multiple commission of the same type of crime or of several types of crime that fundamentally offend the same legal interest, carried out in an essentially homogeneous manner and within the context of the solicitation of an external situation that considerably reduces the guilt of the perpetrator, constitutes a single continuing crime.
2. The provisions of the previous paragraph do not cover crimes committed against eminently personal property, unless the offended party is the same.

ARTICLE 30
(Exclusion of illegality)
1. The act is not punishable when its unlawfulness is excluded by the legal system considered in its entirety.
2. The act committed in the following cases is not unlawful:
a) In self-defense; b) In the exercise of a right; c) In compliance with a duty imposed by law or by legitimate order of an authority; d) With the consent of the holder of the injured legal interest.

ARTICLE 31
(Self-defense)
1. The act carried out as a necessary means to repel the current and unlawful aggression of the legally protected interests of the agent or third party constitutes legitimate defense.
2. If there is an excess of the means employed in self-defense, the act is unlawful, but the penalty may be specially mitigated.

ARTICLE 32
(State of necessity)
An act carried out as an appropriate means of averting a current danger that threatens the legally protected interests of the agent or third party is not unlawful, when:
a) The dangerous situation was not voluntarily created by the agent, except in the case of protecting the interests of a third party; b) There is a clear superiority of the interest to safeguard; c) It is reasonable to require the injured party to sacrifice his or her interest in light of the nature or value of the threatened interest.

ARTICLE 33
(Excusing state of necessity)
1. Anyone who commits an unlawful act intended to avert a present danger, not otherwise amenable, that threatens the life, physical integrity, honor or freedom of the perpetrator or a third party, when it is not reasonable to demand different behavior from him, according to the circumstances of the case, acts without guilt.
2. If the danger threatens legal interests other than those mentioned therein, the penalty may be specially mitigated.

ARTICLE 34
(Consent of the injured party)
1. In addition to the cases specifically provided for by law, the consent of the injured party excludes the unlawfulness of the act when it refers to freely available interests and the act is not contrary to good customs and the dignity of the human person.
2. Consent may be expressed by any means that reflects a serious, free and informed will of the holder of the legally protected interest and may be freely revoked until the act is carried out.
3. If the consent is not known to the agent, he is punishable with the penalty applicable to the attempt.

ARTICLE 35
(Presumed consent)
1. Consent is presumed when the situation in which the agent acts reasonably allows us to assume that the holder consented to the act, if he had known the circumstances in which it was carried out.
2. Presumed consent is equivalent to consent.

ARTICLE 36
(Excessive self-defense excusing)
Anyone who exceeds the means employed in self-defense acts without guilt, whenever the excess results from non-censorable disturbance, fear or fright.

ARTICLE 37
(Excusing state of necessity)
1. Anyone who commits an unlawful act intended to avert a present danger, not otherwise amenable, that threatens the life, physical integrity, honor or freedom of the perpetrator or a third party, when it is not reasonable to demand different behavior from him, according to the circumstances of the case, acts without guilt.
2. If the danger threatens legal interests other than those mentioned therein, the penalty may be specially mitigated.

ARTICLE 38
(Fulfillment of legal duties or legitimate orders)
1. The duty to obey an order from a superior to a subordinate ceases when compliance with the order leads to the commission of any crime.
2. The provisions of the previous number apply to anyone who fulfills a duty of lesser value and, as a consequence of that fulfillment, commits an unlawful act, whenever, in view of the circumstances of the case, it is not reasonable to demand any other behavior from the agent.

ARTICLE 39
(Sanctions)
The sanctions of the Penal Code are those established in the following numbers of this article.
1. Main penalties:
a) Imprisonment; b) Fine.
2. Replacement penalties:
a) Fine; b) Provision of work for the benefit of the community; c) Suspension of the execution of the prison sentence; d) Admonition.
3. Additional penalties:
a) Prohibition from exercising a function; b) Suspension from the exercise of duties; c) Prohibition on driving motor vehicles; d) Expulsion from national territory.
4. Security Measures:
a) Hospitalization; b) Suspension of the execution of the internment; c) Prohibition of activities; d) Revocation of the vehicle driving license; e) Prohibition of granting a motor vehicle driving license; f) Revocation of firearms license; g) Deprivation of the right to subsidies, grants or incentives; h) Loss of illicit profits obtained from criminal activity; i) Loss of assets acquired with the illicit profits of criminal activity; j) Prohibition of carrying out activities; k) Closure of establishment.

ARTICLE 40
(Purposes of penalties and security measures)
1. The application of penalties and security measures aims to protect legal assets essential to the subsistence of the community and the reintegration of the offender into society.
2. The execution of the prison sentence must be aimed at the reintegration of the prisoner into society, preparing him to lead his life in a socially responsible manner, without committing crimes.
3. The execution of the prison sentence also serves the defense of society, preventing the commission of crimes.
4. Convicted persons to whom a sentence or security measure involving deprivation of liberty is applied retain the right to fundamental rights, subject to the limitations inherent in the meaning of the sentence and the requirements specific to its execution.
5. The execution of the prison sentence and the security measure of internment is regulated in specific legislation.

ARTICLE 41
(General rules)
1. There may be no death penalty or perpetual custodial sentences or security measures.
2. The application of penalties or security measures may not, under any circumstances, serve to subject the convicted person to torture or cruel, degrading or inhuman treatment.
3. Penalties are not susceptible of transmission.

ARTICLE 42
(Assumptions and limits of penalties and security measures)
1. Guilt is an inalienable prerequisite for the application of any penalty.
2. Under no circumstances may the punishment exceed the extent of the guilt.
3. Criminal danger is an indispensable prerequisite for the application of any security measure.
4. The security measure may only be applied if it is proportionate to the seriousness of the act and the dangerousness of the perpetrator.

ARTICLE 43
(Penalties applicable to legal entities)
1. They are applicable to legal persons and equivalent entities.
2. For the same crimes, the following additional penalties may be applied to legal persons and similar entities:
a) Publication of the final conviction; b) Good conduct bond; c) Judicial injunction; d) Prohibition on entering into certain contracts or on them entering into agreements with certain entities; e) Deprivation of the right to subsidies, grants or incentives; f) Loss of illicit profits obtained from criminal activity; g) Loss of assets acquired with the illicit profits of criminal activity; h) Prohibition of carrying out activities; i) Closure of establishment.
3. If the legal person or equivalent entity commits a crime punishable by a fine exceeding 240 Procedural Reference Units, the Court may rehabilitate the legal person or equivalent entity if it has conducted itself, for a period of five years after serving the main sentence, in a way that makes it reasonable to assume that it will not commit new crimes.

ARTICLE 44
(Duration of prison sentence)
1. The prison sentence has, as a rule, a minimum duration of 3 months and a maximum duration of 25 years.
2. Under no circumstances, even if due to recidivism, concurrent crimes or extension of the sentence, may the sentence exceed the maximum limit of 35 years.
3. The counting of prison terms is carried out according to the criteria established in the criminal procedural law and, in its absence, in the Civil Law.

ARTICLE 45
(Replacement of imprisonment with a fine)
1. Imprisonment for a period not exceeding 6 months shall be replaced by an equal number of days' fine or by another applicable non-custodial penalty, except if the execution of the imprisonment is required by the need to prevent the commission of future crimes, in which case the provisions of Article 47 shall apply accordingly.
2. If the fine is not paid, the convicted person shall serve the prison sentence imposed in the sentence, and the provisions of paragraph 3 of article 49 shall apply accordingly.

ARTICLE 46
(Penalties applicable to legal entities)
1. They are applicable to legal persons and equivalent entities.
2. For the same crimes, the following additional penalties may be applied to legal persons and similar entities:
a) Publication of the final conviction; b) Good conduct bond; c) Judicial injunction; d) Prohibition on entering into certain contracts or on them entering into agreements with certain entities; e) Deprivation of the right to subsidies, grants or incentives; f) Loss of illicit profits obtained from criminal activity; g) Loss of assets acquired with the illicit profits of criminal activity; h) Prohibition of carrying out activities; i) Closure of establishment.

ARTICLE 47
(Fine penalty)
1. Each day of fine corresponds to an amount between 75 Procedural Reference Units and 750 Procedural Reference Units.
2. The Court may, in the case of imprisonment for a period not exceeding 5 months, which has not been replaced by a fine, determine, with the consent of the convicted person, that the sentence be served in punishment.

ARTICLE 48
(Replacement of fine with work)
1. At the request of the convicted person, the Court may order replacement by days of work to be provided to the State or other legal entities under public law, or even to private social solidarity institutions, when it is concluded that this form of compliance adequately and parly fulfills.

ARTICLE 49
(Conversion of unpaid fine into subsidiary imprisonment)
1. If the fine, which has not been replaced by work, is not paid voluntarily or coercively, it shall be converted into subsidiary imprisonment for the corresponding period reduced by two thirds, even if the crime is not punishable by imprisonment, and the minimum limit of days of imprisonment set out in paragraph 1 of article 44 shall not apply for this purpose.
2. The convicted person may at any time avoid, in whole or in part, the execution of subsidiary imprisonment, by paying, in whole or in part, the fine to which he was sentenced.

ARTICLE 50
(Assumptions and duration)
1. The Court may suspend the execution of the imprisonment imposed for a period not exceeding 3 years if, taking into account the personality of the perpetrator, the conditions of his life, his conduct prior to and after the crime and the circumstances thereof, it concludes that the censure of the act and the threat of imprisonment punishment.

ARTICLE 51
(Duties)
1. The suspension of the execution of the prison sentence may be subject to the fulfillment of duties imposed on the convicted person and intended to repair the harm caused by the crime, namely:
a) Pay within a certain period, in full or in the part that the Court considers possible, the compensation due to the injured party, or guarantee its payment by means of suitable security; b) Give the injured party adequate moral satisfaction; c) Deliver to public or private institutions, social solidarity or to the State a contribution monetary contribution or payment in kind of equivalent value.
2. The duties imposed may under no circumstances represent obligations for the convicted person whose fulfillment cannot reasonably be required of him.

ARTICLE 52
(Rules of conduct)
1. The Court may require the convicted person to comply, for the duration of the suspension, with rules of conduct designed to facilitate his or her reintegration into society.
2. The Court may also, having obtained the prior consent of the convicted person, order that the latter undergo medical treatment or be cured in an appropriate institution.

ARTICLE 53
(Failure to comply with the conditions of suspension)
If, during the period of suspension, the convicted person, through culpability, fails to comply with any of the duties or rules of conduct imposed, the Court may:
a) Issue a warning; b) Demand guarantees of compliance with the obligations that condition the suspension; c) Impose new duties or rules of conduct, or introduce additional requirements into the readaptation plan; d) Extend the suspension period up to half of the prison closest to the convicted person's home or, with the convicted person's agreement, in any other establishment, police or otherwise.

ARTICLE 54
(Revocation of suspension)
1. The suspension of the execution of the prison sentence is revoked whenever, during the execution of the prison sentence, the convicted person:
a) Grossly or repeatedly breach the duties or rules of conduct imposed; b) Commit a crime for which he may be convicted and is punished; c) Commit a crime for which he or she may be convicted; and the suspension of the sentence could not be achieved through it.
2. Revocation determines the fulfillment of the prison sentence.

ARTICLE 55
(Extinction of the penalty)
1. The penalty shall be declared extinguished if, after the end of the suspension period whenever relevant supervening circumstances occur or of which the Court only became aware, the penalty is declared extinguished.

ARTICLE 56
(Provision of work in favor of the community)
1. If the offender is given a prison sentence of no more than 1 year, the Court shall replace this sentence with community service whenever it concludes that, by this means, the services are carried out in an appropriate manner.
2. The provision of work for the benefit of the community consists of the provision of free services to the State, to other legal entities under public law, or to private social solidarity institutions.

ARTICLE 57
(Suspension, revocation, termination and replacement)
1. The provision of work for the benefit of the community may be suspended for serious medical, family, or other reasons.
2. The Court shall revoke the penalty of community service and order the execution of the prison sentence determined in the sentence if the offender, after conviction:
a) Intentionally placing oneself in a situation where one is unable to work; b) Refuse, without just cause, to perform work or grossly violate the duties arising from the sentence to which he was sentenced; c) Commit a crime for which he may be convicted and of which the performance of community service in favor of the community could not be achieved through it.

ARTICLE 58
(Judicial admonition)
1. If the offender is subject to a fine of no more than 120 days, the Court may limit itself to issuing a judicial warning.
2. A judicial reprimand consists of a solemn oral reprimand given in a hearing by the Court to the legal representative of the legal person or equivalent entity or, in their absence, to another person who occupies a leadership position within it.

ARTICLE 59
(Assumptions and duration)
1. The application of conditional release always depends on the consent of the convicted person.
2. The Court shall release the person sentenced to prison on parole when half of the sentence has been served and at least 6 months have passed, if:
a) It is reasonably expected, given the circumstances of the case, the previous life of the offender, his personality and its evolution during the execution of the prison sentence, that the convicted person, once released, will lead his life in a socially responsible manner, without committing new crimes; b) The liberation proves to be compatible with the defense of the legal order and social peace.
3. The Court shall release the person sentenced to prison on parole when two-thirds of the sentence has been served and at least 6 months have passed, provided that the requirements set out in paragraph a) of the previous number has been met.
4. In the case of a sentence of more than 5 years' imprisonment for a crime against persons or a crime of common danger, conditional release may only take place when two-thirds of the sentence have been served.

ARTICLE 60
(Conditional release in the case of successive execution of several sentences)
1. If several prison sentences are to be served, the execution of the sentence to be served first shall be interrupted:
a) When half of the sentence has been served, in the case of paragraph 2 of the previous article; b) When two-thirds of the sentence have been served, in the cases referred to in paragraph 4 of the previous article.
2. In the cases provided for in the previous paragraph, the Court shall decide on conditional release at the time when it can do so, simultaneously, in relation to all sentences.

ARTICLE 61
(Regime)
The provisions of Article 52 and Article 53(a), (b) and (c) shall apply correspondingly to conditional release.

ARTICLE 62
(Revocation and termination of parole)
1. The provisions of paragraph 1 of Article 54 and Article 55, respectively, shall apply correspondingly to the revocation and termination of conditional release.
2. Revocation of parole determines the execution of the prison sentence not yet served.
3. In relation to the prison sentence that has been served, a new conditional release may be granted under the terms of Article 59.

ARTICLE 63
(Inadmissibility of parole)
1. The following crimes are not eligible for parole:
a) Genocide; b) Crimes against humanity; c) War crimes; d) Sexual crimes against minors under 14 years of age.
2. The following crimes against State security are also not eligible for parole:
a) Attack on the life of the President of the Republic, Holders of Sovereign Bodies, the Vice-President, President of the Republic and the Attorney General of the Republic; b) High treason; c) Crimes of terrorism, punishable by imprisonment of 8 years or older; d) Armed rebellion, punishable by a prison sentence of 15 years or more; e) Sabotage, punishable by a prison sentence of 10 years or more, which endangers the territorial integrity or independence of the Country; f) Espionage, punishable by a prison sentence equal to or over 16 years old.

ARTICLE 64
(Prohibition of holding office or function)
1. The holder of public office, public servant or agent of the Public Administration who, in the exercise of the activity for which he was elected or appointed, commits a crime and is sentenced to a prison sentence of more than 3 years, is also prohibited from exercising those functions for a period of up to 3 years when the fact:
a) Is punished: the function or with a clear and serious violation of the duties inherent to it; b) Reveal a lack of dignity in the exercise of the position or function.

ARTICLE 65
(Suspension of the exercise of functions)
1. Whoever is not disciplinarily dismissed from a public function that he performs, incurs suspension of the function for the duration of the sentence.
2. The suspension provided for in the previous paragraph is linked to the effects that, in accordance with the respective legislation, accompany the disciplinary sanction of suspension from the exercise of functions.

ARTICLE 66
(Effects of the prohibition and suspension of the exercise of functions)
1. Unless otherwise provided, the prohibition and suspension of the exercise of a public function determine the loss of the rights and benefits attributed to the holder, employee or agent, for the corresponding period.
2. The provisions of the previous numbers are correspondingly dependent on a public title or authorization or approval from the public authority.

ARTICLE 67
(Prohibition on driving motor vehicles)
1. He is sentenced to a ban on driving motor vehicles when he is sentenced to a ban on driving motor vehicles.
2. The prohibition takes effect from the moment the decision becomes final and may cover the driving of motor vehicles of any category or of a specific category.
3. The prohibition is communicated to the competent services and implies that the convicted person who holds a driving license must hand it over to the Court Registry or any police station, which must immediately forward it to that Registry.
4. If the license has been issued in a foreign country, delivery is replaced by a note, on the said license, of the decreed prohibition.
5. If the license has been revoked or the respective concession is banned, in accordance with articles 111 and 112.

ARTICLE 68
(Expulsion from national territory)
1. The accessory penalty of expulsion may be applied to a foreign citizen not resident in the country, convicted of an intentional crime with a sentence of more than six months' imprisonment or a fine as an alternative to a prison sentence of more than six months.
2. The same penalty may be imposed on a foreign citizen residing in the country, convicted of an intentional crime with a sentence of more than one year in prison, although the gravity of the acts committed by the defendant, his personality, possible recidivism, the degree of integration into social life, special prevention and the period of residence in Angola must be taken into account in its application.
3. Without prejudice to the provisions of the previous paragraph, the additional penalty of expulsion may only be applied to a foreign citizen with permanent residence, when his or her conduct constitutes a danger or serious threat to public order, security or national defense.
4. If the additional penalty of expulsion is decreed, the Judge of Sentence Enforcement shall order its execution as soon as the following have been fulfilled:
a) Half of the sentence, in cases of conviction to a penalty equal to or less than five years in prison; b) Two-thirds of the sentence, in cases of conviction with a sentence exceeding five years in prison.
5. The Judge of Sentence Enforcement may, upon a reasoned proposal from the Director of the Prison Establishment, and without opposition from the convicted person, decide to bring forward the execution of the accessory penalty of expulsion as soon as one third of the sentence has been served, in cases of conviction for a sentence of five years' imprisonment or less and provided that the remainder of the sentence is guaranteed to be served in the country of destination.
6. The expulsion is carried out, causing the citizen to return to the country of origin or habitual residence.

ARTICLE 69
(Criteria for choosing the penalty)
If, alternatively, a custodial sentence and a non-custodial sentence are applicable to the crime, the Court will give preference to the second, provided that it is carried out in a manner prevention requirements.

ARTICLE 70
(Determination of the penalty)
1. The determination of the extent of the sentence, within the limits, considering, in particular:
a) The degree of unlawfulness of the act, the manner in which it was carried out and the severity of its consequences, as well as the degree of violation of the duties imposed on the agent; b) The intensity of the intent or negligence; c) The feelings expressed in the commission of the crime; d) The agent's personal conditions and economic situation; e) Conduct prior to and after the act, especially when this is considered in the measure of the penalty applicable to the crime in relation to which it was applied.

ARTICLE 71
(Circumstances relevant to determining the penalty)
1. Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph 3 of the previous article, the only aggravating circumstances are the fact that the offender committed the crime:
a) For a futile reason; b) By means of reward, remuneration or its promise; c) For discrimination based on race, color, ethnicity, place of birth, sex, sexual orientation, belief or religion, political or ideological convictions, social status or origin or any other forms of discrimination; d) To facilitate or ensure the execution, concealment, impunity or advantage of another crime; e) By treason, ambush, treachery or any other fraud; f) By poison, fire, explosives, torture or any cruel means or means that could result in common danger; g) Against ascendants, descendants, relatives up to the degree or person in a similar situation; h) With abuse of authority or the agent taking advantage of domestic relations, cohabitation or hospitality; i) With abuse of power or violation of inherent duty; j) Against children, elderly people or pregnant women; k) With the participation of a child; l) When the injured party was under the immediate protection of the authorities; m) In the event of fire, shipwreck, flood, any public calamity or personal misfortune of the injured party; n) With the participation of one or more people; o) At night or in a deserted place; p) With superior weapons.

ARTICLE 72
(Mitigating circumstances)
1. Mitigating circumstances are those that reduce the unlawfulness of the act, the guilt of the perpetrator or the need for punishment, namely:
a) The agent's conduct was determined by an honorable age; b) The agent's conduct was determined by an honorable motive, by strong temptation or request from the victim himself or by unfair provocation or undeserved offense; c) There have been acts demonstrating sincere repentance on the part of the agent, namely the reparation, to the extent possible, of the damages caused; d) A lot of time has passed since the practice of crime, with the agent maintaining good conduct; e) The agent has provided relevant services to the company; f) The conduct must have been based on cultural values, uses and customs, provided that they are not contrary to the Constitution nor violate the dignity of the human person; g) Any other mitigating circumstances that precede, accompany or follow the crime.

ARTICLE 73
(Special mitigation of sentence)
1. The Court shall specifically mitigate the sentence, in addition to the cases specifically provided for by law, when there are circumstances prior to, contemporaneous with or subsequent to the crime, which significantly reduce the unlawfulness of the act, the guilt of the perpetrator or the need for the sentence.
2. Only once may a circumstance be taken into account which, by itself or in conjunction with others, gives rise simultaneously to a mitigation specifically provided for by law and that established in this article.

ARTICLE 74
(Terms of special mitigation)
1. Whenever there is room for special mitigation of the sentence, the following shall be observed with regard to the limits of the applicable sentence:
a) The maximum prison sentence is reduced by one third; b) The minimum prison sentence is reduced to one fifth if it is equal to or greater than 3 years, and to the legal minimum if it is less; c) The maximum limit of the fine is reduced by one third and the minimum limit is reduced.

ARTICLE 75
(Exemption from punishment)
1. When the crime is punishable by a prison sentence of not more than 6 months, or by a fine of not more than 120 days, the Court may find the defendant guilty, but not apply any penalty, if:
a) The unlawfulness of the act and the guilt of the agent are minimal; b) The damage has been repaired; c) The exemption from punishment is not opposed by reasons of prevention.

ARTICLE 76
(Assumptions of recidivism)
1. Anyone who, alone or through any form of participation, commits an intentional crime punishable by a prison sentence of more than 1 year, after having been convicted by a final judgment to an effective prison sentence of more than 1 year for another intentional crime, shall be punished as a repeat offender if, according to the circumstances of the case, the perpetrator is to be considered ensured because the previous conviction or convictions did not.

ARTICLE 77
(Effects of recidivism)
1. In the event of a repeat offense, the minimum penalty applicable to the crime is increased by one third and the maximum penalty remains unchanged.
2. The aggravation referred to in the previous paragraph cannot exceed the measure of the most severe penalty applied in previous convictions.

ARTICLE 78
(Contest Punishment Rules)
1. When someone has committed several crimes before the sentence has become final, the conviction for any of them results in a single sentence.
2. The maximum limit of the single applicable penalty is the sum of the penalties specifically applied to the various crimes, and may not exceed 35 years in the case of a prison sentence and 900 days in the case of a fine.

ARTICLE 79
(Supervening knowledge of the competition)
1. If, after a final conviction, but before the respective sentence is served, prescribed or extinguished, it is shown that the agent committed, prior to that conviction, another crime or crimes, the rules of the previous article shall apply.
2. The provisions of the previous paragraph shall also apply where all crimes have been separately subject to final convictions.
3. The additional penalties and security measures applied in the previous sentence remain in place, unless they are deemed unnecessary in view of the new decision.

ARTICLE 80
(Punishment of continuing crime)
A continuing crime is punishable by the penalty applicable to the most serious conduct that constitutes the continuation.

ARTICLE 81
(Previous sentence)
1. If the penalty imposed by a final decision is subsequently replaced by another, the previous penalty shall be discounted from this, to the extent that it has already been served.
2. If the previous and subsequent penalties are of a different nature, the discount that appears equitable shall be applied to the new penalty.

ARTICLE 82
(Previous sentence)
2. The provisions of paragraph 2 of the previous article shall apply accordingly.

ARTICLE 83
(Restrictions)
1. If the crimes are committed before the offender has reached the age of 25, the provisions of Articles 84 and 85 shall only apply if the offender has served a minimum of 1 year in prison.
2. The period referred to in paragraph 2 of article 85 is, for the purposes of the provisions of this article, 3 years.

ARTICLE 84
(Extension of sentence)
The effective prison sentence imposed on an alcoholic or person with a tendency to abuse alcoholic beverages is extended for two successive periods of three years if:
a) The offender has previously committed a crime for which effective imprisonment was also applied; b) The crimes were committed while intoxicated or are related to alcoholism or the tendency of the perpetrator; c) The extension is necessary to eliminate the perpetrator's alcoholism or combat his tendency to abuse alcoholic beverages.

ARTICLE 85
(Other cases of extension of sentence)
1. The effective prison sentence for the commission of an intentional crime is extended for two successive periods of 3 years if:
a) The offender has previously committed four or more intentional crimes, each of which has also been subject to an effective prison sentence.

ARTICLE 86
(Judicial admonition)
1. If a fine of no more than 60 days is to be applied to a legal person or equivalent entity, the Court may limit itself to issuing a judicial warning, if the damage has been repaired and the legal person has not been convicted of any crime in the three years prior to the act.

ARTICLE 87
(Assumptions and effects)
1. The effective prison sentence for the commission of an intentional crime, exceeding 2 years, is extended for two successive periods of 3 years, if:
a) The offender has previously committed two or more intentional crimes, each of which has been subject to effective imprisonment for more than 2 years; b) Upon expiry of the sentence or the first extension, it is reasonably expected, taking into account the circumstances of the case, the previous life of the offender, his personality and its evolution during the execution of the prison sentence, that the convicted person, once released, will not lead his life in a socially responsible manner, without committing crimes.

ARTICLE 88
(Drug abuse)
The provisions of Article 87 shall apply accordingly.

ARTICLE 89
(Parole)
The provisions of Articles 59 to 63 shall apply to cases subject to extension of the sentence.

ARTICLE 90
(Judicial admonition)
1. If a fine of no more than 60 days is to be applied to a legal person or equivalent entity, the Court may limit itself to issuing a judicial warning, if the damage has been repaired and the legal person has not been convicted of any crime in the three years prior to the act.

ARTICLE 91
(Fine penalty for legal entities)
1. Each day of fine corresponds to an amount between 114 Procedural Reference Units and 113,636 Units.
2. The Court may authorize payment of the fine within a period not exceeding one year, or allow payment in installments, the last of which may not exceed two years following the date on which the conviction becomes final.

ARTICLE 92
(Penalty of dissolution)
The penalty of dissolution is decreed by the Court when the legal person or equivalent entity has been created with the exclusive or predominant intention of committing the crimes indicated in this Law or when the repeated commission of such crimes shows that the legal person or equivalent entity is being used, exclusively or predominantly, for that purpose, by whoever occupies a leadership position within it.

ARTICLE 93
(Advertising of the conviction)
1. Whenever necessary for the useful effect of the penalty applied, for the reparation of the damage caused by the crime, for the protection of the assets and interests affected by the violated norm, and to the progress of the science of criminal law and to the fundamental guidelines of modern criminal policy, the Court orders the publication of the conviction decision, at the expense of the convicted person, in a media outlet or notice, for a period of no less than 30 days, at the commercial or industrial establishment itself or at the place of exercise of the activity, in a manner clearly visible to the public.
2. The publication of the conviction decision is made by extract, which contains the elements of the offence and the consequences of the act and its burden on workers collective or similar entities.

ARTICLE 94
(Good conduct bond)
1. If a fine of no more than 120 days should be applied to a legal person or equivalent entity, the Court may replace it with a good conduct bond of between 1,136 Procedural Reference Units and 1,136,364 Procedural Reference Units, for a period of one to five years.
2. The security deposit shall be declared forfeited in favor of the State if the legal person or equivalent entity commits a new crime for which it is convicted during the term, being returned to him in the opposite case.
3. The security deposit may be made by means of a deposit.

ARTICLE 95
(Judicial injunction)
1. The Court may order the legal person or equivalent entity to adopt certain measures, in particular those necessary to cease the unlawful activity or avoid its consequences.
2. The Court shall determine the period within which the injunction must be fulfilled from the moment the sentence becomes final.

ARTICLE 96
(Prohibition on entering into contracts)
The prohibition on entering into certain contracts or agreements with certain entities applies, for a period of 1 to 5 years, to the legal person or equivalent entity.

ARTICLE 97
(Deprivation of the right to subsidies, grants or incentives)
The deprivation of the right to subsidies, grants or incentives granted by the State and other public legal entities is applicable, for a period of 1 to 5 years, to the legal entity or equivalent entity.

ARTICLE 98
(Loss of assets and profits from crime)
For the purposes of the loss of assets and the benefits of crime, the provisions of articles 120 to 123 shall apply, with the necessary adaptations.

ARTICLE 99
(Prohibition of carrying out activity)
1. The Court may order a ban on the exercise of certain activities for a period of three months to five years, when the crime was committed whilst exercising such activities.
2. When a legal person or equivalent entity commits a crime punishable by a fine exceeding 240 certain activities.

ARTICLE 100
(Closure of establishment)
1. The closure of an establishment may be ordered by the Court, for a period of three months to five years, when the offence was committed within the scope of the respective activity.
2. When a legal person or equivalent entity commits a crime punishable by a fine exceeding 240 of the establishment.

ARTICLE 101
(Assumptions and minimum duration)
1. Anyone who has committed a typical unlawful act and is considered not responsible, under the terms of Article 18, shall be ordered by the Court to be admitted to a cure, treatment or security establishment, whenever, due to the mental anomaly and the gravity of the act committed, there is a well-founded fear that he or she will commit other acts of the same nature.
2. When the act committed by the non-imputable person corresponds to a crime against people or a crime of common danger punishable by a prison sentence of more than 5 years, the internment has a minimum duration of 3 years, unless release proves to be compatible with the defense of the legal order and social peace.

ARTICLE 102
(Termination and extension of hospitalization)
1. Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph 2 of the previous article, the termination of internment, the Court considers the matter at any time.
2. The internment cannot exceed the maximum penalty limit corresponding to the type of crime committed by the non-imputable person.
3. If the risk of new acts of the same nature occurring is so serious that release is inadvisable, the internment may be extended, by judicial decision, for another period of up to 3 years if, enacted the measure.

ARTICLE 103
(Review of the patient's situation)
1. The assessment is mandatory, regardless of any request, after 2 years have passed since the start of the hospitalization or the decision that maintained it.
2. The provisions of paragraphs 3 and 4 of Article 108 shall apply accordingly.

ARTICLE 104
(Freedom to test)
1. If the review referred to in the previous article results in has been achieved in an open environment, the Court releases the internee for testing.
2. The review referred to in the previous article results in the termination of internment if the conditions that gave rise to it no longer subsist.

ARTICLE 105
(Revocation of freedom for evidence)
1. Freedom to test is revoked when:
a) The agent's behavior reveals that hospitalization is essential; b) The agent is sentenced to a custodial sentence and may, that the agent has been convicted and discounted therefrom.

ARTICLE 106
(Review of the internment measure)
1. The implementation of the internment security measure cannot begin after 2 years or more have passed since the decision that decreed it, without assessing the subsistence of the assumptions that justified its application.

ARTICLE 107
(Non-imputable foreigners)
Without prejudice to the provisions of an international treaty or convention, the measure of internment of a non-imputable foreigner may be replaced by expulsion from the national territory, under terms regulated by special legislation.

ARTICLE 108
(Assumptions and regime)
1. The Court which orders the internment shall, in its place, order the suspension of the execution if it is reasonably requested of the interdict, that the assumptions for the application of those no longer subsist, the measure is declared extinct.
2. In the case provided for in paragraph 2 of article 101, the suspension of the execution of the internment cannot be decreed if the agent is simultaneously sentenced respective personification.

ARTICLE 109
(Regime)
1. The internment measure is executed before the sentence to be enacted the measure.
2. As soon as the internment measure must cease, the Court shall release the offender on parole if the time corresponding to half of the sentence has been served and the release proves to be compatible with the defense of the legal order and social peace.

ARTICLE 110
(Prohibition of activities)
1. Anyone convicted of a crime committed with serious intent to gross violation of inherent duties, or is absolved from it solely due to lack of imputability, is prohibited from carrying out the activity when, in view of the act committed and the personality of the agent, there is a well-founded fear that he may commit other acts of the same nature.

ARTICLE 111
(Revocation of motor vehicle driving license)
1. In the event of conviction for a crime committed whilst driving a motor vehicle or related to it, or with gross violation of the duties incumbent upon a driver, or of acquittal solely due to lack of imputability, the Court shall order the revocation of the driving licence when, in view of the act committed and the personality of the offender: a) There is a well-founded fear that he may commit other acts of the same nature; b) He must be considered unfit to drive a vehicle.
2. The unsuitability referred to in paragraph b) may be revealed by, among others, acts that constitute the crimes of: a) Failure to provide assistance, pursuant to Article 208; b) Driving a vehicle while intoxicated, pursuant to Article 306; c) Dangerous driving of a means of transport, pursuant to Article 305.

ARTICLE 112
(Prohibition on granting a license)
1. When ordering the revocation of a driving licence, the Court shall determine that the offender may not be granted a new licence to drive motor vehicles, of any category or of a specific category, and the provisions of paragraphs 3 and 4 of article 67 shall apply accordingly.
2. If the conditions of the previous article are not met and the person does not hold a driving license, the Court will simply order the ban on granting the license, under the terms of the previous number, with the sentence being communicated to the competent entity, with the provisions of paragraph 4 of article 67 being correspondingly applicable.

ARTICLE 113
(Revocation of firearm use and possession license and prohibition of granting)
1. In the event of conviction for a crime involving the use of a firearm, or acquittal solely due to lack of imputability, the Court shall order the revocation of the firearms license when, in view of the act committed and the personality of the perpetrator, there is a well-founded fear that he may commit other acts of the same nature.
2. When ordering the revocation of the firearm use and carry license, the Court determines that the agent cannot be granted a new firearm use and carry license, and the provisions of paragraphs 3, 4 and 5 of article 67 shall apply accordingly.
3. If the agent has already been banned from granting a firearms license in the 5 years prior to the commission of the act, the minimum ban period is 2 years.

ARTICLE 114
(Extinction of measures)
1. If, after the minimum periods of the measures provided for, request of the interdict, that the assumptions for the application of those no longer subsist, the measure is declared extinct.
2. In case of rejection, a new application cannot be submitted before 1 year has passed.

ARTICLE 115
(Previous psychic anomaly)
1. When the offender is not declared unaccountable and is sentenced to prison, but it is shown that, due to a mental disorder he suffered at the time of the crime, the regime of common establishments will be detrimental to him, or that he will seriously disrupt that regime, the Court orders his internment in an establishment intended for unaccountable for the time corresponding to the duration of the sentence.

ARTICLE 116
(Posterior psychic anomaly)
1. If an anomaly, with the effects provided for in paragraph 1 of Article 115 or in Article 101, befalls the offender after the commission of the crime, the Court shall order internment in an establishment intended for non-imputable persons for the period corresponding to the duration of the sentence.

ARTICLE 117
(Posterior psychic anomaly without danger)
1. If the mental anomaly that occurs to the agent after the commission of the crime does not make him criminally dangerous, in terms that, if the agent were not responsible, would determine his internment, the execution of the prison sentence to which he has been sentenced shall be suspended until the condition that justified the internment ceases.

ARTICLE 118
(Review of the situation)
The provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2 of Article 103 shall apply correspondingly to the measures provided for in Articles 115, 116 and 117.

ARTICLE 119
(Simulation of psychic anomaly)
Changes to the normal regime for executing the sentence, based on the provisions of the previous precepts of this chapter, shall lapse as soon as it is shown that the agent's mental anomaly was simulated.

ARTICLE 120
(Loss of instruments and products)
1. Objects that have been used or were intended to be used in the commission of a typical unlawful act, or that have been produced by such an act, shall be declared forfeit to the State when, by their nature or the circumstances of the case, they endanger the safety of persons, morals or public order, or pose a serious risk of being used to commit new typical unlawful acts.

ARTICLE 121
(Objects belonging to third parties)
1. Without prejudice to the provisions of the following paragraphs, loss does not occur if the objects do not belong, at the date they were decreed.
2. Even if the objects belong to a third party, loss is declared when their owners have contributed, in a reprehensible manner, to their use or production, or have derived any advantage from the act; or, further, when the objects are, by any means, acquired after the act was committed, with the purchasers knowing their origin.

ARTICLE 122
(Loss of benefits)
1. Any reward given or promised to the perpetrators of a typical unlawful act, for themselves or for others, is forfeited to the State.
2. Things, rights or advantages that, through the typical unlawful act, have been directly produced, acquired, obtained or accessed, for themselves or for others, by the agents or third parties, and represent an undue financial advantage of any kind, shall also be lost in favor of the State, without prejudice to the rights of the injured party or a third party in good faith.

ARTICLE 123
(Deferred or installment payment and mitigation)
1. If, taking into account the socioeconomic situation of the person concerned, the application of paragraph 4 of the previous article proves to be unfair or excessively severe, the Court may equitably mitigate the amount referred to in that provision.

ARTICLE 124
(Holders of the right to complain)
1. When criminal proceedings depend on a complaint, the injured party has the right to file it, unless otherwise provided, considering himself as the holder of the interests that the law specifically intended to protect with the incrimination.

ARTICLE 125
(Resignation and withdrawal of complaint)
1. The right to complain may not be exercised if the holder has expressly waived it or has committed acts from which the waiver necessarily follows.
2. The complainant may withdraw the complaint, provided there is no opposition from the defendant, until the first instance judgment is published. Withdrawal prevents the complaint from being renewed.

ARTICLE 126
(Private prosecution)
The provisions of the articles of this title are correspondingly applicable to cases in which the criminal proceedings depend on a private accusation.

ARTICLE 127
(Resignation and withdrawal of complaint)
1. The right to complain may not be exercised if the holder has expressly waived it or has committed acts from which the waiver necessarily follows.

ARTICLE 128
(Private prosecution)
The provisions of the articles of this title are correspondingly applicable to cases in which the criminal proceedings depend on a private accusation.

ARTICLE 128
(Private prosecution)
1. When criminal proceedings depend on a complaint, the injured party has the right to file it, unless otherwise provided, in cases where they too cannot be prosecuted without a complaint.
2. If the injured party dies without having filed a complaint or having waived it, the right to file a complaint belongs successively to the following persons, unless any of them participated in the crime:
a) To the surviving spouse or person with whom the injured party lived in conditions similar to those of spouses, descendants and ascendants; b) To siblings and their descendants.
3. If the offended party is under 16 years of age or does not have exercise of the right to complain, this belongs to the legal representative and, in his absence, to the people indicated in the paragraphs of the previous number, according to the order referred to therein, unless any of them has participated in the crime.
4. Any person belonging to one of the classes referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3 may file a complaint independently of the others.
5. When the right to complain cannot be exercised because it belongs solely to the perpetrator of the crime, the Public Prosecutor's Office may initiate criminal proceedings if special reasons of public interest so require.

ARTICLE 125
(Extent of the effects of the complaint)
1. The filing of a complaint against one of the participants in the crime extends the criminal proceedings to the remaining.
2. For the purposes of the provisions of the previous paragraph, in determining the maximum penalty applicable to each crime, the elements that belong to the type of crime are taken into account, but not the aggravating or mitigating circumstances.
3. When the law establishes for any crime, as an alternative, a prison sentence or a fine, only the first shall be considered for the purposes of the provisions of this article.

ARTICLE 126
(Extinction of the right to complain)
1. The right to complain shall expire within 1 year from the date on which the holder becomes aware of the fact and its perpetrators, or from the death of the injured party, or from the date on which he or she becomes incapacitated.
2. If there are several holders of the right to complain, the period is calculated independently for each of them.
3. Failure to exercise the right to file a complaint in a timely manner in relation to one of the participants in the crime shall be of benefit to the others, in cases where they too cannot be prosecuted without a complaint.

ARTICLE 131
(Suspension of prescription)
1. The statute of limitations for criminal proceedings is suspended, in addition to the cases specifically provided for by law, during the period in which:
a) The criminal proceedings cannot legally commence or continue due to lack of legal authorization or a sentence to be handed down by a non-judicial court.
b) The criminal proceedings are pending as of Order that has the same effect;
c) The offender serves a sentence or security measure involving deprivation of liberty.
2. In the cases provided for in paragraphs a) and b) of the previous, the suspension cannot exceed 3 years.
3. The statute of limitations begins to run again from the day it ceases.

ARTICLE 132
(Interruption of prescription)
1. The statute of limitations for criminal proceedings is interrupted:
a) With the constitution of defendant in accordance with the applicable procedural rules;
b) Of a Dispatch that has the same effect;
c) When a judgment in the absentee case.
2. After each interruption, a new limitation period begins to run.
3. The statute of limitations of criminal proceedings always applies when, since their commencement and except for the period of suspension, the normal statute of limitations plus half has elapsed.
4. When, by virtue of a special provision, the limitation period is less than 2 years, the maximum limitation period corresponds to twice that period.

ARTICLE 134
(Effects of the prescription of the main penalty)
The prescription of the main penalty involves the prescription of the accessory penalty that has not been executed, as well as of the security measures.

ARTICLE 135
(Statute of limitations for security measures)
1. Security measures shall expire after a period of 15 or 10 years, depending on whether they are custodial or non-custodial security measures.
2. The security measure of revocation of a driving license expires within a period of 5 years.

ARTICLE 136
(Suspension of prescription)
1. The statute of limitations of the penalty and security measure is suspended, in addition to the cases specifically provided for by law, during the period in which:
a) By force of law, the execution cannot begin or continue to take place;
b) The convicted person is serving another sentence or security measure involving deprivation of liberty;
c) The delay in payment of the fine continues.
2. The statute of limitations begins to run again from the day on which the reason for the suspension ceases.

ARTICLE 137
(Interruption of prescription)
1. The statute of limitations of the sentence and security measure is interrupted by its execution.
2. After each interruption, a new limitation period begins to run.
3. The statute of limitations of the penalty and security measure always occurs when, since its commencement, except for the period of suspension, the normal statute of limitations plus half has elapsed.

ARTICLE 138
(Other causes of extinction)
Criminal liability shall also be extinguished under the terms and with the effects established in paragraph 3 of article 2 and also by death, amnesty, general pardon and pardon.

ARTICLE 139
(Effects)
1. The death of the agent extinguishes both the criminal proceedings and the penalty or security measure.
2. The amnesty extinguishes the criminal proceedings and, in the event of a conviction, ceases the execution of both the sentence and its effects and the security measure.
3. A generic pardon extinguishes the sentence, in whole or in part.
4. The pardon extinguishes the sentence, in whole or in part, or replaces it with a more favorable one provided for by law.

ARTICLE 144
(Convertibility of the fine penalty)
1. If the fine is not paid, whether voluntarily or coercively, and has not been replaced by work in accordance with Article 48, a subsidiary prison sentence shall be served in accordance with the provisions of Article 49.
2. If the fine is not established by law on days of prison, between a minimum of 6 days and a maximum of 1 year in prison.

ARTICLE 140
(Civil liability arising from crime)
